174343307,"Hello _PERSON_, I'll share my story with you. I have paranoid schizophrenia. For some time in my life I didn't know what was going on until it progressively got worse. I was put out on the street because of it because people didn't understand it. I wasn't on medication, and people thought I was just a crazy person instead of trying to get to know me. I would be hostile towards people that I thought were doing wrong to me. You constantly hear voices that sound like real people telling you to do things or saying things to you that make you feel paranoid. I thought my own family was going to poison me or the world was after me. I had these symptoms for 10 years until it got really bad. I was going to go to jail or prison at some point because the things I did to others and my self were dangerous. I did and said things to people because I was trying to protect myself and those around me. I thought I was protecting myself. People often have stigmas around this disorder. They often think that we are craz
y when if you think about it, you would probably react the same way as well to voices and visuals you think are real. They are downright scary at times. I would see shadows figures on walls, and hear creepy demonic voices. The strange thing is sometimes the voices were calming and helpful. It wasn't always a negative experience but when it was negative, it is REALLY negative. Luckily it isn't like the 40s or 50s anymore where the medication we take use to fry our brains. I take some now and have gotten better, but it definitely effected my life a lot."

175956490,"Do you know someone with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD)? Are you diagnosed with it yourself? How did the person (or you) accept or deal with the diagnosis? As a therapist who has worked with both adults and adolescents with borderline traits, I have seen my fair share of denial, resentment, and even outright rage expressed in sessions when the word BPD comes up. I had a previous adolescent client ask me to stop using the term BPD while discussing her challenges because “I don’t believe I have that. If I don’t believe I have that, then neither should you.” Stunned by this attempt at controlling a professional, I offered to emphasize only the symptoms and leave the label behind, at least during the hour of psychotherapy. This article will explore some of the fears that clients may have about being labeled with BPD. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/caregivers/2019/07/bpd-diagnosis-10-common-fears/"

175956543,"There are a lot of questions implying a kind answer, especially those expressing doubts about yourself or something you did. For example, with a friend: would you prefer to meet X this evening? Didn't you like my gift? Did I annoy you when I did/said/asked that? I get lost in these situations. Those of us that have long suffered similar fates may cry along with you every step of the way, but it could be just that keeping us down. Excessive apologizing, reflecting, reminiscing, etc. all put us down as though we deserve to be sad or sorry for doing our best. The ways in which we talk to ourselves, and especially talking down to ourselves, is most common among the depressed. Perhaps a better way is to turn around those thoughts into forward moving goals.. even if extremely tiny, that invert depression into hope. So wish for a brighter tomorrow. Plan to enjoy yourself one way or another with whatever opportunities are acceptable to those whom your actions might matter. Live boldly and proudly because you deserve that much more so than kicking yourself. Even if only just in tiny ways, express yourself.. take risks that don't matter.. Dream of your better days that lie ahead and 
Remember: Most of the time, the only person stopping you: Is you."

He barges into his parents room and in the middle of the night and starts ranting and yelling. He then throws the book out the window, breaking it. During this episode the police shows up. His mandate had long recognized ""psychological"" or ""mental"" torture as an analytical concept distinct from physical torture. 175956857,"I've had the RRoD before on my Xbox 360, but it didn't permanently die on me. I turned it on like a few days after I got the RRoD and it worked fine again. Have you tried unplugging everything and then plugging it all back in? Basically, sometimes the Xbox overheats and you get RRoD. It usually has to do with a combination of the heatsink having problems and too much dust. Not sure how much it'd cost to have someone replace the heatsink (It's only a $10 part, though), but yeah... that's often the cause. Or you have to reflow the circuit board, which I suppose isn't an easy thing to do unless you're used to fixing electronics. But sometimes cleaning the dust out can help, and that's a cheap fix. But in case you don't know, the Xbox One X can't play all Xbox 360 games. For example, Skyrim on the Xbox 360 can't be played on the Xbox One X. You gotta buy the Xbox One X version of Skyrim. It's kinda stupid. But at least the Xbox One X Skyrim is enhanced. 4K, I believe."

There were questions I could have answered more clearly, questions I forgot to ask, and a general feeling of apathy regarding how I felt I was being perceived. Not good. Drumming up business is important right now, and it's important that I make a good impression. But I was doing the best I could. This is something that occurs, to varying degrees, with most of the people I interact with. When faced with these (or any) kind of social situations, I feel sluggish and unmotivated. I feel like I don't hold myself as rigidly and/or properly as I should. Nor could, but should. It could be called social apathy, brought on by a lack of energy. For me, energy is the key word, beca
use it seems that in these situations, I'm not as cognizant as I could be, but it seems like too much effort to break out of the haze I'm in. Another way to describe it would be comparing it to people who are NOT morning people: the kind of person who wakes up and can't deal with anyone until their coffee has kicked in. I seem to be in that state whenever I have to deal with people; the feeling that you need to shake your head or slap yourself in the face to ""come to"" and be more present. Who can relate to this?"

175956932,"Hi, _NAME_. You may have already come to a decision since it's been about 3 months since your post, but if you are still looking for opinions, I'd say you should first start documenting the things your ex-husband says or does, both positive and negative. When you read back on your entries, it might present a clearer view. Also, even though your kids are still young, perhaps you could ask them how they feel about seeing their dad, how often they want to see him (after COVID), etc. You can always revisit those questions every year with them. You might find they have their own strong opinions. Since I was young, I knew my parents had an unhealthy relationship and that my father was emotionally abusive and a narcissit. Some kids pray for their parents to stay together, I prayed for mine to get a divorce. They did when I was seven and I remember being relieved. My mom also tried to do what she thought was best and maintain contact between us so my brother and I could have a dad. We never wanted to visit 
him and only went through the motions when we spoke over the phone. He felt little more than a stranger and never contributed financially to support us. On the one hand, I think what would have been easiest for me was to not have him in my life at all. On the other, I think we learn from both positive and negative examples and having him as a model of how NOT to succeed as a compassionate human being helped in my personal growth. I was thankful though when my dad moved out of state a couple of years later and the visits stopped. He still called over the phone, but less frequently as he committed a crime and was in jail for several years. I still responded to his letters because I felt guilty, knowing he was likely lonely in a prison cell. However, when I moved to college I made the conscious decision to stop communications after finding out that the crime he had committed was pretty horrific. He had lied about the reason previously. I'm curious to know what CPS said about the charge against you and the fact t
hat your ex-husband falsified the claim? They might have a recommendation or be able to point you to support resources that will help you and your children's wellbeing. Whatever decision you make, I'm sure it will be with that in mind."

175956934,"First, neither I nor my husband is schizoid. I frequent this forum because I correspond with a friend who is a deep schizoid. Some aspects of my home setup might be useful to you, however. 1) Both my husband and I appreciate solitude and would agree with your definition of being ""alone"". Both of us profoundly resent it when the doorbell rings, unless we're expecting delivery of a package requiring signature confirmation. 2) Not only does my husband have his own study, but this is at the far end of the large basement. So, he essentially has his own floor of the house, as well as his own mini-fridge and half-bathroom. During the day, we usually talk only when he ""surfaces""--coming up to the kitchen to have lunch and dinner. At such times, I can talk as much or as little as I like. He knows this is ""the deal"". Only extremely rarely do I go downstairs to talk to him, and he's forewarned of this by sounds in the stairwell and my ""peeping""--I let out a high-pitched ""peep"" when I reach the botto
m of the stairs. He ""peeps"" back, and I know it's OK to approach him to ask a question. My husband requires humans even less than my extreme schizoid friend. The fact that I have no need to walk past his study door AT ALL when he's home means a lot to him. Hence, the location of your study--whether or not it is in a highly-trafficked area past which people walk--is important. The fact that my husband can expect to be alone in his study, uninterrupted, almost whenever he is in there means a lot to him . I know how vital ""time alone"" is to my husband (does your family actually understand how non-negotiable solitude is for you???). And there are times when I absolutely need to discuss something (being a recovering Borderline Personality Disordered hoomin). The fact that I know he hears me when I need to talk has, seemingly counter-intuitively, caused me to need him far, FAR less. You cannot fake this with women, nor with children. It seems to me you won't be able to give your family ""quality you"", consiste
ntly, without first having stored considerable ""solitude fat"". Somehow, they need to know this, that this is not some perverse whim of yours, but how you are made . They need to know that you will have little to give unless you feel whole, and that it's possible you might even break if you are both deprived of solitude for too long and forced to socialize with your wife's family too much . My computer is in the living room, and it can irritate me a lot when my husband is in the kitchen, but he is in no way controlling, nosy, or invasive, so I mentally have to tell myself to stop tensing up. My husband is not like my mother, my grandmother, or any number of control-freak a**h*les with whom I've worked and spent time over the years. Open communication of fundamental needs is vital. One thing for which I'm truly grateful is that my husband's family was respectful and non-invasive. Consequently, I LOVED my late in-laws and miss them dearly. This was something which I never would have thought possible. I dated o
ther people--remarkable people--whose families were part of the package, and that was too much for me. The mere word, ""family"", make me sick."

174344056,"It sounds like you are a very caring person. I don't know exactly what you should do but if you feel like reaching out, then reach out. She will either accept it or she may be withdrawn still. Still for me, as a person with Schizoaffective disorder--depressed type, I am always happy when people reach out to me, even if I can't express it well at the time. If I am going through something I usually sleep a lot. That is how I withdraw. I don't talk a lot even when I have something to say. Sometimes I still hear voices, like yesterday, even with medication. Sometimes I see visual hallucinations too. Some are benign but others are frightening. It depends how I react to them. Sometimes they are just annoying me but I'm still focused on them and not so focused on what is real that is going on around me. Other times I am able to ignore them better but I still may not be fully able to concentrate on what is going on around me that is real because the hallucinations they seem so real. I have delusions someti
mes but they aren't about other people. Sometimes I do get paranoia though. I don't know if she will get any delusions about you. 175957011,"TP, I do echo the above advice that if you (and your friend should to the same) continue to have these thoughts, that you do make your doctor/mental health professional know. This is just safe and due diligence so that neither of you gets into a more serious situation. That said, it does sound like what *you* describe (I can't say about your friend) could likely be part of an acute anxiety/OCD thought process. Your thoughts become intrusive with fear and dread of being trapped in the panic moment. It feels like you can't escape it and therefore the mind goes places... This doesn't mean you will act on it, but of course it is scary and lets you know just how challenging your anxiety is ATM. If you are not already going to therapy sessions at this time, it would be worth looking into this possibility to help you get to where you need your management to be. We are here for you...keep posting and we'll keep up the support! S.C."

175957051,"Sorry I was away for a bit, dear reader. I went through some med changes, thus head changes and was confused and out of sorts, but I feel like things are becoming more under control now. This week I went to a renowned teaching university hospital, one of the best in the state. I went there to learn more about electroconvulsive therapy, also known as ECT. I am considering ECT as a treatment for my depression that comes along with my bipolar disorder. It scares me how dark depression is and how, if I want to, I can carry out various acts. Here is a rundown of ECT and how it works. I found it helpful and maybe you will too. ECT is a treatment for episodes of major depression, mania, and schizophrenia (which is right up my alley). ECT makes a brief controlled electrical current which produces a seizure in your brain. Although we do not know exactly how it works, it is believed that the seizure activity produces a chemical change in the brain which may cause symptoms to disappear. The next question I ha
d was “Is it safe?” Prior to having the procedure at this particular hospital there are medical, psychiatric, and laboratory tests conducted to assure that the procedure can be done in the safest way possible. A ECT workup will be preformed which may include a physical exam, EKG, and blood work. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/being-bipolar/2019/05/04/ect-and-me/"

175957110,"You said in your first post, ""suspect that my wife may be Borderline Personality Disorder or merely suffering from what I can only describe as sudden onset anxiety."" And later you mentioned possibly bipolar, which is what I have. 1. Sudden Onset Anxiety mayo clinic says: “Panic disorder involves repeated episodes of sudden feelings of intense anxiety and fear or terror that reach a peak within minutes (panic attacks). You may have feelings of impending doom, shortness of breath, chest pain, or a rapid, fluttering or pounding heart (heart palpitations).” 2. Bipolar (mayo clinic): Bipolar disorder, formerly called manic depression, is a mental health condition that causes extreme mood swings that include emotional highs (mania or hypomania) and lows (depression). Impulsive and often dangerous behaviors, such as spending sprees, unsafe sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, and binge eating. As manic: • Abnormally upbeat, jumpy or wired; Increased activity, energy or agitation: Exaggerated se
nse of well-being and self-confidence (euphoria); Decreased need for sleep: Unusual talkativeness; Racing thoughts: Poor decision-making — for example, going on buying sprees, taking sexual risks or making foolish investments. 3. Borderline Personality Disorder (nih.gov): People with borderline personality disorder may experience mood swings and display uncertainty about how they see themselves and their role in the world. As a result, their interests and values can change quickly. People with borderline personality disorder also tend to view things in extremes, such as all good or all bad. Their opinions of other people can also change quickly. An individual who is seen as a friend one day may be considered an enemy or traitor the next. These shifting feelings can lead to intense and unstable relationships. Other signs or symptoms may include: • Efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment, such as rapidly initiating intimate (physical or emotional) relationships or cutting off communication with someon
e in anticipation of being abandoned • A pattern of intense and unstable relationships with family, friends, and loved ones, often swinging from extreme closeness and love (idealization) to extreme dislike or anger (devaluation); Distorted and unstable self-image or sense of self • Impulsive and often dangerous behaviors, such as spending sprees, unsafe sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, and binge eating: Intense and highly changeable moods, with each episode lasting from a few hours to a few days • Chronic feelings of emptiness; Inappropriate, intense anger or problems controlling anger You said about your wife: “The problem is this type of behavior is not limited to me. She will overtly overlay anger on anyone where she will not receive an immediate consequence, e.g. someone at work. But she will distance herself from that person extensively. Two years ago she developed such angst with co-workers she began to telework, thus avoiding the office entirely. She has been estranged from her mother fo
r five years. When she ends any ""relationship"" there is a complete severance of contact. I have several times intervened and convinced her sometimes the conflict with her friend/parent/coworker might simply be a miscommunication often this will work out--until she perceives some slight unintended or not. She can be extreme in her anger and can go from being an affectionate laughing wife.... to full-blown anger in one sentence.” You mentioned she has fear of abandonment, which applies to Borderline. Which of those 3 do you think she is?"

175957182,"Hi all, I'm in my mid forties, male, diagnosed in the sense that health care professionals say I have traits of ASD or Schizoid Personality. The diagnostic criteria are a semi-fit, but the subjective experience talked about on this forum and elsewhere is a close match to my life. Until I was in my late teens and early twenties, I didn't feel any real need to be connected to other people. I was good at what I was good at - mainly debating and computers - and I spent time reading when other people talked. At university I realised that I did actually want to feel connected to other people, but I had not idea how to go about it. It felt like everyone else had a natural instinct for engaging with each other - it wasn't just that I lacked the skills, but that I lacked the impulses that drove the execution of those skills. I spent a lot of time reading academic work about social interaction, but it didn't help. Ever since, I've alternated between depression, obsession with trying to get relationships righ
t, periods where I'm relatively calm and complacent about successfully imitating normal, and times where I deeply resent having to pretend to be someone that I am not in order to maintain connections that are never as close as I want them to be. Most of the time I am now reasonably socially functional. I have an academic career - a job that requires far more social interaction than any of the stereotypes suggest - and I am married with children. I feel that I spend most of my time in roles where ""success"" means that I am managing to impersonate an average person, and hardly any time being myself. I'm tempted to write a book with explicit instructions on how to impersonate being a normal person, just in case it is useful to anyone. I have a massive library of scripts and routines, and rules of thumb on when to execute each one. Page one of the book would say ""Here's the book you've always suspected that everyone else had uploaded to their brains before birth. If you really, really want to pretend to be norm
al, this is how to do it. The knowledge is dangerous. Humans are very strange people, and you will never be one of them. Use with extreme caution."" If I get into just the right mood, I can enjoy social interaction like it is a game that I can play well - enjoyable because I'm doing something I'm good at, and because it helps other people for me to be good at it, but not because it's what I would do by choice. I've just come through another cycle of depression, and I've realised how much pressure I'm putting on myself with my job and family, and not nearly enough time alone. My wife sort of understands how much time I need, but she switches quickly from being willing to consider ways of compromising, to thinking that if I need to spend time away from my family, that we aren't properly married. It doesn't help that her family and extended family is unusually insistent on regularly catching up, and she sees that as the norm, rather than something right at one end of a spectrum where I am at the other. I'm going 
active on the forum just in case other people have good strategies for creating space to be alone, in the same way that I used to wish there was a guide for doing the social interaction stuff. I need time that is just me in my own spaces, but I always need more than I can get. My family is afraid that if they help me get more time alone, I'll just want even more - I can't say that they are wrong, because I need a lot more than I get, and a small taste just shows me how under-aloned I am."
175957183,"Cool I'll check them out _USER_ID_: Oh wow, it's adorable!"
175957184,"Paranoid tonight, went on a walk and was convinced there were cameras in every street light and I was being watched and followed, not fun."
175957185,"This, seriously. Ugh, I hated it every single time."
175957186,"I’m glad you’re thinking about taking your medicine. You say you’re positive, but you make a list of upsets and make statements which suggest that might not be true, in my view. I can write a list of my defeats for you, and a lot of them happened before I read a column on being positive. I was raised in a negative household, and I have bipolar (for which I take Lithium and Mirtazapine anti-depressant), so negative thinking could be one of those or both. I didn’t think I was negative, either, I just thought I was being more practical than others, more honest. I was really just following the tone set in my growing up household before I had a chance to make decisions on my own. For one of those defeats on my list, I distinctly remember my conscious had the solution, but my negative unconscious muddled the works by saying, “That won’t work, because….” And came up with some silly, untrue reason which had me thinking half positive and half negative, and fouled up the works. I realized I h
ad to get my negative unconscious in line with my positive conscious. If one thought negative (unconscious) and one thought positive (conscious) I was going to be in trouble. And I stumbled across a column in the newspaper which solved that issue. It said, before you go into a problem, believe that you can solve. What that does is get both our conscious and our unconscious believing we can solve it, and it frees up both parts of the mind to look for the solution. Rather than, having the unconscious (negative upbringing) looking for reasons why the problem can’t be solved. I so believed in this column, and the woman who wrote it, that I clipped it out and put it on my bulletin board. I told myself, the next time you have a problem, don’t think about the column, but first read the column on being positive to get your mind going in the right direction. It was a two-step process. The first step was getting the negative out of my unconscious, which I couldn’t see and never knew if it was fouling me up. Since 
I can’t see it, let’s clear it out of any hidden negative thinking before we even think about the problem. It’s like mine-sweeping our brain. What was the next problem? My son comes in and says the car's in the backyard and it won’t start. Well, too much problem for me, because we have a small twisting driveway and a big wrecker won’t get into it. I thought, I’ll wait until my wife gets home and she’ll solve the problem. Then I thought, wait, I was supposed to read the column on being positive before I tried to solve my next problem. I got the column down and started reading it. By the 4th paragraph I thought, “_NAME_’s.” What was _NAME_’s? It was a garage up the street that had a small wrecker which could get into our small driveway and a couple of years ago had gotten one of our cars. How had I solved the problem and I wasn’t even thinking about it? By reading the column, my unconscious had been cleared of negative, and it was seeking the answer while I read the column. From then on, 
whenever I was away from the column and had a problem, I would consciously try to clear my unconscious of any negative by saying over and over, “Think positive, think positive, think positive.” And only then start thinking about the problem. It’s a two-step process. Notice, this method only requires being positive for 30 seconds when trying to solve a problem. It doesn’t require you to be positive all day long or to completely change your personality. You can still be yourself. Also, not only do we affect ourselves when we think negative about solving problems, it affects those around us. There could be some people who are depending on us for help, so thinking negative also affects them. That’s not fair. It, too, can affect others who can imitate our negative thinking."

You then say in your most recent post: ""In the final analysis people with true BPD live with a hyperactive _USER_ID_, or so I am told. This then seems to give false alarms of danger and false alarms of the seriousness of provocation...."" about the condition you mentioned, hyperactive _USER_ID_, Inside the brain .com says: ""Now scientists at the University of California, Berkeley have discovered a neural explanation for why some individuals are indeed more anxiety-prone than others. Their findings, published in Neuron, reveal that chinks in our brain circuitry could be the answer, and may pave the way for more targeted treatment of chronic fear and anxiety disorders. In the brain imaging study, the researchers discovered two distinct neural pathways that play a role in whether we develop and overcome fears. The first i
nvolves an overactive _USER_ID_, which is home to the brain’s primal fight-or-flight reflex and plays a role in developing specific phobias."" 175957277,"Hello guys, hope you are having a good day so far. I've been struggling today: depression and delusions--although I'm not giving into the delusions, I keep blocking them out so that's good. I think the depression is from the delusions and struggling to know what is real. The stress was enough this morning to cause me to throw up but that happens a lot these days. I rested on the couch for most of the morning because getting sick takes a lot out of me. THen I got up about 12:30, I think, showered, started the laundry and began journaling which has helped my mood a lot. (So did texting a bit with my sister.) I should practice some DBT today, too, as that is always soothing. I should have done that this morning but I guess I was so out of it I didn't think to. Despite the struggles with ""reality"" I had a nice visit with my family yesterday. It was a bit sad though because my mother has dementia and really had no awareness of Mother's Day and what it means. We gave her some gorgeous, pop-up paper flo
wers (she can't care for fresh ones) and they did make her smile, which is good, but that was about the only reaction we got. Still, she seemed to be in a good mood all evening which is something. She picked out what she wanted for dinner--we do DoorDash--and she seemed to enjoy what she got. Later we watched a TV mystery show we have been watching regularly during out visits. I'm going to stay proactive and keep confronting my symptoms--journaling, practicing DBT, practicing gratitude. I hope everyone here has an ""arsenal"" that they can use to combat their illness. Hang in there everybody, _PERSON_"
175957278,"Hi AK, I am sorry that you are feeling anxious about your upcoming trip. It is not unusual to feel anxiety during happy/positive experiences because our brains often don't differentiate between stimuli...in other words, any event, good or bad that causes us intense emotions/feelings can register as stress. Add to that the change in routine, and the added unknown factors of travel...and you have several triggers for those of us who are challenged with anxiety! Try not to be frustrated with yourself, but rather be proud that you are willing to face your fears and go anyway. That is a huge win! Many people choose not to... I really think, like me, most of your worry is anticipatory...and that once you get there, you'll have a wonderful time. 'Pack' your best coping skills of course, and work them daily! You can do this! Have a wonderful trip, and post as needed...we'll be here if need be. (but I bet you won't need us!) S.C."

175957401,"No. People who say those things assume that normalcy will cure whatever issues you have. They interpret your failure to conform as the reason for those issues, rather than the other way around. It's not a call to action, it's an expression of disapproval just barely disguised as a call to action. The assumptions and expectations involved are completely misguided. There's a strong connotation that you're just failing to do something perfectly well-known (""being normal""), when the main thing you really need to deal with is figuring out something unknown (""being you"", sustainably). Normalcy isn't inherently bad (it's normal for a reason), but when the recipe chronically wears you down instead of building you up, you need to look critically at every aspect of it. There's nothing that you can ""just"" do about it, and that's what that commonplace attitude (""just toughen up"", ""just enjoy it"") fails to capture. Because it's based on a value judgement (""it should be trivial"") that clashes with th
e reality (""it isn't trivial""). I agree. But that's actually opposite to that typical ""toughen up"" attitude I was talking about (which actually implies ""following the herd"" as the solution instead). I'm just not sure if people actually ever switch from ""externally-oriented"" to ""internally-oriented"". It's something that can be emulated to a degree, and that can be helpful, but fundamental change, I tend to doubt it from what I've seen personally. What can definitely be changed though is if you've learned to emulate enternal orientation. It can be unlearned."
175957402,"Hi TMo, I get anxiety prior to, but once I get on the road I feel better. I think mine is more anticipation on leaving. Not really sure but I can sympathize with you. To me a 3-4 hour drive would be next to impossible. I have to drive an hour to see my psychologist and it nearly kills me. I ache so bad from sitting in one spot for so long. I have fibromyalgia though and my muscles ache. If you made the 4 hour drive, I know you can do 3 hrs and 45min. And I think seeing your grandfather will be delightful. Just remember we never know what is going to happen tomorrow and seeing family is a good thing. Even if you might not really want to see people, keep it brief. I know you got this. And you wont regret it. Nothing bad is going to happen. Hang in there. Have a lovely day... Hugs, _NAME_..."

175957423,"During this semester, I took a class where many had told me it was challenging; not the first time this has happened and usually what I did was study harder and I would join study groups and go to the school's tutoring which would help me immensely but due to covid-19, everything has shifted online, as for many. Given the current conditions, I know that I am blessed to have a roof over my head, enough food and a stable internet connections and I am very aware that a lot of people are worse than me but given this class and only this class in particular, I have been crying all week. Because these are online classes and my school in particular wasn't prepared for this at all in terms of tests, its understandable that tests would be harder since now we have access to more info for the tests even though we get sent emails where using these would mean academic dishonesty. The course is already hard as it is and now we have extreme time limits and they change the wording on purpose, meaning we are given m
any many practice exercises and the wording, for obvious reasons, is changed but the problem is that it is changed so much that for instance in my case I spend half of the time just trying to understand many the questions, and we basically have 15 minutes each to answer each one and send a picture of our response meaning in my opinion, professors are not acknowledging the fact that the difficulty level is increased and that we can't do the tests as fast as before. I do not intend for that my grade to be just given to me, I have learned throughout my life that only the things that you work for have value, but I feel this is too extreme; they took away one of our tests, meaning that instead of having x tests we now have x-1, because of a lack of time for them to grade which I get, and according to them there is no way to substitute that grade and this was told to us after taking the second test, which came to a complete shock to us. Also, on the first online test we were given thankfully an option to spend any 
amount of time on a certain question but a restricted overall time, but given those particular questions, some of us didn't even have time to upload some pictures (which on this case it played an important role on my grade on the test), which according to the professors, was our lack of time management skills. At this point I understand this, and agree to a certain extent, even though I was clearly affected by this, but what really threw me off was their attitude afterwards, especially in the way my professor delivered the last announcement. For the final test, now we can't scroll through the test, meaning that our time management will be worse. Also, my professor in particular does not tell us the average score or the grade distribution but another student (given that these are departamental tests) had told me that their professor had displayed it, and the average score was F for all of the tests we had taken individually, and I believe this doesn't come to a surprise to the professors at this point since I 
know about of a lot of people have had to repeat this and other courses of the department throughout the years consequentially. (Side note, they changed part of the grading curve this semester and it affects me (meaning on other years my letter grade would be higher) which makes me kinda sad and mad) But honestly what threw me off the most was my mother. This situation is very painful to me and I know that I have to strive for a better grade, I don't want to fail or if my pass in a way that my GPA would take an impact, but at this point I have felt so defeated and having her yell and degrade me truly hurts the most, and having her tell me consequently that I am irresponsable an immature about this, that I should only study harder because all of these grades are my fault hurts me more than anything else since this is the way she has always reacted when I fail of decrease my skill in something even though she knows I do well and above average in most of my classes and other life challenges and that sometimes I 
just need a bit of love, not more pressure. I know I need to work harder, but right now I feel worse than before. I didn't do hot on my first test, which is completely normal for me since I have an adjustment period for the course but having to study as hard as I did for the latter ones and see that my grade has barely changed and that on top of the current events and the polar change in the test format, I feel crushed. Right now I can't concentrate; everything that seemed hard now seems impossible and I can't think straight. Now when I don't get things, I go on full panic mode since I know that this test is so crucial. I also have other issues, like the fact that repeating the class (which right now I am passing by a hair but still would hit my GPA like a truck) would just delay my degree, besides of issues in my personal life and some other classes, which thankfully are less and most importantly, manageable. At this point, it just feels like I have to fight so much and as I'm losing mental strength, there i
s no way to replenish it in a way to help me get on my feet and fight stronger for this class. Watching YouTube, movies, and _NAME_ talks hasn't helped me which really bums me out since its the first time that I can't find that pick me up by myself. I want to pass and get an amazing grade and most importantly work for it, but I feel as if I am rushing myself too much or not having adequate tools or outlets for me to progress. Sorry for the extremely long post, its just that I needed to vent"

175957426,"I wouldn’t be surprised if ur diagnosis is correct from what u say the length of time is with ur up and down moods. I’m definitely Borderline personality. I was originally upset when i read that the psychiatrist had written that as my diagnosis. Now I know so much about borderline personality disorder, and it could’ve been written just for me with only one symptom of the 9 being different . I don’t take anger out on others. I’m not manipulative. I take it All out on myself . Quiet borderline personality diagnosis was confirmed by my psych who I see for my meds. I knew long ago that I created much of my personality. I used to even tell some people I could do that. I created part of my personality In my late teens. Then i did some touch up work on the rapid mood changes in my mid 20’s. I was stuck w the intensity of the moods :((((.... I I’m an empath which, at a young age, older people would call me a victim soul. So much finally made since. My emotions used to always be so erratic. I 
had an uncle and my brother buying me those stones for anxiety when I was around 5-6 years old. I changed that myself in my mid 20’s. The main difference between bpd and bipolar, which is a mood disorder., is the length of time the person is stuck on an emotion before it changes without any reason. Bpd moods may last for only minutes but never real long. Pw Bipolar can stay in a mood for days or over a week before it abruptly changes very dramatically for no reason. I’m pretty new here and I also forgot I used this app months. By the time I found this site, I had been thru more than I could handle. I was still severely depressed after a breakdown 2 years before. Nobody would ever agree to treat me or ‘weren’t equipped to”. I lost all hope and made back to back serious attempts. Then the behavioral hospital filed to have extra holds put on me. They were upset when, after the 2 serious attempts that put me in there, I hung myself in their room only 2 days after arriving. I had been cleared to leave th
e medical hospital after treatment for the carbon monoxide poisoning. They were even going to get a judicial hold on me but I was able to talk my mom out of helping them do it. Now that was a long post. I shouldn’t have smoked first :// I do want to welcome you here. U are off to a great start. U will obviously be an asset to this site!!!! Nobody here knows me, but for the fact I was out of hope by the time I joined this site . All my posts are more like end of the life posts. Honestly tho, things really are pretty bad. 175957463,"Meditation trains the brain like a muscle to focus. Professional meditators are able to ignore their thoughts while reading a book and don't get lost in thought (Like when reading a book for example - They don't have to reread a paragraph or a page) and when they do, they're immediately able to focus again. There was a study done where people that never meditated in their life were put under a brain scan and then they did meditation for a certain number of weeks for half an hour every day.. They did the brain scan again and grey matter grew in the areas of self awareness and decreased in the areas of stress."

175957487,"_PERSON_, I am so proud of you for posting. It is very difficult for anyone to say out loud some of the most horrific things that have happened to us. First, let me say that I am sorry for what happened and what you had to endure growing up. I am also sorry for the pain that you continue to feel. Please let me tell you that it can get better. I am living proof that it can. However, it does require work. Starting with therapy is a great first step. You need help and you are getting that help. Do not be discouraged if the first person that you see doesn't seem to get results for you. The one thing that I learned after years of therapy is that there is a doctor or therapist available for you, but you might have to try a few before you find him or her. Just be honest with the therapist if you feel like things aren't clicking. If you are dealing with a true professional, he or she will be all too happy to try to find someone that will work with you more effectively. If you are dealing with a not so nice 
one, then you will know you have made the right decision to leave. But, it won't be done in a few sessions. Please don't be discouraged by that either. The work is worth it and it will make you feel so empowered when you come out on the other side. You are strong and you will come out on the other side. You are normal. You are doing the best that you can do right now. You just have to focus on yourself and keep putting one foot in front of the other. Like other things, this too is a marathon. Once you build your toolbox of coping tools, you will start to feel so much better. Medication is certainly an option. I have been on different types of meds for my anxiety and/or depression. You do not have to be over-medicated; however, it does not show weakness to use a little help when you can. Please keep us updated!! We are rooting for you. You can do this!"

175957512,"My mind is usually constantly talking + also gets ""lazy"" sometimes and skips over things since I already know what I'm ""talking"" about aside from the rare song, (like a manson and tool song I posted the other day) where both song choruses were taking turns running through my mind as I pulled an all-nighter finishing an assignment. It was nice because they were distinctly and loudly sung in their voices, in my head, and both had a lot of energy behind them. However, rather than thinking the same thoughts running too many times are something I need to heed or pay attention to, I see it as needing to ground myself or reflect upon what I'm trying to escape from. This sounds quite interesting, but I don't always understand things without examples. I sometimes get keywords or pictures or feelings from people, places, and things, but it can verge along the lines of ""odd beliefs"" Same here sometimes - just usually not in public - and definitely not at work. Though a while back, I was walking down a s
chool hallway, worked up and thinking about a situation I'd just embarrassed myself in, and as I turned the corner, I almost bumped into a young lady clutching her school binders to her chest. We both startled, but I believe I left her more-so, because upon making eyewidened eye contact, I desperately and pleadingly burst out with, ""Well, I don't know! How was I supposed to know what to do?"" which was supposed to stay as an inner monologue. This is what the net says about Buspar: “This medication is used to treat anxiety. It may help you think more clearly, relax, worry less, and take part in everyday life. It may also help you to feel less jittery and irritable, and may control symptoms such as trouble sleeping…. Buspirone is a medication for anxiety (anxiolytic) that works by affecting certain natural substances in the brain (neurotransmitters)."" This is what the net says about Prozac (webmd.com): ""Fluoxetine is used to treat depression, panic attacks, obsessive compulsive disorder….” ""This medication may improve your mood, sleep, appetite, and energy level and may help restore your interest in daily living. It may decreas
e fear, anxiety, unwanted thoughts, and the number of panic attacks. It may also reduce the urge to perform repeated tasks (compulsions such as hand-washing, counting, and checking) that interfere with daily living."" 175957624,"It was brave of you to share and braver still how you are trying to love your family despite all that has happened. I second another's opinion that you may have to leave your hometown, or at the very least your childhood home. You've suffered trauma there, compounded by lack of actions from your parents, leading to feelings of unsafety from two different points. That doesn't mean you can't overcome it, but a healthy distance from where it happened might allow you to loosen a little of your anxiety. As others have also suggested, going to therapy might help you deal with your anxiety even more and begin the healing process. Once you take that step, you might even be able to suggest to your step brother that he seek his own therapy. It's obvious that you still care for him and realize that he has a mental issue that also needs help. I think you are right that he developed an unhealthy attitude from incest porn at an impressionable age which was not addressed by his dad or your mom. Obviously they did
n't know and neither did you until recently, but I don't think a right decision should really have been that tough for them after they found out about the voyeurism and innapropriate touching. If they held your interest and his in such concern, they should have suggested therapy from the get go for both of you. From your mention that he has never had a girlfriend or seemed interested in dating even while sexually attracted to you, it seems that he may have traumatized himself in a way that he can't easily address since those around him pretended like it was no big deal. Obviously he is an adult now and has always been responsible for his own choices, but at 14 and as a young teenager, he would likely not have pushed for therapy himself. Those older than him and responsible for his and your care should have sought help and maybe his behavior could have been curbed rather than cemented. In short, I think you have every right to feel lingering anger at their actions, or lack of action because they not only faile
d you, but their son as well. That sounds harsh, but I don't think their failure came from a lack of love. People, including parents, sometimes make grevious errors. People, including parents, often wish for everything to be fine and think they can make things normal by acting normal. But ignoring deep-rooted issues won't allow any of you to truly grow and move on. You don't have to wait for them to act in a certain manner or say something to either you or your step brother. You yourself are an adult now and can take steps toward your own self-care and mental health. You are brave and you are strong."

175957632,"If its for psychosis basically all the meds are roughly equivalent except zyprexa and clozapine. The only thing that changes are the side effects and they don’t work at all for 25-35% of the population. It’s not so much the doctors as the inefficient tools they’ve been given. For anxiety SSRIs are the first line but a lot of us can’t take SSRIs without also being on a mood stabilizer, if we’ve got any mood elements other than pure depression. If it’s the ADHD the APs directly counteract th stimulants so getting the right balance is difficult and most people will end up with some psychosis. It’s an impossible situation to solve in many cases. I’m certainly not happy with what my meds have done to me but it’s a lot worse to be psychotic imo."

175957658,"If you are feeling suicidal or having a mental health crisis, please tell someone — a friend or family member, a teacher, a doctor or therapist or call 911 (if you’re in the U.S.) or the Emergency Medical Services phone number in your country. You can also call a crisis intervention hotline—these are available in the U.S. and in many other countries. You do not need to be actively suicidal to benefit from a crisis hotline. International crisis hotlines: http://www.suicide.org/international-suicide-hotlines.html OpenCounseling International Suicide & Emergency Hotlines A list of suicide and emergency helpline around the world with links to more detailed hotlines. 175957741,"OceanFisher, If I were you I would contact a psychiatrist and see if they have anybody doing telephone therapy. You can use skype, zoom or facetime. Or just the telephone. And the people you were helping are definitely hurting. There is probably no soup for the people that were coming to get it. No matter how bad it seems, there is usually somebody worse off than ourselves. Try taking things slow, slow your mind down and try to make the best of things. I am sure that there are good things in your life you can reflect on. They may be small but they are very powerful when it comes to the way we are feeling at the moment. 175957766,"I think people say they fear death, but they don't really fear death, they fear what it means. Realistically, you can't fear death because it's something you'll never experience. We only experience something when we reflect on it and, by its nature, you can't reflect on your own death. So, what is it that people really fear? I think a lot of it is fear of missing out; that the world and the people you know will carry on doing stuff and you'll eventually be relegated to a picture on the wall and eventually that will go into someone's bin. I had this conversation with someone recently, and I asked them whether they'd feel better dying if everyone died at the same time, in some catastrophic event. They thought about it for a few seconds and then said yes. I get the point that people often need something to cling to; something that makes them feel that their suffering has some meaning, but how do you get to that? How can you believe something when you know, inside yourself, that it's just a fairy-tale? 
A comment above said that people can't just see this life as a game, but why not? If they choose to believe in a god, which makes little reasonable sense when you think about it, why not believe it's just a game? How you choose to rationalise existence seems to be a combination of personal choice, upbringing conditioning and social comfort. The most rational explanation I've heard as to our existence is simulation theory. People scoff at this, but it makes more sense than some magic man in the Bible. People scoff at it because it doesn't provide them comfort. People suffer and I guess it sucks to be them; we all suffer from time to time. External suffering can't really be avoided, but this is about internal suffering and that we do have a choice over. -- 06 Dec 2019, 07:26 -- Ha."
175957767,"K., Yeah I heard your part of the country got an early and heavy snow! Wow! Stay warm as is possible and yeah...hibernate...good plan! ;) S.C."
174345087,"I wrote this on /r/schizophrenia; I need to take it easy on myself but I can't. I'm good at writing and have a lot of thoughts in my head. But I can't DO. Something about negative symptoms makes people call us lazy, undisciplined. Yet we try really really hard. It's like the bar of energy has been lowered. Anhedonia, apathy, numbness, etc.. And for some reason it comes with hallucinations, delusions, paranoia, etc.. Imagine if it was just negative symptoms. People would think we're just lazy and that's all there is too it. I'm too ""lazy"" to even watch TV and eat junk food or use my PS4 or xbox. I haven't gamed since I was 12 which is when my negative symptoms started. My positive symptoms started when I was 16. I'm 23 now. I don't do that ****. I try to do all of these things but burn out so hard. Taking college classes, working part time, exercising (Hiking, gym, skiing, mountain biking, taking walks), guitar, Internet (Netflix, podcasts, reddit, youtube, social media, investing, etc), meditatin
g, reading books, talking to people like friends, family.. But I'm always tired as ****. I barely focus on one thing for a long time. I'm going completely no where. I don't have the effort to THINK. The antipsychotics and negative symptoms kill my creativity so I'm constantly looking for a CURE. This disease is really ****_NAME_ up. I try to understand it and listen to people that are motivational and they help a bit but there's only so much energy that I have. I take Vyvanse to stay awake. I'm depressed because of negative symptoms and tried to kill myself twice. I'm soooooo ****ing tired. It's not just being ""lazy"". It's something different but I can't explain it. Psychiatrists don't even pay attention and they don't even really know I bet. I try so hard to fight these negative symptoms and it's like I'm trapped in a mind that already has the dopamine so I don't need to do anything to get it. I barely eat, I don't want sex or even a relationship. I didn't even want friends at one point. I just wanted to d
ie because everything seemed meaningless and I wanted nothing."

175957776,"Hello _PERSON_ That is a fantastic attitude you have......an inspiration to us all! I am sorry you have had to give up on your big dreams, but let me point you to the fact that you can NOW RE-DREAM YOUR DREAMS ! There are still dreams to be dreamed and to be fulfilled, once you factor in the ability equation....but even at that, there are helps available for one, even before we look, or know that we need them. You use your phone or computer (re posting) so pray tell me, who could be more successful at encouraging others with depression, than you could? Living one's dream has nothing to do with a salary, or an office door, with the name on it. Living ones dream is governed by the satisfaction one receives for being a blessing to another human being And that you are already doing....so build on it. Yes, I can read between the lines, as I read all over your posts, so I have no doubt you might smile sweetly, as you read my post, and think ""if only she knew"". Well....maybe I do understand a bit. As a 
little girl I always wanted to be a nurse. As I reached mid-teens the desire was very strong, and a program was set up in our school, for girls who wanted to enter nursing to join a group whereby we could volunteer at the local hospital on the weekends. Oh I loved it, and it worked well, but something began to happen to my hands and arms...a nasty burning red rash began to break out, and the doctor thought at first that I was maybe allergic to the disinfectants we used to do certain things, so he suggested that I should not book for the summer, and see if we could get this cleared up. Well, it turned out to be the start of psoriatic arthritis.....so there went the skin and the joints....and there went my dreams!! My life has turned out very differently, but...I hasten to add, at 79 years old, I can tell you that I have had a wonderful life. It is still going, the dreams are still being dreamed, and there is far more for me to do than I would be able to do in another 100 years.......PLEASE LORD.....NO !!!!! WH
EN THE TRUMPET BLOWS I AM READY TO GO to my new body and new home!"

175957795,"Between 2001-2009, I was dealing with terrible anxieties. During this time, I had my medications adjusted. And I also was put on new medications. But none of it was helping me to calm down. In 2008, I started seeing an EMDR-trained therapist. After a few months, and after a combination of the EMDR and more medication changes, I finally began to calm down. It felt great, as I was no longer living with excessive anxieties. By early 2009, I was much more calm. I don't know if the calmness I was then feeling was because of the EMDR, the medication changes, or a combination. But either way, I was finally calm."

175957807,"Tbh not really as this would become rather lengthy lol. Trying to summarize it we usually have people who are very dependent, sometimes borderlinish, who have a need to evacuate their badness outside somehow, while keeping very strict split-images in their minds of peopel who are all-god / always there for them / have all the answers etc and people who are all-bad / who are never there for them / cant get it up in bed (yea this has been a recurring topic for some reason *shrug*)... often not actually wanting answers but rather toilets as it seems. Then we have people who are often rather anti-dependent, with unclear intersubjective boundaries in the sense of for example [subconsciously] seeing other people as parts of themselves, or extensions, or who might identify with the projections the other person is using. So the dynamic is actually objects projection of badness -> devaluation of object. While this is somehow an emotional reaction, I'd rather think this has a lot to do with faulty cognition.
"

175957823,"A relatively new term in psychology. Symptoms: -An intense or obsessive interest in the bigger meaning of life and death. The interest in exploring this may override a person’s enjoyment and engagement with other day-to-day activities. -Extreme distress, anxiety, and sadness about the society they live in, or the overall state of the world. -A belief that changes in anything are both impossible and futile. -Increasingly becoming, and feeling, disconnected, isolated, and separate from other people. -Cutting ties with other people because they feel like connections with others are meaningless or shallow and they are on a completely different level. -Low motivation and energy levels to do anything they would normally do. -Questioning the purpose, point or meaning of anything, and everything, in life. -Suicidal thoughts and feelings. How would one make a differential diagnosis between this and schizoid PD ?"

asis. Food with carbohydrates will raise our blood sugar. The more bread, potatoes, rice, food made with flour and sugar that we eat, the higher our blood sugar will go. You will know this because if you test your blood sugar right before you eat and then about two hours after you finish, you will see how your blood sugar rises when you eat any of that food. ""What can you eat? Meat, chicken, fish, vegetables (but not potatoes or corn), lettuce and other leafy greens, peanut butter, eggs, milk products with no sugar added, cheese, nuts. Corn is a grain and has a lot of carbs. ""A good meal could be a piece of chicken, some sauteed bell peppers with some slices of onions, a small salad. Other dinners could be a different piece of protein (meat) and different vegetables like mushrooms, eggplant, zucchini squash, small portion of green beans. 175957850,"Yes, you said one of your medicines (Depakote) would be the mood stabilizer for bipolar, and one (Trazodone) is for the depression. I've read on this website where 5 or 10 people were treated for bipolar, and the psychiatrist gave them only an anti-depressant, because they came in as depressed. Well, they're supposed to ask about any manic episodes they may have had, in case they are bipolar, not just depressed. Because, if they're bipolar and they gave them only an anti-depressant, it can send them into mania, and panic attacks. I've had that kind of treatment, misdiagnosed and miss-medicated, myself. So you are fortunate that you got diagnosed and medicated right, as far as both a stabilizer and and anti-depressant. What are you in now, before you took the medicine, a depressed state? Did you have any mania? Are you noticing any improvement?"

175957872,"Chanell93 said... Hi all I'm new to this site... wondering if anyone is still on this thread? I also have to deal with these eye prombles I first started to notice an afterimage of certain objects on the wall it would be like a clear image of it on the wall.. then I noticed if I look at the tv at night and look away I can still see the image on the wall that also happens with my phone .. and i also see trails in my vision and now they started where I can see a clear trail around a lot of things including my own arm or hand and it's really bothering me! I've had two regular eye exams one just two weeks ago and saw an ophthalmologist about a year ago and all said my eyes were fine just a little astigmatism.. also if I move my fingers I can see a clear air or soemthing a clear glow around my hands sometimes ..I get very anxious and read about my symptoms all of the time so I do believe I make it worse on myself.. just wondering others experience Sounds the same as what a few of us here have described. 
My afterimages aren't as intense as yours, I can see them but they dissipate quickly. When you look away and see the image, does it stay for long periods of time, even if you blink numerous times? Or is it 3-10 seconds. The visual trails you are describing seem pretty accurate to what we see. Same as the moving of your fingers, which is just the trailing occurring with brief motion. I assume you don't see the trailing if you are actually watching the moving object, only the peripheral. Have you taken drugs before, legal or otherwise? Any natural supplements? How old are you, and when did you first notice it. Was there any trigger? Are you stressed/depressed at all, and/or suffering other medical issues? If you go to this link: https://www.testufo.com/framerates#count=3&background=none&pps=480 Stick your mouse cursor somewhere in the middle, and stare at it (you can blink if you need). Do you see a translucent, milky white extension of the moving ufo's behind it? Some people believe this part of Visual Snow. A 
sub symptom of a general issue of the visual cortex of the brain. Seeing a static type flickering of some sorts when there's dim lighting, or even during the day. Visual trails like we mentioned, afterimages that are positive or negative, and many other symptoms that are sort of lumped together with this supposed brain issue. I'm skeptical that it's the cause. As that would mean everyone here that hasn't taken drugs or anything, just has some idiopathic version. Seem's rare and unlikely to be the case. I've read other people say they've had their significant other or family members see this ""trail"" we see. But it's just harder for them to see it, or to get the conditions right for them to notice it. And that we just happen to REALLY see it because we're overly aware of it due to anxiety and that we're in this feedback loop of always thinking of it, because we see it, creating a vicious cycle. If ""normal"" people can see it at times too, then it's something that it's inherently not normal, and perhaps we tr
uly are just more in-tuned to it, or have it possibly to a greater degree. I've also noticed that if I close my eyes but still barely open, like when you squint, the trailer seems to be way less intensive. Which I wonder if it has something as well to do with how the amount of light entering my eye is being processed. I don't really see it in pure daylight, or when it's dark. I see it with like low to medium lighting in my house. Or if I'm in the car in garage, and turn on the car light I see it a lot. It seems to be very noticeable with contrast differences, so something bright or light colored against a dark color, ect.."

175957898,"It sounds like you have so much on your plate. As cliche as it sounds, it truly does help to do one thing at a time. So even in a new state, maybe see if you can do a televisit/telehealth visit with an online therapist so that you have the support you need wherever you are. That can get you grounded. Then the next steps of getting your meds. And when you feel you are taking care of you, then you will be in a position to help your daughter without being overwhelmed. Even the Bible says this at Ecclesiastes 3:1 ""There is an appointed time for everything, A time for every activity under the heavens"" I'll summarize an article I read since we can't post links here. But it said what can you do when facing overwhelming demands? Maybe these suggestions can help. See if you can enlist the aid of others. Made your needs known. See where you can be accommodated or adjust schedules/tasks as needed. Keep track of the number of demands on you. Can anything be delegated to others or postponed if there is no one 
else available? Be selective about what you take on/accept. If you lack the energy, it's okay to say no. Bottom line. If you try to do everything, you may put yourself in a position where you can't do anything. I hope any part of this has been a help to you and that you find your ground, your strength, and some peace in the days to come. Best wishes."

174345402,"I would say for me... about 40% of the time is nearly (positive) symptom free(hallucinating once a week or less), 40% percent of the time is spent in periods of mild/moderate symptoms (hallucinating around half the days on and off) and 20% of the time is just BAD. 175957978,"It's very difficult at times but you have to reach out and keep trying. It's like being in a relay race, keep jumping over the hurdles and if you feel you just cant do that or you run out of steam, stop and be kind to yourself... You can do this, have faith and keep pushing on, no matter how hard it gets. Remember life is not easy and things may appear to be great for others in your point of view, but everyone has issues and struggles what ever it might be. Be GOOD TO YOURSELF! Don't give up, don't give in and don't be afraid to ask for help! Seek support groups that deal with anger, depression whatever it may be you are NOT alone. So many of us struggle with those types of issues. Block out politics, news and everything negative. When you feel better about yourself doors will open and the ""insignificant things"" in life are easier to deal with. Do what YOU want in life as long as you can provide for yourself and know you are not alone. If that road is to difficult ASK for help. God Bless. ; )"

175958034,"Not gonna lie, I've been there. While I do struggle with some depression and anxiety, my husband is far worse. He was hospitalized on suicide watch last year and it's so hard for me not to get angry at him when he has bad days. When he has bad days he misses work and it affects us financially. I don't know if I have any good advice, but I can tell you I understand the apathy and the frustration. It can be a lot to handle, especially if you have an off day but you feel like you can't afford to be upset because it could trigger your wife. Don't let her guilt you. That sounds terrible, but when she says things like ""I finally had a good day,"" or ""you should divorce me,"" be blunt. Tell her you love her and you're sorry that she's struggling but that it's important for her to understand how you feel too. 174345487,"Yeah. The ""standard of care in the community"" in any major US metro area for anyone prescribing serious meds is that, once you send the patient off with the script, you are the captain of the ship. You own it and everything that subsequently occurs--whether you personally wish to acknowledge this fact or not. So, yeah, you can suck at your job and push people off to the _NAME_ because you are too lame and pathetic to take responsibility for your patients, BUT, if something untoward or bad ever were to happen and you were not available and you had not empaneled someone to cover for you in your absence, there will be an armada of clincians who will be delighted to step forward in court and say that what you did does not meet the minimum stnadard of care in that town. Someone has to take the calls. Doesn't have to be you, but it has to be someone. You can't toss people out the door on Clozaril and not be responsible and available. If a neutropenic patient called you and you did not answer and they d
ied or got super sick, you are toast. Even dermatologists, which I was the surgical version of for many moons, prescribe extremely dangerous medications and must be available when the rare emergency does occur. And they do. So, most reasonable clinicians take their own calls or, if they are truly ""off,"" someone responsible is assigned those calls while they are absent. Just my personal take and experince, of course. I freely admit to being very old school on such matters."
175958045,"Ever play Terraria or Starbound? They're similar in concept to Stardew Valley, and they're pretty much endless. Admittedly, I haven't played Starbound in a while. I bought it in 2014 on my Mac because my friends at school were playing it, and the devs have made a number of changes to it since then. It used to have no storyline, but now it does have a full story with lots of missions. You get a spaceship and you get to upgrade it so that you can fly to different planets/worlds that have different enemies and resources. You craft all sorts of things. You can also build houses, buildings, etc and move people in. It's pretty similar to Dragon Quest Builders, except in 2D pixel art rather than 3D."

What is does to the nervous system and possibly of developing autoimmune issues is what the lasting affect is all about in ""chronic lyme"". _PERSON_ helped many people on that forum deal with

just not worth the effort for me. Its easier for me to just be alone which kind of sucks but thats the honest truth (wish it wasn't). I hope you find positive results as Anxiety is no fun - My anxiety was so bad I couldn't leave the home to check my mailbox or even do groceries or and would starve - I like in CA and found out about a 2 year social anxiety experimental program at Stanford University where they used CBT to reprogram your thinking and track your progress. They had me do things like go to starbucks and start conversation with one stranger a week , or when crossing a sidewalk pa
use and wave to a driver facing you (its weird but they wave back) The CBT helped me a lot . Another thing which helped was learning NLP. The NLP was good because i can pull up some tools and use them in a highly stress situation . Joining Toastmasters was one the best things I think toastmasters (it took me many months of driving round the building to build courage enter for my first meeting) - This really really helped me build up a lot of courage to put myself out there - Toastmasters is also free - look for one in your area they are all over the world ). I also joined a small improv group which really helped also and an acting group. I still have anxiety but its been reduced by about 70% . if I was to pick one thing that really helped me the most i'd have to say ""toastmasters"". After a toastmasters meeting i felt a buzz throughout like i could face the world head-on for the next few hours of the day . good luck ,"

175958154,"I've been in your situation before, in more ways than one. The first situation was, I was living by myself at about age 27 and lost my job, which had a lot of secondary results. Loss of money, loss of socialization, a rise of my emotional problems, which at about 27 was the appearance of my bi-polar ailment which I had not seen full-blown before. I was also not use to making my own decisions. I was also negative unconscious when it came to solving problems. So everything is stacked against me, including myself (my negative unconscious, which really didn't want to solve problems, I wanted to be me (incompetent) like I was raised by my negative parents, with my bi-polar also fowling up my thinking.) So I know I need to see a psychiatrist, but which psychiatrist? So, I can't decide on that, which gives me an excuse to not do anything, but when probably the real reason I'm not doing anything is my negative unconscious which doesn't want me to solve the problem (which my conscious thinking wants to solv
e the problem.) because that's the way I've been raised: worthless, incompetent, can't make a decision. I'm comfortable with that. That's who I am. So I had a nervous breakdown. What I could have done, from what I've read is, believe I can solve the problem before I go into it. To damp out my negative unconscious, which I can't see, I say three times, ""Think positive."" Only then do I start to think of the problem. (See a psychiatrist, pick one on the list, if you don't like that one, go to another one, with my unconscious negative not nullifying my conscious positive decision because I've already damped it out: ""Think positive."" As for the medicine, I was once in such a dilemma, but read in a book, if you;re concerned about a medicine, take only a portion of the pill, that way, if it has bad side effects, you'll only feel a half or a fourth of them. So you can try taking only a small portion of the pill, and if it has side effects you don't want to deal with, don't take any more. You're pretty smart to be 
reaching out for help."

175958158,"_PERSON_, when a patient is at a teaching hospital it can be overwhelming with all of the various students being involved with medical care. I know they need experience, but when it causes anxiety to ramp up, it is bothersome. Listen to your actual dr that is in charge of your care & this is who to ask questions to. When you see the dr make a list of questions to ask the dr too. Years ago my brother was in a car accident & was careflighted to a teaching hospital. He had a brain injury that required a level 3 trauma unit. The closest one was a teaching hospital. His wife had the option of allowing students to be a part of his care & she agreed to it. So many people in/out of his room. However, we identified who his drs were & this is who we dealt with directly. I had a heart attack & had a blood clot hit my left lung. I was on blood thinners while in the hospital to dissolve the clot. Before being released they implanted a filter so that if I got anymore, hopefully the filter will catch it. I was sc
ared at first, but decided I had to let the fear go. Please listen to your dr about the stroke & what he said about the blood clots. If you were in danger your drs would tell you. It is very good news that the stroke was not a bad one. It's going to take some time & patience to get back to normal. Hang in there. As the other member mentioned, check on getting a social worker involved. I would call the hospital & inquire about this. There may be a very good chance something like this is available for you. Yes, you do need to get out of bed & get some activity going every day. Even if it's walking around in your house. I don't know what the weather is like where you live, but just going outside & getting some fresh air is helpful in more ways than one. Take care."

175958181,"Following on from the previous post making a study of how the 'voices' attack or torment their chosen victim, target. I thought I could elaborate even further with a post about the observed methodology. So here it goes. 1) They come in the form of a type of harassment displaying Phishing tactics in order to gain information or they might prefer to mock you instead. Attempts to make you their plaything. 2) What's key to them is the formation of a trigger by the use of Trauma Bonding, this could be achieved through Phish for something from your past, or forming a new sensitization stimulus by word or association. This will then act as a key, or switch in order to play psychological 'games with you through the use of voices that seem to have no point of origin. 3) Anchoring also works via a similar method, this trick is to induce a bad reaction through an everyday stimulus or association to the voices conversation. ( the general direction they are alluring too) 4) Some times or most of the time mine t
end to mimic what you expect top find upon Twitter ( like a Death _USER_ID_ Twitter Storm, or their Facebook witch hunts) 5) The interplay is like Cat & Mouse game or a game of charades like what I have pointed out before in the previous post. The additional fun and games like group gaslighting, Ghosting with personnel items, shining bright lights at night, Floating Box surveillance scare, intimidation tactics are more covert and cloak and daggers, their designed to let you know that you're under watch or being tagged, monitored and openly persecuted clandestinely, or to get you to act out in a derogatory way in order for your to be recorded via iPhone apps. This is also called being Baker Acted. 6) The Power and Control dynamic runs straight through the whole experience, i have never known a more obvious way to put it, no other pathological diseases consist's of psychological power and control attributes other than voice-hearing, Cancer or HIV don't have this construct within them. 7) Another common thread w
ould be the Voyeuristic torture aspect to hearing voices, as they can comment or troll you with venomous impunity 24/7 while you go about your daily business around the house. These are just a few of the things I have noticed over a period of 15 years."
