174345841,"Lately, I feel as though my ex-girlfriend, from over a decade ago, which I dated for 9 years, that her self-confessed ""people"" that were keeping tabs on me, that they still might be. I've said some things on here that I deeply regret. But as I contemplate on it, what I said about her, it was like a Hamletian ""wild justice"" that happened out a ""Nerve"" that grew out of me. I come here to confess and help me move on. My psychologist said it helps to write out my thoughts and feelings. So I come here and do that and it helps me understand myself. She told strangers everything about me. All of my flaws and imperfections that are quite frankly humiliating, and they've grown to shame me publicly.. Every fine detail that characterized me as the epidemy of evil and wickedness. Coming here is like going to confession. Where I confess everything. Some things are just feelings, some of them are actions, some of them are just blowing off much steam. Imagine my horror when I realized when my ex-girlfriend'
s words of my imperfections reached a psychology professor, who said it plainly. The professor said it. It was empirical. she sat in the doorway and told me before we even sat down. It could not be denied. My ex girlfriend played a hand in trying to ruin me in an academic setting, where I was shelling out thousands of dollars for her entertainment. She stacked the dominos, and knocked the one over that lead to my collapse as I had to face that professor in her office, because her words got to that professor. The day I got out of the hospital I was a wreck, and I sought my ex-girlfriend's consul, only for her to justify her actions with pithy excuses of how I made her live in poverty, that my paint career is abhorrent, that her ""people"" have been stalking me. And in her weakness, when she was suicidal over her abortions one morning, that she had when she was with me, she sought my consul, and I betrayed her because I told all of you this on this forum. I told nobody else but you guys. Now Imagine if her ""pe
ople"" were watching me when I stated this on this forum, and went on a rant because I felt this ""nerve"" or impulse for Hamletian ""wild justice"" that I had to get off my chest, in private with a confess meant for just my friends here. There was no intention of signaling to her ""people"", outside of this forum. It was just meant for you guys. I then felt paranoia, and reacted with terrible feelings and regret, and guilt, and fear that her ""people"" saw it, but I have no way of finding out. My schizophrenia, my paranoia, makes me feel as though I am always being singled out. Now what if her ""people"" have and read that? This is why I named the character of _PERSON_ first book _NAME_ Daedalus. _NAME_ for the person thrown to the lions, and Daedalus, the person who created a labyrinth. But lately, I feel it to be more of a Gordian knot, that I can't figure out how to untie. I need to sever it, which would be deleting my account here. But you guys are my friends, and I care for you, and you make me more awa
re of myself, and you're part of my support net. I'm just conflicted, and these are my recent thoughts which are stuck in a pattern of thinking which I get fixated on. And then I sit back, and just exclaim I'm cursed, and I feel a bit of acceptance. People, for some reason, single me out, and try to give me the scarlet letter because they are unable to grasp the underlying issues, some of which they could never imagine! Schizophrenics often feel as though they are being ""gang-stalked"" but my ex has given me a reason to feel that, that public shame thrown my way. I don't let it get to me, because if they do then I just understand that their just an instrument in a system of oppression that makes men feel as though they can't seek therapy and talk about their feelings and impulses. Shame is the tool of the mindless herd, where they try to strip a person of their dignity, of their sovereignty within. Guilt and shame are different. Guilt is something I've worked to iron out in every imaginable sense. I have a f
uller understanding of who I am now, and have made great progress. Shame, however, is something that is thrown onto a person in public. It's external, and very effective. It's what drove Faust's love, _NAME_, towards her death. I wish I could just untie this knot, but to do so requires aid from one of my exes' ""people"" that she self-proclaimed. Everytime I get close to an answer, it slips away and drives me ****ing insane!"

175958353,"_PERSON_, I found this today and thought you may find it interesting reading. Love ya! Sassy Bipolar Disorder May Be Strongly Linked with Parkinson’s Disease Recently, researchers in Taiwan found that individuals with bipolar disorder may have a significantly elevated risk of acquiring Parkinson’s Disease (_PERSON_, 2019). The authors followed a cohort of more than 50,000 patients with bipolar disorder at baseline, and compared them over the time frame to healthy controls. What they found was that individuals with bipolar disorder, had a nearly sevenfold greater incidence of eventually acquiring Parkinson’s Disease than those without bipolar disorder. Furthermore, individuals with a history of manic and depressive, or mixed episodes, as well as a history of hospitalizations for bipolar disorder, had a much higher likelihood of acquiring Parkinson’s later on in life. The notion of a bipolar-Parkinson’s link is not new. Prior literature has suggested a link between the two conditions at the 
level of neurotransmitters. One prime example is that of serotonin, which plays a major role in bipolar disorder pathophysiology, particularly with respect to depression. As it turns out, serotonergic activity is also notably reduced in Parkinson’s (_PERSON_, _PERSON_, & _PERSON_, 2016). To read further on this topic click here: https://pro.psychcentral.com/bipolar-disorder-may-be-strongly-linked-with-parkinsons-disease/?utm_source=Psych+Central+Weekly+Newsletter&utm_campaign=fc0ad0d86c-BIP_EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_c648d0eafd-fc0ad0d86c - _PHONE_NO_"

175958356,"Break your tasks into chunks so they seem more manageable. First, just focus on orientation on Sunday and put the rest of it out of your mind. Then once orientation is over, focus on the next task. Keep doing that, even if you have stuff happening back-to-back, and it should help ease up some of the anxiety. This is the strategy I employ. One thing at a time, small picture, etc. Good luck!"

175958403,"_PERSON_ is on two Anxiety forum threads (“Lexipro (or other SSRI’s) and Muscle Twitching” and “Left pectoral muscle twitches”). I’ve had muscle twitching also and did not connect it to medicine for 5 years. But the twitching was connected to a medicine I was taking (Mirtazapine anti-depressant). Net says Mirtazapine is an SSRI which “stands for Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor. SSRI antidepressants are a type of antidepressant that work by increasing levels of serotonin within the brain. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that is often referred to as the `feel good hormone'”. So when the question arises, does (“Lexipro (or other SSRI’s) [cause] Muscle Twitching” I found the answer to be, yes, Lexipro and other SSRI’s can cause muscle twitching. This is of interest to me because I take an SSRI (Mirtazapine) and I have muscle twitching. I have taken that medicine for five years. For the first 3 years (taking 15 mg.), I made no connection between taking the Mirtazapine at 1
2 midinight, and by toes starting to twitch 30-45 minutes later, plus my appetite increasing to where I had to get up and have a snack. Due to circumstances, the connection dawned on me and my psychiatrist reduced the med to 7.5 from 15 mg and I thought all was taken care of. For the last 2 years on 7.5 mg, I would have occasional toe twitching but it has increased, followed by getting up and having another snack. So I get to bed at 12 midnight, and at 5 a.m. I have yet to get to sleep. Two days ago for the first time, I connected all of that, so I took my Mirtazapine not at midnight, but 5 hours earlier at 7 p.m., hoping the side effects would wear off at midnight, and they did and I slept from 12 midnight to 8 a.m.. about the SSRI Lexapro (treats anxiety and depression net says), Webmd.com says under rare side effects: A Feeling Of Restlessness With Inability To Sit Still Muscle Tremors Cramps And under “Side Effects, 5th paragraph: “twitching muscles”. By clicking on “twitching muscles” in the 5t
h paragraph of Side Effects, it said: ""Twitches. Unlike tics, the majority of muscle twitches are isolated occurrences, not repeated actions. Muscle twitches are also known as myoclonic jerks. They are entirely involuntary and cannot be controlled or suppressed."" So I would say SSRI’s can cause twitching muscles. You also said, “Recently, and even before going back on the Lexapro (after being off of that for 8 months), I’ve had the annoying and worrisome twitches and spasm in my left breast muscle.” Trying to figure out what to do after finding out the SSRI’s can cause muscle twitching I’m finding to also be a problem. I’m trying to take my Mirtazapine 5 hours early. But the twitching toes starts only about an hour or two after taking the medicine, so I maybe I can take it 2 hours before bedtime. Anyway, that’s the situation as I see it."

I look up at the cosmos, past the dread abyss and dying stars, and I see two choices an individual can make: One can look up and see a world full of meaning, purpose and providence; and then the other choice is the materialist position where this life is all there is, and after we die, that's it, because we were just a random mutation. Personally, I'm drawn to mystery, and I ask weird question like, ""Why does e=mc2, and not some other equation? Science has a difficulty time giving us the 'why' answers--which religions answer. I think this eternal drama we've found ourselves in is confusing since birth. However, the fact that I can feel anything at all fills me with awe sometimes, and a glimmer of hope. omething out there. One thing I find mysterious is the term ""atom."" In greek it means ""indivisible bit,"" Sounds crude that that's what ultimate reality. 175958479,"I've never seen this as a benchmark before, but it would make sense. _AT_MENTION_ You need to identify the constructive purpose: why are you trying to make the point? If someone has body odour, you want to focus on the stink, but it's more important to focus on why you need the stink gone. Then, turn it into a $#%^ sandwich - a turd hidden between two pieces of bread: ""_NAME_, I really appreciate your friendship; it's been very important to me and I don't know what I'd do without you around, but I have to tell you that you need to take more care of your personal hygiene. I know this is difficult to hear, but you're a terrific person and if you took care of this then imagine how much more effective you'd be?"" Alternatively, be brutally direct. I use this example as it was one I had to deal with. I invited the person into a conference room where we could be alone and said, ""_PERSON_, you stink mate and everyone's talking about it. ct with people but you'd be surprised at how often that works, providing you keep to the facts and, as stated above, find a constructive purpose for the comments."

175958547,"Honestly man, I'm going to tell you from personal experience, quitting any psychiatric medication cold turkey is going to put you in a world of hell. 175958623,"I meant to reply to this as well, so it didn't get fully lost in the woodwork. It's very unpleasant to feel trapped or hopeless. If you're in crisis or planning to kill yourself, reach out to a crisis line or take yourself to the hospital, etc. Personally, If I wanted any real degree of emotional support - especially for hopelessness/deep discouragement - I wouldn't be searching through these forums because the areas that could offer it (depression subforum, etc) are barely active at this time. I'd call a crisis line or go to my therapist. Not just for bpd anymore, DBT distress tolerance, emotional regulation, interpersonal skills, mindfulness can also be helpful in getting through crisis - as well as for learning skills in the mentioned areas. It's easy enough to find through online searches or YouTube. Counseling as well if you know what would improve your life, and you want clarity and help getting there. Quality of life can always be improved in some way or another if one is committed to it. Ev
en if it doesn't seem that way."

174346196,"I once called 911 on the hospital because I legit thought that they were poisoning my food and other things. Think of the meds as what they really are (Antipsychotic medication). They do the exact opposite of LSD, shrooms, mescaline and DMT. Psychedelics can cause hallucinations, dissolving of free will, paranoia, psychosis and delusions. Antipsychotics antagonize serotonin 2A receptors which decreases dopamine. Too much dopamine is in the temporal lobe (Hearing?) which causes voices. Dopamine can go into the back of the head and cause visual hallucinations. Your prefrontal cortex malfunctions. Humans are the only known animal that can get schizophrenia because they have a prefrontal cortex. If you do a lobotomy and severe the front of the brain, you become a zombie. Antipsychotics can make you feel like a zombie but not at moderate doses which usually work for psychosis. There's also spirituality that you can think about when you're not so scared. I couldn't sleep last night and was going slightly 
psychotic but thankfully the Seroquel kicked in and I could go to sleep. I imagine things in my head and it just turns out into suicidal, homicidal, weird thoughts because I also have obsessional OCD and intrusive thoughts. It's the dissolving of free will. Free will is an illusion and animals don't think about what we're doing. But we do. We are the most advanced form of life and we think too much. Remember, no one is in control. If you look at earth from a spaceship, you're just watching a bunch of monkeys fighting over different Gods and killing each other. Hippies doing psychedelics from love and the bad trip, coming from hate and repressed traumatic memories in the subconsciousness from what evil people did. It's easy to be cynical, or think people are out to get you from environmental factors of what has happened to you and the thoughts that you think. Thoughts are hallucinations but you have to trust your thoughts. You don't trust your thoughts and you are lucid. Without the meds, you could lose insigh
t."

175958641,"Now lets continue with inmytree1988. From my experience, medication isn‘t an enemy. I also was very skeptical about the first time my psychiatrist suggested it to me. I was scared because I knew about some side effects, that I didn‘t want to get. But I am so glad that we found the right medication for me, because it really made a difference. I take something for anxiety and depression and after a few weeks of consistently taking it, I felt a lot better. The thing is, you shouldn‘t expect the first medication, that‘s given to you to be working immediately. Sometimes you have to try one and see if it‘s right for you. If not, go to your doctor and try a different one. I had to try two different medications first, before we found this one I‘m taking currently which is working really well. If you‘re very concerned about the possible side effects, tell that your doctor, they will really explain everything to you and clear up your concerns. One thing you really need to take into consideratio
n is, that medication isn‘t magically taking your problems away, it only supports you and gives you some feeling of lightness in your life. But it is still you, who has to work on your issues. Medication can only make it a little easier. I heard from some people that for them it wasn’t the right thing and it didn‘t work, but again it depends on you, it takes patience to find the right medication and for it to work. It could totally be the right thing for you or not, but you have to try it to know. One last thing on being scared that it doesn‘t work and that you will always be like this... man it‘s tough, I understand that this feeling can be so crushing and heavy and I don‘t know what to say to this here as a comment (and I don‘t know what‘s going on in your personal life)... and just saying something like: „You‘ll be okay“ and „Things aren‘t as heavy as you might think“, are just empty phrases tbh. So the only thing I can say is, that you aren‘t alone and trying things out can r
eally make a difference."

175958647,"For stomach anxiety what had worked for me in the past is meditation and breathing exercise, also general physical maintenance. Professionals will put you on meds. Which if you are going through a severe period I think can be ok, kinda like a band-aid. But you can't keep it on for too long.... and it doesn't fix the problems anyway. If you want to get better, you need to work it out. Like physical fitness, you need to work your mental fitness. And just like physical fitness, it can be a lot of work. It's easier with other people, find group therapy, meetups that gather to do exercise/meditation/anything. Easier in bigger cities where lots of meetups occur. It worked well for me. Until I stopped, which, is up to you. Good Luck. Oh and I say meditation/breathing for stomach anxiety because a lot of the work from those come from centering your energy into your stomach area and then releasing it evenly through your body. Imagine your stomach like a furnace, that keeps your body comfy. If your fire burn
s out, or starts raging, your whole body is out of whack."

175958651,"SnD, Exercise is without a doubt a power tool, and one that I can personally testify about ! I have been tempted at times to cancel my classes on really challenging days, but never actually have... ...and I can't think of a time when I haven't felt better after being physically active! (I teach dance and move the entire time my students do!) This is not to say that exercise is the end all be all cure...there are still going to be some that need the benefit of an Rx, because everyone's situation is unique. However, it is a great place to start, along with other self help mechanisms! Thanks for the helpful reminder! S.C."

175958689,"Hello donna6630, Welcome to Inspire! Thank you for sharing your story. We encourage you to check other discussions on Inspire about bipolar depression and coping with medication side effects. You can start by typing your search terms in the box near the magnifying glass at the top, right side of the page or by clicking the links below. Search: Bipolar Depression Search: Coping With Medication Side Effects Our partner for this community, Mental Health America, also provides resources on their website including information about treatment options, screening techniques, and self-help toolkits. This information can be found at the following links. Mental Health America: Finding Help for Myself Mental Health America: Recovery and Support Mental Health America: DIY Tools In addition, you may want to check out our iFred community. It is specifically for anxiety and depression support, with over 8,000 members discussing their experiences with bipolar depression and coping with medication side effects. You 
can read more at the link below. Inspire Community: iFred We hope this helps and encourage you to continue reaching out! -TeamInspire"

175958781,"Hey there… thanks for reaching out, I admire how strong you’ve been all this time. Let me just say I used to love alcohol. Like, LOVE it, I’d have a strong mixed drink every night, usually 2 beers every day, and wine a bit as well. Let me just say, taking it to school in a metal cup was not the best idea. I didn’t get caught by anyone there… a lot of the kids noticed but thankfully didn’t tell the teachers. I went for like over 6 months like this, and I felt the same way you do now. Made such a huge difference, I felt so much better and happier, but as the effects kept wearing off with time, had to keep having more. School was very stressful, which was why I brought it in. However, eventually my mom caught me. As in, another parent alerted her… I kept drinking, but not at school. And while it seemed effective… looking back it wasn’t worth it. I mean, it did help at the time. But now… I can’t hardly have alcohol at all. I think I had my life’s amount in less than a year. Now, 
if I have more than an inch in a glass of alcohol, I get a pain right where my liver is. I’ve gone a while without drinking, still is that way when I do. If it’s a strong one, it hurts worse. If it’s light, I may not notice it right at first. But it’s always there if I drink. Probably not the best thing, seeing as I’m not even 20 yet… and was 14-16 when I was heavy on it. There’s definitely nothing wrong with easing out of a hard day with some alcohol, but I’d recommend looking for better options. For example, NA beer instead of regular – tastes almost the same! Or, a light wine cooler instead of straight wine… or a weaker mixed drink vs. too strong. You’ll be glad in the long run if you do this… You’ll be able to have alcohol longer without the intense pains. And no, it’s not stupid at all to do. I sympathize completely because I used to be that way. It was one of a few bad coping strategies I had. It isn’t good for your health, just gonna say that as it is, but no judgements he
re. That’s just a fact. And I completely agree with you. I am a Christian, but religion rarely works as a way to get through these feelings. I had to have a therapist, counseling and medication. Being a Christian didn’t fix this for me. I used to think it made my life perfect. I felt so much better, it relieved my anxiety, I was actually happy, and I loved the feeling. But in the long run, now I’m so annoyed that I can’t have much more alcohol anymore. So yes, I felt the same way as you did. By no means am I here to preach to you, but here’s a link you may want to check out. I know you’re not a Christian, but just watch it with an open mindset. This video has completely changed the way I view life, and even if you’re not a believer, it may help you, as well: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FOkuZpZKVpo ... and like I said I’m not sure if it will help you or not. Just trying to help. Thank you for reaching out, and keep fighting – you are not alone!"

175958817,"From my experience psychiatrist's define your level of ""illness"" by how objective you can remain with the hallucinations. Personally I have never had hallucinations, but I have what I call conversations, which sometimes happen all day. cess, only to be recalled after a significant number of fatality-related lawsuits. After all, at one time, DDT and thalidomide got thumbs-up, just like glyphosates. My mother caught and survived the Hong Kong flu: ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1968_flu_pandemic ). I survived what I now realize was near-fatal food poisoning eati
ng my usual shrimp dish from a New Haven Chinese restaurant, survived a suicide attempt and a broken back, survived cancer. My late grandfather lived to 92 on absolutely no medication, with an incredibly sharp mind, despite a lifetime smoking Camel straights; working for decades without sunscreen on the open ocean in the equatorial sun wearing a tank top as a shirt--despite not being one, he was as a dark as any African American; with exposed asbestos under his kitchen sink; eating sunnyside-up eggs with butter nearly every day, bloody rare steaks often, and drinking scotch. He openly defied every FDA recommendation, ate what he wanted, lived the way he wanted, and had but one remedy for everything from clinical depression to eczema, ""Swim in the ocean."". I come from a long line of real men and women who did not jump when told to. I will not kowtow to any authority. If it's my time to get sick and/or die, I'm fine with that. havior just because some turd in a lab coat who couldn't stand eye-to-eye with my grandfather tells me to. I do believe that could be what it is. I found the article very interesting. Here is the address: https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/the-mindful-self-express/201809/how-ptsd-and-trauma-affect-your-brain-functioning You can copy the above and put it on the address bar, and the article comes up on the screen. Here is a summery of what the article says: Research suggests that the brains of people with PTSD differ from brains of those without PTSD in two main ways: • They are hyperactive to threat (_USER_ID_). • They have difficulty regulating or damping down anxiety and anger (medial PFC). Effective treatments for PTSD seem to address these brain dysfunctions by either decreasing the reactivity of the _USER_ID_ or increasing the ability of the PFC to calm it down. Therapists who are trained to recogni
ze and treat the signs of PTSD can be much more effective in reducing the considerable suffering associated with their trauma experience. Educating patients about their symptoms and the neurobiology of PTSD can be de-shaming and increase their self-compassion and sense of control. 175958998,"A common symptom of mental illness is called Anosognosia. It is the ill person's inability to recognize the illness they are suffering from. You are not alone and it is one of the most frustrating aspects for a loved one or caregiver to experience. I cannot give you a solution to your question because I have the same circumstance with my 23yo son and it has not resolved itself yet. If you want to stay with your wife, you are going to have to learn how to deal with and react to her symptoms and hold your breath that she somedays recognizes the issue and is receptive to treatment. I strongly urge you to watch youtube videos by Dr. _NAME_ as he is the foremost expert on this topic."

175959000,"Hello to all who take a few minutes to read this . Since August of 2018 out of nowhere I developed what is called air hunger or should I say “dyspnea” and may I say it has to be the most uncomfortable sensation I’ve ever delt with . I’m 28 y/o 165lb and healthy . Iv had every test under the sun performed. PCP/Pulmonologist/ENT/cardiologist/GI/ Allergist , even a mental health doctor and not a single doctor has come up with a diagnosis except yea... I’m sure you’ve already guessed it “ANXIETY” witch for some reason I find is complete BS in my opinion. I had a blood taken and thyroid checked as well all normal . This sensation has been 24/7 since the day it came on last August not a single medication these doctors that I listed above have helped . Now to conclude that this may be anxiety... my PCP has me on Xanax witch is doing absolutely nothing for this sensation. all it does is makes me feel like not moving wonderful drug.... and In the past being this has been going on for 8 month
s I was put on many other benzo’s that also did nothing for this urge to take deep breaths . I was completely fine before this complete nonsense has come into my life and destroyed it. The only thing I had issues with was my temper witch kinda runs in my family. And stress from normal things in life witch I think every human being goes through. I have an amazing girlfriend of 10 years a great family, job I work hard at, and anything a young man could ask for . But now life is extremely uncomfortable and doing every day things is just horrid . I don’t know how I’ve even made it this far with this debilitating symptom. Nothing is making sense here and I’ve literally been praying for just an answer and a cure for this evil sensation. Now... I did use marijuana pens for about 8 months prior to this happening simply for pain from motocross accidents(broken bones) and like many others I enjoyed a calm and happy high hanging out at home or with friends listening to music and tinkering with our bikes . It wor
ked . Deff with pain and fatigued from being a mechanic witch is hard on your body . I will never touch a pain killer or get sucked into the opioid usage. The horror stories I’ve heard... so that being said I came to a complete stop with the Weed pen thinking this could have been the cause of this symptom. Well 3 months had passed and nothing got better so I kinda ruled that out but I figured I’d share that . It’s sad that I see others out here on these forums searching for answers from this literally silent but completely life altering symptom and we are getting no answers . All I ever hear is it’s all in your head ... but it’s a physical symptom and never goes away even with the treatment of these “head” medications that just make you feel like crap on top of feeling suffocated...? So as of this very moment I’m waiting for blood test back from the labs to see if Lyme or any infections related to Lyme may be the cause. but all my tries to curing this have gone down in flames . Just would like 
my life back . I have so much to live for so much to enjoy so many good people in my life . This has made me a miserable person and I’m so tired of it . So please if any one has anything new to mention or even an answer to this evil be my guest. We all need to get better ! 175959001,"Helping those with mental illness can be rewarding. Making a difference in the lives of those trying to cope with this terrible illness not only helps them, it can also help you. Just knowing that you helped someone can be rather rewarding. However, helping others doesn't have to be rocket science. Granted, becoming a psychiatrist isn't easy. It's not a simple job. Being a psychiatrist and prescribing medication isn't a menial job by any means. But helping those with bipolar disorder, PTSD, depression, etc. doesn't necessarily require rocket science. Heck, just being a good listener when someone with mental illness is telling you about their problems isn't rocket science. However, it really can help people. Also, it doesn't have to rocket science in order for you to find it to be interesting and fascinating too. I've talked to those dealing with mental illness before. And while doing that wasn't brain surgery, I still found it to be both rewarding and interesting."

175959005,"40 million Americans face limitations in their usual life activities due to chronic illness. A chronic illness is an illness that lasts one year or more. 75% of all healthcare costs are due to chronic illness, and mental illness is one of the most expensive. The most common chronic diseases are heart disease, smoking-related conditions, alcohol-related conditions, diabetes, arthritis, cancer and mental illness. While direct healthcare costs soar, the total cost of chronic disease to the economy in 2007 was $1.3 trillion. Total economic cost includes lost productivity and the cost of disability and unemployment claims, in addition to medical costs. As the number of people with chronic illness increases, this total cost is expected to hit $4.2 trillion by 2023. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/09/the-numbers-on-chronic-illness/"
175959006,"Counties in the US with the worst air quality have a rate of bipolar disorder 27% higher than the national average. Prevalence of bipolar disorder was higher in the industrial east than on the west coast. Researchers surmise that pollution is the reason. A complicated set of factors goes into the expression of bipolar disorder, and much of the scientific focus has been on genetics. However, research published in August finds that environmental factors account for 32% of the risk of bipolar disorder. The study looked at insurance claims for bipolar disorder by county and compared the number of claims to EPA data on the environment. A significant relationship between poor air quality and high rates of bipolar disorder was established. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/10/air-pollution-and-bipolar-disorder/"

175959011,"Years ago, I received treatment from a mental health agency. Everyday they would have a mental health worker employed by them come to the house that I was living in to help me cope with the depression and anxiety issues which I was facing at the time. They'd help me get through the day. They also had other clients that they worked with who also needed that kind of assistance. The mental health workers that I worked with back then told me that if you're a mental health worker, you learn something new each day. They couldn't tell me specifically what they learned each day while working with their other clients, as that was confidential information. However, I thought it was cool that they learned something about helping people with psychiatric issues like me each day. And I thought it was neat that they enjoyed learning new things about helping those with mental illness as well as learning about the illness itself each day. So if you're considering working in that field someday, realize that if you d
o enter the mental health field, you'll be learning something new every single day."

175959077,"Hi. You have a gift for writing. Have you ever contemplated writing a memoiristic account of this experience, this delusion, as you call it? And even post it on Medium or other blog? At the same time, you've been told by doctors that you've had a psychotic episode, which is unsettling and probably not something you want to or should repeat, if at all possible. 175959102,"Hey, I’ve self-harmed for almost two years now, and I believe it is very addictive. Like any habit, it can become unhealthy based on why you choose to use it and how much you use it. 175959163,"RTMS is rapid transcranial magnetic stimulation. The patient is hooked up to a machine that “zaps” and stimulates an area of the brain that researchers believe is most responsible for clinical depression. I received it in a lengthy double blind study at Stanford while it was awaiting FDA approval. Even though it was a double blind study I could tell very soon that I was receiving the real treatment. Just MY experience of course... it was a huge failure for me, made me much worse. I almost ended my life. Rspecial if you go ahead with it I wish you all the best. Pay close attention to changes you feel and let your doctors know right away. _PERSON_"

175959179,"Yes. We're lucky in our unluckiness. Having to prioritize 'gripping the armrests' can help to keep us from getting sucked into the bs. For several decades, media conglomerates have invested billions of dollars in fabricating lies which are as unresolvable as impossible objects ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impossible_object ). These, along with bright, shining celebrity irrelevancies, are designed to keep the masses distracted, angry, and divided. Real information of vital everyday concern, such as net neutrality and the enduring availability of clean drinking water, exists but one must actively seek it, evaluate it, and verify it. Many people are lazy, still more are tired, so tired that their creative energy has, in some cases, degenerated into mindless chatter about laundry days. They are too tired to remember to make time to look at their lives. If it's any consolation, I don't believe anyone involved in the 'laundry days' thread(s) would be proud of how they used their time. One of the thing
s I most deeply loathe is when, on a forum, someone shares something off-beat, and the 'forum elite' (what bs!) jump all over that person simply for having a different opinion. Sincerely held opinions which differ from the majority are vital to the health of any community. 175959180,"I'll share what happened at my job last year in a different post to keep these things short, but I do need to share the fact that I'm on long term disability right now for anxiety/PTSD. This last year has been a nightmare, issues with my job and lack of adequate medical care led me to end up on long term disability. Along with that, I lost my house (sale fell through), then had to file for bankruptcy. I ended up with a very bad attorney, and lost my home, lost my rental, lost both of my vehicles, and went for an entire month without pay because my bank was taking all of my direct deposits, which then resulted in me getting my electricity and cell phones disconnected. I ended up doing all of my paperwork myself, and then paid an attorney to help me file it and go to the hearing with me. I lost $5000, along with everything else. In February, a month before I was going to end up on long term disability, I tried to get my ex to take care of our kids (he never does) so I could go out of town for medical 
care. He lives 85 north of us, in a different state, but he works in the town that we live in. He just didn't feel it was his responsibility to help me. So, once my bankruptcy was discharged, I sent him the official letter, telling him I wanted to move to AZ, which is where my oldest son and step-daughter lived. I wanted to move out there primarily for our daughter, who is extremely gifted in both music and art, and they had a school out there that I hoped she'd be able to attend. I didn't think my ex would have any issues with this, he didn't bother much with our kids, and he knew I was doing this for our daughter. He didn't, but his mother did, she's got an unhealthy attachment to our seven year old son. He told me that he agreed to let us relocate so I began to plan the move out there. Two weeks before we were supposed to move, I was served. He was not only objecting to the move, he was also asking the courts to give him sole custody. Why? He alleged that I had a severe mental illness (didn't have to say w
hich one), and that I took drugs (which drugs?), and that I was planning to take off with our kids (that's why he told me he agreed, to get me to start making plans to move out there). Included in that objection was a restraining order that prevented me from taking our kids out of the county. I, fortunately, had just taken money out of my 401k, or I'd have been unable to hire an attorney. I hired one, didn't meet her until the first hearing, which was to see if the judge would allow us to go out to AZ temporarily. She should have known better, this judge doesn't allow temporary relocations of children, but that was minor in comparison to my attorney telling the judge, as soon as she called on her, that she wasn't prepared for the hearing. It didn't go well, and the judge denied my request to relocate. While we waited for the judge to make a decision, we remained restricted to the county, and then I started getting the subpoenas that his attorney was issuing, along with a HIPAA waiver, so they could get approv
al to access my medical records. I was horrified, I felt so violated by this, you'd think there'd have to be some basis for this, other than an allegation. It seemed as though they were just going to let him keep fishing through my records until he found something he thought he could use to get custody. I hired another attorney, I had to pay him $8000 up front before he'd start working on my case, but he never did anything other than send emails to me and my ex's attorney. It'd been almost two months, I was still under the restrainer order, I had hoped to at least go visit my sister before my kids went back to school, but my ex's attorney wouldn't agree to let us go. By now my discovery documents were almost a month overdue, this attorney still hadn't even filed a notice of appearance, much less done anything productive with my case, so, on to attorney number three, and another $7500. She was, by far, the cruelest person i've dealt with in a very long time. I was optimistic that she'd help us (I'm a fool), bu 
four days after I paid her, she started telling me that she thought I woudl end up losing my children This was based on what my doctor had put in my file in June 2019, that said I was withdrawing from my children. I don't know why she felt it was necessary to tell me that when she had no strategy or game plan to follow it up with. I have PTSD, but I imagine any parent who was told something l9ike that would panic. I spent the weekend torturing myself as I went through all of the emails from back when we were still married (2014 - 2015). I didn't know if that would help, but I figured it might help demonstrate where my anxiety issues started. I didn't send them to her though, I just sent a quick email asking if she thought they'd help. For that, she spent three hours chastising me about trying to play the victim. This happened two more times, and her accusations just kept getting worse, and she continued to tell me I was going to lose my children. I didn't feel I had a choice but to let this woman do this to m
e, I knew I wasn't going to find another attorney, I had trouble finding her! I asked her earlier this week if she'd be willing to just speak to my brother, I knew she'd be less likely to do that to him than she had been to me. For that, she told me she was going to withdraw from my case, and now I'm probably going to have to go up against a very nasty father's rights lawyer. I've lost $35,000 since June, $25,000 of it was through these attorney's. I don't feel like anyone cares about me or my kids, my ex hasn't been impacted at all by this, since his legal fees are covered by his mother. I feel like I'm being held hostage. I'm holding it together, but I'm all alone here, if nothing else it'd be nice to have people that i could talk to that understand what I'm going through. 175959226,"Hi _NAME_, I am sorry to hear that you are experiencing this new and disturbing symptom. I have been through it myself and it is really a challenging one....since as you said, turns into a vicious cycle of anxiety=symptom=more worries=increased symptoms! Breathing Exercises really were my relief when it came to the feeling of breathlessness. In all honesty, it can be tough when first learning the discipline of using breathing techniques, but well worth the perseverance and continued practice! (even if at first it makes you more focused and aware of the issue) One exercise in particular helped me. It is called 'The Divided Breath'. It gives structure and brings a sense of control over your breathing once again by visualization and counting/timing. (if you are interested let me know and I will do a search and copy and paste instructions here for you) You can also look up the suggested breathing exercises in our Resources at the top of the main forum page. They should all be helpful to you. Getting to 
work on breathing techniques as well as continuing your regular coping skills should give you the relief you need. Peace and progress, S.C."

175959258,"The thing about SPD is...it isn't usually a sudden thing. I am mystified sometimes by the stories that I read about from people who are in relationships with those they suspect of having SPD. Like, personally, even as a fairly secret schizoid, it becomes really, really hard to mask my complete emotional unavailability and lack of attachment after a short time. How do these relationships even happen? It blows my mind. I have to say, that if it's a sudden change, you might want to be looking into depression as a back up. Depression and SPD can have similar symptoms. For example, sleeping a lot is more of a descriptive sign of depression than it is SPD. Low energy, could arguably be both. Lack of interest in sex could be both. Lack of interest in normal activities could be both. Depression can be sudden onset. Schizoid personality disorder isn't usually. I do see that there were apparently signs of SPD before, like a lack of relationships or initiative. I scratch my head a little at why anyone would w
ant to enter a relationship with someone like that, but to be fair I have SPD, so in general I question why people choose to have relationships at all. I hope things work out for you. I don't think it's healthy that ""he's working to meet your expectations"". That doesn't sound like a healthy relationship for either of you. Seems like a power imbalance to me."
175959259,"Yes!!! Am autistic addict.. Very easy to stick with habits, hard to break out of them - Very hard to change (Initiate new task..). You have to do it in a split second - It requires practice which makes the brain neuroplastic and easier to learn, adapt and change. It gets easier with time - Like playing a game - Then you want a challenge even more and realize that you're miles ahead of anything you've ever dreamed of. It's a reason as to why _NAME_ wrote in mirror text or used his left hand. _NAME_ started out with a learning disability and now he's a world famous cognitive trainer. He says to use your left hand when brushing your teeth and morning routines etc - Says to learn as if you're going to teach someone else the same thing.. Stuff like that. I think it's a reason as to why people with dyslexia become so creative (They have to think outside of normal reality/language). I've been learning these things - My room is spotless.. Everything is always in the same place (But that can become a hinder
ance as well so it's good to change things up - I think that's why people end up wanting change anyways because it's a natural brain muscle reaction to help us survive.. 174347123,"I've been hospitalized a few times and I'm thankful for those experiences. I've been hallucination and delusion free for over 4 years and that would not have been possible without those hospitalizations which gave a safe environment for us to find the right combination of meds for me. I have a really amazing life now and most of my experiences inside were okay. Most people are nice in there (the patients and nurses). Different ones focus on different things. Some have a lot of group and individual therapy while other's it's more free time. They usually have outside or recreation times and art or music therapy every week. There was chapel available on Sundays. I don't smoke but I kept a separate sweatshirt I would use to go out on smoke breaks so I could get outside a little. Some places have delicious food and some have pretty yucky stuff, but it's tolerable. There are usually snacks available throughout the day since so many people need to take meds with food at different times. It was hard being 
mostly cut off from people (although there were weekly visiting times). I came away with some crazy stories. I even miss it occasionally because although my life is really good now, there is something nice about not being responsible for things, just following a routine and going where asked. The people who knew I went in were really understanding. Other people didn't look at me differently (even though sometimes it felt like I should have been wearing a sign that said ""Hey I'm Schizophrenic"". Most people are really so focused on themselves and how they are feeling that they don't generally care or pay that much attention to other people's lives."

175959281,"But new research has shown that the brain can form new neural pathways and create neurons even in adulthood (Neuroplasticity and Neurogenesis). ... Intermittent Fasting. ... Travel. ... Use Mnemonic Devices. ... Learn an Instrument. ... Non-Dominant Hand Exercises. ... Read Fiction. ... Expand your Vocabulary. ... Create Artwork. Dancing Sleep ""Several investigations have shown that structural and functional cerebral neuroplastic processes emerge as a result of long-term musical training, which in turn may produce cognitive differences between musicians and non-musicians."" ""Physical exercise is thought to stimulate neuroplasticity through the regulation of central growth factors, and current evidence points to brain-derived neurotrophic factor as the potential underlying mechanism through which physical exercise might enhance the effectiveness of CR."" ""There are two main types of neuroplasticity: Functional plasticity: The brain's ability to move functions from a damaged area of the brain to o
ther undamaged areas. Structural plasticity: The brain's ability to actually change its physical structure as a result of learning."""

175959369,"Hello I'm 67 yrs old, but due to health issues, it feels like 97 on most days. Like a lot of people, I stay in more than I used to. It bothered me at first bc when I have a good day, I want to get out and do something. But life is different now, so I have found other things to do that don't involve being around crowds. I remind myself that many people have it much worse. Younger people have to go to work, not knowing if the work place is taking the proper safety precautions. And so many jobs are being lost now. I pray a lot for young people now, bc they are facing so many problems that we never had to deal with. As for myself, retirement has been a big adjustment. I didn't like it at first, bc I was used to being busy and having a schedule. But I've come to realize there is a lot to be said for having no schedule. I can do what I want when I feel like it. I can read books I never had time for, watch TV all day if I feel like it, and spend time just for myself. After having worked all my life, this 
is not so bad. It can be lonely at times, and I admit that's very difficult. I've been a widow for a while now. So it's important to make connections with other people. It's a little harder now with this pandemic, but you can find a way. And you need something to be interested in. I've always loved animals, and I have 2 dogs that wouldn't have homes if I had not taken them in. Now they get lots of love and they give me a reason to get up in the morning. You can make a life for yourself if you put some effort into it. It's worth it not just for you, but for your grandson as well. You will have good days and bad days, but we all do."

175959389,"I think it might help me on a prn basis and I’m going to try it. If I heard my doc correctly, I believe she said I can use it that way. She told me this after she’d rx’d It for me for sustained use and I couldn’t tolerate it. Here’s what happened: I started with 5mg. 2x/day. The first few days (2-4 days) I felt good, more energetic and motivated. I accomplished some things I’d been putting off. Then....insomnia started and got worse. During my waking hours, I was starting to feel driven and almost compulsive. After about 9-10 days, I knew I couldn’t sustain such usage and began tapering it down and off within a week. So much for needing a built-up blood level. So what I’m thinking could work is just using it 1-2 days when I’m feeling anxious or worried, probably 5mg per dose. It was at that dose previously that I felt good. This is my working theory at this point. I know that’s a low dose, but I’m 74 yrs old and may do best on a low dose. Will let you know how it goes. 175959395,"In one sense, it sounds to me like you already know the answer to your own question, which is the same as my answer to my own ""overwhelming question"", namely, to avoid the ego-syntonic ""playing to our strengths"" and to opt instead to try to annihilate our deep internal fears. In another sense, there is a question which I was bred to ignore, namely, ""Can I truly enjoy myself?"". Are you really enjoying yourself coding? Are you really in a state of ""flow""? Or has it (secretly, deep-down) come to bore you? Are there coding risks and adventures which you have not yet explored? Do you really want to fight your inner demons, or do you just not know how to relax and have fun? I suspect that many people truly do not know how to do the latter. Having enough saved to be able to give the finger to the world would certainly help in this situation. You've got a real-life family and can't go too far off-road financially, so I hope your startup idea has real and not delusional merit. Sorry to be blunt here 
but, when one is alone in one's head it's too easy to lose perspective, by both exaggerating and trivializing one's abilities. There must certainly be many venture-capital people who've come from software development positions who would be able to perceive your merit and who would appreciate a ""sales pitch"" devoid of smoke and mirrors. Regardless of what you do, one day you will be dead."

174347280,"I would suspect many people with schizophrenia may not be completely interested, or even unable to adhere to serious topics. Idk, I really dont. That's a large guess, which I think is incorrect. But I can tell you, most of the regulars here post on Roll Call. There are very close, respected, and long-time regulars here. Schizophrenia forum doesnt get a lot of random people popping up and starting threads. So the regulars have kind of built their own community within this forum to keep up with each other on a daily basis. Also, the non-serious threads you are talking about; movies, video games, ""did you shower?"", etc, it's a way for us with schizophrenia/schizoaffective to be able to have routine in our lives, and keep busy, or just keep their routine in check, in order to maintain the most stable life possible for us."

175959441,"I've always tinkered with my meds, I'm still doing it, I will always do it. I understand you. But you have to know how to do it very slowly, and with a doctor's supervision. I know I'm crazy, I will always be crazy. My first psychosis drove me to suicide and ruined my future and how people see me. I will be on meds my entire life. When I first looked at my mountain o meds I had to take, I looked at them as if ""This is what my life has amounted to."" But that's the wrong way to look at it, I now look at it like, ""This pill is life, this pill that I take once or twice fixes me."" My med changes are simple, I decrease very slowly over months, until I start to feel differences, like psychotic feelings, or insomnia. Then I have to go back up, but it takes a very long time to do that. It's very much the long game. I once dropped a med willy-nilly and it destroyed my life--for good. Because I went off of Wellbutrin all of a sudden, all at once, because I felt it wasn't doing anything, I went off and it 
gave me multiple panic attacks a day for 5 years. TO stop the panic attacks I got on a mood stabilizer, and that gave me bipolar symptoms of rapid cycling. I wanted an ice pick to do through my eye it was so bad. Then I was forced to go on an SSRI and that's the story of my life, because I went off a med willy nilly I suffered panic attacks, which led to anhedonia, which then lead to bipolar rapid cycling, and that sent me on a _USER_ID_ for years. You've got to do it slowly, safely, and under supervision. Example: I had my Geodon at 80mgs for years. I got off moodstabilizers because I didn't think I needed them anymore. So I got off of my mood stabilizer, and I didn't have panic attacks anymore, nor did I rapid cycle. My doc said okay, lets up the Geodon to 160 for the insomnia. That didn't do it. But I added Trileptal. And that releaved my insomnia (hypomania in the back ground). So now that I have my insomnia undercontrol I can slowly go down to 120mgs on my geodon, which is a good dose, and all is well. b
e safe. It takes a long time to do it the right way."

174347343,"- Age 0-12 Undiagnosed: Pervasive Developmental Disorder - Not Otherwise Specified (PDD-NOS) and ADHD. - - Age 12-16 Undiagnosed: Avoidant Personality Disorder (AvPD). - -Age 16 (2012): ""Diagnosed"" by psychologist in ER: PDD-NOS, OCD and Psychosis - - Age 16 (2012): Diagnosed by psychiatrist and new psychologist (Previous psychologist wouldn't take anyone under 18): “Schizotypal Personality disorder” (Possible PDD-NOS) and “OCD” (Possible PDD-NOS) causing severe depression. - - Age 18 (2014): Diagnosed: Schizophrenia, PDD-NOS (The intake psych ward psychiatrist wrote it down on my second admission after the third good psychedelic trip) and Depression. - - Soon after Schizophrenia diagnosis at age 18 (2014): Substance Use Disorder and went back to original psychologist. - - Age 20 (Summer of 2016): Stumbled upon 4-AcO-DMT (A psychedelic) during drug experimentation where 3 “good trips” cured most of AvPD. - - Age 20 (Day after Christmas 2016): Still had AvPD (Psychiatrist asked me why 
I didn't want to talk to anyone yet still went outside to smoke) but once released, I took 4-AcO-DMT again and had a “Super Bad Trip”. - - Age 20 (2017): Severe depression (Went to psych ward), still dealing with AvPD but both started to fade away within that three months of opening myself up socially (When my psychiatrist changed my meds and from what I learned from the psychedelic trips) - Started to suffer from Hallucinatory Persisting Perception Disorder (HPPD) causing derealization and depersonalization (Dissociation). - - Age 21 (2017): Started to completely lift out of depression, AvPD was gone which manifested in psychosis from not understanding the life trip and psychedelic trips that I went through and moved away from isolation. - - Age 21-22 (2017-2018): Made lots of friends, amazing life but still dealing with slight psychosis, depression and OCD symptoms and then the dissociation started causing severe panic attacks that lasted 3 hours at most at a time unless I either went to sleep or took 1
-3 Ativan (Where one Ativan is how I got myself to sleep). - - Age 23 (Start of 2019): Dissociative panic attacks started fading and then used low doses of ketamine (A dissociative) to treat depression - Altered to more pleasant dissociation from ketamine. Last severe dissociative panic attack was on last low dose of ketamine (When I ran out). Didn’t need Ativan anymore. - - Age 23 (End of 2019): No symptoms of psychosis, depression, dissociation but slight OCD (Which I try to ignore). - - Age 24 (2020): ???????"

175959464,"I agree, it's very hard for those of us that live alone. I have always found ways to meet people, but right now it's not really possible. Not in person anyway. 175959470,"I don't intend to make light of what it means to be schizoid. It's just telling that one of the few places on this international, anonymous internet where I find insightful, real communication about the nature of existence happens to be a forum for a type of mental illness that forces its sufferers to address 'reality', 'society', and 'life' in ways most humans spend their entire lives actively avoiding. As though the natural bent of the human mind were to obsess over lowest-priority concerns until the last unavoidable moment. In life, I believe we all reach that point. A few will have prepared for years, having had no other choice. Most, however, will be clocked unawares and for them, it will not be pretty. * * * Ultimately, creativity and the process of abstraction is about the removal of the unnecessary, revealing the speaking core of a thing. Similarly, the journey of life is about getting rid, getting it out there. This discussion has helped me to realize that life is not only about shedding p
ossessions and hangups, but about shedding ideas and plans which we have hoarded for some nebulous future date which never comes , in order to be completely, radiantly 'empty' at the end. And the only legitimate way to shed creative ideas and plans is to execute them , earnestly, without premature judgment. To Hell with those who accuse us of causing them 'secondhand embarrassment'. Better to dance/write/paint badly than to be an uptight FAQ frowning from the sidelines."

175959488,"I'm so sorry you're going through the loneliness. Sometimes big changes like moving and starting over can seem overwhelming at the beginning, and COVID certainly doesn't help. But you're doing the right thing trying to find ways to be present and moving on with your life even during these circumstances. Is there any way to do safe socially-distanced activities at your place? As someone else mentioned, just music or singing can be enjoyed with people at a safe distance. Is a community garden or book club, cooking classes or anything like that available where you are? Or maybe people would be interested in starting those. People can read the book and meet on Zoom or in a socially-distanced large area and discuss the book. Might be quirky but still fun. Same with cooking where one can demonstrate a meal and others can watch from Zoom or a distance. It might take creativity, but that's half the fun. 175959540,"Yes conditioning varies for everyone, but it is always the result of what we are taught by parents, teachers, peers, employers...etc..which ultimately determine our reactions to certain experiences in life. And sure, no-one can have a clear idea on how others see them by subjective exploration alone... but does it really matter how others see us?. We are never going to be accurate in our objective assessment of how others see us anyway, in the same way we may not be accurate with our subjective self exploration. Cognitive bias is going to operate in both instances."

175959580,"Juice from concentrate has vitamin C, but much less than fresh juice because it has been pasteurized, which degrades some of the vitamin. Fresh citrus fruits, however, contain chemicals that work synergistically with the vitamin C to bolster its effects in the body, making it more effective, healthwise. Many of these antioxidants and flavonoids are either discarded when the fruits are made into juice, or are destroyed during processing. If you are deficient in certain vitamins, it's fine to take them in chemical (vitamin pill) form, but you should they to get as much of them from whole foods as you can. I myself am rich in vitamin O, which has yet to by synthesized artificially and therefore is best absorbed via meat injection."

175959697,"Suicidal thoughts or attempts are a horrible mental illness that has effected me for years... I am lucky to have eventually gotten the right therapy for this when it has happened. One of the biggest problems with this is other people's denial of this happening. I need everyone to know this is real and I've never lied about it or sought help for suicide for any other reasons. I would never fake this for any reason. I know it's hard on everyone. It's been very hard on me. It comes from being severely depressed with no future in sight at the time of the suicidal thoughts. LET ME STRESS THAT I AM NOT FEELING SUICIDAL THOUGHTS NOW I AM GOOD RIGHT NOW. In the past when my depression has gotten severe enough to do it I have tried a few times I have been lucky to have messed it up completely and servived. At some point finally I had the suicidal thoughts and realized this is the time to call for help. Everyone in this situation please don't be afraid to call 911 for help. I have done it a few times now. Th
at is how I got the therapy and help I needed for the suicidal thoughts and it has stopped me from the attempts. They rush to your aid right away. The 911 operator assures you they are coming to help. They don't treat you bad. They check you into emergency then transfer you right away to a behavioral unit or Psychiatric hospital and both are a huge help. They give you therapy a nice room, food and most of all the time to heal. You meat with psychiatrist and social workers every day until you get better then they help you with a plan to get back to life after enough days of therapy and medication. I have done this 4 times and every times and every time has helped me cope... Don't be afraid to get help for suicidal thoughts before you make it to the point of attempting bcuz I consider just the thoughts hurting yourself and others that love you..."

175959790,"As promised, here's my update: Just too many side effects from the EMSAM patch. Worst were insomnia, higher blood pressure, frequent indigestion (and I have reflux/EOE which was nonexistent for months before starting EMSAM), chills, and shot my anxiety through the roof. Overall, I did not feel well on the patch so have discontinued. Any trials for SSRIs/SNRIs require me to be two weeks off the patch. The amount of time needed for the drug to be eliminated from my body. That's about it. Hope you all are doing well and thanks for contributing to this thread."

175959840,"Yes, same. Since childhood. The poet Mark _PERSON_ does a good job of articulating a feeling that is hard to describe or pin down. It is more than the terms 'emptiness', 'loneliness' or 'feeling disconnected' describe, as often such feelings have a strange mix of beauty and sadness; elation and despair. A friend recently posted me an extract written by _PERSON_ on 'Living in a more light-hearted way'. He certainly paints things realistically and it is a welcome change from the usual platitudes; Although a little grim, and I think I need to find God to help me handle it, I appreciate the lack of sugar-coating. I totally agree. And while it may not fall under the category of 'neglect', the emotional damage it causes is far-reaching. I think it postpones the inevitable existential crisis for 20yrs or so. Kids grow up and leave home. That is when parents, especially the mother loses a sense of purpose and begins a journey those of us who have no kids, and who have mental health issues, have been on for 
many years. I guess the difference is, they seek solace from other 'empty nesters', socially and will re-fill the void with other people and of course grandkids. Then they die. True. And may I add 'non mainstream' to childfree. That is so great It is amazing how the 'right' person in our lives can help us so much; more than therapy or reading, or drugs. It is a gift to meet such a person in this life-time. I guess my process of self discovery (of being outside the bell curve) has happened in recent years through romantic relationships. I blamed my choices in men ( all had addiction problems and personality disorders to varying degrees) for my worn out and apathetic state of being. In learning to understand why I connected with such men, I have learned so much about my own 'weirdness' ( as compared to others). 175959879,"Hi _PERSON_. I would of course not try to make a medical diagnosis on an internet forum, and in any event I am not qualified to do anything like that. But I can tell you that I sometimes feel winded or out of breath when I am particularly anxious. One thing that helps me, sometimes, in that situation, is a breathing meditation. (Some refer to ""mindfulness meditation""). There are some apps, such as Insight Timer, that have a lot of free guided meditations. It does not require any knowledge or expertise -- you just slowly breathe, usually in through the nose, and out through the mouth, and focus on your breath. When your mind wanders to other things (which it will), try to bring your attention back to your breath. Good luck."

175959923,"I am bipolar/manic depressive, in addition to having anxiety, endocrine, gastrointestinal, and cardiac issues. I am a survivor. Six heart attacks have failed to take me, thank God. But the years-long battle to survive has taken a toll on my psyche. I am now a shut-in. Not in the sense that Covid-19 has made most of the world shut-ins, but rather a full-blown at times -- I am a Gemini and twins battle it out constantly -- extrovert who has succumbed to the introverted side of me. Always one to keep people at an emotional and psychological distance, the fact that my inner circle shrank over time is unsurprising. We all prune our trees of life during the course of our lives. But most of humanity has that one friend that is there through thick and thin. Some of us do not have that. I made poor choices in ""friends"" and ""friendships"" for the better part of two decades. The fact that I was undiagnosed and untreated during that time is not an excuse for the hedonistic lifestyle that I lived. One cannot 
and will not build lifelong (healthy!) bonds with others if they are disappointed when they wake up each morning that they are still alive. So the gap is self-inflicted. The question, ""Where is square one?"", is derived from the fact that intense therapy, finding the ride medications and levels, and family support pulled me from that fog. I put myself through and completed college. My health is the best it has been in years. I am ready to get back out into the world. To contribute. To work. To experience. But I am petrified because I do not know anybody out there in the world, anymore. I become mentally-paralyzed when I contemplate starting a job around not just new people, but people in general! I am so introverted now that I am much more of a thinker and listener than a speaker. And that has caused some miscommunication as some have felt that my quiet distance (my own personal safe place, bubble) is arrogant disinterest. So, where is square one? How does one come out of this type of isolation and re-enter 
society? And do it in a healthy fashion? Not just for me, but for others because I do not want to make them feel uncomfortable, either. Believe me, it is uncomfortable enough just for me."

174348232,"Hey, 1-8th. I have congenital bipolar-schizophrenia-like illness in my brain, as I call it, and share many similar experiences with you. You should just know that there is a whole apparatus in the brain that identifies self and other constantly. It is a whole, big thing. In us, aspects of this system, which includes all visual processing, go awry. Break. So, I woke up three or so days ago and was terrified because my brain told me I was a character in a video game, not a human. Had to ask a schizophrenia bud if it was true. She laughed. I'm like, no. For serious. She's like, bro, that' s your illness telling you that. You're good. So relieved. What you have is very likely just your unique version of this process. The question then, is, why? What is the current med lineup and doses? I do suspect you can improve this, maybe a lot. Maybe make it totally go away. Maybe. Partly. _PERSON_. But you should have hope and you are brave and a hero to me and us for coming here to share. Yay!"

175960076,"Hey there. I’m sorry you got the virus. That must have been scary. There are a lot of unknowns about coronavirus still, and I am by no means an expert, but I found a good FAQ by the Penn State Institute of Life Sciences. My understanding from it is that if you have isolated yourself for 10 days since the beginning of your symptoms and it’s been 3 full days since you’ve had fever or other symptoms that you should no longer be contagious. Also, people develop antibodies to the virus if they’ve caught it themselves that should protect them from getting it again for at least a few months (until the strain changes because it might mutate). Since you’ve been cleared to be out, even if you may be having minor symptoms still, he got the virus too and has those antibodies, so I don’t think you’re going to give it to him again. I hope this helps put you at ease. Here is the link: https://www.huck.psu.edu/institutes-and-centers/center-for-infec...."

Some kid brought head lice to school and spread it around. I cut my D's long hair(one reason kids get lice faster), washed everything in the house and the dog of course and put unwashable items in garbage bags. Plus of course, checked for lice in everyone's hair with the comb. I put the goop in our D's hair, to kill any lice. It played in my mind and days later, I got the feeling of lice in my hair. Then one night, around midnight, I cut my hair real short. LOL! You probably do not have the flu, particularly the Coronavirus. If it makes you feel better, as mentioned, see your Dr. or go to a walk-in-clinic. Other things you can do if you want to: *Get a flu shot *Wash your hands frequently *Try not to touch your nose, mouth or eyes before washing your hands, if you have been out *Check your temperature morning and evening to catch a f
ever and to make yourself feel better *Stock up on whatever you need especially: medical items like cough syrup, Tylenol, etc. possibly on Amazon, if you don't want to go out *Orange juice wouldn't hurt *Get lots of rest *Stay out of crowded areas, unless you go to work or need to purchase items. Choose times when less people go. *Ask your s/o to stay a good distance from anyone who shows symptoms or areas they know they have touched *Dress appropriately for outside, if you must go out *Cough and sneeze into your elbow and mention it to others who have forgotten *If you go out, wear gloves when opening doors, pushing a cart, etc., touching buttons on elevators, etc. * Wearing a N95 mask is helpful but a Dr. on the news said that it is not necessary unless the person already has the flu. I think that is ridiculous! People with autoimmune diseases and the elderly, are trying their best not to get sick. So anything that they can do to protect themselves should be encouraged. The hospitals are overfull, as is. Th

175960265,"Thank you for the nice comments. She may not be bipolar. As someone who is that, and I’m not a doctor but I’ve seen different disorders, for bipolar she needs racing mind, gets hooked on one wonderful idea and manics on that. Goes into buying sprees, sleep problems, then has depression, and back and forth between can’t do enough to can’t do anything. Does she have that? I’ve also seen borderline personality syndrome, my now deceased wife had that, and I’ve read a lot about it. And you said your wife had trauma. Do you know if she was sexually abused? Is she a sexually active type person? This rage thing doesn’t sound bipolar, but sounds to an amateur like borderline. I went to borderline personality syndrome on the search engine, which you may want to also, and psycom.net had a quiz which either the subject or someone close to that person could take. Here are some of the questions: 1. My relationships are very intense, unstable, and alternate between the extremes of over idealizing an
d undervaluing people who are important to me. (True or False) 2. My emotions change very quickly, and I experience intense episodes of sadness, irritability, and anxiety or panic attacks. 3. My level of anger is often inappropriate, intense, and difficult to control. 4. Now, or in the past, when upset, I have engaged in recurrent suicidal behaviors, gestures, threats, or self-injurious behavior such as cutting, burning, or hitting myself. There are more questions on psycom.net, which I found by typing in borderline personality syndrome and it was on my search in the top five listings. Those above questions seem to me as an amateur to hit real close to what your friend has. What do you think? You need the right diagnosis for them to give the right medicine. If they keep medicating for bipolar, and it’s not, the medicine won’t help. On the other hand, I’ve heard that borderline is hard to medicate. You said, “She does self medicates with marijuana consistently, and that helps most of the time, but she 
has so many co-morbid conditions - PTSD, sexual assault from the past, anxiety, agoraphobia, seizures, etc - that Marijuana isn't enough sometimes.” You also said, “We took her to an in patient program at one point. She spent a week at a facility. But for the last few years I haven't had consistent insurance coverage for mental health coverage, and we can't afford to send her to the doctors she needs all the time. Right now I have no coverage at all - not even counselor. She has prescript ions that we pay for with cash (thank god we have a friend who works at a pharmacy!) but being bipolar, she doesn't take them regularly.” There are free mental health clinics. You can look on the net search engine for “Mental Health Clinics for My Hometown” and maybe pick the one closet to you. Let us know how this is going."

175960295,"Hey _NAME_. I am diagnosed with bipolar disorder, anxiety, MDD and a few other things stemming from this lovely group. In general to your questions, I know that there is help and stuff out there for me. However, being able to find help can be difficult, access can be hard since we live in a rural area and costs can be crazy even with good insurance. I only discovered this site by accident a little while ago and that was just a happy accident when I was searching for a crisis hotline. Any help that I get is usually limited to what my providers are willing to refer me to for insurance purposes. In terms of access to help, it really depends on what you need. I can easily find a therapist, but when I say that it means that I get a list of names and its a random draw until you find the right fit. I didn't have a consistent person managing my medication until I got pregnant with my first son. That was when I met a Dr who I trusted and who has helped me for the last 3 or so years. I had been suffering for 
a lot longer before then and just didn't know what to do. Being passed around from person to person makes you give up on yourself pretty quickly. I have been having a really hard time since I got pregnant with my second son. He is about to be 9 months old and am still flirting the line between being admitted and being able to stay at home safely. This is where cost really comes into play. Now I not only have to worry about my health and staying home, but the cost (especially since covid) is crazy with a lot of options. This limits me to what I can afford and it's not much. I already spend a lot on therapy visits and Dr appointments, so the added cost of being admitted or extra sessions etc. can be crippling. Money matters more than life in the healthcare systems eyes. I think that it is even more true when talking about mental health. Sometimes Drs can see it as something that we are doing to ourselves. You can see that you have to save someone's life if they need emergency surgery or if there is something th
ere that you can physically see. When it is someone in front of you asking for help with something that they can't see it's harder. It makes it harder for me personally to ask for help. It's hard to ask someone for help with something you can't really find the words to explain, but that you know is slowly building and killing you. I got more if you need more lol. I'm happy to try to explain anything that I have said to clarify for you. If I don't respond on the thread just PM me. I am an open book about myself. My children are off limits."
