175960307,"Hi there, my name is _NAME_ and I'd like to share a bit about my experience. Keep in mind that I have never been for a prolonged psychiatric hospital stay, only just a temporary one when I crashed my car drunk a year and a half ago. I recognized immediately that the only people being released were the ones praying and pretending like they were happy. (more on that later) Being outside of the psychiatric system this whole time has enabled me to see things in a somewhat different light than those of us who have had the misfortune (or fortune, depending on how you look at it) of being told how you must think about your condition. Anyways, on to my crazy story. A little over 3 years ago I was sitting in my car smoking meth amphetamine and watching pornography when I started to hear the first voices. They sounded like voices coming from the yard next to where I was parked, so I didn't bother too much with them. As I progressively got worse, stopped conversing with people in real life, and continued to d
o drugs and watch pornography, the voices became louder and a strong delusion began to present itself. I was led to believe that there was an elite group of hackers that wanted to put me through some tests to see if I could join their hacker group. Being on drugs 24 hours of the day and sometimes staying up 5 nights in a row, for whatever reason in my warped mind at the time, I thought this was actually a good idea, cause I mean damn who doesn't want to be a part of an elite hacker group, right? In hindsight it seems incredibly silly considering I didn't know the first thing about computer security or programming, as all I have is some 4 credits from a failed computer science degree. Anyways, I went along with this delusion for several weeks, messing about with my computer and trying to follow a series of tasks, which always ended up with me confused and completely insane. At one point I was disassembling my laptop computer piece by piece looking for a rogue audio recording device attached to the motherboard, 
(which I found btw just to add to the craziness). While this delusion was going on, I wasn't even concerned with the fact that I was hearing these voices, I was convinced that they were elite hackers so they must have some way of communicating through my devices. Next thing that happened was the voices started to make it clear that they weren't happy that I wasn't able to prove to them that I had hacking skill, so I started to have anxiety over it. I started to think thoughts that they would try and kill me because I couldn't prove to them that I could hack and that they were extremely mad at me for wasting their time. Once I started to feel this fear, the voices began to prey upon it. This seems to be a common theme among others I speak to that have the same condition, they are fearful and the voices prey upon their fears. The voices started telling me things like if I couldn't show them that I could hack that they would have to clean up the situation, and dispose of me. This is when I started feeling like I 
was being stalked by a gang, weird black cars would pull up in front of my mothers house where I was staying, and people full of tattoos would routinely get out of the car, poke around, and then get back into the car and drive away at high speeds. Weird stuff. This went on for several weeks time until I had this like breaking point delusion. I somehow got it into my head that because I was 30 that maybe I was Jesus. Maybe that is why all of this seemingly mystical stuff was happening around me (voices, random objects appearing, moving, etc). This delusion drove me completely out of my mind, and I started believing that my own mother was the devil because her tongue was moving around all crazy and she started to say weird things to me like prophecies about when Jesus would come back, but not in her voice but this deep evil sounding voice. This seemed so completely out of character for her because 1- She is a chaplain, and she knows full well that the bible teaches that no one knows the second coming of Jesus b
ut the Father, so her saying these things to me seemed like she was not herself. It got to the point where I was running around my house with a knife and didn't have any clue as to what was going on. That's it for part one, writing this out is actually kind of therapeutic :P I'll be posting more parts as I go here."

175960380,"...or rather DON'T watch them! I was watching an emotional movie today that triggered a panic attack for me. 175960422,"It occurs during silent reading.Neuropsychologia, 33(11), 1433-1454. where it is is defined as the internal speech made when reading a word, thus allowing the reader to imagine the sound of the word as it is read. This is a natural process when reading and helps to reduce cognitive load, and it helps the mind to access meanings to enable it to comprehend and remember what is read.Although some people associate subvocalization with moving one's lips, the actual term refers primarily to the movement of muscles associated with speaking, not the literal moving of lips. Most subvocalization."

174348722,"hi. prozac seems to be helping -me- at the standard dose of 20mgs/daily. that's on top of my abilify. wellbutrin was OK...I had a bit more energy, mood was better, I ate a tad less...but the dose was too high for a while, i got jittery and ditched it. and... i think with the antipsychotic/tranquilizer, its a matter of hitting the 'sweet spot.' oh, and drug selection, too. im on abilify because it didn't cause the same level of EPS as the other 'atypicals' i tried. does it help negative symptoms? honestly...at low doses, I could see it helping, but at the full dosage, its more like...a less toxic/nasty antipsychotic. if the dosage is too low, personally...problems/symptoms would pop up that would overshadow lingering negative symptoms. why bother? now, excessive dosing...that can definitely zombie-fy people. happened to me...a psych wanted me on 30 abilify, then he topped it off w/ additional abilify to add in an ssri (not prozac). i basically turned into a functioning vegetable. oddly enough...no E
PS. weird, huh? back in the day, ritalin helped. Rx amphetamines kinda did, but...there was this weird feeling, being on an amphetamine and a tranquilizer, at the same time...unnerving, i'll put it that way. i have a friendly acquaintance who takes a seroquel xr at night and an adderall xr in the morning...she likes the combination, she seems to be doing better. each person is different. mirapex has been touted as helping negative symptoms. i have never taken it, so i cannot offer any personal experiences. when possible...meaningful social interaction helps me. low pressure activities, learning new things. writing. tackling projects bit by bit. on a more basic note, just keeping my space clean(ish) and cooking for myself, even hygiene (lather, rinse AND repeat) helps move me along in the right direction. oh, and b-vitamins and antioxidants. those seem to help. i don't know if its placebo, if its a direct affect, or if they just improve response to the psych Rx...but yeah, works for me."

175960459,"Mood stabilizers prevent seizures/mania. Mania and seizures can kill brain cells too along with psychosis. We only have so many of them; ""Researchers have estimated that about 85,000 neurons die every day in the cerebral cortex. That's equivalent to one every second. However, new evidence suggests that in a specific area of the human hippocampus, known as the dentate gyrus, new neurons are produced continuously into adulthood – around 1,400 a day."" So Idk what age you are: Early 20's? We are still growing brain cells! Stabilize ourselves first. My moms friend with bipolar gets so manic from alcohol that she has seizures and then she can't talk or move. People just write it off as ""She's crazy"" but I'm afraid that she's going to go down a very dark road with the damage she's doing to her cognition.. And all the depression she gets too. It all started because she always stopped her meds. _USER_ID_: The future will be wild though. Cures for everything. Injecting stem cells into certain parts of 
the brain, mixtures of chemicals to treat certain things, extremely better understanding of genetics, anti-aging.. etc.."

175960479,"_NAME_: I can't even imagine a positive household. Apparently, I passed negativism onto my now grown son because he and I can't be in the same room together. No stranger feeling than, ""I've created a monster who is out to destroy me."" You said, ""I learned positive thinking by practicing positive thinking. I was raised in a positive household."" I was 50 when I learned positive thinking from reading a column in the newspaper. It was written by a woman. It spoke to me. I've been telling people about it ever since. I look back at the mistakes I made when I was negative and in a way, I can't believe it. Which is what I'm trying to get people to avoid now. When I see others walking down that same road as I did, it really gets me. You're talking about how much medicine has helped you, I can give you some history of that. My grandmother, my mother's mother, was bipolar which is where I got it from. My mother didn't have it, it can skip a generation. So my grandmother had bipolar, she just didn't have a
ny medicine, if you can imagine, which you can't. It was in the 1930s and '40s and early 50s, and they had no medicine for emotional problems. They had a mental hospital in every state (see the movie ""One Flew Over the Coo-Coo's Nest"" with _NAME_. It had no medicine, but it had high walls. It was 100 miles from her home. So instead of being treated at her home, like we are, she was treated at the mental hospital, which had no medicine. When she would visit in people's homes, she would look through their medicine cabinet, and anytime she saw some pills she would take some of them. Maybe, one of them would work for her. They didn't. So whenever we take our medicine, yeah, take it for granted. It wasn't always like this. We were born into the right era."
175960480,"The crypto investor that was worse than what the soldiers said made me feel bad about taking care of my mom when I told him about her cancer. Things slipped my mind that hurt her feelings. he dumped the wine into her glass last night in front of me and I should have smashed the glass and bottle off the table. But I just let it happen. There's no controlling an alcoholic. I told my sister that it was like a bad trip. She told me to stop comparing life to a bad trip. She took the wine with a tramadol and then started crying saying she's a bad mother. 175960526,"I've read where if you are concerned about the side effects of a pill, you can take only 1/2 of the pill or less. That way, if there are to be any side effects, they will only be half as strong or less. If OK, you could consider taking the other 1/2 of the pill halfway through the time when you will need another one. You can keep taking 1/2 or less until you fee comfortable about the medicine, or believe that it is causing more problems that you can handle, and then perhaps get you doctor to change the medicine. I take most of my medicines at bedtime. While there is concern about side affects, there is also a good chance that the pill could help you. I've read that my attitude going into a problem plays a huge part in its outcome. That is, if going into a problem, I believe I can solve it, it greatly increases my chances of solving the problem, for I have told my mind, ""Look for ways to win."" And it will. However, if I have told my mind, I don't think I can solve this, it will look for ways to lo
se. Your mind is simply doing what you tell it to by your ""feelings"" about the problem. If your feelings about the pill are so poor that you are crying about the results before you take it, then you are anticipating, looking for, getting down on your knees, begging for failure, and it will come. Just like you ordered it. It's not just what's in the pill, it's what in your mind. This problem may work out very well, but with a bad attitude, it's the next problem that's going to get you. Give a man a fish, and you've help him for a day. Teach him how to fish, and you've helped him for a lifetime. At the top of the list of people writing in seeking help in this forum, there is an item called, ""Anxiety-Panic Resources"" which talks about the importance of being positive when trying to solve health or other problems. It's called Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) which wants you to know there is more to working on your illness than just taking a doctor's pill. If you want to improve your chances with this and ot
her problems, I think it will behoove you to slow down and read these suggestions, rather than just racing through to when it's time to take the next pill. I know with your mind swirling, it is not easy, but maybe put that on a list of things to do."

175960548,"Hey there, I went about two weeks with palpitations every day. I went to three different doctors, checked for murmurs/MVPs, and had an EKG. Everything is normal. Except for anxiety. I can only speak for myself but brains are tricky tricky. (A few months before I felt like I couldn't breathe for almost three weeks). Anxiety can cause palpitations which can, of course, cause more anxiety and more palpitations. It's a vicious cycle as I'm sure you know. Perhaps you could do some reading on ""health anxiety."" I bought a few books on it (versus reading the internet) and it has helped me a lot with how anxiety manifests physically, and offers a lot of tips and tricks. And from checking on your past posts, it seems health anxiety might interest you (e.g. ""Overcoming Health Anxiety"" book). Anyways, good luck and be well. 175960553,"The half life of thorazine is 30 hours so there's still 25% (200mg?) of chloropromazine in your system. If you tapered down by half after 24 hours, that's 520mg? So there was much more in your system before you stopped because really you were on 800mg if you were taking it every night. If I were you, I'd slowly decrease it with the help of a doctor. Apparently there's no tolerance or addiction but you never really know because everyone's different. It can cause symptoms of psychosis with withdrawal - Lack of sleep can do this even for people that don't have problems with anxiety or psychosis. Stay safe!"

174348887,"Could be the Wellbutrin (Bupropion). It's a cathinone. ""Cathinone /?kæ??no?n/ (also known as benzoylethanamine, or ?-keto-amphetamine) is a monoamine alkaloid found in the shrub Catha edulis (khat) and is chemically similar to ephedrine, cathine, methcathinone and other amphetamines. It is probably the main contributor to the stimulant effect of Catha edulis. Cathinone differs from many other amphetamines in that it has a ketone functional group. Other phenethylamines that share this structure include the stimulants methcathinone, MDPV, mephedrone and the antidepressant bupropion among others."" It is a light stimulant so it wouldn't cause as much psychosis as Vyvanse if anything. Also Abilify is a partial agonist of D2 receptors so it also increases dopamine a little. It may be why you're able to read more and stuff. I've had the effect of feeling like God controlling my thoughts and it's not pleasant. That's usually when I take an olanzepine."

Ambien has a very short half life (Shorter than zopiclone or temazepam) so it's a good med to take long term. 175960596,"This post hits hard for me. Why? I've been skinny my whole life as well. My BMI has been the same as my age every single year. It used to be 18-19 when I was 18-19. I remember my old psychologist saying ""I'd hate for you to be pushing 200 pounds"". Well the day has come. It's like a form of body dysmorphic disorder. I didn't like being too skinny either because I remember a few years ago, I took off my shirt to go in the pool and my sister said ""Ew you're so skinny"". I didn't realize. I bought Berberine (A replacement for metformin) to test it out. No doctor will take me seriously because I'm a ""Normal weight"" but I'll end up overweight with diabetes even if I

175960616,"Hello -- so sorry to hear what you are going through. Of course, you feel worried, upset, frustrated and want to help. Your dual-diagnosis boyfriend needs to obtain professional help to achieve stability before he can fully benefit from a peer-led program, such as AA. His immediate needs are an appointment with a psychiatrist, who most likely will prescribe medication, addiction counseling and therapeutic support/counseling to learn how to make lifestyle changes. When a person has depression and addiction, it is sometimes called dual-diagnosis. People with depression find it hard to reach out for help sometimes. People with addiction are reluctant to give up their addictions. One thing you can do for him is research the mental health centers in your community. You should be able to find this information on your local government website under ""human services"" or similar. Call or email the agency in charge of mental health (they will also handle addiction). They will either provide direct services 
(therapy, support, diagnosis, medication) or refer you. Outpatient day programs are excellent. He might attend a program like that, for example, for several weeks. Once you find and write down or print this information, you can ask him if he would like you to be with him while he calls one of these agencies for help. Don't nag him about it. Just present him with the option. But just once. If he doesn't take you up on it, I suggest you leave him and get on with your life. Therapy will help you understand why you chose him and why you remained with him. There are also 12 step groups (free) that help men and women understand life with an addict and healthy boundaries. Dedicate yourself to your own recovery and self-care. Focus on your favorite interests, reconnect with your friends and family and think about your values and goals. All that may have taken a back seat while you were concerned about this man and his problems. His addictions did not and will not allow him to give you the same consideration you give 
him. Those addictions are his master. Until this man enters recovery and treatment for BOTH alcoholism/gambling AND depression, he will be an anchor that drags your life down. Plenty of people with these problems do reach out for help. Hopefully, he will call the numbers you give him. But if he does not, remember: a man who says he loves his daughter but doesn't get the help he needs loves his addictions more than his daughter. A man who says he loves his daughter but isn't around for her doen't appreciate that love is a verb. A man who isn't good to his daughter is no good to his girlfriend or wife. Some things in life are simple and it doesn't get anymore basic than that. This man is okay with putting you through hell. That's on him but if you let him put you through hell, that's on you. Everyday, you are responsible for your own happiness, your own wellbeing, and if you have children, theirs. But that's it. So, deep inside, you know what to do. You focus on you and you focus on your family. You focus on pe
ople who uplift you and cherish you. You focus on your own needs - exercise, eating right, having fun, working, connecting with people who are good for you and getting support. You have given him plenty of chances. Give him just one more -- the chance to get real help from a professional. Then move on. P.S. If he ever mentions suicide again, and you believe he has a plan, do not hesitate to call 9-1-1 if he is with you and refuses to go to an ER. Don't put yourself through any misery over it, just do it. In some cases, a police officer will accompany him to the ER or mental health ER. This doesn't mean he is in trouble, that's just what they do."

175960631,"Hi friend and welcome back! Although I am sorry to hear that it is due to increase anxiety currently for you. :/ One of my most powerful/helpful tools is the repetition of Positive Mantras. It does take practice and some time for the reassuring phrases to help calm us down, and to start to change our thinking process... ...but change things it will! Our brains and its chemistry actually believe the positive words we speak and the anxiety is derailed or even prevented by this important practice. If negative thinking increases anxiety (and we know it does!) then positive thinking decreases it. We have a link in the Resources on this...or you can simply take your worries/fears, and create your own reassurances to speak to them. Best with getting your management where you need it to be again! Keep posting so we can keep you encouraged. S.C."

175960634,"Have you let your doc know what is going on? Maybe lexapro isn't right for you. I am sorry you are feeling nausea everyday. I got nausea taking chantix. I quit taking it. It just kept getting worse. I can imagine you would be at your wits end with this situation. I would call the prescribing doctor's office. Let us know what happens., Hugs, _NAME_... Do some breathing exercises during the panic attacks. Breathe in through the nose and out through the mouth. While breathing out through the mouth, purse your lips and control that breath. Make the out breath be a little longer than the in breath. This is called smelling the roses and blowing out the candles. It really does help get back control."

175960664,"I think the best way is to be mindful like any other stressor. Try to have a more positive outlook on them. For me, voices didn't bother me - I tried to find meaning in them just to occupy myself. With delusions, you need to trust yourself and realize that YOU aren't your THOUGHTS. You're much more. Make a time during the day - Every day, to challenge the delusions.. But that's less important than talking to a therapist or someone close to you about them so you have a different perspective (99%, people don't believe in the delusion and will reassure you. The delusion will come back within a few seconds but positive reinforcement can help to train your brain to realize when certain thoughts aren't real). Until then, keep trying different antipsychotics to find one that works. Everyone reacts differently to every med because we all have different brains and neurochemistry."

174349040,"I'm not schizophrenic but I have some psychotic symptoms. I often have to remind myself that I can't know what people are thinking / feeling, and how they are reacting to me, because my brain likes to automatically go there."
175960685,"These are interesting questions, or perhaps difficult to frame a response that provides clear information e.g. would be clear enough that if you met her you would have an ""aha moment"" sufficient to say ""This is the person described"". In so far as a long-term personality I would say it is somewhere between angry and significant internal insecurity and any sense of not having ""control"" will push her to anger or coldness. She is very ""black and white"", I think the actual term is dichotomous. It would be entirely accurate to say she struggles to see the complexity in people and situations and is unable to recognize that things are often not either perfect or horrible, but are something in between. Like a phrase casually used and not cause for alarm that someone took exception to something. She is reserved to withdrawn in social settings. She will reluctantly attend such an event but never without a drink or two or three first. Places like a mall or large grocery stores, places with crowds she a
voids to any extent possible. I know that sounds bleak but in small groups of 4 to 6, say perhaps neighbors, at what we call ""Bloody _NAME_ Sunday"" which is small group that meets at the HOA early on Sunday morning during the summer she is engaged and talkative, even when we used to have small ""poker games"". This stopped one evening when she became angry and never restarted. So far as enjoying doing things this is his or miss. She did enjoy riding on the back of the _NAME_- until she didn't. I own a small cattle operation as sort of a hobby ranch with a partner she at one time was very enthusiastic about it, until she wasn't. She is pretty much a stay at home person-- who enjoys drinking. In ""normal"" times she likes to have ""movie night"" or she wants me to watch ""crime shows"" on T.V. (like 48 hours or review of actual cases). Friends? None that she cares to see on a routine basis. She does have a friend she has known since childhood, whom she will regularly turn, but this is usually when she is angr
y. They do not meet but a few times a year, despite her living less than two miles away. Again unless she is particularly angry with me. She is not what I would call ""bubbly"" but when things are good she is happy, affectionate and even wanting to discuss future plans. I have learned however this is transient. For example, once we planned a ski trip about 4 months out. I paid the advance rental, we purchased replacement ski togs. about three weeks out she got mad over something and announced the following day she was not going. After a week of working to resolve this- and failing, I canceled the trip in order to get a least a portion of the rental back. Later it was, ""why did you cancel, you must not actually want to go with me."" This has happened a couple of times to the point now, if a trip is planned, I let her make the reservation and the deposit. She does love going to the beach or traveling to places like Jamaica or Mexico and while there she is a remarkably happy person. On a road trip, she is not p
articularly talkative and truly does not observe things in passing cars or along the roadway generally. Of course, if it was truly remarkable she would comment. I will say she is perhaps an awful ""back seat driver"". She talks some but this is episodic. They only did an EKG and provided me an in-haler. That was the first time having an in-haler. Through out the year that thing helped me a lot, along with fresh air and very supportive co-workers. One thing to help ease my mind is to listen to music. I learned from another person to focus on just one instrument in a song. JUST ONE INSTRUMENT. It helps tremendously when I feel stressed as heck. During the past 1.5 years, I've been dealing with vertigo like symptoms and heart palpitations. My primary doc referred me to a cardiologist. Had a 24hour monitor hooked to me. Nothing showed up. n Ear, Neck and Throat disorders. I'm currently going to appointments with them for balancing and more. Last Friday, the same exact episode of anxiety attack happened again. Everything seemed normal. I did use an oxygen tank for the first time. It helped my breathing very well. The chest pain lasted for about 24 hours. I work at a grocery store Full Time having to wear a mask. That thing is detrimental to my health. I have been complaining for months about it. I know that the mask wearing was a key component to this attack. So now I have a note for work to minimize my mask wearing. That seems to help normalize my breathing a tiny bit. I don't know your situation with mask wearing, but I suggest to stay away from it as much as you can! Besides stress, are you an overly-emotional person? Do you see a therapist to talk to? Have you 
been tested for anything mentally? Talking to a therapist is a wonderful way to stay a bit more less stressed. They are very resourceful people who can help in ways to cope with certain situations. 175960751,"Let me share a European view. (Sorry to spoiler the interesting conspiracy theories with boring science). Here in Europe we have some countries that did ran out of hospital capacity. There are people arriving at the hospital, cannot get proper treatment and die - maybe sitting in a chair while they would need oxygen or a respiratory treatment. Doctors actually do disconnect 80 year old people from the respiratory device to give it to a 50 year old person, the 80 year old persons die then. (Triage). The army is searching dead people and they find a lot in the streets. Other European countries still have sufficient capacities, there far less people die. Statistics say the difference is 10% die in the countries who are short in hospital capacity and 1% in countries with sufficient capacity (however, this statistics has a bias because some countries test less than others). Scientists (well known ones, by a state order) here simulated a free outbreak and came to the result that roughly 50% (forgot the n
umber) of the population would become sick, mainly in June/July, and then the outbreak would stop because the majority would be immune. However, the scientist estimated hundrets of thoudands of deaths by this approach (in a 80 mil. people county). So in Europe the strategy is, to slow down the outbreak to an extend that the health system can cope with (more or less). Drawback: The countermeasures would have to last until 2021. The slower, the longer ... Then 70% of the population would have had the sickness, be immune (or dead), and then the immunity of the population would be sufficient, and the sickness stops on its own. I hope that a vaxine or a medical treatment will appear soon, because the economy cannot wait until 2021. I see three options: a) Don't slow down. Population is immune in harvest. On a worldwide scale millions will die. b) Slow down. Far! less people will die (remember 10% vs 1% above). But it lasts a looong time. c) Slow down until vaxine/medication has been released. Then spread it and re
lease the counter measures. (Or in theory d) vastly extend the clinical capacities and then let the outbreak run freely. But that's not realistic. Machines and new staff need time to be prepared.) I like c) most and wonder that there are billions and billions available for economic help, but I don't hear from billions and billions for vaxine/medication research ? Incl. money to speed up the regulation authorities. My grand-grand-father died by the spanish flue by the way in 1918. Such events aren't so special maybe ..."

175960771,"I started doing this thing I saw on reddit, it's a community called the X effect, basically you make a 7x7 (50 days) grid on paper and cross off each day with an X for whatever your desired habit you're trying to develop is. So I made a couple, one for no candy, one for no caffeine, one for reading at least an hour a day, and one for using duolingo. It seems very motivating having something physical to look at and check off as the days go by. After I (hopefully) finish with these I'll do more x effect grids for other habits I want to develop"

175960783,"Hi GS and welcome! I am sorry to hear of your anxiety and pain/symptom issues that are challenging you at the moment. I can relate to this very much being a fellow health anxiety sufferer. Depending on were you live and how early your appointment was set for, you may very well have already be finished with your consultation. If that is the case how did it go? If you've yet to go, then I echo _NAME_ advice of practicing deep slow breathing, as well as repeating reassuring and positive mantras to yourself as you wait to be seen. The Resources that she mentioned will be great to look into for more long term help in managing your anxiety and worrying about health related matters. We have a few sites there that help specifically with Health Anxiety that you can get started with. If you find you need more help in this area, then looking into getting a therapy consult/referral would be the next step to take. As far as your question regarding what SSRi's/A/D's are safe during pregnancy, asking your OBGYN w
ould be best. We have had several mommies here who had healthy deliveries/babies while taking their Rx's, but everyone is different with differing needs, so your obstetrician will tell you what the best plan would be. Post with us anytime for support and understanding. We care and are here to listen. Hoping you got some good answers from your doctor today. Update us if you like! _PERSON_ Cat"

175960784,"Greetings folks, a small and surreal update: At 4am yesterday, my wife called me and said that she had rented a room downtown...asked me to pick her up...so I drove over, picked her up and thereafter, we went to McDonald's for breakfast...she said she was very sorry for leaving... Then, I drove us back home to sleep... At about 7.30am, she woke me up and said that she felt very sick and needed to go to IMH...surprise surprise! So, groggily, I woke up, drove us there. Went to A&E. She was crying badly one moment, and then singing and laughing the next. And then we saw the doctor. I passed my letter to the doctor and my wife described some details about why she left and how she felt about stuff...The doctor arranged for a thorough review of her condition in June and in the meantime, prescribed a double dosage of Valproate, as well as,...hold it there.... I don't know the name of the 2nd med cos' I can't check it! Cos...when we went back home to sleep again and I woke up at 12+pm( I start work late an
d end work late), heavens, she was gone, some clothes were gone and the meds were gone... So...it's super surreal...she actually came back, she actually went to IMH, she actually was prescribed medicine, the medicine is with her, BUT she's not with me... The last I heard from her before falling asleep, she was calling to cancel the rented room in the apartment...maybe she returned cos' she couldn't cancel...I don't know what the heck is happening either...she has not responded to my three or four messages either... Guess I'm sleeping alone tonight again... Super surreal day. It's like Thanks God, but huh? Guess time will reveal His plan..."

175960799,"Today I will be writing about support. I want start off by saying, everyone is going through something. No one can understand what that person is going through. They can only support them. I have a lot of people complaining to me about their life. As I have said before it has drained me. But I always think to my self at least you have support. I call it back up. Some people don't have that at all. They go my bestfriend, my parents, my significant other or my kids don't get me. I have no idea what goes on in these relationships but I'm pretty sure it's not bad. I say that because they call these people. Ask them for advice and support and say they love them. I think how people like me don't even have that. I don't have a good relationship with anyone right now. I feel like people only became close to me cause I make them feel better about their problems. But that's not love or support, that's a leech. So, what I'm trying to say is I could never know anyone situation or their pain. But could you imag
ine going through all this hurt and not having anyone their for you. No one to talk or cry to. Some people like me have to wake up everyday and say what's the point. I understand venting but sometimes people call me and say I can't make it I give up on life. Then say so and so took them out. Their kids said I love you. Someone they claim, they hate. Or that person doesn't love them. Gives them money, let's them live with them or found them a job. I think to my self you have support. Well, if you want to end it all. I should have been did it lol. But seriously it drains all of who you are to hear people complain about having a little bad day. I have them everyday lol. People should focus on the good things. Be thankful that you have someone their for you. Especially, if they know your problems and still support you. That's what I try to do, focus on the good. And I don't even have a support system. I often ask my self what keeps you going lol. Some people like me wish they could come across some unconditional 
love. Just saying your life couldn't suck as much as mines. And I'm laughing. Just saying that's why my phone is off lol"

I take the attitude that you can either act or be acted upon so proactive engagement actually prevents outside interference."
175960811,"Many people who have struggled with mental illness elect to seek treatment for their illness. And some of them in America must go on state disability while they're recovering, as they can't work full time at a job because of their issues. But some of them are able to overcome their illness and get off being on disability, and are able to work full time once again. However, some of them are unable to do so and must stay on disability for the rest of their lives. Having to be on state disability for the rest of your life, to me, is not complete successful psychiatric treatment. To me, it's partial success. But at the same time, I'm glad that many individuals are able to make progress in fighting their illness, even if they never fully recover and never are able to work full time once again. They are able to live happy, productive lives in spite of it."

175960814,"I am a very private, proud and positive person but I would like to lay it all out there because this is probably the only time I would and this is hopefully a place where someone can relate and offer some advice on how to move forward so please be patient with me. Thank you for taking the time to hear me out. After a visit to the hospital to collect my meds recently (I am currently living and working in Thailand) the nurse was Brilliant at obtaining my medical history. With my medical background as a Paramedic in Johannesburg South Africa (which I have to thank for my PTSD) and my lifetime history with my mental illness her questions we all relevant and I realised that what I considered flaws actually could explain so much. I suffer from PTSD - under control and manageable (some situations. loud noices, bangs, someone giving me a fright, and confrontation are still all triggers but as I said controlled and manageable) OCD - manageable and I can control myself but frustration can often lead to tears 
once I am put of the situation. Dyslexia - an every day battle especially as I am an English teacher. But I have a medical license and PPL aviation license so only mild insecurity there. RLS - shaking or movement of my lower limbs especially my feet awake for asleep. Chronic headaches - this has been a life time struggle and the everyday norm besides the odd migraine (in bed under the covers) once every 4 to 6 months. Bipolar - perfectly managed with meds and self control Anxiety - permanent struggle leaving me wired and tired emotionally drained (not conducive for all relationships) Tic - permanently flicking or picking at my thumb nails especially when I'm trying to concentrate (this is not noticeable unless I am really anxious. HSP - this is my biggest problem and I can not seem to manage it. Substance abuse - alcohol use to a be an escape but mostly ended up with an episode. I smoke marijuana once a day before bed (I like it but don't need it) and then there is the all favorite benzodiazepine and ritalin 
not to mention a past with Cat addiction. My substance abuse is not an addiction (besides the CAT for 6 months) but if I have it I will take more than prescribe to get a rush or high. If my month quota is up the I simply wait for the next month. I don't go looking for it but if i have it i abuse it so yes it is a problem. Lastly, hear is the kicker. An undiagnosed mystery with no answers or treatment that has worked - I lactate. For the last 16 years I have had milk in my breast ready to feed a baby at a drop of a hat. Never had any children! Just milk all day long. Very embarrassing. I am currently on bipolar and Anxiety meds. No benzodiazepine (because I enjoy those way to much) So as you can see above I have a lot to deal with but am managing rather well according to my lifes history. But that is exactly my point, I am in a great space. Yes I am still haunted and tested every day but I feel now is the time to look inward and begin to actually start healing instead of coping. A few months ago some people sa
y (I found myself) but basically I just realised that I am to blame. My actions. My consequences. My decisions clear minded or during an episode. The pain is mine. I owned it. All of it. No blame just me. By doing this I feel like I have given control back to myself. I can finally face the truth and now I can do something about it! I have been coping for so long, my question is how do I move forward. What do I work on first and how do I do this work. I am unable to seek counseling as the language barrier and culture in Thailand is to great and has proved to be ineffective. I can not work on my PTSD trauma alone. Does anyone have absolutely any advice."
175960815,"Life is worth living even after something devastating like this, even if you go on alone. Some practical steps to take: Believe it or not, the right music can significantly help whether it's listening, playing, or singing, you can find consolation in music. Express your feelings. If your girlfriend is unable to communicate with you, express your feelings here on this forum. We'll listen. Or with a therapist/counselor or find someone to talk to, a relative, an old friend. If you're religious, Psalms 94:19 says ""When anxieties overwhelmed me, you comforted and soothed me"" meaning that when we have nobody else to talk to, who comforted us? Who soothed us? God himself DOES take an interest in you. Talk about it with Him, every feeling, every hurt, every thought. Meditate on things that are comforting. If you like to read, read things that make you smile whether it's silly memes or favorite books, articles on what you're going through, things that you take an interest in. Stay busy if it's working wit
h your hands or doing things you enjoy whether it's exercising, walking, house projects, playing with pets, your secular work. Whatever you can do to stay calm during this difficult time. I hope you can find some peace and comfort."

175960872,"Hello and welcome! I am sorry for the late reply. Kids just started school again yesterday, so I was not on the forum. Your concerns are certainly valid, so do not add to your already existing burden by thinking they are frivolous or appear to be vain/bragging. All the things you mention are things all of us have felt at one point or another, and are especially challenging for someone your age. Our thoughts can easily become negative when we are stressed, when we experience a rejection, or when someone carelessly makes a comment that hurts us. When we have negative dialogue in our heads, it increases our anxiety...and the anxiety can lead to more negative thoughts/feelings perpetuating a vicious cycle. What have you tried thus far to get relief from your anxiety? If you are just starting to seek answers, I suggest looking into our Resources at the top of the main forum page here for great self help material. I would start with the stress relieving exercises and meditations to help bring down your o
verall anxiety levels. We also have some sights specifically for social anxiety issues, as well as a link explaining how to use positive mantras to combat negative thinking. If you really want to make some effective changes, singing up for Moodgym (an online therapy self help program) is a great step! If you find you need more help than self help provides, then talking to your doctor about your treatment options would be the next step. Medication and or therapy are great tools to discuss and learn about . Keep posting with us as well if you find it helpful. We care, understand and support is key! Looking forward to getting to know you better, _PERSON_ Cat"
175960873,"I resonate with your last sentence. ""I seem happy but I don't know if I am."" One of the ways that I cope with my lot in life is learning. Learning helps me frame my existence, which gives me some relief. A german philosopher once wrote that what matters is not experiencing happiness, but deserving it. Learning that turn of phrase, and a bit others help me frame my situation. I think one of the best things for me was to take courses on great literature so that I can hopefully find a narrative that I connect with. And I one speaks to me, then I go to the library and borrow it, and dive deeper. This was one of the best courses by one of the best professors. Each lecture goes over one book, and each lecture is only 30 minutes. This professor knows how to tell a story too. He's got passion for what he's teaching. If you like this one, which is one of his best, there are many more by him. These courses go on sale many times a year, so I keep a close watch and buy them. However! Most good libraries are 
filled with them too! My library has 2 bookshelves of these courses to listen too. Their dope. If you like this one I can recommend more Life Lessons from the Great Books | The Great Courses Plus"

175960890,"Laid down to rest yesterday, twisted to look at the clock, reducing the blood flow to my chest, and got a little chest pain. Cut on the heating pad that is always plugged in and on my bed. The heating pad on my chest expands the blood vessels and the heart doesn't have to work as hard. After 15 minutes I was curious whether the heating pad had stopped the chest pain momentarily or whether it was going to still be stopped when I got up out of bed. The chest pain was not there. When you have chest pain during the day, can you sit or lie down and apply a heating pad? Probably with a pillow or two to keep your chest up. Your heart may be just telling you it's getting tired and it needs a rest. Does your chest pain happen when you've over-exercised? If I'm going to be doing the laundry that day, I don't take my 30-minute walk. I've learned the hard way, that's too much exercise for my chest. How did you deal with your chest pain when you worked? The doctors in your city are probably as well-equipped as

175960898,"Her idea of the title is that loving the child and providing nurtance isn't enough (except that would be true with most kids in the system as well as any kid with mental health issues). The ""goal"" is creating attachment (she seems forceful about it though) - and addressing the often underlying cold homicidal rage within them - and addressing the behavioral issues that put them or others at risk (possible examples: stealing, destroying property, lighting things on fire, sexually assaulting others, trying to harm and/or kill people and/or animals, blackmail and other forms of intimidation, lack of emotional regulation, substance misuse and other high risk behaviors). I agree with your line of thinking As far she's concerned, a lot of ""enough"" seems to be about gaining control and dominance over them because they're 'bad' and need to be made 'good' ...... you might be starting to see some of the basis of my ongoing complaints around moralizing. ^ this approach isn't exactly effective for adult add
icts or people in corrections either, but it's commonly utilized in those areas too. I was searching for a free download of her book until I read through her blog and was too disgusted to search further. Though I might still read it in the future when I'm less emotionally reactive. The other part of the mind frame is about forcing bonding via ""hold"" techniques. ^ I won't even start on how invasive, disrespectful and retraumatizating that could be. She and other caregivers act like the kids are the ""bad guys"" and need to be fixed by the ""good guys"" = the caregivers. ^ I have enough experience to know that when adults start portraying children as more adept and powerful beings than them (as I saw some people imply in related discussion threads which others validated) it means they're plenty ###$ up too and just don't have the insight to recognize it. I read one excerpt, and from the way the 6 year old was described, you'd think the child was a criminal mastermind with a fully developed adult-functioning b
rain - or the psychiatrist was retarded - or that the writer was showing their own severe emotional immaturity and scapegoating the 6 year old. Funny what the vast majority prefer to believe rather than looking at their own behavior Complaining how ""manipulative"" the kids are is a terrible connotation to have connected with the youth because then almost everything they do or need they have isn't taken seriously - they're just ""manipulating"" All humans manipulate to meet their needs (behaviorism) - some just do it against the ""rules"" of acceptable behavior. Other trains of thought are more trauma informed - like where one addresses ""manipulation"" as trying to meet a need but there's either a lack of skill or a it's result of power imbalances or other forms of disempowerment. ^ and that all behaviors have a reason. ^ and that acting out is when people don't have the skills to deal with a stressful situation effectively. Lack of skills can be difficulties with emotional regulation, problem solving and ot
her forms of reasoning, changing tasks, social interaction skills, communication skills (like naming feelings or describing what's wrong or what they need), low frustration tolerance, the fact that a lot of kids with behavioral issues tend to have a naturally low-irritable mood baseline, etc. ^ and your perception of their behavior influences how you treat the kid which influences how they respond (Dr. _NAME_). Kids act out not only as a result of a variety of a lack of skills but a trauma emotional baseline is usually 6, 7, 8/10 (as opposed to 2, 3, 4/10), so they go over the edge a lot quicker. I agree with trauma-informed perspectives: with any behavioral problems in youth, instead of control battles and power struggles, one should focus on giving dignity, respect and offering as much control and choice / self-determination as possible, etc. < the more out of control they feel, the more legitimately dangerous they are (and rightfully so). The more comfortable and in control of themselves and their environm
ent they feel, the more they're able to come up with their own answers to their problems (positive psychology). My issue is that I can become ridiculously overly protective with any human which is also very unhealthy, so staying out of the way can sometimes be difficult for me and something I need to work on. I seem to have derailed again"

175960910,"_PERSON_ - I think the feedback you've received so far from MrALEX and art_PERSON_ are both basis are both valid, but the title of your post is a question (regardless of no question mark, smile I'm not a grammar Nazi, lol). First of all, you essentially asked a yes or no opinion question that's really has no right answer. At the end of the day, _PERSON_, only you can decide if it's worth trying or not. But without knowing any details about the nature of your severe depression, your age, some more things about who you are, how you see yourself, some of your background, your experiences in life, and current general health status outside of your depression and/or your living situation; no responsible person is going to give you a black and white, definitive answer one way or another, but I'll give it a try. Taking into account what I've just said, I think you should assess for yourself if if you think it might be helpful. Take a survey of yourself as if you had never met you before as any new Doctor, 
Therapist, or new acquaintance might. Do this before wasting any excessive time on the matter. Form an opinion about who you have been and who you are today. Just not some things down that you think might be a pro or con to consider it like any other medication or substance. CBD is a refined derivative, used by many for both medicinal and recreational reasons. Nothing is for everyone and never let anyone tell you that it's good for you or bad for you beautbecause they really don't know, including friends, doctors, or therapists. You are by far and away the best judge of that. It is what it is and you are taking initiative by posting and responsibility for yourself by asking questions to educate yourself. For this, you can congratulate yourself for and continue to ask questions of therapeutic support forums like Inspire, or friends or family you might be comfortable talking with about it more. I'll venture to say that because you a have what you describe as severe depression, that you want feedback as to wheth
er anyone thinks it might help. The answers will vary widely on the subject, and a CBD is not quite the same as other forms of perhaps more naturalistic ways of dealing with pain, anxiety, or depression. Personally, I'm not a fan. I've tried it for various reasons and decided it's just really not my thing. That's just me. My opinion however should not really sway you one way or another. It's just what I think, not what I could possibly know for someone else. That all said, I'm 48 as you could easily determine from my profile, no stranger to depression and much prefer smoking a little bit of the most mild marijuana that I can acquire in small quantities to roll a joint with once in a while and watching a movie or reading that I find to be a calming state and takes a little bit of life's edge off every 3 or 4 weeks or sometimes months or years. Could I recommend that to you? Of course not. That's simply what has been my experience. Really nothing more and nothing less. Call it a child of 70s thing, but the effe
cts of THC nor any stigmas attached to it have never been a big deal to me. My 78 year old mother tried CBD for both pain anxiety, and it wasn't her thing either, she lived through the 60s and 70s, and decided CBD wasn't for her either, no big deal. Keep in mind, CBD and plain old pot or marajuana are a little different from each other and not the same thing, nor is what their generally used for, why and how, and by who for whatever purpose. They are not interchangeable, but they can both have overlapping positive and negative effects, where in my experience, some have told me that a minor negative effect of either one is that it makes them a little paranoid sometimes for whatever reason, but again, that's them, not me. Generally, speaking though, it's unlikely tryinf either would kill you or make you some sort of addict. That's why you should approach it all from the standpoint of getting to know yourself as you might as someone else and make an educated decision. I hope this was helpful and that you keep in
teracting and taking initiative for yourself. You got this _PERSON_!"

175960929,"Luvs, SC is right about how cysts can happen. There was a young woman that worked at our office that had cysts. Hers would come up over night, no warning. She had plenty of testing & they were benign. What her dr did tell her was to avoid all caffeine & chocolates. When she did this, yes they would still reappear, but it slowed down the progression a great deal. If you are considering going to ER over the weekend, keep in mind ER's are not there to diagnose & treat unless it's a true life threatening situation. I am not saying not to go, but be prepared for the usual anxiety speech & told to follow up with your own dr."

175961079,"That’s really awesome to hear! The main thing to do is keep rotating through a variety of foods. This way you don’t get tired of particular foods in your diet, so you always want to finish your snacks and meals if it’s something you haven’t had in a while. Some people even say that 3 big meals a day isn’t as healthy as having smaller meals (4-5 recommended daily) more frequently/snacks, so don’t stress about only having 2 meals. As long as you’re fueling your body between your meals, that’s all that matters. You’ll need to work towards 3 daily meals, but that won’t happen on day #1. I’m really glad you’re happy about your accomplishment, it’ll make your mood and health a lot better when you’re eating more to fuel your body. It’s so encouraging to hear what a breakthrough you’ve had with this. Thanks for sharing xx"

175961087,"Labelle: You said you were diagnosed with ""Major Depression with Panic Disorder"" and prescribed Klonopin which net says is for seizures and ""also used to treat panic disorder (including agoraphobia) in adults."" You also have Ativan tranquilizer for short term problems. Don't you need an anti-depressant if you have major depression? How close are you to a mental health clinic? You need to get under the care of a psychiatrist. verywellmind.com says about major depression and panic disorder: ""Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) for Depression and Panic Disorder"" ""Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is one form of psychotherapy that has also been found to be an effective form of treatment for depression and panic disorder. ""CBT works by altering one’s negative thoughts and behaviors to reduce depressive and anxious symptoms and to improve overall functioning. A combination of CBT and medication is the typical treatment option choice for panic disorder and depression."" ""It is possible to have 
panic disorder and a co-morbid diagnosis of clinical depression; these treatment options can address both conditions."" It really helps you to identify the negative thinking patterns that are present in your internal dialogue and how to turn them around. 175961136,"I had been anxiety free for 3 weeks, which was a record. Now I know it was naïve of me to think that I'd conquered panic disorder because as everybody says 'it can't be cured but it can be managed' but I really was starting to feel like my old anxiety free self again- I was even at the point where I stopped dreading bed time and could actually sleep. I'd been eating and sleeping well and couldn't have been in a happier place especially as I was finally feeling like me again and I was meeting a friend of mine yesterday. We were deep in the middle of a conversation (about an old school friend) when the panic hit me like a bolt of lightening, I felt the familiar intense fear flooding over my body and struggled to breath, it felt all over the place, my ears started to ring and my palms sweated. One voice was screaming at me to tell my friend I was about to die and the other was saying just stay in the conversation else she's literally going to think you are a lunatic. I tried to listen to my therapist
s techniques but it happened so fast and I felt like I'd forgot how to do my breathing excercises all together. In the end I managed to keep it from her and felt fine after, but it came over me for no reason. I slept badly that night with sleep starts, tremors and nightmares for the first time in 3 weeks. I know most people say don't dwell on why you get panic and reasons but I just feel very disheartened as I was starting to really make progress and for no reason at all it's just flooded back. I'm sad that I thought that I was starting to gain control and feel relaxed; hearing one good voice in my head and no battles with myself. It seems there are no patterns, trends or algorythms as to why, where or how my panic happen, it just came as a big fat reminder that it can't be controlled Everybody suffers from some kind of anxiety but not many people understand that I get it for no reason and the few people I tell try to understand by linking it to their anxiety which is most probably just worrying and then thin
k i'm just a worrier; I know this because this was how I used to view anxiety- I could never imagine people were plagued with such fear and panic especially for no reason- which is why I write to you guys because as caring as people around me are, you understand more. When panic comes over me it feels almost like I've fallen into the upside down in The stranger things and life is the scariest thing in the world. Can I control it or does it control me?"

175961141,"Anxiety is hard...I find consistency helps so if every Monday I goto the grocery store and every Wednesday I do X I get less worked up about it, but I still get a certain amount of anxiety. I have notecards that have encouraging thoughts like I may be experiencing anxiety but I can do this anyway. Mostly I have those in my car in case I have issues driving. Basically I push through the anxiety and feel better on the other end. If you don’t do the thing you feel worse all around and it magnifies your anxiety. As far as the depression it sounds like your taking the right steps, you’ve just gotta keep doing fun things regularly."

175961148,"Abstract> Identifying state-sensitive measures of perceptual and cognitive processes implicated in psychosis may allow for objective, earlier, and better monitoring of changes in mental status that are predictive of an impending psychotic episode, relative to traditional self-report-based clinical measures. To determine whether a measure of visual perception that has demonstrated sensitivity to the clinical state of schizophrenia in multiple prior studies is sensitive to features of the at-risk mental state, we examined differences between young people identified as being at clinical high risk for psychosis (CHR; n = 37) and non-psychiatric matched controls ( n = 29) on the Mooney Faces Test (MFT). On each trial of the MFT, participants report whether they perceive a face in a degraded face image. The CHR group reported perceiving a greater number of faces in both upright and inverted MFT stimuli. Consistent with prior work, males reported more faces on the MFT than females in both conditions. Howe
ver, the finding of greater reported face perception among CHR subjects was robustly observed in the female CHR group relative to the female control group. Among male CHR participants, greater reported face perception was related to increased perceptual abnormalities. These preliminary results are consistent with a small but growing literature suggesting that heightened perceptual sensitivity may characterize individuals at increased clinical risk for psychosis. Further studies are needed to determine the contributions of specific perceptual, cognitive, and motivational mechanisms to the findings. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41537-021-00156-1?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+npjschz%2Frss%2Fcurrent+(npj+Schizophrenia)"

175961196,"Hello there, I have been exactly where you are, and I ended up leaving school because of it. It just became too much for my body to cope with such high stressors all the time. It’s something not many people can understand because it’s not something. I ever wish upon anyone. Honestly, I take it one day at a time. And one thing at a time now, because the alternative is flare ups, pain, and tears, all we can do is take care of what we do have, for/however long we have it, including our physical bodies. Everyone deals with this sort of thing in their own way and at their own pace, because well its a lot to digest on any given day. I’m not going to sit here and tell you its easy, because its not, but you learn so much when you have so little. Focus on what makes you happy. Do right by your body. Listen to it. Write. Read. Walk. Do something good.. for you."

175961316,"Hi! I am sorry to hear you're having a hard time. I myself know that hearing it will get better and that it's only a phase does not help. You probably feel stuck in the moment, and trying to look to the future for better times might feel impossible. Being told it's a phase often made me feel belittled about my feelings, as though they didn't count because of my age. I would suggest that you get in touch with a local crisis line or help line. You don't have to be in crisis to call. In my experience, they are very understanding and patient, and can guide you toward getting the help you need, even if your family doesn't support you on this very brave endeavor. My anxiety and depression manifested heavily as a teen, and the hormones and my family life made things even worse. When I moved out on my own and had my own life, some things got better, others got more complicated, and some things, honestly, got worse. I've struggled with depression and anxiety my whole life and at times have felt totally cons
umed with both. I'm sorry you don't feel listened to at a time right now. I am here if you ever want to talk to someone or just vent."

175961320,"This thread is....a trip and a half. I always find it really interesting to find people so put out by their 'relationships' with schizoids, just because I work so very hard to avoid having any personal relationships at all. I understand with other PDs how things might linger and get malignant, but it seems like it would be a fairly easy thing to avoid 'abusive' behaviours from someone who isn't actually interested in maintaining a relationship by just also avoiding the relationship. Maybe a little difficult if the schizoid in question is a caregiver, but.... I am intrigued as to how these relationships happen. Avoidance - Yes... I like the term exposure. Yes, I want to limit my exposure to er....everyone. Belittling - More when I was younger. Hardly ever now. Except maybe bullies and narcissists. Oh, gosh, it's so much fun. Chronic Broken Promises - Eh...I'm pretty good with promises. I might flake on get togethers if my stress level is too high. Cognitive Dissonance - I don't think so...but...woul
d I know? Confirmation _PERSON_ - I struggle less with this than normal people 100% Denial - Would I admit it? I don't think I'm denying anything. Dependency - No. I have no one to even depend on. Depression - Maybe sometimes. Dissociation - I think I know where to find reality when I want it. I think my dissociations are all intentional little mental vacations. The description for this one makes it sound unintentional. Entitlement - I have not much if any. Escape to Fantasy - Yes. Feelings of Emptiness - Maybe? People make me feel empty. Alone, sometimes, I feel full. _PERSON_ - No. Identity Disturbance - no. Imposed Isolation - Hell yeah! Just on myself though. Y'all can do whatever you want. Invalidation - I....don't think so. Sounds insidious. Lack of Conscience. No. I have so much conscience. I am annoyingly blessed with it. Low self-esteem - Ehhhhhh. No. I don't think so. Masking - Oh yes. I'm too truthful to do it very well, but I absolutely mask myself so as to not horrify others on a regular basis. N
eglect - I have no dependents but it's hard for me to fulfill the emotional needs of my family members. ""Not my fault"" syndrome - no. Objectification - no. Pathalogical Lying -- other than to get out of social events and interactions? No. Projection - I don't even know how that would work. It's pretty clear to me that I don't have a substantial overlap with the feelings of others. Selective Memory. No. Selective Competence - Yes. Great tactic to keep people from taking advantage of you. Recommend 100% Stunted Emotional Growth - Probably. In terms of relationships...yeah, I think I am unable to move further. In everything else, I think I do grow. Tunnel Vision - When I am stressed yes. It can be an effective coping mechanism."

I solely take care of my 2 year old daughter with little support from my husband. My husband has mental health issues as well. He deals with anxiety, depression, and ocd. We are similar creatures of habit, but we deal with our social and emotional well beings very differently. I do not communicate my needs, wants and frustrations with him. I do not like confrontation, and bottle my emotions up until I become passive aggressive with an attitude. And he, coming 
from an abusive childhood, has to be in control and verbally lashes out when angry. We have had marital problems from the beginning, but nothing ever changes. He tells me what he needs from our marriage but I find it difficult to reciprocate when I feel disrespected by the hurtful things he says when mad. In therapy last year I tried to deal with some of the issues in my marriage, along with my own mental health issues. I became more vocal about the things I disliked 
in our marriage. I ended therapy because of how many arguments we were having over it. I am open to different ways to deal with my issues, but I feel medication is the last resort. I didn't like the way medication made me feel, and I'd rather not while taking care of my daughter. I love my daughter and husband, I am thankful for my life and health of my family. 175961373,"command /bin/bash returned exit code 1 class=""content""> If it doesn't bother you, don't worry about it. You're aware of how you affect other people, both negatively and positively. That's enough. You care about this issue enough to make a post about it, but if you ruminate over it too much, you'll create a problem for yourself where none exists. I could relate to most of what you said, and although I don't think you stated your age, know that it took me many years to be comfortable with the way I am. I think many people with non-destructive personality disorders need to just grow into them and accept themselves. You don't sound unhappy, so don't push it. I've found that while most people expect some kind of return when engaging in any kind of relationship, some don't. If you suspect you may be needlessly hurting somebody by simply not caring, don't walk away. Let them make that choice. Friends can come in handy at times, even if they're not truly friends from your point of view. Yes, sometimes yo
u have to put on your mask and play the game. Needy, clingy types will see through that, and you won't have to be bothered by them. Over time you can pare down your acquaintances and friends to those few who are not overly expectant and tend not to exhaust you just by being in the same room. The fact that you feel comfortable around your brother verifies to me that schizoids prefer familiarity. I've had a lot of people moving in and out of my life but the two who have remained thus far have been around for many years."

175961414,"Hello and welcome! I have heard that while expired medication won't harm you...neither does it usually help much because of a loss of efficacy over time. If you are unsure, try calling your local pharmacist. They are really knowledgeable about _PERSON_ and questions such as yours. I hope you get the answers you need soon! 175961415,"Another question about SSRIs, as I struggle to figure out what to do. I started Zoloft at 25mg. That is almost surely not a therapeutic dose, but I wanted to start low to deal with side effects, since the only prior time I tried an SSRI (8 years ago), I had trouble tolerating even a pretty low dose (of Lexapro).. I took the 25mg for 9 days and then switched to 50 mg. I am on day 18 at 50mg. I cannot tell whether it is doing any good, since I do not know what I would be like if I were not taking it. But I don't think it is doing much good. It is, however, messing with my sleep. (Maybe to some extent the anxiety is messing with my sleep, but I think the Zoloft is mostly to blame). For the first two weeks, I took a low dose of Klonopin every night, to help fall asleep. But I stopped doing that because I don't want to take any risk of getting hooked on Klonopin or any other benzo. Now I can fall asleep on my own, without a pill, so I guess that is progress -- but I wake up too early (like 530 am or so) 
and with a very uncomfortable jittery/agitated feeling. The p-doc suggested I try taking the Zoloft pill a little bit later in the morning (I was taking it around 8; now switched to 1030 am or so). He said early morning jitters might be a sort of withdrawal symptom, as the amount of Zoloft in my body is reduced. So if I take the Zoloft a bit later in the morning, the jittery feeling might happen a few hours later the next day -- like 8 am instead of 530 am-- but by that time I will be up and going so it won't impact me much and I might not even feel it. I tried that yesterday for the first time. I had a very interrupted night of sleep. I slept very lightly and was up a lot during the night. And still woke pretty early - though to be fair I also went to sleep pretty early. I will try this again today, taking the pill around 1030 am, and see how it goes. The doctor also said if this does not work, I could try splitting the dose and taking half in the morning and half late afternoon, in an effort to keep a more 
steady amount of the medication in me. It seems like there's no way to predict what will work, so they just make up every different option to see what might work. I feel like a lab rat. The doc also said he thinks I probably need a higher dose than 50mg of Zoloft, since 50mg does not seem to be doing much for me. But he understands that I will not go above 50mg until I can address the sleep issue that I am having with 50mg, because I have to assume that increasing the dose will only exacerbate the sleep problem. At the same time, he said we may conclude that Zoloft is not the right med for me and maybe switch -- as I mentioned in a prior post -- to Paxil. But I think Paxil might have worse side effects than Zoloft, and the cross taper can create its own side effects, and Paxil is reportedly harder to get off of too. So I am not sure I would do the switch. I would probably instead just throw in the towel. so to speak -- stop taking meds, and instead try to address my situation solely through therapy (I have a 
very capable therapist). I don't know how people deal with all the medication side effects, and sleep deprivation, agitation and jitters, and switching from med to med, etc, all without any assurance that any of it will do any good. It sometimes seems like the cure is worse than the disease! I would welcome any advice you might have. Thank you."

175961449,"Hi _PERSON_ and welcome back! I don't have personal experience, but have heard many similar feelings expressed from members who are trying a new Rx for the first time and have concerns. While there can be some unpleasant start up effects for some people, not everyone experiences them. Also they are temporary and often end up being a small price to pay for a medication that after a few weeks, can give you years of benefits. This is of course a personal decision, but consider your quality of life with anxiety. Is the possibility of some side effects more uncomfortable than the other option of living with the anxiety as is? Of course only you can answer this, and I am not trying to sway your decision...just giving you something to think about . I wish you the best with your decision...keep us posted so we can keep you in support! S.C."

175961552,"Thanks for your kind words. I have some rare extra time right now, and honestly it feels good to be of comfort, and I empathize with what your dealing with alone. This so much for you to bear alone, I agree that you need more support. Holding in devastating things is very hard on a person. When we hold things in, we put up barriers between ourselves and others in order to protect ourselves. And we can end up isolated. _NAME_ questions are helpful as far as helping us figure out where you are and where you might get more of what you need. Your original post cried out to tell your mom, but it sounds like that may not be possible? Sometimes we don't get the support we need from our parents, but the action of asking for what we need from a therapist acting as a parent can be a release. The therapist can give you that feeling of having your pain acknowledged by someone really important to you, like your mom, as you might long for. In the short term, _NAME_ a buddhist teacher, does wonderful talks on tru
st, compassion for ourselves, and working through pain. (Free podcasts and videos). Meditation is also a great tool for releasing pain, and _NAME_ offers guided meditations too. There are some little tricks to comfort yourself, like hold your hand over your heart, close your eyes, take a deep breath, and say things like ""I'm here for you"", ""I love you,"" or ""I'm so sorry"". In this way, you can offer yourself comfort and support. It sounds a little hokey, but it helps. Another weird and simple trick that helps is aura clearing: Wash your hands and comb the air with your fingers around your head and torso saying ""I am free, I keep only what serves my wellbeing, and I release what doesn't. "" And then wash your hands. It sounds insane I know, but it is strangely uplifting. I wonder what you think would help you? What would reinventing yourself look like to you?"
