175961729,"I really have no idea where to start. I have a physical disability known as a right-sided hemiplegia/ right-sided hemiparesis as a result of at least one year of intense physical abuse when I was between 2 and 3 years old. Due to the disability, I have an abnormal gait and used to get muscle spasms which have improved significantly since I had a baclofen pump installed in early March 2020. Although my physicality has significantly improved since the operation, I still struggle with issues of feeling worthy of anything (love, attention, happiness) even from my fiance who I literally love more than life itself. I graduated from high school in 2014 and have been struggling like crazy with college, which wasn't even my choice, to begin with. I've been working towards a degree for the past 6 years with no tangible sense of meaningful progress. The reason this is such an issue for me is that growing up I was constantly in and out of hospitals, but when we got home there wasn't a lot that I could physical
ly do to contribute. I have always felt an overwhelming sense of duty to go above and beyond for other people's sake but never my own, I don't know how to want greater things for myself. And typically, society looks down upon those who can't contribute, regardless of the individual's personal circumstances. I feel that I have internalized these values which makes it nearly impossible for me to forgive myself when I make a mistake or fall short of others' goals for me. I start to hate myself and wish that I was dead because for me, being dead is more favorable than being a living failure incapable of change, due to an overwhelming sense of dread and anxiety whenever I try to step out of my comfort zone. I know that this is important to at least practice because you never know what you're capable of until you go through the pressures of trying something new. I used to be very willing to try and push myself but for the past few years I haven't been able to go for a simple drive or walk around my college campus w
ithout my muscles locking up and feeling like my heart was going to physically explode, I get that nervous. I don't mean to blame others but my family really hasn't been as supportive as I would have hoped. Instead of gradually trying to calm me down they constantly tell me to ""get over it, it's not that bad, I'm making a mountain out of a molehill"" this really doesn't help when I'm having a panic attack because they're looking for a quick fix so they don't have to deal with my problems. They also never try to empathize with my struggles until I choose to tell them how bad things really are (me wanting to kill myself). This is extremely painful for me because I don't know how to calm down, my mom never taught me how to cope with difficult feelings, it's always been: ""You're too weird, I don't feel like dealing this, shut up."" I have learned that I can't rely on them so I turn to quick fixes such as marijuana, alcohol, and cigarettes. Due to my sense of anxiety and fear, I'm afraid to try anymore but at th
e same time, I still feel like a literal ""absolute"" failure. This has led to a deep-seated sense of self-hate and confusion as to what to do next, I feel like there's nothing more that I can do. Which leads to thoughts of suicide, I'm upset about being disabled and not being able to experience the world in ways that many others take for granted, and while I'm able to have good days, most of the time I feel like I'm a burden to everyone who I feel has had the misfortune of knowing me. I don't like getting wrapped up with other people even if we both benefit because I worry that they will lose interest in me because I'm always so upset. This makes me feel terrible because I feel like I'm neglecting them, when in fact they are my lifeline. I don't like the idea of me constantly being codependent on others because I know that will stifle what little sense of self that I have left, even though I have no idea what to do with it. I'm only 24 and I've gone through 4 therapists in the span of 5-6 years, had nearly 2 
psych admits (for the second one, this was about a week before my baclofen pump insertion and I got scared that they wouldn't let me out in time so I lied and told them that I made a mistake and was fine while still in triage.) And while all but one of my therapists were very good at their jobs I'm still struggling with feelings of not wanting to exist and thoughts of suicide are slowly creeping back in. I know that my friends ""love"" me and my fiance would be devastated, but there aren't any reasons that I can find for myself to stay around. My life feels like torture because I'm constantly stuck between wanting to die to free my mind, staying around for others, and being afraid of what's on the other side of life if anything."

175961783,"I have committed myself about 6 times due to bipolar disorder or bulimia nervosa. During manic episodes I have done my fair share of questionable, outrageous or unkind things. My experience is that my family knew that I was not my normal self and that I was experiencing symptoms of mental illness. Of course the nurses knew this as well. My family knew the kind of person I was any other time than during episodes so they were very forgiving. I find people’s ability to forget other people’s difficulties is rather great, as they are more preoccupied with their own insecurities and misfortunes. Please love yourself and know that you are worthy and a wonderful person."

175961831,"My first serious side effect of what was labeled anxiety by a variety of doctors was the feeling I could not take a deep breath. Various doctors just ruled it anxiety. I had a variety of tests, allergy, asthma, lungs etc. Finally the allergy doctor said she thinks it could be vocal chord dysfunction. She sent me to an ENT who in turn let me see a speech physical therapist who put a scope down my throat. She could see that my breathing was the issue. I spent months learning how to breathe properly. It did help. I have to remember to breathe properly. That said, I still get that sensation of discomfort and I am aware of each breathe at times. I use Ativan now and then and it takes my mind off my breathing for a day. Check out VCD. Not saying that is what you have but not that many have heard of it."

175961870,"I've been hospitalized multiple times. I've also been told that it's very likely it could be something that could happen again so I should be prepared for that. I've learned to look at hospitalization as just a part of keeping myself well. It's not a guarantee that I'll ever need to go back, but I'm grateful it's there if I need the help in a crisis. It has helped me to get back on my feet before and hook me up with the services I needed to stay as independent as possible honestly. Maybe you could even do a Wellness Recovery Action Plan or something like that stating what you will and won't allow if you're ever hospitalized. That may help you feel like you still have some control in case of a mental health crisis. In my experience the hospital really wasn't that bad. Some of my stays made me angry but not because of my treatment in the hospital. I was angry for just having to deal with mental illness, but I'm learning to accept it and deal as best I can. Honestly, though, most of my stays were quit
e pleasant now that I look back on it. Yeah, it wasn't ideal. However, I'm grateful I had a safe space to get help, get meds adjusted, and get the treatment I needed. Every time I was hospitalized I had to stay for a mandatory period of 72 hours (if I remember correctly). That was to make sure I wasn't a danger and o monitor my illness. I got my meds adjusted, talked to doctors about my symptoms, went to different groups, and I was generally well taken care of. The only thing I really hated was being probated. My stays typically lasted about a week or two to get back to functioning well. I haven't been in the hospital in almost four years though so I've made some great progress. The last stay was two weeks. One or two weeks seemed about average for myself and the other people I was with. But I think it just depends on the individual and what's best for them. People have been okay with me after hospitalization. My friends who were true friends were really supportive. My family was okay though we're not very cl
ose. I've gotten some people who've been curious but never rude and their conversations are innocent enough questions. I've found most people to be pretty understanding. I've been much harder on myself than others have. Except for maybe my grandmother."

175961930,"You say: “I guess I’m looking for advice from people who have been through this.” I’ve been through it. Along with my wife, I raised a child who is now grown and it was close to everything you said. One reason it was that way was because I was bipolar I (with full mania and depression, while net says bipolar II is depression but only partial mania.) For my bipolar, I take Lithium to deal with the mania and Mirtazapine for the depression, which has really helped me. We can be thankful that we have medicines that can improve out condition. My mother’s mother had bipolar during the 1930s, 1940s and early 1950s, but they had no medicine for that and she spent much of her life in a central state mental hospital 100 miles from her home. Today we have medicine that works and that we can take at home and we don’t have to be at a state hospital with medicine that doesn’t help. We can be very thankful for that. As a parent, in addition to being bipolar, I was also not the disciplinarian. I was 
the roll on the floor entertainment center. I was also unconsciously negative from either bipolar, the negative household I was raised in, or both. I stumbled until a column that said, “If you aren’t positive, you probably aren’t a good problem solver.” It said, go into a problem thinking you can solve it. I said, next time I have a problem, I’m not going to think about the problem, I’m going to get the positive column down from the bulletin board and read it. The next problem was, my son comes in and tells me, “The car’s in the backyard and it won’t start.” I think, ""I don’t know what to do, how are they going to get a wrecker into our tight driveway backyard? I’ll wait till my wife comes home and she’ll solve the problem.” Then I remembered the bulletin board column on being positive, that I’m not supposed to worry about the problem first, I’m supposed to read the column on first being positive before trying to solve a problem. I get the column down and start reading it. By 
the 4th paragraph, I said, “_NAME_.” What was _NAME_? It was a small garage near our house that we had used before that had a small wrecker that had once before gotten into our twisting driveway and gotten one of our cars. How did I solve the problem, and I wasn’t even thinking about it? The column on being positive had opened my mind to solving the problem, rather than closing it to thinking I couldn’t solve it. So, believing you can solve your next problem vastly improves the chances that you will. Or, one problem at a time, and be positive about that problem. You also say, “Okay my dad is bipolar II and I haven’t been diagnosed because I’m pretty good at compensating and none of my docs have considered it a diagnosis helpful. But inside my head is a cacophony (discord or disharmony) and I’m always on the verge of losing it.” Since your dad is bipolar, you may be also. My grandmother was, and I was. You’ve already said, “inside my head is a cacophony (discord or disharmony) and I’m a
lways on the verge of losing it.” Symptoms of bipolar from mayoclinic.org says, “When you become depressed, you may feel sad or hopeless and lose interest or pleasure in most activities. “When your mood shifts to mania or hypomania (less extreme than mania), you may feel euphoric, full of energy or unusually irritable. These mood swings can affect sleep, energy, activity, judgment, behavior and the ability to think clearly.” Do you have that? You say, “I just don’t have any realistic way to imagine getting better.” You’ve written in for help so that’s a start."

175961938,"Your government should have a list of disorders that render a person automatically eligible to disability income, and disorders requiring that you meet other conditions. Where I live at least, it is better if you produce every three months , a medical form filled by a doctor attesting you have long term work limitations, until your demand is accepted. I told my psychiatrist I wanted to work, had some pills prescribed, went to work one day or two, gave up, couldn't bear to be around people. Before leaving the office, you could pretend that you almost forgot the medical form you brought with you. Oh and by the way, being dirt poor is bad for your health you know. Last diagnosis was schizotypal with precarious contact with reality. The funny thing is I'm pretty sure I have a better grasp of reality than most people. There was another form I had to submit to my social security office in which I described briefly my life history and limitations. Also a phone interview was scheduled with a government doc
tor, but the law didn't require me to have it, so they used the info they already had. Good luck."

175961940,"_PERSON_, you are making an effort to take control of your life which, apparently, is filled with Anxiety. Therefore, you are using coping skills to manage it the best you can. It's true... Just breathe! The very fact that you are aware of your problem, is a major breakthrough. It's just not easy. Maybe a support group (besides this online approach) would help you; to hear how others who have the same problem you are trying to work through, deal with their anxiety issues. So many of the difficult things in our lives must be handled with whatever coping skills we are taught, learn for ourselves or need to face head on. I know that from the time I was young (I'm and old lady now), I would get myself through with self-talk. You work out little tricks for yourself. This is not really about ""anxiety"" per se, but an example of dealing with the things that come at us in daily life, like job interviews and other matters we have to face but make us nervous, anxious or actually fearful - I would convince m
yself that I was an actress, and this is the scene I had to get through. With that in my mind, I could get through just about anything for the next 30 minutes (or whatever). I'm just trying to point out to you, that we all have issues, demons and so forth, and everyone - who appears to have it all together - has the same problem as you or someone else, but has just learned how to manage it. Believe me, I used to wonder why everyone in the world seemed to be an ""adult"" and seemed so successful and in control of their life, and I wasn't! Come to find out, just about everyone felt the same way! It's like, Fake it, Until You Make It! Good luck."

175961967,"Good for you, _NAME_. I've always thought that getting out and helping and volunteering was very helpful to ourselves and to others. There is a saying that goes: ""Happiness can't be found , wen u seek It for urself But wen u give to others , It 'll find its way back to u ... Dats The Mystery of HAPPINESS...!!"" I've always advocated for others to volunteer at places like libraries, senior citizens homes, hospitals, walking a dog at a kennel. I've never thought of the farm and the food pantry. I've always advocated those places for others but I don't actually go to any of these places myself. I have a condition in which I can't be around a lot of noise, and every place seems to have phones, functional music and other sources of noise which I can't tolerate. So I feel I'm kinda locked out. Also, I must have some sort of psychological condition, I just don't gravitate towards crowds or people. Now if I'm in a situation with other people, I'll be the most talkative person there, and I'll enjoy it more 
than the others. But I don't purposely walk out and seek those kinds of places. It's probably social anxiety. My dad was like that. He stayed by himself except for work. But now that you've mentioned it, I may have to give that food bank a thought. I think socialization like that, helping others, would help ourselves to fight depression and low self esteem. I went to Easter Seals therapy workshop putting tags on soap boxes, but putting tags on soap boxes around other people, and from depressed, I was probably the happiest person in the building. 174350809,"It's good that you seemed to have found something that works. It seems that they treated the depression in 2001. Were they finally treating the mania in 2009? Was the jumping up and down mania or were you just happy? Is there any bipolar in your family. I got mine from my mother's mother, who was bipolar before they knew what it was, and just called it schizophrenia. But then they didn't have any medicine for either of that in the 1930s and 1940s, so she basically went untreated in a mental hospital. So we can appreciate the fact that they do have medicine now for bipolar, depression, anxiety, schizophrenia and other such conditions. We can be very glad. My grandmother would go into people's medicine cabinets looking for a pill that would calm her down from the ravages of bipolar. Now we just go to the drug store. For my bipolar, I take Lithium for the mania and Mirtazapine for the depression. Those were the pills my grandmother was longing for."

On a chair. Sitting down makes me feel pinned down on that chair for the whole session. No control over how close she and I are. I stand up (for instance leaning against the wall) or I sit on the floor (towards the end of the session). This way I am free to move around 
so I have some control over the space between us. Seems silly but really does help me feel a little more at ease And I actually refuse to sit down even for a minute for fear of not daring to get up again"

175962141,"Hi Joy1989, Welcome to the anxiety and panic support forum. Citalapram (aka Celexa) are SSRI's. Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor. The thing with these medications is they can take awhile to work. Though you can start feeling better sooner, they can take six to eight weeks to reach full potential. So being patient is the key. I would let the doctor know what is going on. It could just be a side effect that may go away in seven to ten days. Or the medication might not be right for you. The doctor may be able to give you something to calm you at night. What time of the day are you taking the medication? If you are taking it in the evening, it might be the reason for poor sleep. Some medications are suppose to be taken in evening, some not. I hope that things get better for you. Stay safe. Hugs, _NAME_..."

175962213,"_AT_MENTION_ - Ativan can be pretty addictive. Same with other benzodiazepines. I save that for once in a blue moon use. One thing that has been shown to work quite well for health anxiety is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy— a practical, relatively short term therapy. If your wife is motivated to beat the health anxiety, that might be the best approach."

175962326,"Hello _PERSON_: I see this is your first post here on PC. Welcome to Psych Central. Here are links to the Depression & the Social Anxiety forums, here on PC, just in case you haven't already found them: https://psychcentralforums.com/depression/ https://psychcentralforums.com/socia...ective-mutism/ We here on PC cannot offer mental health diagnoses. (For that you will need to see a mental health professional where you live or , perhaps, do some on-line therapy.) Plus I'm not a mental health professional. So I can't suggest what may be causing your ""apparitions"". I have some similar experiences myself although they're not as intense as yours seem to be. Mine occur primarily at night when the house is dark & quiet. I presume mine are the result of a longstanding anxiety disorder plus I'm an older person so I presume age has something to do with it as well. Here are links to 7 articles, from Psych Central's archives, that (hopefully) may be of some help: Social Anxiety Overview | Psych Central 6 Way
s to Overcome Social Anxiety Treating Social Anxiety Disorder with Mindfulness https://psychcentral.com/blog/podcas...-controls-you/ https://psychcentral.com/blog/five-f...-need-to-know/ https://psychcentral.com/lib/what-ps...and-feel-like/ https://psychcentral.com/lib/psychotic-depression/ I hope you find PC to be of benefit."

175962347,"I like commenting about mental health issues to online forums, such as HealingWell.com, in part, because I like to try to help others who have mental illness like I do. However, I occasionally worry that my comments, which are intended to be helpful to others, will actually make some people reading my comments feel worse, especially if they're having a bad day. For example, if I talk about how I found talking about my past traumatic experiences to a therapist as something that helped me, it may get someone who is reading my comments who has also been through trauma in their past to think about the trauma they've been through, and maybe feel worse as a result. Therapists run into the same basic problem. Psychotherapy can be upsetting at times for some clients. However, that doesn't mean they should stop performing therapy. But still, I sometimes worry about making comments about mental illness to forums such as this one. What do you think about this? Also, do you worry about this sort of thing as we
ll?"

175962477,"Hi there, I assume you already tried the therapy and medication options? Discussed your situation with a professional? If not, there are many ways to overcome panic disorder. Therapy (either talk therapy or Cognitive Behavioral Therapy) and medication are two of them. Mindfulness training and mindful meditation make a huge difference. I really suggest you read about them. I was put on 50 mg Sertraline after my diagnosis and I had great help from that. Also then I learned to recognize my symptoms and cope with them. I learned to shift my focus to a nearby object when I notice panic symptoms were coming. Learning your triggers and being aware of your thought patterns are essential for dealing with a panicky mood. You can discuss everything with your doctor and that would be my first advice for you if you have never addressed your worries before. Hope you feel calmer soon."

175962553,"I only say 'unusual' in that others find it hard to know what is going to trigger me or not. It is unpredictable to myself . But after giving this considerable thought I think everyone's triggers stem from a perceived injury to their sense of self. This is going to vary based on one's level of narcissism, paranoia, fatigue, childhood experiences, life experiences and learned reactions. Because I have led a vastly different life and am different in nature to those I have to currently live and work with, my triggers are often interpreted by others as 'unusual', but for me they make perfect sense. Apart from this, another trigger for me, and many, stems from perceiving others as stupid/ignorant. If they are in a position of power and I have to kowtow to them... that makes me wild, which is why I cannot handle bureaucracy or jobs that entail customer service. One could say this is a 'perception' probably... but really it is not. It is an unfortunate fact of life that many morons are in a position of po
wer."
175962554,"OF, as of this past April, I limited my news watching to my local news only for 15 minutes only every morning!! I sip on a little coffee during this time. I check my phone for my weather. This lowered the stress & anxiety level greatly. Give it a try, sitting & watching what's going on across the country is feeding your stress levels. Remember we can only control ourselves. The problem with distributing the vaccines is the availability of medical personnel to give the shots & the space needed to accommodate people. The paperwork has to be processed, then the shot & then the person has to be monitored for 15 minutes before they are allowed to leave. This is the problem. I live in a very large city. Our local health dept posted an online sign up for the vaccine only taking so many people per day. People are given an online appointment only, no walk ins allowed. The online registration asks your age & pre-existing health problems that puts a person at high risk. This started on 12-31 & people stood in 
line for 5 hours in the cold rain that had an appointment. They vaccinated less than 800 people that day. I signed up my husband & I up, but we cannot stand in line for hours like that. They also will not be doing the shots every day either. A few weeks ago they were claiming Walmart, CVS & Walgreens are gearing up to vaccinate people. You've been in these drugstores, now how many people do you think they can accommodate in one day in their closed quarters, not many. I go outside a lot during the day & just deep breathe to clear my thoughts. Even in the cold I piddle around on the back porch. I play online games sometimes, I like card games. Sometimes we get in the truck & just go for a ride, nothing like getting out of the city & riding around on the back roads. We don't have to get out of the truck to do this. Anything for some diversion. Regardless of all the chaos we all have many things to be thankful for, sometimes that gets lost in the shuffle. Yes, keep the politics out of the threads whether names ar
e mentioned or not please. Mods really do not like editing posts or having to lock them."

175962598,"For almost a year now my husband and I have been doing food prep, which means that we prepare our meals in advance for the week. We’ve found it extremely helpful in helping us to eat in a more healthy way, working around our busy schedules and around my mental and physical illnesses. Feeling proactive Being prepared for the days ahead and knowing that I have planned healthy meals and prepared food for our little family with help from my wonderful husband, allows me to feel proactive and empowered. I am using everything at my disposal to beat my mental illness, not to allow it to dictate my life. Often during the week I am too tired or my mood is too low to make a healthy meal, so it’s tempting to eat something unhealthy or get a takeaway: food prep means that we have healthy, tasty meals there that we can just heat up to curb this need. I have that satisfaction of knowing that I am taking action, taking control of my own life rather than allowing bipolar disorder to take that control away. http
s://blogs.psychcentral.com/bipolar-journey/2019/11/how-food-prep-has-helped-me-fight-my-bipolar-disorder/"

174351605,"Just stay away rom PHL professors. I had a global ethics professor tell a class, ""One white man is more creative than 10 Asian men."" as he ranted about how all of this philosophy of mind things were just confusions, there is no mystery about it, and gave us _PERSON_ papers. It was hell. It might have triggered my schizophrenia because I was strapped down and was forced to empathize with a professors own frustrations on how we need to give up philosophy and do something more practical. I have had him 2 classes and every day I felt the weight of depression from his classes and his emotions on how we need to give it up. He was genius, but so punishing. I think me and another kid were the only ones who received A's. He said he got the scholarship because he asked for it. I wasn't about to grovel to a professor. By the end of the philosophy of mind class students were in fear of passing so they showed sympathy with his wittgenstien views without understanding the papers the professor gave us. 
He literally made it a herculean task to pass that class because he was frustrated with the subject, trying to groom students to view the problem as he saw it. This is a common thing in philosophy classes. If you share their view, they love you, if you show even disinterested criticism of the teachers cherished beliefs they attack and black ball them."

175962707,"My theory is that having parents/caretakers who are BOTH overbearing AND neglectful will lead to a greater chance of someone developing this condition over time. Many times we think it's either one or the other (overbearing or neglectful). In my own personal case, it was a situation that would swing wildly from overbearing parental dynamics to neglectful parental dynamics. There simply seemed to be no real ""happy medium"". Having said that, I can't blame my parents for my condition. They are simply how they are and whatever happens...happens. I don't know anything different other than being who I am. Certainly, parents will play a role in shaping their children's personality to a certain extent, no doubt. Anyway, feel free to chime in with your thoughts/opinions."

175962712,"Hello there. I first want to ask you, because I’ve seen the misdiagnosis many times, if you’re sure you don’t have PTSD? 174351719,"This one is brand new, and thus, exciting to me. Along with the fact that this personality disorder is interesting, seems very intelligent mind-based (and relatable), my motives for this question is I'm looking for a niche that I would be content working with. I was trying to figure out, given so much time spent in the ""mind"" rather than in the ""heart"" or ""present moment"" whether this PD could get mistaken for others who are detached and predisposed to spending more time in their ""heads"" than ""hearts"" I'm not one to be convinced one's nature or biology is the overriding factor of the development of a personality disorder or any other mental illness. Although I'm aware trauma isn't always a factor, I think it is more often than not. That, and environment (things that could be or could have been changed), in relation to mental disorders, is a source of interest for me especially when it comes to criminal activity - but also living in other worlds and odd beliefs (from personality disorder t
o full-on primary psychotic disorder to mania or mental disorders in general). I'm also usually able to hold positive regard, acceptance and dignity for most humans regardless of history, while at the same time, I still have a relatively strong conscience. I'm interested in complexities, creativity, some level of psychosis, trauma, rage, aggression, lack of attachments, unemotional, callousness in connection to all of this. For the life of me, I do not want to work with vulnerable or emotionally injured individuals the way a normal person with ptsd or c-ptsd would express themselves. I don't want to work with people who cannot take care of themselves or those who have slightly different challenges in reasoning such as ASD or FASD or people who are completely out of contact with reality or have a major ID not that there's anything at all wrong with them. My point is invulnerability and ability to fend for selves - and interesting and enjoyable for me. Every symptom of mental disorder I show, is related to copi
ng mechanisms. This also brings be back to wondering about comorbidities of Schizoid PD re: RAD and C-PTSD; however, I'm fully aware everyone is not me. It keeps me curious though. Maybe research. Sounds like an awful lot of boring classes and procedures to learn though"

175962730,"Psychiatric medications have come a long way over the years. And as time goes on, they'll keep getting better and more effective. However, I strongly believe that no matter how advanced psychiatric pills become, no matter how good they get, psychotherapy will always be around. Talk therapy will always exist and will always be needed for lots of people struggling with mental health issues, such as anxiety and panic attacks. The reason I believe this is because they'll never be a pill that will solve all your problems and make everything better. Psychotherapy will always be necessary for lots of folks because those with mental illness need to learn how to learn how to cope with their issues, how to make their lifestyles more healthy, and how to replace irrational beliefs with more rational beliefs."

It's not as illegal as you might think. In the state I reside in bullying was made a federal crime 2 years ago and state agencies wouldn't do anything. You can allow it to keep happening the rest of your life or do something that will benefit you as a person and make bullying you something that may end up with them on the floor. I would suggest a martial arts school that suits your taste and style. I'm a purple belt in Shotokan and like the hard style strikes. When I was actively training I considered 3 people against me a fair fight and fought 3 more than once, but that was years ago. I'm still intimating and recently not seen as easy prey by two young guys who thought better of trying whatever they had planned happening outside at 2am on me. Jujitsu and joint manipulation has always interested me and if I get hold of your fingers, 
you're going to ground and they will never be the same. It doesn't take strength, only knowing how they are not supposed to bend and making it hurt comes with it. Either would be good exercise and give your confidence a boost. To do nothing is to accept defeat and you'll be seen an easy mark for anybody with a tendency to pick on those weaker than themselves far into the future. Work to change yourself for the better and learning a formal style to defend yourself is the best advise I can offer. Or learn to love life as a target for those who only pick on people who are weaker than themselves. It won't stop till you look too intimating to try or show them how it feels to be on the receiving end. You will be surprised how much better you feel about yourself afterwards."

175962947,"I agree with others. My brother in law once told my husband when he first started out as an electrician and was looking at a huge complex of buildings to wire not to look at the whole project, but instead focus on one building at a time. He lives by that every day 40 years later. Take one thing that is in your control and scratch it off the list. Things that are semi in your control, like health issues means taking your meds, getting some exercise if you can, taking care of yourself the best you can. If you're worried about a colostomy leak, which is a possibility, make sure you are always prepared with a kit for such things. It won't be the end of the world if it happens if you are prepared for it. As far as worrying about things that are not in your control, Jesus said it best at _NAME_ 6: 25, 34 “On this account I say to you: Stop being anxious about your lives as to what you will eat or what you will drink, or about your bodies as to what you will wear. Does not life mean more than food and t
he body than clothing? So never be anxious about the next day, for the next day will have its own anxieties. Each day has enough of its own troubles. In other words, as my Mom always likes to say, don't go borrowing trouble. The things beyond our control are of no use to us expending energy and anxious worry about when there is nothing we can do about the outcome either way. See if there's something in your life that brings you hope, even if it's just playing with the pup for a bit or the beautiful orchids you have. Fixing up the house little by little and not getting weighed down in the details. One step at a time."

175962975,"Hi Eelpie1, Welcome to the forum. I agree about talking to a doctor or therapist and work on the issues of low self esteem and such. When we have low self esteem it is easy to think of ourselves as unattractive in many ways. Even though in life, looks really don't matter. It comes from what is inside a person, how they act. Are they kind? If your girlfriend undermines you and tries to make you feel bad about yourself, I would think it is her problem. She feels beneath you and is jealous.. Normal people don't go around hurting their friends. Being told you didn't fit the look does not mean anybody thinks you are ugly. You just weren't what they were looking for. There are many different looks with people. And... Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder. What one person finds attractive isn't necessarily what the next person finds attractive. I hope you stop putting so much stock in appearances. Really, what is on the outside doesn't really matter. Sure it is nice to look good, but really the true beaut
y comes from inside. How you treat others. I hope you talk to somebody. I think you would feel better about yourself. Also as SC stated, check out resources at the top of the page... You sound like a good person. I hope you feel better soon. Hugs, _NAME_..."

175962979,"You mention being very anxious: “Hi there, I’m so anxious right now I don’t know what to do” “Yes it is definitely my thinking, I do recognize the problem but, how do I change those ? I mean I have try to accept Then and remember that they are just thoughts but still make me afraid” “I’m still worried about everything and what if I developed a new illness? What if I am depressed? What if I never get better? What if’s are just so bad lately."" ""Willing to try everything to get better ...this is debilitating me” From there my anxiety went so bad...every day is like what if? Why do these thoughts come to my mind? And fear comes to my mind."" ""I truly believe this fear is all part of this pandemic ...realizing that we are so vulnerable you know, ...I went to the new therapist who recommended CBT, I have never actually tried it ..."" ""I think I am getting what you re saying ...I mean things that have happened to me make me more scare of the same situations again. For example I am 
kinda of feeling better about the covid situation and then I hear there is going to be another lockdown and I start very anxious. I mean look at what that situation has brought us already you know."" As far as where the anxiety comes from, you said: ""Yes I mean I love my family it’s just that they are anxious too"" So you’ve spoken of anxiety quite a bit. Webmd.com says the symptoms of that are: • Feeling nervous, restless or tense; Having a sense of impending danger, panic or doom; • Having increased heart rate; Breathing rapidly (hyperventilation); Sweating; Trembling Do you have that? The website also listed several types of anxiety, one was called; Generalized anxiety disorder includes persistent and excessive anxiety and worry about activities or events — even ordinary, routine issues. The worry is out of proportion to the actual circumstance, is difficult to control and affects how you feel physically. It often occurs along with other anxiety disorders or depression. You said your therapist t
hought you might be depressed and suggested you talk with your doctor. The symptoms of depression for women are (healthline.com): • mood, such as irritability • emotional well-being, such as feeling sad or empty, anxious or hopeless • behavior, such as loss of interest in activities, withdrawing from social engagements; cognitive abilities, such as thinking or talking more slowly • sleep patterns, such as difficulty sleeping through the night, waking early, over sleeping; • physical well-being, such as decreased energy, greater fatigue, changes in appetite, weight changes, aches, pain, headaches, increased cramps Do you have that? As for medicines, you said were taking Citalopram anti-depressant, 20 mg., which net said was the initial starting dosage. verywellmind website says about that medicine: “By reducing the rate at which serotonin is reabsorbed, Celexa (Citalopram) changes the brain chemistry, improving mood and reducing feelings of anxiety. Celexa can assist in decreasing the severity of p
anic attacks and other panic disorder symptoms. So, your medicine seems to be very good. It's an anti-depressant which also helps with ""reducing anxiety."" It my view, it may need to be increased. You might want to bring some of this up with your doctor at your next appointment. These are just my views as someone who also has emotional problems with bipolar. You can look up these and other topics, also, by typing them into the search engine, which is where I found them. 12"

175963007,"_PERSON_ (kjodwyer) said... The sort of mindfulness I have found helpful is when I find myself engaging in continuous negative thoughts - by focusing on the task I am doing in detail this activates (so I am told) a more frontal part of the brain as opposed to the deeper brain area where negative thoughts originate and this breaks the cycle. That is an EXCELLENT example of how someone can CHOOSE something to help them self verses simply giving in to negative thoughts! Often times people give in to negative thinking and simply feel they have no say in how they are thinking but the MIND is your BEST tool to use if you simply choose to use it~ you can over power *negative* thinking but it does take practice and an awareness that it's happening again. Over time it becomes much easier and you can stop those *negative* thought much quicker! So it's awesome that on your own you have discovered this tool. Meditation is something that MOST people do at least once or twice daily~ They focus on thoughts that m
ake them feel good~ some chat~ There are a wide variety of ways to meditate and I know several of the members here incorporate that into their daily routines so if your looking for suggestions concerning what to do or how to mediate may I recommend that you post to _PERSON_. She's the Assistant Manager here at *Hearts* and the Master Mind of *Hearts* Web Page here~ I know she is someone who mediates daily and finds it very helpful to her own well being PLUS someone that I personally can attest to, that will do her best to be of help to you. There are MANY other ways you can stop yourself from going to dark places in your mind. If you look thru the many folders here at *Hearts* many of those methods/tips that people use to help their own self are posted in those folders. If you need any help finding something simply post and ask and we will do our best to find what your looking for. If your in need of support we chat every evening from 7:00 pm to 11:00 PM EST or later if someone on staff is wiling to stay unti
l they are no longer needed. *Hearts* is open and staffed all Holidays as well. All the very best that life has to offer you! Welcome to *Hearts* (((hugs))) _PERSON_~ *Hearts* Forums Owner"

175963013,"As I understand it, extroverts recharge by social interactions and, by contrast, introverts recharge by isolation. During these trying times, those of us who are introverts should take consolation in the fact that we're the ones who can best endure the recommended self-isolation. It's almost like our routines have not changed that much. Unfortunately for extroverts, they feel more at a loss with decreased physical interaction. I believe I am an introvert, or more accurately, an extroverted introvert: I often try to ""push"" myself out more to try to present a ""balance"" in my personality. At this time, I feel I can relax the ""pushing"""

175963032,"Cross posted on FB I found a post i made on a website a few years after i was released from the troubled teen facility i was put in against my will at age 16 (2003-2004). This doesn't even scratch the surface of the things i went through and saw at this facility. #BreakingCodeSilence Here is another quote from a survivor over on Cafety: ""I was in the lockdown unit for the first 4 months and in the cabins (in the winter) for the remainding 4 months. The lockdown unit is one room with 12 beds in it. You are not allowed to look up from the floor at anyone entering or leaving the unit. You are not allowed to look at other patients or talk to them. You have to sit in the middle of your bed all day, back to the wall, no sleeping, eyes open. If you are seen by another patient breaking a rule (which i never understood as you aren't supposed to be looking at other patients) you are then confronted by the whole group and are given a consequence. When I was on STU (the lockdown unit) I was restrained countle
ss times. The very first time I was restrained on the bed, I had these huge mitts on my hands to keep myself from picking at my fingers. I will not deny that I had been harming myself by picking at my fingers. The nurse on charge put bandages on all of my fingers. As I was in my bed with these huge mitts on and bandages, I was touching the ends of my fingers to see if the blood was still flowing to the tips of my fingers as the bandages were way to tight. A staff saw me doing this and literally jerked me onto the floor as those horrible sirens went off. They hoisted me up onto the bed after about 5 minutes of holding me down (I wasn't resisting as i was terribly frightened). As they were strapping my legs and arms into the bed net I remember (and will never forget) the words that the staff said to me. She said ""We are not doing this to hurt you."" ALl i could think about at that time was why am i being strapped to this bed. I will never forget these moments. In the cabins we live in a small cabin with 12 bun
k beds. We slept in our own sleeping bags as it was winter. There was no electricity in the cabin. There was one lightbulb over the staffs desk that was lit by a car battery. The cabin was heated by one woodstove in the center of the cabin. We were forced to clean every place we visited, (the YC, the bathhouse, the cabin) numerous times. If there were over 5 specks of dirt found in the location, we were made to clean it all over again. Repeat process if more dirt was found. Sometimes we spent the whole day cleaning the YC while the staff sat in the chair and watched. One patiend that was there was always vomiting her food up. She threw up in the woodpile and they made her clean it up. She even resorted to vomiting in the vent in the school bathroom. After a month it was discovered and they just ended up giving her a grocery bag to carry around and vomit in whenever she wanted. IF she vomited in the bag she had to carry it around with her until the staff said she could dispose of it. Is this sanitary??? NO. Ev
entually this girl passed out in the toilet and was taken to the hospital, probably from severe dehydration. Girls were put in straight jackets and walked around all day. We had to carry around bags of sand as a consequence. Our consequences as a group got so backed up that we had to wake up at 5am and do over 200 push ups for weeks. I was pretending to be asleep one night and I overheard the staff making fun of a few patients. When i told my mom about this in treatment i was brushed off by my therapist as being manipulative and lying to get attention. there were so many things that happened that i would love to forget, as they still give me nightmares to this day. I am 20 years old now.I have No doubt that this is life changing."""

But you are what's important.

175963084,"Hi _PERSON_ and welcome! I am sorry to hear of your health anxiety challenges. I can relate as this is my main issue as well. So you have been on your Rx for about a month, with one increase...up from 5 mg I am assuming? Unfortunately with an A/D the symptoms that we experience with anxiety can get worse before things start to turn around and improve. (and the therapeutic dose for you is reached) You are perhaps a third to half way through your break in period with your new med. This can be a challenging time, but one that is temporary...and made easier with coping skills. Please see our Resources at the top of our main forum page here for great self help material that you can get started on today. There is material specifically on help for health anxiety there...as well as general stress relieving exercises to learn and practice. These will help if your work them regularly. Keep posting with us as well if you find it helpful. We understand, care and support is key! Talk soon, S.C."

175963089,"Hi Schizological1 . Number230000 : Unfortunately the idea that academic researchers spend a lot of time alone is not an accurate stereotype. I know some get away with it, but it's very rare to be both reclusive and successful. And success does matter, even for little things like having a nice quiet office. I can't be too detailed without giving away personal details, but academic research work involves: - talking to the admin staff (you have to be friendly to the admin staff or life gets very hard very quickly) - informal chats with the junior researchers to answer questions and keep them on track - meetings to help students or postgrad researchers navigate the university - meetings with other staff about students or postgrad researchers - supervision meetings with my own PhD candidates - telephone calls with industry partners - emails with or about any of the above - coffee with collaborators or potential future students or researchers - talks by other staff or postgrads (with associated mingling) 
- teaching (with associated talking to students before and after class) - committee meetings Not all of those happen every day, but a typical day can have quite a few. And that's when not actively trying to put together or run a project. Projects add a lot more meetings. I'm sure there are jobs that don't require a lot of talking to people, but academic researcher isn't one of them."

175963104,"I would like to recommend a book called The Transformation by Dr. _NAME_. He starts with the assumption that we all have trauma, to varying degrees. His chapters guide you through evidence-based techniques to quiet your anxiety and depression. I have downloaded the audiobook and listen to a chapter at a time, pausing frequently to go through the exercises, from breathing to dancing to writing and visualizing. His chapters on the relation of food to mind-body health are worth reading alone. I guess what I'm trying to offer you is a way to help yourself, while hopefully you also seek help from a psychologist and/or psychiatrist. You've done the necessary first step: by ruling out organic illness and defining that you have issues that require attention. Now you are at the beginning of tackling those really difficult issues to make progress to being the person you want to be. It won't be easy, but it is absolutely possible. Good luck."

174352237,"Hello! I've been newly diagnosed ""Schizoaffective Disorder: Bipolar Edition"", and I've been a little nervous to talk to anyone about it. I am receiving help, and am fairly capable of handling myself so I'm not afraid on that front. My psychiatrist says that I'm very good at managing myself, and that I was employing reframing therapy on my own already. I'm looking for long term treatment therapeutically for my experiences, but it still feels so unreal. I don't hear voices, but I sense presences (Often malicious), and experience really intense and vivid, almost intrusive imagery in my head? I've spent a fair amount of my life feeling bugs all over my body (I thought it was normal, so I didn't talk to anybody about it. That's a whole story to explain.), but more recently it's gotten really bad (I lived in an apartment for a year that was infested with bugs and had to sleep in a bed which was infested and it was just, a lot to deal with. It made me realize the sensations were completely indiscernible 
from the real thing.) which sparked me reaching out for help. The doctor approved me to try my plan for care (Talk-therapy first, and if that doesn't alleviate the bug sensations, then I'll try medicine.), but it still just feels weird to use the term ""Schizoaffective Disorder"". I always figured that you had to actually physically SEE and HEAR the hallucinations to be diagnosed with that kind of thing. The sensations of bugs are really vivid, though, so that part makes sense. I also experience delusions of grandure (Where I feel in my lil' heart of hearts that I'm a creature from outside of this reality, or that I'm famous, ect..) and delusions of paranoia where I think everyone around me hates me/is disgusted by me if they aren't explicitly being positive towards me. Even so, I know cognitively that the experiences aren't real, and it's just very exhausting emotionally. It's like I've been strapped into a ride and even though I know I won't fall off, the twists and turns still feel like I'm gonna fall off, 
and one part of my brain is trying to tell the other to stop screaming about it. You know? I think the bipolar portion of the diagnosis is because I sometimes have restless spells of activity where I can't, for the life of me, sleep. My brain has to Do The Thing and I end up just kind of stuck inside the passenger seat making plans to keep it from wrecking my general schedule. I guess what I'd like to ask is, was anyone else surprised to get the diagnosis? Was anyone else worried about trying to talk to other people about it? I have some solid people I'm comfortable talking about it with, and I have reached out to my circle, but it's not really a diagnosis I want to shout to the rooftops. Does my experience sound like the real deal, or is it possible that what I'm experiencing isn't Schizoaffective? I'm going to get a second opinion from my therapist when I get one (Already sent the email to my doctor, so I'm on top of my treatment plan.), but it still feels weird. I know it shows up differently for everyone, 
and it won't look the same way in two different people, but a lot of resources mention hearing voices, and I just don't hear voices. I've been reading up on it. Also, it's nice to meet everyone!"

175963157,"I may have gone on a tangent there. I'm trying to figure out if there's some possible connection between the obsessions some people with OCD face and schizotypal ""odd beliefs"" Some people may wonder if they've have hit and killed someone with their vehicle without realizing it. From there, they can work themselves into a state where they become close to convinced they actually have - and from there, they can swing over to questioning maybe they did it on purpose and they're ""morally corrupt"" Yeah, I don't fully know where I was going with that question - other than maybe someone who may have unwelcomed thoughts of brutally murdering their wife that they love, thoughts they can't fend off. As a result, maybe they question if they're evil or being possessed which, in turn, may lead to beliefs such as if they watch movies with anything occult-ish in them, it will draw evil spirits towards them and force them to actually act on those intrusive thoughts. Maybe they believe coming into contact with a
nything related to the topic of the ""supernatural"" on TV, social media, conversation, music, etc will open them up to evil because maybe they're particularly sensitive or ""open"" to it. On top of it, they decide watching TV or listening to music with any type of sex or violence also aligns them with ""evil"" And maybe then, anything with profanities, etc.. Now they've constructed a set of beliefs and things they must avoid otherwise they'll turn ""evil"" or become possessed and end up committing the violent murder of their wife that they do not want to commit. Odd beliefs? I think by moral, part of what you mean what is seen as right and what is seen as wrong by others. I'm connecting this to a filter people must have in regards to social acceptability & anchoring themselves within societal norms. Along with that, it reminds me of that theory that psychotic symptoms can come from the brain not being able to filter out and categorize as much sensory stimuli as normative people can. ""Sensory gating"" or som
ething? I'd say this is the source of genius and creativity. Then again, I don't want to acknowledge it because I think it falls in line with the ""dopamine hypothesis theory"" for psychosis which then co-signs the digustingly mass overprescribing of antipsychotics all because our systems don't want to put any real effort, resources or investment into treating people. (I'm not saying some people don't legitimately need them. I'm just saying at this stage, it's more often just a cop-out for the medical profession. I'll stop my repetitive rant here). This also makes me wonder, when you speak of things that are denied by most or go unnoticed, would the reverse side of the coin be people who are paid to present information most effectively and on different levels of consciousness? Such as news presentation, advertising, politics, etc...? As in, if you were talking about an increase of aliens in the country, a psychiatrist is likely to think you're delusional and talking about beings from outer space whilst a norm
al person will assume you're talking about illegal immigrants? Or that a psychiatrist is more apt to understand metaphorical or abstract language than a normal person? Infuriating. Most people are brainless; half of what they accept is a mistake. Extremist feminisism forces this and they use it to hide the stereotypes they themselves project. Speaking of descriptiveness, I'm currently enjoying the exploration of taking nouns and adjectives and turning them into ""-ing"" form verbs in creative expression. Makes sense. For me, a flood of emotion and information stops me from being able to speak at all sometimes. Also ineffective. I guess it must also be connected to whether or not you're willing to put the effort into making something edible enough for the primate to consume and whether you're practiced at it. ^ Being only exposed to people not worth the effort, can leave it difficult to do on the rare occasion when you actually want to. This is interesting because if I isolate for too long I have can have quit
e a hard time adapting to the wavelengths of others and being verbally lucid for the first day or so - meaning I have to stay quiet, listen a lot and keep my sentences short. You may be thinking that I'm more perceptive than I actually am. I do, however, enjoy creativity and trying to understand complex and novel things. As I always say, best for humanity to be eradicated. Although, I'm uncertain of how comfortable I am in the idea that I'm asking a starving polar bear to come out of the water so I can ask it questions. Speaking of which, do polar bears normally eat primates or only fish and birds? Do they normally only eat what they catch? Or do they normally eat carrion as well? I'm wondering what meals are to you? Words? Interactions? Expressing ideas? Human connection? Or am I totally off the mark here? Thrill of the hunt? A source of nutritional value to stay alive and healthy, or...? Do you have a fixed set of vocabulary you like to stick to? Or is it adaptive and ever changing based on inspiration and 
situations? Anyone who's interacted with me knows I ask too many questions, so please feel free to ignore any or all of them."

175963188,"- Why can’t I connect emotionally to my partner? - What is this wall between me and other people? - What is it that makes me feel smothered in relationships? - Why don’t I feel lonely/miss my partner when she’s gone? - How can I explain this non-negotiable need for excessive alone time? ^The above are all broad term questions and not specific to you. I don't doubt that there has been anyone who cannot relate to it. Everyone feels the need to have their own space and relationships can be smothering. Successful relationships come with a compromise. Thinking that these thoughts are different from anyone else's thinking is most likely going to be the real problem here. If you believe your thinking is that of an outsider you will most likely feel that way or act like one as this would probably cause intense social anxiety. The worse this gets, the worse these thoughts will get and a vicious cycle will continue. So, first things first: Normalize your thinking. It's not unusual. Secondly communicate 
with those you are in a relationship with. My partner and I each have individual rooms in our place. It works out although I generally sleep in his bed. At least I have the freedom of my own space when I need it and it's not an unusual want."

175963201,"Welcome to my life! I can’t even come close to telling you crippling, terrifying, overwhelming bouts of anxiety, depression, and manic episodes I’ve had in the last 14 years. I am too struggling day to day, minute to minute with the fear of dying. I agree with _NAME_, I’m not afraid of actual death. It’s the PROCESS of dying. Heart attacks and strokes are my main fears. The fact that you KNOW you’re dying or think you’re dying is the issue with me. Like what happens when you’re seconds from death? Does it hurt? Are you aware that you’re dying ? What’s after death? These are all obsessive and intrusive thoughts. Some may call them irrational, I call them human curiosity. Some may think these thoughts once or twice in their lifetime and never really bother with them again. And then there’s us, we all have our own “type and triggers” of anxiety. I find my anxiety to be a blessing and a curse. It helps me to stay on the right track in life. But it’s also very overwhelming"

175963224,"I have an inner MP3 player. Various forms of inner mono/dialogues are sometimes there, sometimes not, but what stays consistent is that, when I'm not particularly thinking of something or focusing on something (even if I may be trying to), there's a song playing on repeat in my head. If it happens to be a song that I don't remember well, then it's maddening. Not hard to change the track though, so that much isn't particularly problematic. It's pretty common that I hear or even just think of a word (sometimes a pretty common and mundane one) and then hours later I notice that there's a song playing in my head where the chorus starts with that word, or something like that. The same happens with any type of sound. It doesn't have to be a sequence of notes, it can be a single tone. Like if there's a song that has waterdrop sounds, and I hear just one drop of water falling and it sounds specifically similar enough to me, it can easily be enough to bring that song to the forefront. It can be songs I have
n't heard or listened to in years, not uncommon. This still applies even right as I'm waking up. It's usually a song I've been listening to, but sometimes it's a totally surprising one to me. It's usually a song with some kind of ""anxious energy"", for lack of a better description. Right now it's this one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DTO3tja7uaQ This is one of the things that make it very clear to me that I really do have ADHD with a proper H. It definitely both affects and is affected by my mood, and shapes to a significant degree my sense of where I am in space and (especially) time."

175963236,"R., Only the inert compounds in a generic Rx differ from the name brand. So unless you just happen to have some reaction to part of what makes up the 'filler' component of the non brand pill (highly unlikely) you will not note a difference, as the actual medication base is the same. Try your best to trust your doctor if you decide that medication is something that you could benefit from. We are here cheering on either way you decide to go. S.C."

175963278,"I haven’t posted here in a while and I’m planning a few update journal entries but I need to collect my thoughts after the shift I had. First off I want to say that I LOVE my new job. It’s entry level but the pay is competitive and even better it’s in the medical lab field, which is exactly my wheelhouse. But today at work I was listening to my usual podcasts and I just was not retaining anything I was listening to and I didn’t want to “waste my time” listening to podcasts just to have to relisten at another date because I don’t have much patience for repetition, generally. So instead I switched to music. First I tried listening to new foreign language music with the thought that a) if I can’t understand most of the lyrics and don’t know the translation by heart already then they can’t trigger me and b) by listening to new music I was trying to reintroduce myself to pop culture that I love that I’ve withdrawn from for far too long. Didn’t work. Instead, rather than focus o
n the beats and try to see if I like a new song or not I was just flooded with intrusive thoughts. They weren’t negative thoughts so much as just... it felt like I was finally allowing myself to think about all the feelings and issues I’ve been setting to the side in favor of just surviving and getting through the day, week, month, life. In fact, some of my thoughts were tinged positive and that seemed to make me even sadder. Somehow the positive thoughts and the comforts I desperately want to hear are just making me ball uncontrollably. Just in writing that last sentence an example pops into my head and I’m sobbing now. Example: I’ve been doing so well recently and been on such an up swing all year, despite the absolute garbage fire that is the state of the world in 2020; and now I’ve had a few setbacks recently and I’m falling apart and it hurts so bad but I’m AWARE and I’m RECOGNIZING IT and I’m currently feeling a little manic-like energy, hopefully in a good way, and I’m taking action
s and making plans and trying to get out of it. And that’s progress. And that is currently making me hyperventilate-cry. I feel like I’m finally getting a handle on how to manage my depression and how to recognize when I need to get help and knowing and ACTING on the things it’s in my power to change. And somehow that progress makes me sad? I tried switching between some other new music playlists on Spotify but apparently all the new pop music is either too relatable and painful or too empowering and THAT was also making me cry harder than the pain. Finally, I relented and went back to my phones’ library of downloaded, personally curated playlists and listened to some upbeat music I know I love, and while some songs still stung, overall I was able to calm down and finish my shift without anyone approaching me to ask me if I was ok, because that would just be mortifyingly embarrassing. Thank god for masks! Maybe I should have stopped and gone home, or at least stopped and composed myself away from my d
esk. But I didn’t and I got through it. Instead I stayed at my desk. And I fought to feel my feelings. That’s right. I felt my feelings. Eventually, I just relented and allowed myself to explore all the things that were making me sad and all the options I had for fixing the small issues and setting goals to lift my spirits and remembered all the hobbies I loved and want to start practicing. So yeah I just had a very emotional shift of work where I sat at my desk entering data like a drone on autopilot while in my head and body I was feeling all the feelings and feeling empowered and inspired, all the while crying as silently as I could and simultaneously hoping that I did and did not get caught having a breakdown by my coworkers. I left work quickly after I was all done and then immediately parked in a neighboring parking lot to send my brother a message thanking him for his Xmas gift to me. After all that I just really felt the need to practice some gratitude in the hopes of lifting someone else up. Beca
use I just did not feel good and I wanted to make someone I love dearly feel better than I feel right now."

174352554,"I was diagnosed with ""Psychosis NOS"" about 5 years ago. To be honest, I don't really fit into any category very well. I truly believe that unidentified people have been monitoring me for a long time. In my mind, I have a lot of circumstantial evidence (no smoking gun). The rest of the details don't matter too much, but honestly the entire ""delusion"" is plausible (but highly unlikely). Its not impossible, and they are interpretations of factual events. I have no other symptoms of schizophrenia. I'm so traumatized by people telling me that I'm ""misinterpreting"" situations. Its been the focus on my therapy for 8 years. And its what (very well-intentioned) friends have been telling me forever. I no longer trust my own thoughts and opinions. And I don't feel comfortable asking for help anymore... people are just going to judge me and make me feel responsible for things that are outside of my control. Its traumatizing to be repeatedly told that your own opinions and intuition and knowledge are a bu
nch of ""thought distortions"". I get that everyone is trying to help. I don't blame anyone. But, here I am, feeling completely trapped, and I don't know what to do. I was seeing a therapist. I told her upfront that I needed someone to accept my experience as ""Reality"". I guess she thought that she could change my mind. Finally, she told me that we couldn't talk about my experiences anymore. So, I had to quit. I'm not a fragile person. I wasn't overly attached to her. I'll find another therapist. But its so frustrating. This is exactly how my family handled the situation. We just couldn't talk about it. And my sister said she needed boundaries. But my experience is a huge part of my life. So what do I talk about with them? Does anyone have any recommendations for finding a therapist that is experienced with people diagnosed with delusions? 175963356,"I’m a 77yo guy, 10 years retired from IT, conventional work and family history, divorced for 19 years after 22 year marriage, miscellaneous relationships since divorce but have given up looking for an intimate relationship as I’ve finally accepted that I can’t honestly offer a potential partner any hope of a heart connection. I started a writing course this year. One of the assignments allowed me to write a Personal Essay, a recognised genre in nonfiction writing. I chose the topic of “Indifference” and set an essay scope of: my adult lifelong indifference/apathy, society’s attitude to individual and group indifference, scientific and medical takes on indifference and two fictional portrayals of characters exhibiting strong indifference. While researching the medical-scientific conditions that have indifference as a symptom, I re-visited Schizoid Personality Disorder (SPD), a diagnosis which I, and a couple of therapists, had previously considered. We rejected the diagnosis because I ha
ve been, for all my adult life, socially available, interested, and engaged. I have behaved as an outwardly “normal” husband, father, grandfather, lover and friend. And then I came across the sub-category of “secret schizoid”, a schizoid who functions “normally” by complying with expectations and playing a part in which their personality is not involved. Though I’ve yet to get this self-diagnosis confirmed professionally, it feels right. I feel enlightened, knowable and validated. Though it’s satisfying and a relief to acquire a “label”, to receive a diagnosis, it unavoidably raises the question “What now?”. I think I have three options: 1. Business as usual 2. “Come out” 3. Try and change Option 1: Business as usual. I know I am an impostor. I behave socially as though I have normal feelings. Nobody (except my ex-wife) has ever challenged the falseness of my behaviour given my underlying lack of feelings. There may be other people – I can’t have fooled them all – who know ab
out my underlying indifference but accept my company nonetheless. Some people, probably most, don’t know about my indifference and are misled by my behaviour. Those people see me doing normal social things and assume it’s because I have normal social needs. I don’t. I do those things for other reasons: intellectual stimulation, fun, altruism, sexual desire, conflict avoidance. Funnily enough, I’m not unhappy day-to-day with how my life is going, particularly now that I have acknowledged my indifference. At least, I feel no pain or distress that needs immediate attention. I have a nagging feeling that I’ve never been part of the human race, having never known what loving and being loved feel like. And, as I approach the end of my life, I wonder how I’ll deal with a negative evaluation of my life as I look back from my deathbed. Option 2: “Come out” Come out as the unfeeling, unempathetic person that I am, decide what that means for relationships with family and friends and act on those decision
s (scary for me – possible conflict, potentially hurtful for family and friends). But least, I’d then be living honestly, authentically, no longer an impostor. Option 3: Try and change Try and change to become a feeling person. I think that will need psychedelic-assisted therapy (PAT) or something equally brain-altering. Other therapies haven’t shifted me. Getting some of the beneficial mind-bending results claimed by PAT proponents would represent the best of all outcomes available to me. If I get nowhere with PAT, I’m no worse off. There will be no bad outcomes – I will be trusting my guides to get me through any bad trip. This forum is the first context in which I’ve disclosed my new insights. I would be glad of any responses from fellow schizoids, particularly “secret ones”. Previous to registering for the forum, I searched for and found some posts mentioning “secret schizoid” but since I registered and logged in, the search facility seems to have disappeared – I’ll keep looking! I
’m looking for comments on my self-diagnosis and suggestions for therapeutic techniques that have worked for others. Thanks in advance for any interest."

175963362,"Hi. I have not been officially diagnosed with anhedonia yet, in fact until yesterday I had never heard of it. I stumbled upon the word reading these boards when i saw a message that read like i had written it. A member commented and said it sounded like anhedonia so I researched it and could put money on the chances i have been dealing with this for years. I am 49 and I would say probably since my 20's I have had this in some level of severity. I am posting here because I really need the input of others and opinions. I am not opposed to seeking talk therapy, but I do like to know what I am seeking therapy for due to my past experiences with therapists. But I do have a very good relationship with my pdoc so if it is something medication can help there is no problem. First of all, I read the definition of anhedonia and it stated it is the inability to feel pleasure. I take it a step farther, I really dont feel any emotion. By reading posts here I see that is not unusual so i think so far i am in the 
right place. The whole thing is I dont feel bad. I am not sad. I have been blah in the past for years but that lifted about 6 months ago and i feel ok. I just cant do anything. I feel internally paralyzed. (i do suffer from anxiety and have wondered if it is my anxiety disorder doing this..but i think they are all linked) I can smile and laugh at tv shows but i feel like I fit the criteria for depression because there is no joy. Even when I see my grandbabies, the lights of my life I dont feel like I am emotionally at the level of normal. I dont get mad, I have no passion for anything in life, no motivation all the while I crave change. I am logical now with emotional things it feels phony. I am a genuine person i dont like to be fake but I cannot get excited when i supposed to or cry when i am supposed to, even if i want to cry. w if that makes sense. This has really become a problem in the last six years since i am unable to orgasm now. This creates a whole new set of problems for me and my husband because my sex drive has died. Another thing I noticed about the reward center of my brain is now when i smoke pot i dont get high, maybe 2 percent of the time if it is extremely potent weed...If I drink i dont feel drunk, no more getting tipsy. I get the physical affects of alcohol when i have too much beer, my speech will slur, i might tip over slightly but i feel no high and on two occasions i took shroomshad no trip. 175963388,"Maybe. It seems like a mostly descriptive list of features anyway. I don't know where it came from, but my guess is that it was invented by someone who had a theory about statistical links and causation and stuff, and wanted a separate category that would suit their surveys / research. If you mean that as an extension of your agreeing with me, then I think you missed my point. Everyone , without exception, will cling to (or at least passively stick to) some type of nonsense or other until $#%^ hits the fan. The difference between different people will be a matter of degree and circumstance, not a matter of ""some do it, others don't"". Belief is the necessary scaffolding for sane thought. Now here I bring back the word I just used: scaffolding. It's belief as a foundation that's dangerous and harmful. Religion per se is fine (as long as it leaves me alone). Dogmatism is not (and it doesn't even matter if it's religious or not). I don't see a difference between militant atheism and militant religion
. Or militant politics, for that matter. Potayto, potahto. I suppose you're implying that those people are dumb because of that? I don't get it. I mean, I like my recliner better than the floor, because it's more comfortable. ""Of course it is. It's a recliner."" I can't speak for anyone else, but I fear death, and those aren't the things (or the types of things) that I fear about it. I just fear... death. Death is bad. It's to be avoided. I want to keep existing. That's about it. Oh I've heard of that one. How is it different from a creator god though? It doesn't change anything other than narrative flavor. It's just a more ""sci-fi"" way to anthropomorphize the unknowable. It's no different from old-fashioned mythologies (monotheistic ones included). Religion isn't about belief though, it's all about social cohesion. If it's not, then it's not religion. Not necessarily. Again, the actual problem is dogmatism (or fundamentalism), not religion itself. I was raised under a specifically Catholic mindset, but I 
was always taught that no religion was fundamentally wrong just for being a different religion. My parents can be passive-aggressive about a lot of things, but I can tell that they actually don't mind and don't care that I don't have a religion and that I openly dislike and dismiss the very idea of religion. It's ""my thing"", and religion is theirs. This used to be the dominant attitude and mindset around here until very recently. It baffles me to no end how it changed so quickly and so drastically. Wait, what about Hindus? If they don't count as ""pagans"" from a Muslim point of view, then who does? Some people believe in their religion. Most are probably just members of it, and proclaiming and (at least publicly) adhering to a certain set of beliefs is just a formal requirement for membership. It's that membership that they care about. And on the other side of things, the pope doesn't care if you sin. He does care if you sin and then insist publicly that you were right in doing so. Because then you're brea
king or challenging the intended social cohesion. Fundamentalists though... They're beyond my understanding. Dismissing them as ""dumb"" and ""weak"" is clearly a mistake though."
