175963423,"Mtinside: Nope You Can NOT give up! I say from honesty, no IT's just not an option, ""because"" you haven't discovered what is on the other side of this problematic dark wall yet you keep hitting! You see, you Do have the ability to survive this! It will take a few adjustment, reset your thinking & hopes towards thinking forward. I'll explain further... Hitting Bottom Is one of the most difficult experiences anyone could ever experience! Not many understand what it is like to struggle, trying to keep ones head above water ...when it truly ""feels"" as though as if every circumstance keep knocking backwards, or as if you've tapped out every possible resource you thought possible. I compare it to much like struggling to keep ones head above water because it seems it takes every bit of energy to try to stay a float, but still treading water and it gets exhausting. Then just as you think things calm down for a moment, then is seems as if you keep getting yanked back under, just as you manage to gasping 
for a breath of fresh air. This air representing catching a break to just get through the next moment or day? Also hope or help a person pursues reaching out for proactive help through proper channels, medical professionals, etc. Especially more difficult when it might seem they are not taking you seriously, are forgetful or just not as proactive as you'd hope they'd be. *Depression, PTSD, anxiety, loss, are difficult and can become crippling. It may be easy for people to give advice, medical opinion, or guidance, but what they are not aware of is that people in these stages are asking for someone to step in and literally help navigate one through these situations because when a person is drained, crippled, shutdown, they are weakened, it takes maybe just one unselfish, kinda and truly concerned person to reach in and ask, ""How can I help you through this moment?"" Secondary to this they need to sincerely follow through! When experiencing these roughest of times, a person reaches out for help, guidance, and 
sincerely want to make healthy choices, get back on a path towards better days aead an thrive verses being stuck in the victim/survival mode which is so very exhausting. Trying to pull yourself up to the next level, to a safer zone, but frustrated because it can feel much like a person isn't able to get their footing, only to stumble, scrape our knees & elbows trying. Or as if grabbing at the air becasue a consistent helpful hand is not available. When a person is unable to swim and begin to drown. they kick, struggle, pull at anything and anyone around them hoping to help feed their survival. Consumed by the weight of the stressors, we fear we will have so much more difficulty, that we'll end up sinking deep under the surface. Hoping someone will at least throw a rope or some sort of life saving raft to help keep us a float. The key point to these analogies is your lives shouldn't have to be where we end up stuck in victim/survival modes. No one wants to be in such a dark and bewildering places during their 
lives. In fact there is a constant resonating instinct to struggle becasue....""Deep down inside, you know the there IS a reason why ""You Are Still Here On Earth"" regardless of how difficult the battle may be. There IS a reason you are Existing, fighting for your own life! The thought you hold onto is You want to know the positive outcome after difficult struggles. You forward your thinking towards the near future, keep asking & keep pursuing for ...""What IS' on the other side of this wall?"" and this will help your mind and brain t pursue further. I share with you something helpful. Something that helped not only myself but many others out here in Inspire.com & beyond! No more keeping past sad or negative happenings or event as if there are on a calendar or count-down clock. There is nothing to gain from keeping up with these events. Reflection is helpful in minimal lengths of time, but should be mostly because ""you WANT To Move Beyond life experiences. Not keep them anchored to to drag around with us, l
ike a cannon-ball & chains. They are not that which makes us WHO we are. It will be helpful to No longer keep count the past time frames regarding when terrible events occurred. she perceives I did she gets triggered, This can be something as simple as a misconstrued text message. When I think of it through it appears too ludicrous to warrant such behavior. Once she gets an idea in her head, she is like a bulldog dug in a _USER_ID_ of war. She can shut you out as if you never existed. Interestingly there also seems to be a cyclical, seasonal pattern to her behavior as well. Every early to mid-spring, she can get triggered over god knows what, and will blow this up in her mind to the point of she wants a divorce ... so remaining calm and giving her some space after a few months she seems to return to ""center."" The particular pattern has existed since I have known her (10 years). From many of our conversations, I have detected this pattern existed in other relationships- however, she refused to acknowledge the pattern. es this privately. She is hypersensitive to any form of perceived criticism --even if solicited. That sequence may be fast-moving and unexpected, but it's still one thing at a time, each one evoking the next. 175963506,"I've found the Melatonin works, also. It's sold at health food stores, drug stores, groceries in health section, maybe. I take 4 of the 1 mg., an hour before bedtime, so it has some time to take effect. Some people take it 2 or more hours before bedtime. Now I also have medicine for my bipolar (Lithium for mania and Mirtazapine antidepressant) so just taking 4 Melatonin at bedtime wouldn't put me to sleep if I didn't have the other meds. An hour later, at bedtime, I take a 5th Melatonin. If I go to bed at midnight and I wake up at about 4 or 5 a.m. and it looks like I'm not going back to sleep, I can take a 6th Melatonin. My psychiatrist says none of the health foods have been tested, like medicine has, and she doesn't like them. But I don't like taking sleeping pills, so a health food pill sounds better to me. I buy the 1 mg. size so I can alter how many I take. I find a heating pad can also help me go to sleep."

me so boss' always love me. Anyway, I think most people just don't have the courage to be sad. They think being positive and happy 100% of the time is the goal. I think it's stupid. They only get sad when they don't have a choice, when they lose someone or something really bad happens. And they don't know how to deal because they don't know how to be sad... If there was no fear of death, if there were no anxiety, if there were only happiness, we probably wouldn't be typing on computers. We'd probably still be single cell organisms because hey, life is good. Just be you, it's ok. You don't need to fit in the perfect script that people seem to want you to fit in."
175963566,"Andwes, There is a direct mind/gut connection making nausea a very comman anxiety symptom! It is actually the earliest manifestation of stress, with children as young as toddlers experiencing tummy aches due to emotional upset. That is not to say that adults don't also experience anxious stomach issues...quite the contrary! Many people suffer with a wide range of digestive issues due to mood. You may want to try the simple remedy of an otc antacid. High stomach acid brought on by stress will cause nausea. I've had good results with this in the past. Peace and progress! S.C."

175963571,"The cognitive effects that can happen with dissociative drugs (Ketamine for example are focus suppression, introspection, memory suppression, personal bias suppression, spatial disorientation, suggestibility enhancement, thought deceleration, time distortion, cognitive and physical disconnection, existential self-realization, identity alteration. You could be having depersonalization and derealization (Dissociation). It can last from an hour to a week or more. A benzo would help to get you out of it if you're also feeling anxious because of it. Seroquel or olanzepine can help too."

The extra or too big of holes causing information to become jumbled - but also when managed, a point of creative genius. ^ Problems with ""Sensory Gating"" where people with psychotic disorders are believed to not always be able to tune out or categorize information from the environment and their rel
ationship to the overload of incoming information (internal and external). The role it (""dopamine hypothesis theory"") is claimed that dopamine plays a part in, is the more dopamine you have, the faster one's neurons are firing off and the more sensitive to input the brain is and the more likely sensory input is to be miscatagorized. I find this interesting on another tangent because it may apply to different ""languages"" of causation and thus treatment. I was watching something on ADHD where the doctor was talking about how addressing the proper workings of points a, b, and c, would actually have the same effect as treating the kid based on brain chemistry aka drugging the $#%^ out of them. ng taught or conditioned? Is it doing what you've been conditioned to do without not fully connecting why and then being expected to use it transferably. 175963674,"Yes, thanks for keeping us up to date. I've been in some turbulent situations, also, and didn't have a whole lot of help with it, so I know how tough that can be. You said earlier she was on ""both Olanzapine and Valproate"" with the first being an anti-psychotic and the second used to treat seizures. As an amateur, I don't see any anti-depressant there or a mood stabilizer like Lithium which is what I take. I don't see anything to treat depression or mania. I was given an anti-psychotic (which is sometimes used to treat bipolar I've read and experienced). It was called ""Stelizine"" (sp?) It's an old style anti-psychotic, and the newer ones are supposed to be less severe. It gave me panic attacks and was supposed to be treating my mania and my depression. I heard in some countries, they use it for torture. It took away my severe anger that I was in, but it also stripped me of all other emotions including good. So, when you say, ""her mood was very stable when she was on the anti-psychotic (Olanzap
ine) but she was more like a zombie who couldn't feel much"" I kinda want to jump up and down. That's exactly how I felt on Stelazine anti-psychotic. It was torture. I had no emotions. To think they are still giving that medicine decades later after I had that and still having the same results is impossible for me to believe. Now, it must work for some people for from time to time here people who are bipolar say they are on an anti-psychotic. I know someone who was given Stelazine because he was so angry so much, but it wasn't the first medicine they gave him, but only when all else had failed. But that's my guess as to why she felt like a zombie on an anti-psychotic. You can look up the side affects of that medicine by typing in the name on the search engine. You said, ""...just curious why you say I'm in a precarious position...? As in lifetime of uncertainty perhaps...?"" One reason I said that is, the way you described your wife: “A few days ago (and over the course of a few days developing), she starte
d to have mood changes, being suddenly energetic, suddenly lethargic, having impaired judgment, hearing voices, not sleeping at all for a few days, grand ideas about getting a new place and applying for new jobs, not being able to focus (blank stare), withdrawing from me and our activities totally, fingers twitching every few seconds, suddenly bursting into tears, irrational fear of dust mites and seeing black shadows in the room. PHEW I think that's about it. ” With the doctor's help, she had dropped the anti-psychotic and was only on the other medicine and did OK for a year, you said. Well, she's obviously not on the right medicine if she's acting the way you described above, and now nobody even knows where she is. The second reason I said you were in a precarious position is, from looking at the net, it is saying psychiatric care in your part of the world is not the best. I have seen many a bad psychiatrist, but for your wife to be acting like she is and now she is missing, tells me she is not on the rig
ht medicine. She may not have been diagnosed right. Was she depressed a lot, and then manic, mind racing, trouble sleeping, couldn't concentrate? (You can look up the symptoms on the net by typing in ""bipolar"" on the search engine. Looking at that, do you think she's bipolar?) That's why I said you're in a precarious position. Even when she's at the doctor's, she may not be getting good help. Tell me what you think her diagnosis is, as far as being bipolar, then look at the suggested medicines for that, and see if you think she was getting the right meds."

Get up, get breakfast, make sure I already have my drinks cold and ready, sit down, play my creative playlist, and move my pen, or just read (i still hold my pen even when I read), the earlier the better, by 11am if possible. I lament though, because I don't commit to many things, like the basics of hygiene, and cleaning my room and bathroom, but I have small wins with my creativity, and I feel like those will outlast my life, at least I hope. Things you want to do, versus things your heart desires in life. I understand that I'm deeply ill and flawed, so I look over the small stuff, and focus on what my heart desires, because without those, i fear my life would be empty. Fear has been one of my greatest motivators in life."

175963694,"Hi! I've not been on the forum posting much anymore due to coping well with PD and life in general. When i read your story, freaking similar to what i experienced. Other than the country and occupation, i was also jolted awake one day in 2015 feeling the exact same issues that you did, yet somehow being able to cycle to the nearest hospital in my town in japan. I just graduated from post grad and felt that i was wasting my time still hanging around in japan, aka no money/income and feeling bad. Fast forward, turning up on HW forums, reading stuff, writing journal entries, meditation helped me alot. I would get that heart pumping thingy and can't be able to sleep(Yes, it is horrible), but since my mom sent me a buddhist chanting song, I just had it on my earphones in a soft volume and practiced meditation. Honestly, i had no avenue or didn't know where to get help other than HW and it was horrible. 1 Year down, I'm back in Singapore, feeling all strange and having light sensitivity, depersonalizatio
n at times, feeling that theres a glossy vision and getting random mild panics. Though I've only gotten 2 full blown Panic attacks 1 in Japan 1 in Malaysia, I can relate to your random mindblowing mild panic symptoms. Now in 2020, i'm almost 80-90% fine. Realised that the triggers to such conditions, random caffeine intake(coffee/cola) at times, but potent on an empty stomach, and usually stomach issues(gut). If my stomach is fine, i'm fine. I did go for psychological counselling in 2016 and that taught me a good range of coping techniques as well. Long story short, you'll get there. PD is pretty common. First few months to a year sucks. But keep on the road, eat healthy, decaf. Recognise the triggers will be the best. Best of health to you! I did use Xanax when i get a full blown PA in malaysia. But that's all for the drug use. After i realised the triggers I managed to get over it. And imo, 20-30mins of random PA symptoms i can still manage. Though it tires the heck outta me :P"

175963699,"I had a similar experience back when my anxiety was at its peak and I started having panic attacks. Once I got control over that, I was able to smoke again with no problem. Now many years later my son is going through exactly what's happening to you. Depending on how bad your anxiety might be, another form of medication may or may not help you. In his case, it does seem to be helping him although he is still too afraid to try weed again. He described it as similar to a terrible acid trip. What the dispensary recommended for my son was pretty much what _PERSON_ said: try a CBD:THC ratio product, maybe go with something at first that is low in THC. The indica/sativa thing is debatable but certain strains definitely work better for me and it all seems to be relative to the person. If it really helps you and you stick with it, I'm sure you can find that right blend for you. Peace my toking friend! May you be anxiety free!"
175963700,"I got disability due to OCD. It is my understanding that personality disorders do not qualify as conditions that warrant government assistance. In order to get it, you need to be seeing a mental health professional. Disability does not care to hear about your hardships. If you are deemed disabled, it is because the psychiatrist/psychologist checked off the appropriate box on the government form they were sent after you applied for disability. Also, be aware that if you begin to see someone on the basis that you ""need disability"", it may be harder to get a sufficient diagnosis. For every person on disability, there is someone looking to get it without it being warranted. If you're in the US and are talking about Social Security, most claims are denied the first time around. They know that people who are truly suffering and compromised will persist whereas fakers will have less incentive to push ahead with legal aid, which is sometimes necessary. I've been on numerous gov't assistance programs sinc
e 2006 and I can tell you that I'd rather be functional enough to earn my keep."

175963742,"I'm hoping that there might be people out there who can help me understand something that I am going through right now. I didn't know if this should've been posted in the sexual health community, but I feel like this is all tied with the feelings I'm having trying to cope with the loss of some loved ones recently. My Aunt suffered from depression and she committed suicide in March in 2019 and then in August my older brother passed away. He had Type I diabetes and just refused to take proper care of himself and eventually it caught up to him, but his loss was sudden and completely devastating to my family. I've been having a hard time with it. There are good days but there are very bad days as well. My fiance tries to be supportive of my feelings, but sometimes when I tell him that I had a bad day and was thinking about my brother he'll ask me why I was thinking about him and I have no answer for him. It's the tiniest thing things that will make me think of him, so small that sometimes I don't even 
understand what it was that caused the thoughts to start myself, but a lot of the time I don't feel like I should have to explain why so I'll keep it to myself and in a way ""suffer in silence."" I have a tendency to not talk to anyone else either as I don't want to burden them with my problems and there seems to be an acceptable window of time that people are understanding about you feeling grief, but that time frame has long since passed and people don't seem to be sympathetic anymore. About 1 1/2 months after my brothers death, my now-fiance proposed to me and I feel terrible because I've had pretty much no sex drive for a while now. I think it started gradually after my aunts death and then when my brother died it just killed all feeling of sexual desire I had left. I still crave emotional intimacy and need physical affection, but whenever he tries to get physically intimate with me I freeze up and can't bring myself to feel anything. My fiance suffers from anxiety and I know that he thinks I'm not attrac
ted to him anymore, especially because he's gained some weight over the years we've been together, but that really has nothing to do with it and I wish I could find the right words to explain what's wrong with me, but I honestly just don't know how because I don't understand it myself. I've always had a healthy libido and we used to have sex multiple times a week but now we're lucky to have sex more than once a month. Can someone explain why I've had this drastic change and how I can go about changing it? My fiance has never tried to pressure me into doing anything I don't want, but I can see the hurt in his eyes when I turn down his advances and I feel like if I can get to the root of my issues and find a way to deal with them we would both be so much happier. Any advice would be greatly appreciated!!"

175963763,"So it occurs to me that I’m very med oriented to the point where I can see people becoming more depressed or psychotic after reducing meds or changing them. I feel like in a way the meds define who we are. The med you pick as your final med can change your very personality, how ambitious you are, how sad, how able to work or not. There is a continuum between medicine and illness though. A lot of people want to be off meds entirely but then they often become more ill, and the illness dominates them. But then they are their true self for better or worse. People are all different so where in the continuum between meds and illness do you see yourself? I’m asking this because I don’t want to promote meds as the perfect solution for everyone if they aren’t. Let’s say pro meds is 1........and 10 is no meds with the normal range in between. Where do you lie on that range? I realize that for some meds don’t work, but this q is directed at people that they work for at least partially."

175963768,"Ok. So I have been going through a lot of stress trying to bring myself to a decision that would determine the course of the rest of my life. Should I give him a second chance? I dated my ex for 3 yrs while we were still in our early 20s him being 2 yrs older. I’d like to believe we were young and dumb and because of that we both have the potential to evolve and change. He was abusive(not to the point of serious harm but still hit me sometimes and made me feel powerless). He grew up in the street( sometimes ppl have no other choice) and was and still is very good at communicating with anyone, very persuasive and can mentally understand everyone he came across. I guess you can say a mind fuk psychological genius. That’s one of the reasons I loved him so much. He was unlike anyone I ever knew. Things like that can’t be taught but only learned by circumstance. Anyways although he couldn’t support us financially he is a go-getter and where ever I fell short in money, he would go hustle and help 
make ends meet. He had my back. And despite some emotional and mental pain, he made me stronger. Taught me things I would never have learned. Toughened me up mentally and physically. We also had a lot of fun together. We connected on a level that is nearly impossible to reciprocate. Naturally though a part of me was growing tired and wanted to get away from it all. So when he went to jail for 5 yrs(petty crime trying to provide for us-broken justice system), I found my escape opportunity. Still though I couldn’t let go. I still accepted his jail calls and he still makes my heart melt. I’ve tried to convince myself to move on but I can’t. I can hear the changes he has made mentally. The way he speaks, the way his thought process works, the way he has ambitions now have all elevated from being locked up and confined to nothing but his own mind. It sounds like he is no longer this little boy drug dealer but a man who is hungry for success because of where he has been and what he has learned. He still loves 
me and will always love me and he is begging for me to give him a second chance to show me that he can be the man I deserve. I can’t even count how many apologies and vulnerability speeches he has given. Of course actions speak louder than words but should someone like this deserve a 2nd chance even if the memory of pain will always be there. Is it possible to fully heal from the past and allow him to reconstruct a better future. A part of me wants to let go because of what he did but a part of me also does not want to give the next woman a rare diamond that my pressure and pain helped craft. Yes I still love him and to this day he is the only person that truest understands me mentally and can elevate me to my highest growth. Do I deserve a more subtle relationship with someone else. Has our relationship been tainted beyond repair? I just don’t know what to do. Have I given to many sacrifices to give anymore? What are your thought?"

175963812,"Recovering from serious mental health issues is never a smooth process. And it takes time. Psychotherapy is a slow process, and therapists know this. They don't expect their clients to get a lot better overnight. And they know their clients won't recover smoothly either. Hitting ruts/walls while trying to recover is normal."

175963839,"When I think about shame I think about my early childhood. I was reprimanded a lot for my behavior which I mostly attribute to my mental illness. As a child, being Bipolar II can result in not necessarily odd behavior but hints of mania that opens the door to be shut down. I wasn’t made to think I was “bad” or anything but the harsh discipline my parents imposed led to feelings of shame. As an adult I still carry shame with me. Given certain situations usually I automatically think I am wrong, or overstate the word sorry when I’m not at fault, and that is a ramification of internal shame. It has weighed heavily on my shoulders and only now at 42-years-old, I am starting to work on recognizing that feeling and try and push it away. It’s a challenge cause since it was formed at such a young age, it’s almost ingrained in me or a part of my personality and I don’t even know if you can change a personality. You can work on behaviors but when shame is intrinsic to your being it’s a strugg
le. I have to make a conscious effort to stop myself when feelings of shame surface, and examine the situation that brings forth feelings of shame to try and circumvent that feeling. It can be something minor like I hear a harsh tone of someone’s voice and it becomes a trigger for shame which stems from recalling my father’s harsh tone when reprimanding me. Or someone says, “We need to talk.” I’ll immediately think something is wrong, and whatever it is, it’s my fault. It’s wild to think I have spent a lifetime lingering in shame and only now am I starting to understand to fathom it, and want to do the hard work to try and diminish it. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/manic-depression/2019/06/30/shame-on-you-shame-on-me/"

The search was whether human nature is ""good"" or ""evil"" rather than honesty. I liked it more than his famous book, The Alchemist. I found it good timing because I'd had a drug-induced psychotic break back when I was 19 and I ended up experiencing auditory hallucinations with the onset of them waking me up in the middle of the night in the psychward commanding that I preform an act of violence that isn't at all in my nature. I got up to do it, but stopped myself and it was a battle within myself that ended in my requesting the psych nurse to put me in the lock up room. 175963867,Sit on a chair or sofa and plant your feet firmly on the ground in front of you. Close your eyes. Imagine that you are growing roots out of the bottom of your feet like a tree and that you are sending them deep into the ground. Sit still and continue to imagine these deep roots as you breathe deeply. This should bring you back to center and ground you.

175963932,"Yeah 2mg is like a ""Xanny bar"". 0.5-1.5mg for me kills my worst panic attacks. That's all I need. I take 0.25mg for rare anxiety states or to help me sleep. Psychiatry has no knowledge of harm reduction in using meds and addiction centres have no knowledge about it either (Because people are going to use drugs no matter what - Nothing is 100% safe). 174353506,doc checked clozapine plasma levels and they're within range
175963983,"This is a common symptom for people with severe, chronic anxiety/fatigue/insomnia. It sounds like it might be a ""visual aura"" (also called visual migraine), which definitely plays games with your vision (i.e., cause optical illusions that aren't there or the result of eye disease) but, thankfully, is very brief in duration. Many people race to the doctor and end up getting ""normal"" vision exams/MRIs, reassuring that eye diseases or stroke aren't the causes. Visual migraines are often painless, but a slight headache can also precede or follow it. Thankfully, it's only happened to me 3 times before in life--usually when I had a previous bad night's sleep or bad/stressful day. At first I freaked out, raced to the eye doctor. Now I know if I get it, if I just lay down for a few minutes, close my eyes, and rest, it will be gone in a few seconds. Here is a link you might find helpful: https://www.brighamandwomens.org/neurology/neuro-ophthalmology/visual-migraine 12345"

174353535,"""Saccadic eye movements and their neurological control signals change significantly as the human fatigues. Electronic instrumentation with a band-width extending from DC to 1 kHz enabled the recording of anomalous looking saccadic eye movements that occurred as the subject's physiological state changed. Fatigue can produce: overlapping saccades in which the high-frequency saccadic bursts should show large pauses; glissades in which the high-frequency bursts should be much shorter than appropriate for the size of the intended saccades; and low-velocity, long-duration, non-Main Sequence saccades in which the motoneuronal bursts should be of lower frequency and longer duration than normal. As few as 30 saccades of 50 deg magnitude or a longer sequence of saccades as small as 10 deg can produce these aberrant eye movements and their concomitant neuronal firing pattern variations. The effects of fatigue could explain some of the variations between and spread within published data for velocity vs amplit
ude of human saccadic eye movements. Measuring the resistance to eye movement fatigue could become either a common clinical tool for diagnosing specific or general disease states, or a research tool for studying dyslexia or fatigue."" So I'm fatigued when it happens? Well duh. It happened when Vyvanse wore off.. But there's also a lot of psychological issues too like lack of focus - And people with ADHD tend to have these movements, analysis suppression, etc.. Ah nvm I'll come back to this later. I'm gonna talk to my doctor and an optometrist because it's not normal to be re-focusing 50 times a second during a panic attack no? More on this; ""The discriminant analysis resulted in three eye movement measures; the scanpath length during the free viewing test, the horizontal position gain during the fast _PERSON_ paradigm of the smooth pursuit test, and the duration of fixations during the far distractor paradigm of the fixation stability test. An integrated score using these variables can distinguish patients w
ith schizophrenia from healthy controls with 82% accuracy."" ""Eye movements reveal a dissociation between memory encoding and retrieval in adults with autism"""

175964029,"I agree. We learn behaviour based on reward. People are rewarded for their close relationships by reciprocation, which starts at day one as a baby. If someone hasn't had that reciprocation, then they have no in-built desire to repeat the behaviour because they've not been conditioned to expect a reward. It can be learned later, but it's much harder. People say it's about trust, but it's not trust; it's familiar expectation."

175964048,Hi Welcome to the forum. Lexapro is a good medication it's the strongest of the SSRI medications and is very activating so it's best to take it first thing in the morning. 10mg is the target dose for anxiety disorders and it can take between 6-8 weeks to fully kick in and the first few weeks can be rough whilst you are getting used to the medication. Any start up side effects usually settle within a couple of weeks so stick with it and you should see some improvements. I used to take it and found it really effective on both anxiety and depression and I did not get many side effects so I hope it works well for you so keep us posted. It's important to remember that antidepressants will not cure you they will only help ease your symptoms so it's important to combine them with self help we have some good links in our resources section so take a look. I would also speak with your doctor about getting a referral for talking therapy such as CBT as this is very effective probably more so than medication. I 
am pleased you have found us you will find good support here from others who can relate to what you are going through. _PERSON_.

174353591,"16-30 are when symptoms usually develop. My negative symptoms (Anhedonia, apathy, lack of motivation) started when I was 12 and positive symptoms (Including hearing voices, delusions, paranoia) started when I was 16. The most common percentage of cases that otherwise happen aren't childhood schizophrenia (Because that's very rare) but instead, after age 30. Diagnoses overlap each other so if your symptoms are interfering with your life to the point where you can't function, you should see a psychiatrist who will monitor you for a few months to a year or more to make the correct decisions of med treatment. It's important to see a psychologist/therapist and make sure you're eating right, exercising, have a good quality of life with support, meaning, a good environment, etc.."

175964067,"I have, for as long as I can remember, been able to explain how I feel. I was told I had good insight. Even when talking about other people that I know, I show insight. I have bpd. And am very empathetic. I feel others feelings... before even they do at times. I may even understand why I feel the way I feel. 175964068,_PERSON_ - Sing for the Moment
175964069,"_USER_ID_: It sounds as if you've got your wits about you since you're questioning your marriage. That's more than I've seen from a lot of people who post here with similar questions. However it seems that, in your situation, both of you have a lot of your cards on the table. Understanding each other and being honest will make whatever you and he are destined for a lot easier on you, emotionally speaking. There doesn't seem to be anything to do at this point than to compromise. If he agreed to therapy would that be enough for you? Therapy can do only so much for a schizoid, or any personality disordered person. You both run the risk of reaching some kind of breaking point. Is it worth it to you? Is he a one-in-a-million type of guy? I'll stop here because I can't possibly even pretend to be able to put myself in your shoes and I don't want to steer you wrong. Reading on may help... I've always believed that love makes people a little ignorant and blind to what they don't want to see. Of course this 
can work the opposite way; being overly paranoid and clingy due to insecurity, but in this case, that kind of clingy paranoia tends to define the problems in a relationship. Histrionic behavior always overshadows the kind of schizoid apathy/avoidance we are discussing here. Anyway, the ignorance I was talking about above also extends to all the facets of a relationship that lead to love. Courtship, for example. The empath has an innate need for romantic companionship, so he or she will unconsciously overlook the little signs that their schizoid partner is not as enthusiastic. (""diminish some details"" as _USER_ID_ put it) This is how I got away with it. They make it easy. I can't speak for the people who have in the past claim to have fallen in love with me, but I suspect there has been a sort of blind hopefulness and a will to control: ""He'll come around"", or more simply put in pop music terms: ""I will make him love me."" So how do they express this? By being accommodating. By letting me dictate the term
s of our time spent together. By giving me gifts. I figure if I'm already involved in some kind of courtship, why not go ""full-on shallow"" and try to manipulate more out of them? It's like: damn! this relationship shlt is so easy! I just stand here and get complimented and people buy me dinner! This is not to say there was never any neediness on my part; no matter how secure I am in the belief of my emotional unavailability, there is always the belief that maybe this time will be different. Being treated well further clouded my judgement. But all of this falls apart the minute that ridiculous four letter L-word is first mentioned. It's as if it's some sacred incantation. Once it's said, any non-compliance on my part suddenly makes me the bad guy. The heartless one. I am accused of letting them on. By this time, it does me no good to remind them that they blithely ignored all the warning signs: my emotional aloofness, resisting eye contact, never instigating any kind of non-sexual affection. And sex makes it 
all the more complicated. To me, the sex was good because they were basically just another trick I could tolerate outside of bed. To them, the sex was my way of communicating the emotion I couldn't express verbally. By this point, the whole thing is a great big ugly confusing mess. It implodes. The end. I watch TV alone on my couch while they sit home and cry in the dark. I do feel guilty, but only in a cognitive sense. I have no choice. It sucks."

175964096,"I think the whole thing about it ""stemming from defense mechanisms"" and such just doesn't apply to me. To me the root of it is more simple and fundamental. I always see it as a parallel to my inability to ""see in 3D"" (stereoscopic vision). It's a subtle thing, and it can go unnoticed for a long time, but it can have deeper implications, and ultimately it's a sense that I just don't have. Going to a social gathering is like going to a screening of a 3D movie. The whole purpose of the activity is lost on me, all I get from it is the higher ticket price and the inconvenience of the (allegedly-3D) glasses I have to wear and the uncomfortably dim and/or doubled image on the screen. I can squint as hard as I want, I'll never get why everyone else in the theater seems so amazed. And the same principle applies to everything in my life to some degree or another. Here's a really long sciency text about it for those who might be into it: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6491888/"

175964101,"Apart from the fact that attempted suicide is a criminal act, I understand your thought processes to some extent. I’m sure you’re fed up with well-wishers and folks who insist you have your life ahead of you, etc. The reality is this: your headspace is broken and it’s not your fault. Repeat after me: “it’s not my fault.” Put that on auto playback. When I read posts like yours, I try to remind myself to listen and respond with empathy. My first thought is that you’re not as fragile as you think. When I reach the point where I see only one way out of the pain, it’s because I closed my eyes to the world. I want grand changes and spontaneous solutions because one group says these are the best years of my life; the other, my best years are yet to come. No wonder you don’t know if you’re coming or going. You’re not fragile bc you came here. Fragile people succeed with suicide. And there’s no do-overs for them. You’re not fragile bc despite the soul-crushing despair, you asked fo
r help. Now click this link and get the help you’re looking for. https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/"

They were in their own leagues compared to anyone at Harvard or Vanderbilt. So... 175964160,"I don't crave the types of relationships that actually exist. I crave the unattainable ideal of a relationship where I won't constantly have to _USER_ID_ what I say because the first 12 thoughts that run through my head would take too long to explain. Human beings, when they're trying to create intimacy, often fall back on what is almost universal, things like -- enjoying your family and, you know, doing things together. And ...bless them... they try so hard, but it's like trying to squeeze blood from a rock. And then I have volumes of thoughts on whatever obscure thing I'm currently into but no one has heard of. I guess it's a type of existential loneliness, the idea that the things that you think about are things that no one else is thinking about, and the things that everyone thinks about are things you never think about."

175964163,"One of my very intelligent, very educated family members once said to me “people who have started doing better won’t as often go to post on those online forums “ This is a wonderful place to post and for people to connect! However, it is true that once treatment has started to really work and you have begun to feel better .... you are less attracted to post on these forums. I say this, because I want to communicate that people who have become better may not come here to share that they’ve greatly improved. Sometime these forums can seem like only bad news from folks. Important news none the less! I don’t mean to say this forum is not wonderfully valuable. What I want to communicate, though, is that you also can become better and you can get offline. Relief from this monster called anxiety and panic is possible! I am posting here again for the first time in about two years. I don’t know what _NAME_ me here tonight, but this form was a place I frequented weekly years ago. I was so despera
te for answers. So desperate to know that someone beat it..... I am a thirtysomething-year-old guy. Out of nowhere I began to suffer from panic attacks and very bad anxiety. It seemed to rule my life and it was incredibly upsetting how often I would have dramatic instances of high anxiety. I thought that my life would forever more be ruled by panic and anxiety moments. I was crushed inside thinking my life was forever darkened by this. My doctor prescribed me Prozac and also time released Xanax. I take them at night. 2 years in ..... I am 80% better! This isn’t to say that I don’t have moments of anxiety. Especially, health related anxiety. I also have anxiety when I travel away from the state I live in long distances. However, I push myself to do these things because I know the discomfort is important to feel and that once I get to where I am going I will realize that absolutely nothing what actually happened to me that I may have anxiety about . I talk to myself and say “NO you are totally ok” , bec
ause that really is the truth of the matter. When you know panic and anxiety cannot do any harm to you, you begin to control it — not it control you. I simply wanted to come back here to encourage you (and myself) to keep seeking to get better. I remember as a new anxiety sufferer that I was so hopeless. There is no reason to feel that. This can ENORMOUSLY improve. Please know that."

175964277,"I don't know if I would definitively say that I have this as I do not have a diagnosis, but I certainly relate to it. I am unable to visualize most things in my mind; there have been times during which I have been unable to imagine my own face even though I knew what I looked like in general. I also have an elaborate fantasy life, but faces and often even bodies are abstract to the point where I have to spend hours writing their physical characteristics so that I don't forget. I mainly focus on the ""characters'"" personalities and interactions, which is easy for me despite my general inability to visualize their bodies. When I read books, watch movies, dream, or become extremely focused on a lecture or talk, physical characteristics of even pictures or humans right in front of me become equally as abstract. This sounds strange, but I don't notice that it's happening until later when I try to recall anything visual and I can only remember general concepts or occurrences. It can be quite irritating 
at times."

175964309,"I don't recommend phenibut cuz tolerance builds fast and withdrawal is 10x apathy. I've been tapering down for over 6 months. Most people that take it every day end up taking like 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, 40g. I taper down to 500mg then take 1300mg twice a week and go back down to 1g then taper back to 500mg. I've been doing that for almost a year. I just can't take as much as regular people because too much makes me feel stupid. Ketamine made me realize that I'd rather be my thoughts than to look at them - I enjoy sadness I've realized. It's ok for me to have apathy and anhedonia as long as I'm not around people to be social. Usually I only take phenibut when I'm going hiking twice a week because everyone around me is always so social and positive. I don't trust anyone else taking phenibut because it's addictive. I wouldn't trust myself taking it before I got anti-addictive effects from a big psilacetin overdose."

174353961,"Barcode: It’s good that you’re looking out after this person. Most people don’t have that. You said this person has been diagnosed as Bipolar I. As a bipolar I myself (with the full mania), these people can be hard to work with. 1. Drugs.com says Abilify is an anti-psychotic…used to treat psychotic conditions such as schizophrenia and bipolar I disorder and is also used together with other medicines to treat major depressive disorder in adults. 2. Klonopin it says is a benzodiazepine, and can be habit forming. (drugs.com says it is in the same group as Xanax and Librium, tranquilizers) 3. Lamotrigine is an anti-epileptic medication also used to delay mood episodes in adults with bipolar disorder. If they are just taking the Lamotrigine, does it stop or slow down the mania? Does it reduce or take away the depression? You say, “Over the past year I have noticed many of changes finding out through that time that they discontinued taking their Klonopin out of the blue and to my knowledge no l
onger is taking the abilafy as well just leaving them the Lamotrigine.” You said, “Over this time I have witnessed self destructive behaviors.. a lot of lying.. saying things deep and meaningful only to turn around a few days later to discredit it all.” “I'm not completely naive about bipolar and the episodes it can bring.. I've noticed few where they deny it and a day or two later tell me their manic.” “But my question is how much does playing Dr with one's own meds effect someone with bipolar or not keeping up with actual Drs and therapy play in the mood changes and behaviors cause I'm loosing a good friend over the stress of it all.” You said, “these have all been being prescribed by a nurse practitioner and hasn't seen a psychiatrist or therapist in some time.” Is there a psychiatrist that you can see? It sounds like this person could benefit from seeing one, and then taking their medicines. And making return visits to the psychiatrist. Can you look up on the net and see if there are any 
psychiatrists in your area that you can see? You can also look on the net for Mental Health Clinics in your city. Such clinics usually have a sliding scale for pay, which goes all the way down to zero if you can’t afford to pay. If so, can you call one of these places and see if you can get an appointment? If so, check with this person to see if that is alright with them, and if so, make an appointment? You’re on the right track. You may be just a phone call away from help."

175964338,"I thought it may be an interesting topic. I see time and time again the belief for people to constantly push their comfort zones and if you’re not taking risks at every turn you’re missing out on life. But here’s my take on it, what is so wrong about living comfortably in your same routines, if you are at peace and feel Stable. Risks do not always pay off and can actually cost you your mental health and well being as well as resentment frustration and regret. I think it’s dangerous even to promote risk taking as some kind of glamorous way of living especially when you suffer with mental health. I believe comfort zones should be promoted because it brings balance and contentment. People who step out and can’t relax within their comfort zones complain that things aren’t going right, life is too hard, but they carry on with the next big risk to keep repeating the cycle. There’s something to be said about a simple life and living within your comfort, maybe we should be more content with a 
life that’s comfortable instead of always chasing the next big thing? We are taught we need to live achieving everything we want but I don’t think that’s possible and that should be ok. But society says it’s not and you must go after it at all costs until you achieve it. There’s no limit to what you can do and all that nonsense, personally I believe everyone has limitations in some way and maybe that needs to be accepted rather than pushed and aggravated all the time because society pressures you. I’ve felt even more a failure because of my limitations with my mental health and the pressures of this warped society. Now I’m learning it’s ok and maybe they are doing it wrong and don’t have a clue. Taking big risks because of the influence of society and leading me to believe that’s what I’m meant to do to lead a happy fulfilling life has brought me nothing but stress and mental anguish. Ive had to figure out the truth for myself. What’s everyone else’s experience?"

175964437,"I can only share my experiance. 1. Stop and breathe! Those breathing exercises truly work. They stop mine. 2. Look around for a trigger. Side effects can happen. However being in a medical study myself I learned that they have to report everything. If ONE person in the test group eats something wrong and throws up it is blamed on the study med. Even a migrane sufferer can cause a med to have that side effect. Mental meds are difficult to find the right one that works for you. Everyone is different. If you are that worried about side effects, write a journal. It can help see if the med is working for you. e on you. I have been on a med for years and I'm wonderful. I have a few minor panic attacks a year now. My service/therapy dog helps so much."

175964459,"I gotta say that if your bf or you are concerned, then swapping saliva is not the activity to engage in going forward - be cautious, continue distancing, and get re-tested. Several places are still examining cases of tested, cleared and released people who then tested positive, in particular, South Korea, praised the world over for being one of the countries that's had the ""right"" approach. They had a resurgence after learning some people they ""thought"" were in the clear then tested positive again. One would ""think"" having anti-bodies would bode well, but this is still the very early stages of an emergent and spreading virus the experts worldwide DO NOT have any definitive answers about as far as re-acquisition or whether this virus possesses the ability to mutate different strains. just want to punch him right in the face - I really wish I could. The first time I did it, it wasn't hard enough. I listen to music, and there's so much music to listen to. Technology is like a psychedelic trip rabbit hole that we can go into.. Same with life and the world. Do you think we'll ever be able to watch all the YouTube videos there is? I want people to feel happy - Yet there's yin yang and life has to be the way it is just because that's how it works. I can't save the world because I realize that I don't want to.. There has to be a variety of things or else life wouldn't be as great as it is... And that's why people put faith in reincarnation.. Because it's true.. I know that there's souls and unexplained astral projections happening every second.. One person dying and being born every second. It's madness. And we're all so delusional. I want people to explain what they mean and open up cuz there's such bad people. Not many people change their views so easily with new information. I could read - Bu
t I need dopamine. I need a new environment. I absorb everyones energy. Sometimes I question whether or not I'm a good person but I know I am... And that's the problem. I feel stupid sometimes and that I'll never know - Or that it doesn't matter and to dooo thinggss.. Go to school - But I have to make the right decision in what can make me happy. I mostly feel like I'm running out of time and need to rush everything. I try meditation but I can't relax - I get scared. I can't be in a quiet room. uld do - I feel like that's wasting time or I shouldn't do that... That I shouldn't think I'm mentally ill and just live life - People say I'm not mentally ill because I'm too high functioning and ""not crazy"" so I believe them... All the things that sick people have said in the psych ward have made me sick even years after just because of a few sentences or words that they've said.. Sorry for the long reply.. I just want it to be sunny outside and to enjoy time without drama - Have good friends. I feel like people hate me - I'm not normal. 174354189,"Dear xopink3, Oh have you brought back memories of my son. He's now 23 and doing okay. Lazy, but stays out of trouble. My son was diagnosed with ADHD at 4. Started seeing a psychiatrist at that age also. His first in-patient stay was at 8. Between and 11 he had around 12 hospitalations; including 2 residentials. By fifth grade we were transferring him from public school to alternative schools because his behaviors were so extreme that public school couldn't handle him. Oh he had an IEP (individual education plan) and all that. He started puberty at 8. At 9 I signed him up for S.S.I and he was approved almost immediately. I was told about The Fengold Diet by his grandma (biological dad's mom). It's more of a food program and watching what you eat. Pretty much you go back to an 1800's diet. No processed foods. No red dyes. No canned food. You eat only fresh or frozen veggies. Fresh meat. Weened him off sugar as well. He was allowed sugar-free candy. Watch out for the sugar-free chocolate, because if 
you eat to much of it, it will give you diarrhea. White chocolate hyped him up less than milk chocolate or dark chocolate when a special occasion occurred. This diet turned him around. He went from (I think) 5 prescriptions to 1 and everyone that was around him asked me what I had changed, was it a new medication? He was as different as night and day. He was also on a Omega-3 rich diet an earlier time but without the success of the _PERSON_. When he was 19/20 he quit taking his medication after talking with his doctor. He had been on so many different medication that I lost count. But did keep a record of the ones he had adverse reaction to. There had been I believe 23. Ranging from mild to severe reactions. When he went off he said; he woke up one morning ready to take his medicine and realized the emotion or feeling he had been having was anger. His medication was making him feel angry. The anger stopped for the most part when he quit his meds. He is diagnosed as Bipolar and minor schizophrenia. When he was 
in grade school he heard voices that would tell him to hurt or kill someone. He could be very violent and was at times. He didn't understand and wasn't really old enough to be able to control or handle his behaviors. There were uncountable amount of times I would have to restrain him so he didn't hurt himself or anyone else. I have had to call the authorities on him because I couldn't handle or get him to calm down. As an adult he told me that there were times when he acted up because; one, it was easier and two, he got more attention. He knew the breathing exercises that works for him, can be respectful and responsible but he chooses to be lazy. He knows his limitations and what can or will set him off. So he plays video games much of his time. Friends come over but he seldom goes out. This is the life he has chosen. I don't approve or like it but he says, mom ""it's my life to live as I want"". Good luck and I hope this helps you in some way. Oh, and something else. You have to take care of YOU!! If you wea
r yourself out emotionally and/or physically how are you going to be able to help your son."

175964531,"I see. I think that people in the UK have reacted fairly reasonably to what is being said. Yes, there is bulk-buying. However, the government is asking that people don't do that and to think of others and their essential needs. It's an interesting moral argument. Another argument being made is about those who continue to go out to pubs and clubs and in public more generally, against the advice being made, especially if they have respiratory symptoms. The argument is that these people may be acting immorally. I suppose as an ethical experiment it's interesting. The supply-stock shortage is a fairly obvious one to see happen. People are anticipating a risk of there being no or little access to supplies in the coming weeks and months and so want to make sure they have enough for themselves and their families. The whole 'you may be asymptomatic and spreading the disease, putting others at danger' argument is more interesting. Most people who still go out are tending to use 'we're young and probably are
n't going to die because of it' and 'everybody is going to get it anyway' as rebuttals which I think is less easily justified since, rather than being about survival, they have the capacity to put other vulnerable people at risk by refusing to let go of their current lifestyles. It'll be interesting to see what happens when more severe restrictions are imposed on us and how people act in response to that. At the moment, the government has only given us advice. I'm waiting for what happens when we are told we have to do something or other so to protect others."
175964532,"That's a really hard position to be in. Only she knows how she really feels, so it's hard to know what she really wants. You can keep sending her encouraging words, you could visit her but if she refuses to see you don't take it personally. What does she like? Maybe bring her something that she loves but it could worsen her mood. Does she like nature? Maybe convince her to go sit outside somewhere and just breath fresh air, talk or maybe eat(like a small picnic). Sometimes it can help to be around someone and not have to speak, just to have someone in your presence who will not make you feel judged and bring calmness. Bring her a gift, a card, or something creative from the heart that can be a daily reminder that brings positivity.You could do that online or in person. Just something for her to be reminded that you are there. Don't ask her a lot of questions and just let her know you are there and will not judge her or want to make her feel worse. Sometimes it can be hard when someone's mental heal
th is suffering to be complete honest or share their true thoughts due to shame or judgment. I'm not sure how she feels but maybe you can try something I mentioned or come up with something on your own. Hopefully you can find a way to help her."

175964548,"The current COVID-19 outbreak is spurring depression, fear, anxiety, and stress on a societal level. On an individual level, it may exacerbate anxiety and psychosis-like symptoms as well as lead to non-specific mental issues (e.g., mood problems, sleep issues, phobia-like behaviors, panic-like symptoms). Cancer patients (CP) are more vulnerable to these psychological issues as well the viral infection. Contributing to these are the difficulties in get medical and diagnostic care, prescription drugs, and medical supplies; and the economic situation. CP with mental health issues such as OCD, PTSD, anxiety and depressive disorders, and paranoia may experience exacerbation of their symptoms. CP can be proactive and alleviate some of their psychological vulnerability by: • Reaching out and seeking support from mental health professionals (i.e., psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers) • Getting medical and other supplies delivered to one’s residence • Engaging in healthy distractions such a
s reading, watching movies, taking walks, exercising, and learning a new skill • Developing a routine • Obtaining information from reliable sources • Curbing media exposure to certain times in the day • Being aware of what is anxiety and what is reality in one’s thoughts and conversations • Following guidelines (i.e., using prescribed handwashing methods, avoiding touching the face, avoiding hugging and shaking hands, staying at home and contacting one’s medical provider when experiencing medical problems) • Connecting with family and friends through the internet, social media, video calls and phone Following these guidelines can assist CP navigate through the corona virus pandemic. _NAME_ MD Professor of Pediatrics and Medicine Georgetown University School medicine Washington DC"

175964553,"Hmm. . . Hello _AT_MENTION_!. Hope All Is Well. Nice Nights & Days And Such. Meditation. To Subtract Oneself From Society, Civilization, And Culture For A Moment In Time. Is It An Easy, Or Difficult Task To Tackle?. Some Say Easy, Some Say Meaningless. Either Or, It All Depends On The True Goals. If It Is To Be The Leader Of The Free World. Meditation Probably Won’t Get You Very Far. If It Is To Calm Your Senses, Find Rest, And Comfort In A Sometimes Chaotic Environment Of Confusion. Well…, Meditation May Suit Your Personal Tastes Accordingly. How To Meditate?. Which Is The Closest To Correct Way?. Well…, There Is No “correct” Way. There Is Only What Works For You Personally. If One Wanders Quietly From Their Societal Hierarchy And Position In The World For 15 Minutes. That Could Be A Quick Step In The Right Direction. Sit. In A Comfortable Position. And Focus On Your Breathing. . . 1 2 3 In, Rest. 1 2 3 Hold. 1 2 3 Out, Rest. 1 2 3 Hold. or In 1 2 3, Rest. 1 2 3 Hold. 1 2 3 Out, Rest. 1 
2 3 Hold. And Continue The Cycle. Whichever Seems More Fitting To You Personally. And Clear Your Mind Patiently. Without Concern For The Usual Endless Stream Of Thought. Close Your Eyes During The Cycle. And Stare Through The Backs Of Your Pupils. As You Stare At The Backs Of Your Eyelids. To Regain The Moment Of ‘Right Here, Right Now’. Clear Away The Cobwebs Of Uncertainty. And To Regain Control Over Your Personal Sense Of Living. Give It A Try In The Way That I Have Mentioned. And If It Works, Great!. If It Doesn’t Help in Any Way. Well…, I Apologize. But!, Hey!, At Least We Tried (!!!). Good Luck!. ~P.s. Hope, Trust, True Love, Honesty, Joy, And Endlessly Eternal Peace!.~"

175964619,"Years ago when I was in group therapy, I was dealing with lots of unpleasant anxieties. And as anyone with bad anxieties will tell you, when you feel real nervous a lot, you don't want the anxieties to go away next week or next month. You want to calm down right now! The group therapist told us that overcoming anxiety often takes time. My response to that was that I want to calm down now. Other members in the group said the same thing. The counselor told us that we needed to be patient. He was right. But it's still hard when you want the anxiety to go away quickly. However, I took his advice. And now that my anxieties have been low for many years, I'm glad that I chose to have patience. I'm glad that I gave psychiatric treatment a chance because it helped me a lot, even though the anxiety I was dealing with took a long time to go away."

175964623,"So, you both have psychiatrists, that means you probably have good information to rely on, unless your psychiatrists are no good. And those psychiatrists have likely told you that people do indeed ""come back"" from depression in that they achieve stability. But mental health recovery is not like getting over a cold. When you have depression, you are in recovery for life. It can get worse or better. Half of recovery involves therapy and prescription medication and the other half involve lifestyle changes (that are typically supported with counseling). To support your son, you can always be a good role model by taking good care of your own needs; meds, sleep, eating, exercising, meditation, support groups, working at job/volunteering, hobbies/past-times, social connections. Hopefully, he will learn by example. You can direct him to supports in the community, like day programs, drop-in centers and support groups. You can always suggest a medication change or a change of doctor, although that is reall
y his decision to make. If he lives in your home, you can also charge him rent, expect him to work, do his share, clean up after himself, and not make him tea! Does he make you tea? Hugs are great but let him make his own tea unless he is physically or intellectually disabled. If he isn't doing that, and he plays video games all day in your home, let him live elsewhere so he can grow up a little. If he plays video games all day and lives in his own home, your psychiatrist is right, there isn't much you can do except hope he follows your example."

175964651,"""When ever possible, be kind. It is always possible to be kind."" Dalai Lama Be kind to yourself, treat yourself the way, you want others to treat you; with respect and love. Working with mental health professionals (psychiatrist and therapist) is important; also know you're not alone, one in five adults lives with a mental health condition which impacts their daily life. While there is no ""cure"", treatment does work, recovery is possible, and everyone is different, so everyone must find what works best for themselves. Having peer support can provide insight and a community that understands the difficulty of dealing with symptoms of mental illness. Check out non-profit organizations that have peer led programs and explore what works for you. In the meantime #Vote4MentalHealth."

175964660,"This encapsulates the idea of Humanism, which must be the fundamental ""right,"" as it deals with normal human behaviour and provides the best framework for people to be able to be individuals without infringing on the rights of others. And that's where the issue lies: when we impose additional notions of right and wrong where they serve a purpose other than to support that basic rule. In most social structure there's an element of good and bad, but these only exist when people draw up rules to state the good and the bad. It creates divisions by exclusion. How many people have opinions that don't affect them? How many people get offended by issues they have no personal experience of? How many of them derive their belief in those scenarios based on research and objectivity, rather than their own internal conflicts raising their head in metaphoric association? The only true freedom is a releasing of specific rules and an acceptance of humanistic social responsibility."
174354376,An increase in plasma brain derived neurotrophic factor levels is related to n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid efficacy in first episode schizophrenia... - PubMed - NCBI

175964712,"aelachi: rxlist.com says about Anafranil (clomipramine hydrochloride), that is is ""a tricyclic antidepressant used to treat symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) such as recurrent thoughts or feelings and repetitive actions."" The possible side effects include ""drowsiness and tiredness"" so I'm thinking it has some parts that help calm you. I was once on Sinaquan tricyclic anti-depressant which I always heard from the psychiatrist had a calmative affect. So, since your medicine, Anafranil, is also a tricyclic I thinking it might also have that. The medicine I'm on now for my bipolar is Lithium (for the mania) and the anti-depressant Mirtazapine for the depression. Those medicines seem to make me calm, also, and help with my anxiety. When I was only on an anti-depressant (Sinaquan tricyclic), I remember one of my quirks was, I'd be walking down the street, which I knew there was nobody else on that street, and I would turn my head to look backwards as if looking at someone. I knew this w
as some sort of unusual behavior, that I had some sort of problem (anxiety). But I recognize that trait from what you are saying. I think if you can get on the right medicine, this might go away. Or, increase the medicine that you have. I don't know anything about medicine except the ones psychiatrists give me, so you'll have to work this out with your doctor. Also, as has been said, some sort of talk therapy such as CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy) or CAT (Cognitive Analytic Therapy), which stress positive thinking that you can solve this and other problems. The resources section at the top of this list of people writing in with problems (""anxiety-panic resources"") tell what that positive thinking therapy is in written form, without having to track it down all over the place. You want to approach this problem, and others, in as many ways as you can. The net says other side effects of your medicine are: anxiety, restlessness, sleep problems (insomnia). Are you having trouble sleeping? How long have you ha
d these issues? Post Edited (_NAME_) : 6/26/2019 12:52:10 PM (GMT-6)"

The extent to which I smoked was not excessive, however it was substantial enough to alter some modulation within my neurochemistry. The trouble really began when these symotoms began to induce harder and more psychotic disturbances, specs of paranoia began to overcome my consciousness, I started hearing the voice (ocadionally still do) of my ex girlfriends father projecting a over excessive authoritarian thought broadcast, resenting and reproaching me as to why I had behaved the way i did with her daughter and basically just continous uncomfortabl

175964826,"Thanks for your concern.. but.. My psychiatrist basically ditched me due to cuts on funding for mental health before the coronavirus (Cuz oil was low and the economy here was crashing) - So she wasn't allowed to see anyone on the teleconference anymore. But there was an exception - To possibly see her once before she refers me to another psychiatrist. Then the coronavirus happened. Stimulants can be prescribed 3-4 times a day. I only take mine once a day. Today I took two. When I took my meds exactly as prescribed (Such as seroquel and mirtazepine), I had heart palpitations eventually so I stopped them. I see everything as a grey area. I'm not good with rules. EVERYTHING. All the problems that people are arguing about on the internet, I see both sides. My mind is so open that I feel like I shouldn't be alive. Everyone has beliefs and gets judged for them. I get judged by the video chat people for saying what I don't really mean - Which they take seriously. I don't take myself seriously. I laugh at 
myself. I don't think anything is real. I'm just trying to survive. I was a very weird kid too - Like completely disconnected from reality. I don't make any sense. I'm likely intelligent but schizotypal or something. I don't think objectively - I'm a mixture of subjective experiences - I know that I don't know things - In awe of everything? Autistic? I don't know. The extra vyvanse is to help me focus on reading as a distraction - Maybe play piano or guitar. I know I have a sleep-wake problem - Never got a sleep test. My treatment team is always so lazy or careful with me yet fascinated by my mind. I've always been praised for my mind - People do things.. I'm rarely ever in my element.. One thing (One very important thing): I've been on meds for many many years. And they keep changing. Most peoples meds keep changing, - People change, environment changes, we grow older, diagnoses change.. I feel like it's all absurd how people are so certain about things. Maybe if I had a SO or a friend, she/he can help me bu
t I don't want a relationship... And people all they live for is a partner, kids, and the pointlessness of it all to me - People make their own meaning.. I have to do that.. That's why the video chat people got mad.. They're right.. But it's painful to know the truth.. Some lies were said.. No one.. NO ONE - Thinks this much about their convictions and identity and the world and is so damn mental yet sane at the same time.. And the psychedelics.. I don't want to get started.. 175964847,No a true meditation that’s where you go out Into the Woods near a stream and Babbling _NAME_ sit on a beach towel cross your legs and hold a position for 15 minutes and take you in the sound
175964848,"This is the accentuation of attention. You grab something from all the sounds, images that surround you and your attention is focused on it and gives it a special meaning, increases it as under a magnifying glass. Attention is fixed on some details, snatches out individual phrases. This condition can be caused consciously without any consequences for the psyche. Just limit yourself in time, suppose-1 day. It's like magic, you somehow start creating a new reality that swirls around you and involves you in your game. In the morning you leave the house and all that you can mentally attract, attract to yourself-accidentally heard scraps of conversations, accidentally seen lines in Newspapers, in the hands of passers-by, snatched phrases of radio and TV announcers, headlines, etc. I assure you, in the evening you will see how accurately these signs are woven into your life, how accurately they assess YOUR situation, to what extent they give wise and complete advice. You can turn on the TV in the evening 
for some program, and you will hear a great dialogue or monologue about yourself, about your life, about plans for the future. But this gift is from the devil. Do not forget the next morning to turn off all the accents and enter into a normal state of consciousness. The effect of accentuation of attention can occur when you for example, strongly hit your toe and then it seems that all passers-by try to step on this toe and each wall flies on this finger. It's like the energy of the situation is working. Such is the programming is obtained."

175964859,"""I said that I am an atheist because that means that AA will not work for me..."" I haven't drank for 24 years or attended one AA or NA meeting during all that time. I'd drop in for a 20 year commemorative key chain but it doesn't even mean that much to me. I have, however, sat through enough meetings to know your ""Higher Power"" doesn't have to be God. Someone else can explain it better than I care to. ""yes, it's a poor coping mechanism but it helps me get through all the mess..."" The problem with that is the mess never really goes away when you drink. It's still there when you sober up along with any mess you may have gotten yourself into while you were ""trying to escape reality"". Reality will still be there come the cold light of day. ""still it's like I need a better reason to get off the stuff than I currently have..."" You said you were still young. Give it time. Maybe drinking won't cause you problems with the legal system, relationships, etc. Maybe it will and that's what it will take 
for you to see stopping drinking more attractive than continuing to drink. Everybody's different. ""it makes me feel so much better and that will be hard to give up."" That's why they call it an addiction. I've got no stake in whether you quit drinking or not, so go with my blessings. I sincerely wish you the best of luck, you're going to need it."

175964885,"Nicotine itself doesn’t interact with APs (such as NRTs and vaping) like _AT_MENTION_ said. Only tobacco does, like the kind you get from cigarettes. Doesn’t really matter how much dopamine you give your system, the meds will always balance them out. If they don’t, and you need a high ‘dopamine’ diet (I say that loosely, some SZ do) then you need to up your side effect med dose. Hope this helps."

175964902,"_NAME_ was having excessive panic attacks. The attacks were intense, erratic, and debilitating. They lasted anywhere from brief seconds to a longer incredulous 30 minutes. Worse yet, they came out of nowhere with unknown causes or triggers which kept her from fully functioning at home, work, and socially. She was embarrassed, ashamed, and defeated by the attacks. A normally social person, _NAME_ found herself withdrawing from the people and things she loved the most as her fear of the panic attacks worsened. Her predicament was strange because _NAME_ was a lovely person with a friendly personality and these attacks were so contrary to her nature. She was able to converse with a wide variety of people and unusually comfortable in new environments. She was engaging, delightful, and pleasant to be around making these panic attacks that much more out of the ordinary. The attacks began when she was a teenager and had been getting progressively worse as she aged. To the point that now well into her 30’
s, she was unable to hold down a job for longer than a few months, her marriage was on the brinks, and she had few if any friends left. After ruling out several disorders and medical conditions, _NAME_ was diagnosed with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD). But on the surface, she did not look like a person with BPD. She didn’t have emotional outbursts, didn’t openly display any fear of abandonment, never made a suicide attempt, and had a long-term relationship with her husband. However, these symptoms did manifest internally, not overtly or externally. https://pro.psychcentral.com/exhausted-woman/2019/08/what-is-covert-borderline-personality-disorder/"

175964924,"When I had my shrink appointment on Monday, the doctor said it sounded like i felt ""stuck"" in my situation. It did not seem right to me, that I don't feel ""stuck."" But, the only feeling i could come up with is jealous. I was jealous of those who do not have issues. So, I have been thinking about it for the last couple of days. What is it that I am actually feeling/wanting. I do not want out of my life. I love my daughter, husband, siblings, parents, and career. I don't feel ""stuck"" in my situation. I just wish I was not me in this situation. I feel it is not fair to my loved ones and friends. I feel like my feelings do not fit my situation in life. I should be happy and content (I know, those ""should"" statements are not helpful and are caused by distorted thinking). I just don't necessarily feel up to the job of being me. How do I feel? - very depressed, frustrated, tired, and ashamed. Why do I feel this way? - no idea. My life is good. I have an appointment with my shrink again next Friday
. I wonder what I will say. Will I have dissected my feelings enough to make it clear for someone else to understand? I have a lot of SI, but it is more like an earwig than an intended action. I keep hearing inside my head (not with my ears), ""I want to die."" But, I do not want to die. However, as this depression continues and is even getting worse, I am having a harder time with these thoughts. They used to feel like they were no big deal, just a song I could not get out of my head. But now, it is morphing into something else. Not sure what, but it is changing. I still have no intention to act. But, the idea is becoming more and more tempting. I will not take my life. I cannot do that to my loved ones. As I always say, ""if i am willing to die to unburden my family, I should be willing to live, so I do not hurt my family."" So, where does that leave me? Trying to figure out how to deal with these feelings and how to feel better. I need this depression to lift. It is getting int the way of my life."
