175964941,"Good points. That's something I always believed from a young age. Also why I thought everybody was an hypocrite. They were doing stuff they did not want to do, pretending to like it when in fact it was just a means to an end, but not even a compatible one. It's like being miserable for the sake of it and hoping for an afterlife reward that may or may not come to pass, but while you did that, you sacrificed the life you did have. Why hope for happiness when you can have it right now? And how is it that leading an unhappy life make you ready for a happy afterlife? Chances are you won't be able to enjoy it, or know what to do with it, same as now. That's what I understand as false self, and it shows a bit everywhere. One thing I noticed young adult, was that people were quite gregarious, until they got a sex supply, at which point they would suddenly disappear. So all the friendships and antics were just means to an end, not the real thing, and it showed when you pushed a little. Why people choose to 
live this way is a bit beyond me. This being said there are some people that do those normal things and are quite fulfilled in it, and they would not want it any other way. So they probably describe normal, because they are leaders and happy. Plenty are wannabes though, who think normal is only the appearance of it, not the internal self-driven drive for it. I saw it in a striking way, in the _NAME_ autobiography, at least the parts I read. It was all like that. The whole drive was to look in a certain way, even though the internal reality was completely different. There was no thought about doing things for its own sake, it was all geared to look better than others, not even simply the same but better. So its envy to an nth degree, and jealousy when it does not work, or when those achievements are not recognized. It lead to murder eventually. Yes, and that is something I often say to people, but they deny it. Mostly people that rely a lot on empathy to move around and do things, have that presupposition deep
ly rooted, but unconscious. Not surprisingly, because ""diversity"" and tolerance of it is what people claim to like. But that also is a means to an end quite clearly. The last thing they want is someone feeling differently than they are, but they might accept different behaviors, as long as the feelings are right. It can lead to a lot of misunderstandings, because they assume you are the same, so they aren't talking to you but a ghost of themselves. And if you tell the real you, they will correct you. Either that, or they will simply suspect you of something nefarious, because the behavior is not consistent to hiding what they would hide, thus the hiding must be worst and monstrous. If you don't hide small things, then there must be bigger things. Or if that person does not want to steal this small thing, they must be aiming for something bigger. That's pretty much what I was telling my previous doctor, which funnily enough took his retirement. Fortunately I would say. The new one just signs stuff, which is 
a lot better. I don't need moralizing from some person that hasn't thought things through, and I did not want to share his miserable life. Not surprisingly, he wanted gratitude for his work. If he did what he did out of love and not for some other reason, like looking mature, which was his big thing, he would need no gratitude and in fact he would be grateful for the opportunity to do what he likes and signed on for, which is to sign my papers. For some reason he never expressed such gratitude, and that's because he is a fake. The new one seems genuine. It does make quite a difference, because the fake is going to cause all kinds of problems for no reason, while the other won't. Little sabotages all the time, it gets annoying and old pretty fast. Its hard to fight off as well, although I have possible plans for one of his accomplice. It's an interesting question, and it turns out the coronavirus is giving some answers to that. People are basically forced to adopt schizoid-like behavior and thinking because of 
an invisible threat, but that is real nevertheless. So you can see the type of reactions. Some deny it because they can't see it. Others want to show they are courageous and become reckless. Others are ambiguous and try to compromise, so they turn to superstition, like mask wearing. They are ready to take risks as long as there is a possibility that they might be able to diminish it. But their prime goal is not health or security, even though they pretend (that's the false self). Some schizoids do that supposedly, in a metaphorical way. Some like me makes charts and try to predict deaths. Mostly though, people become religious. Some experts are put forward, and they preach the good news, or the bad if people sinned like not washing their hands. They preach social distanciation for the mass, and special protection, masks included, for the sacred, the essential worker. Those masks are a special garment reserved for the rituals of healing and food distribution, but reserved only for them when doing said rituals. 
Although this protection is mainly spiritual and a sign of sacred, others are allowed to wear counterfeits, or at least they were able to force them to admit grudgingly that everybody is essential in some ways. That's how religion and superstition fight each others, or deal with each others. But the idea here is that everybody does the same, act the same, for the same reason, which is based on ""science"" all the while trying to deal with nitwits who don't follow protocol. All on their own though, people would not become schizoid, they could not because the guidance would not be there, so they would look for it and then they stop distancing. They will only distance if they are convinced there is a good reason and that everybody else is doing it, except the sacred. There is a reason I promote religion. I can see needs, but also why people don't fulfill them. For me, this whole thing is mostly business as usual aside from a few inconveniences. For others it is a disaster, or for some an adventure. Lots of diffe
rent feelings going around, but nobody is indifferent. Fighting this is like fighting human nature and how it organizes naturally without falling into superstition, but without falling into irreligion either which is what the denial does. Also why I jumped into its theology pretty fast and tried to be conversant in its symbolism and causalities and models. The whole phenomena is interesting though, rarely will you see a religion appear and organize in a few months, or even a few weeks. It already existed though in Asia, which is probably why they are doing better than Western countries, which tried to mimic with limited success so far. I don't think it is really a matter of right or wrong, its about what works for which goals. Its one of the peculiarities of the Western mind to thing in black and white. Right or wrong, instead of simply what works, and having goals and plans. Sometimes politics is more important than the truth, and that is the main thing people are rediscovering which I suppose comes as a sho
ck. It's been going on for awhile though, way before the virus, which simply accelerates the process. There is also a question of temperament. Some people want to conserve, some others want to spend, and each have their own advantage and disadvantages. Its been a few hundred years that people suddenly decided and spend was the way to go, its the liberal model. Spend, create and consume. Its good until it becomes reckless. Now there is an opposite trend, towards conservation, which is why nationalism of all sorts are appearing. Overall though, nationalism is stronger all things considered. Its more stable, more just, and does not lead to a catastrophic event, but can lead to a slow death due to lack of motivation. The lack of ability to imagine or deal with intellectual things, or enjoy them, I wrote about a few times in the past. A few years ago I gave some links to the desert fathers, which were giving tips to overcome that. Its certainly an issue, and quite possibly the schizoid is more at ease in that worl
d than in the physical world, while for most people it is the opposite. So there is truth to it, and it is a well known thing, or it used to be well known. People compensate by watching movies and so on, and again, it is what religion tried to provide with the means of the time, some things to think about for those that aren't exactly great at it, or inclined to it. They even forced it on people, once a week, to make sure they made a slight effort. It was a conscious decision to do that, but at the same time, it also forced schizoid types to interact with others in a safe environment. Lots of things could be said on that subject alone, which is complex with lots of twists and turns. But my opinion is that in the end, the destruction of religion, at least that one, basically allowed something like schizoid to be considered as a disorder. But it was quite ordered in the past, it just isn't valued anymore unless money can be made out of it, which is usually rare, and not exactly a money maker, because once an id
ea is out, it does not destroy on consumption, so people can just appropriate it, and not pay anything. So the schizoid gets robbed of everything. His ideas, dignity, etc. All the more reason to avoid others. It just adds insults to injury for no reason."

175964977,"Hmm, I can understand it can be very frustrating, I am not diagnosed with OCD either but as in terms of health anxiety I have my own rituals, false beliefs, intrusive thoughts, etc. When persistent thoughts come, my way of dealing with them is treating those thoughts as someone else's. Not necessarily the moment I have them first because it's usually very hard to deal with them when you are caught unprepared. But after a while, I re-evaluate them by replaying them in my mind from another person's mouth. Like I am listening to a stranger and how I would react to those thoughts. Because your reaction is what counts, not the thought itself."

175965014,"I thought I'd give a quick update. I'm two weeks into a 30 day monitor. My cardiologist said she thought it wasn't anything to be worried about and sounded like simple ectopic heartbeats to her. SHe still wanted to get an idea about what all I was dealing with so we could make better plans on how to treat it. As she put it ""Obviously, just throwing pills at it to see what works and what doesn't isn't the right answer for you based on how your body reacted to beta blockers."" My palpitations have primarily been calm since getting the monitor. There's a few days I'm having to hit the button a good number of times. Today is one of those days where it seems like I'm having several an hour, but most days they have calmed down (and certainly nothing like I saw after taking the beta blockers.) Ironically I did have to adjust my blood pressure medication. My doctor raised me up to 10mg a day of Lisinopril and, as usual, my body did not like that. I went from an average of 140/90 down to 115/75. I felt lik
e a sloth during that period. Everyone said ""that's normal"", but the problem is when you're used to a higher blood pressure, you don't want to go to normal at breakneck speeds. I'm balancing it with one 5mg in the morning and one 2.5mg at night now which seems to have kept me from having issues."

175965022,"OK, so I'm in this Al-Anon meeting, for people who have friends or relatives with alcoholism, and it comes time for me to speak. I give my feel-sorry-for-myself negative spiel of how worthless I am and how rough my life has been. That's the way I was raised, OK. As a 5 and 10-year-old, I believed what my parents said. That was my first mistake. As can be expected, I carried that downtrodden, negative attitude into my adulthood, just as I carried the English language into my adulthood as I had been taught as a child. So, in the Al-Anon meeting I'm what? A 45-year-old, negative-baby speaking English. This woman sitting next to me did not believe my parents, that I was an idiot who had a rough life, and she was not negative. She did not gaslight me with constant statements that both me and my life were worthless. She erased everything my mother had said to me for 45 years in three seconds. How did she, a total stranger, do that? By, after I finished feeling sorry for myself, she said, ""Oh, you were h
aving a Pity Party. We've all done that."" And she had the nicest, most understanding look on her face and in her eyes. The 45-year-old baby was exposed in front of the group of being a baby, of believing what my mother had said. She did not believe that. She overrode my mother. What was the commonality? Both were females. I needed that common bond to make the transfer, one of them cruel, one a savior. I had unconsciously looking for that person all my life. I changed my allegiance from my pathological mother to this nice woman, who I never saw again, in about 5 seconds. As a 45-year-old man, I never wanted to be exposed in front of a group again as being a big baby. It was like electric shock. My psychic was struck by the nicest, most understanding but insightful, and, yes, mothering person I've ever met. If you've never been embarrassed in front of a group and exposed as being nothing more than a big baby, don't try to guess what that feels like. Because of that pain, information and compassion at the same 
time, I have never felt sorry for myself again. Because every time I try, I see that woman's face and I hear her voice and my Pity Party just doesn't work as I try to curl up into a ball and be a 5-year-old. My allegiance is still to her. That compassionate mother figure. My guess is, you are getting some kind of reward for believing a parental type person in your formative years and you do not want to be disloyal to them and believe that they did not have your best interest in mind. So you cling to where you are, even though you complain about it every now and then. But you really love it and can't be talked out of it."

175965026,"Ok so take the needed steps to become less isolated....the other grad students are off the table but you can still make friends other ways. I met one long term friend on Craigslist which can be a little dicey but now a lot of dating apps have friend finders as well....although people can be weird about if they want to date you and you’re only looking for friends. The classic way if you’re not into the tech is to join an activity, maybe a painting or poetry class at a local community college or your cities recreation center. Join a sport or meetup group. Goto a coffee shop or grocery store and talk to people waiting in line if they haven’t pulled out their phones yet. As a person with social anxiety I can say that none of these things are easy for me but I’ve done them all. Finding friends is incredibly valuable even if you only find one. I do think you should get the degree but only because you’ll be ahead of the game when you’re done. 8 hours of zoom sounds crazy to me tbh."

175965093,"One needs to understand there is a huge difference between shyness and severe social anxiety. I believe many people who are ""shy"" have an endearing quality about them. They also seem to ""listen"" very well - a great characteristic! I also believe ""shyness"" may be something you are born to be, and may be something you were meant not to change about you! I don't believe simple shyness precludes you from a wonderful quality of life - thinking otherwise sounds a bit prejudicial. As you become older, you will probably understand this better. P.S. I am not what one would call a ""shy"" person."

175965095,"The thing is, now that we know(are aware, and theres no way back to unaware).. we have a choice. Either to live in a life full of fears, or just simply dont give a ###$. I choose the latter. If you let go of fear, then youll start to think more normal after a while. I have days where i most of the time dont think so much that my thoughts are being heard. One more thing, we are having this physical experience, so make it as good as you can(despite the fact that your whole world has turned upside down after the ""psychosis""). Make your body/brain as ""happy"" as you can EVERYDAY. What i do to make my body ""happy"" is working out. I started it 5-6 months ago. You set goals. And you do the best you can to reach those goals. F ex if you can bench press 80kg set 86kg as a goal for the next month. And so on. Your everyday life gets a meaning. You start to think thoughts like: ""damn, i shouldve been able to lift that weight"" ""hmm maybe i should of done this instead, or that"" etc.. And for the brain, 
study interesting topics, i myself like science alot, so thats what im studying. Im even planning to go back to uni again."
175965096,"You're not alone. I understand. I really do. I've been dealing with this for much much longer. I did try to overdose once. I don't talk about it because it makes people uncomfortable. I was even told that I was just attention seeking. That's so not true! I get the way it feels like I have weights pulling me down sometimes. I barely have the energy to get basic things done. It becomes a goal to manage a shower, washing my hair is too much sometimes, and when it's really bad I can't find the energy to even eat. All I can tell you is to find a mantra you can repeat to yourself. Like... It can't get any worse. Or I can do this one thing. Say it over and over. Then clap yourself on the back of you manage it. And don't put yourself down if you don't. Just begin saying then...I can do this one thing tomorrow. I WILL do it. I'm sorry that your friends and family are so discouraging and don't understand or notice you. Unfortunately that's par for the core. That's just part of it. Other people don't get it a
nd don't seem to want to. I will be here to help anytime so don't ever feel so alone that you self harm. I hope it helps that you're not the only one to feel like this."

175965147,"I understand how this feels. I have been diagnosed with depression for the last 7 or 8 years and every time we find a medication that seems to work, I find that I am allergic to it. It's hard but it takes a great deal of trial and error. In the mean time I did alot of things that helped me manage my depressive and anxious symptoms a bit better such as always keeping a book on me to read when I needed a distraction or ""scheduling"" time for a hobby each day. I recommend asking your doctor if they can either add a secondary medication for anxiety that you take with your Lexapro, or maybe a different depression medication that works a bit better on it's own for you. 175965223,"Its's good that you wrote back. You said in your latest post, that you had been diagnosed with: “GAD, Panic Disorder and Depression for 8 years now, and just in the past couple weeks it’s spiraled out of control.” And, “My family says it’s 100% my anxiety and they’re not worried at all.” And “It’s getting to the point where I’m at a loss for what to do. I feel rather hopeless.” And “Should this sensation be happening for three days in a row? Is it cause for concern. I’m 20 and in decent health, no real past of any major health problems, but I have severe panic disorder and generalized anxiety disorder so it’s hard for me to tell if it’s anxiety or something I need to go to the hospital for.” As for myself, I have bipolar and have had anxiety attacks. I would wonder, if you’ve been diagnosed it would seem that you have been to a psychiatrist or a mental health center of some kind. Can you go back to that? I went to the net (mayo clinic.org) and one of the things it 
said was, sometimes mental health issues can be inherited. I was having a lot of emotional problems but only realized it was bipolar when a lay counselor told me, “I knew your uncle, and he had manic-depression, and you probably do, too.” So, does anyone in your family have mental health issues? This can sometimes be a tip-off and a help to know that. As to if and when to seek help, I went to the net for panic attacks and the same mayoclinic.org said: “A panic attack is a sudden episode of intense fear that triggers severe physical reactions when there is no real danger or apparent cause. Panic attacks can be very frightening. When panic attacks occur, you might think you're losing control, having a heart attack or even dying. “Many people have just one or two panic attacks in their lifetimes, and the problem goes away, perhaps when a stressful situation ends. But if you've had recurrent, unexpected panic attacks and spent long periods in constant fear of another attack, you may have a condition calle
d panic disorder.” “If you have panic attack symptoms, seek medical help as soon as possible. Panic attacks, while intensely uncomfortable, are not dangerous. But panic attacks are hard to manage on your own, and they may get worse without treatment.” “Symptoms of panic disorder often start in the late teens or early adulthood and affect more women than men.” “Left untreated, panic attacks and panic disorder can affect almost every area of your life. You may be so afraid of having more panic attacks that you live in a constant state of fear, ruining your quality of life.” “A form of psychotherapy called cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can help you learn, through your own experience, that panic symptoms are not dangerous.” This website, healingwell.com, also recommends CBT in treatment of ailments such as panic disorders, and has a list of readings where it talks about that. This list of resources is found above the list of people, such as yourself, who are writing in about their problems. 
It stresses positive thinking that you can deal with this, which I firmly believe also. This is very important, because I've found that if I go into any problem feeling defeated, it greatly increases the chances that I will be. But if I feel going into the problem that I can solve it, that greatly increases the chances that I will, for I will have programmed myself to be looking for ways to win. The Mayo Clinic website also said there are several medicines that can be used for this condition."

175965282,"I have found that creating my own routine is a big help. If left to my own devices, the anxiety will soar, but by trying to keep to a routine, it helps me stay grounded. A checklist off of an article I read on how to beat pandemic fatigue has been really helpful. Some things that have helped is where it says to: Stay connected with family and friends. Even if it's just texting silly memes and GIFs, having Zoom meetings and gatherings, playing games with each other online. Making the best of circumstances. Since we can't hurry the pandemic along, we have done a lot of house projects that have made it feel more cozy and functional and helps our enjoyment of our space. Sticking to a routine as mentioned above. Meditation, prayer. Having quiet time with a cup of coffee and just looking or stepping out into the garden or sitting in the sunshine is so calming. When I start having a panic attack, _NAME_ 41:13 keeps me calm, so I meditate on that Scripture in case you find comfort from the Scriptures as we
ll. Staying active. I have my exercise routine, for me it's Monday, Wednesday, Friday and then walks on the other days, even if it's just around the block. I think we'd all go stir crazy if we were cooped up 24/7 without ever seeing the sun, so that helps me. I listen to some music while walking and if it's raining, I just walk with an umbrella. Just trying to keep moving. I hope any of these suggestions help. These are strange times and it affects everybody so differently. I hope you can find some peace of mind."

175965311,"I certainly feel higher level of anxiety in the morning. Pretty much every morning. Like the OP, I find that it usually dissipates -- at least to some extent -- when I get up and going. But sometimes it is hard to get up and going... Some have said the morning anxiety is a result of higher cortisol levels -- that cortisol levels are cyclical throughout the day, and tend to be highest in the morning. I once asked a doctor whether I should do one of the 24 hour cortisol level tests, to see whether I have super high cortisol levels in the morning. He said there's no point - not much can be done about it anyway. When I first started taking my SSRI (Zoloft), I woke up every day, very early, like 5 or 530 am, with an extremely high level of agitation. It burned off but only after I went out for a run. Pretty unpleasant running, exhausted, at that hour. I wondered why this happened only in the early mornings. In any event it stopped happening after a month or 6 weeks maybe. But even now my morning agitati
on level tends to be pretty high."

175965342,"I've struggled with being faithful in every single relationship I've been in. I actually lost a really great relationship with someone I loved deeply because I was unfaithful. Everything was perfect but my bipolar was out of control. It's been over a year since the end of that relationship and I've realized that a lot of my inability to stay faithful was because I didn't believe I deserved something so good and I also didn't fully know what I wanted long term. I didn't understand my own worth and the attention of someone, anyone else determined my worth since I couldn't determine it for myself. I needed the attention because it made me feel like I meant something. Even though I was getting attention from my significant other, I needed more the worse I felt. When I worked on myself and valued myself, found myself worthy of good things, I realized I could disconnect from those unhealthy relationships and people and say no to certain situations. No matter how badly I may have wanted it, I was able to 
say no and choose the better options. I don't know if this helps you, but I wanted to at least share my experience in the hopes it does help. Promiscuity and impulsive desires are a part of bipolar, unfortunately. But building up your emotional independence and working on not being codependent will help you be in more control of those choices and to be a better partner."

175965396,"Hi S.A.P and welcome! I am sorry you are feeling scared for your health atm. I understand how this feels and it is miserable. Let me reassure you that your fear is a common one. I read many almost identical posts to your several times a year here. It is a common Health Anxiety concern. The water at any water park has been treated and therefore safe from the pathogen that you fear. Only natural, standing water would harbor such organisms...and even then, it is extremely rare. You can safely let go of this concern... ...but if you find yourself worrying about various other health related issues, you might want to look into treatment for Health Anxiety. You can get started by checking out our Resources at the top of the main forum page here. We have several helpful sites and book suggestions that could help. Post here with us anytime for support! Scaredy Cat"

175965401,"Hey Desoxyn, sorry you're having so much trouble with sleep. Have you ever tried napping during the middle of the day to try to mitigate some of the effects of lack of sleep? I'm not saying you're having effects from lack of sleep. But I know that when I sleep a decent amount every night, I feel substantially better in mood. Maybe set a timer for a 30-45 minute nap in the middle of the day and see if that helps... Also, have you tried any guided relaxation or meditation exercises before sleep? Have you tried taking a hot shower before bed? Some of those things may help."

175965488,"Taking over a year to use up the equivalent of 40 doses of Xanax is exemplary use _USER_ID_, your doctor freaking out probably either means she suspects you're doctor shopping and getting prescript ions from others, this is a big problem with opiates, in which case you should probably fire her because a doctor who thinks you're lying is dangerous, or the local legal situation has gotten so bad she's worried about losing her license, which would also mean she couldn't continue to help you and others. As others have recommended, get a refill from a psychiatrist. Since Xanax has worked so well for you, there's no reason to change to another. about Klonopin and other benzodiazepines, my experience from using them on and off for 25 years, plus what I've researched, is that they're pretty much all the same in terms of hitting the biological target (which is also roughly the same as the Z-drugs like Ambien), which particular one is best is based on how they act in the body, like how fast they take effect 
(the faster, the more addiction potential), how long they last, and how your body removes them, which has potential for interactions with other drugs. I was started on Ativan, but I cleared it from my body too quickly getting withdrawal symptoms before the normal 8 hours were up, so I was changed to Klonopin, which has a much longer half-life. Withdrawing from it is more than obnoxious, although not quite ""hell"" for me, what I've done is to do it very slowly, taking at least 3 weeks for each dosage reduction, 2 weeks that are not fun, and another to recover, the whole process taking many months if starting from my max of 0.5 mg 3 times a day. One problem is that it's a potent drug, with the lowest tablet of 0.5 mg way too much unless you're good with an Xacto knife, or your doctor switches you to another benzodiazepine with lower effective dosages in the smaller pills. And when I say ""good"", at minimum I need to divide a single tablet into sixths for the last few steps. And the above and what other people 
are saying emphasizes that if possible, you should take these drugs as seldom as you can like you do, take a steady dosage over 2-3 weeks and your body will get adapted to them, which you could say is form of addiction."

175965496,"You said, “I’m new to forums and being in society.” I know the feeling. A few days ago I made myself sit down and figure out how to use my cell phone, which I don't use I just want to know who to use it in case I have to. You did well to reach a forum for assistance. You mentioned bad experiences so on the net I looked up Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). I don’t know that you have that, I don’t have any such training, I just have Bipolar for which I take Lithium stabilizer (600 mg) and Mirtazapine anti-depressant (7.5 mg). I typed PTSD into the search engine and one of them was “Anxiety and Depression Association of America” (adaa.org). It said: “PTSD is diagnosed after a person experiences symptoms for at least one month following a traumatic event. However symptoms may not appear until several months or even years later. The disorder is characterized by three main types of symptoms: • Re-experiencing the trauma through intrusive distressing recollections of the event, flas
hbacks, and nightmares. • Emotional numbness and avoidance of places, people, and activities that are reminders of the trauma. • Increased arousal such as difficulty sleeping and concentrating, feeling jumpy, and being easily irritated and angered. Do you have any of those? WebMd.com said: ""Several types of drugs affect the chemistry in your brain related to fear and anxiety, including: • Fluoxetine (Prozac) • Paroxetine (Paxil) • Sertraline (Zoloft) • Venlafaxine (Effexor) The FDA has approved only paroxetine and sertraline for treating PTSD."" • One of the treatments webmd.com said was Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) which this website, healingwell.com., advocates. You can find that under ""Bipolar Resources"" which is above the list of names of people who have written in on the opening page of the ""Bipolar"" forum. It is simply a matter of feeling positive that you can solve problems, including those involving health. In that, if you think you can solve a problem before going into it and 
before actually trying to solve it, you believe that you can solve it. It improves your chances for solving the problem, for your mind looks for ways to solve it, rather than closing down your mind’s search for solutions because you don't believe you can solve it. So do you believe you can solve this?"

175965516,"I've always felt we needed to be social mammals for the purpose of survival eons ago, but failed to evolve enough to let go of that social need. It has been my observation that those who are socially and emotionally independent of others; family, relationships etc... are faring better during covid-19. I watched a couple today and noted their boredom with each other; their taking for granted of each other, and was thankful I am no longer in a relationship where every fibre of one's being has to be compromised , however little , by the constant presence of another. Basically, I think we are not 'social' animals in the true sense of the word in todays world. We have a preconceived idea that we are, based on historical and habitual behaviour but today it is a need borne from boredom, loneliness etc because we cannot handle being alone, when in fact this is what we need to cultivate. ie. being alone and happy with that. We can feel Love, compassion for others energetically without the need for the fake

175965522,"I'm figuring out ways to harness and capture creative-genius thoughts. We all have them.. It just takes work. I let them pass my mind every day - Especially before I fall asleep which is when they are the most prominent and hardest to catch.. ""_NAME_s research into his split-brain hypothesis in the 1960s showed that some activities, such as spatial reasoning and appreciation of beauty, stimulate the right hemisphere of the brain, while things like analytical thinking and language stimulate the left hemisphere. But creativity requires a whole-brained approach because it requires lateral thinking, or thinking about things in new ways. When we “think outside the box,” we devise fresh approaches to solving problems and meeting challenges. Work to build your whole brain by using both right and left sides. Try juggling or doing origami, or just do daily activities like writing your name or brushing your teeth with your non-dominant hand. Start looking at things differently -- literally -- by wearing 
your watch upside down or using your phone upside down. Try writing backward: it worked for _NAME_, who wrote his notes in “mirror writing.”"""

175965616,"Today is World Suicide Prevention Day. I have many conflicting feelings about what this word ‘suicide’ stands for and I will share them with you in this post. You may agree disagree and I hope you will comment as you see fit. As many of you, dear readers, already know my story, I am going to share some of it again in hopes that it might help someone else. A little over a decade ago I had my first suicide attempt in California. It was bad. I was taken to the emergency room late at night and ended up in intensive care. I really do not remember much. After that I went to the psych ward for a three day hold. A three day hold is customary if a person tries to kill him or herself. It gives the person a chance to stabilize. At the end of that period if everyone, being the case worker and psychiatrist and perhaps others, agrees then a judge rules if you go home or if you stay in the hospital. I was allowed to leave, partly because my parents had made arrangements to see a psychiatrist and therapist bac
k in Oklahoma where I would resume living with them. It was in Oklahoma that I first learned I had an illness called bipolar disorder. Before that, I’d never heard of it. My next attempt in Oklahoma was not as dramatic as my first, but it did require another emergency room visit, stitches, and the hospital psychologist. I had to stay in the psych ward, but this time it was for a longer period – five days. It was miserable there. No real therapy. Horrible food for the vegetarian I was at the time. But at least there was a visiting hour. My mom came every evening. Same kind of escape deal, the judge and all that. I remember as we left, looking out the window to the thirteenth floor of the hospital where I had stayed and was so happy to be out and free. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/being-bipolar/2019/09/10/world-suicide-prevention-day-2019/"

Now if you are asking if people with schizophrenia are easier targets for this kind of torture then I don't know. I have schizoaffective disorder and I think I am neither more or less of a target than anyone else. I still think I'm smart and have my wits about me most of the time.

174355757,"Thank you everyone who has replied so far. I've been busy figuring some things out personally and dealing with the inanities of quotidian existence and haven't had an opportunity to respond to you all. I have a bit of time this morning and I'm in a good place so I'll try and address some of the awesome responses this thread has generated so far. Not sure what order makes the best sense to respond to.. This'll be a long post and formatting may get weird... Bare with me Thank you for your kind words Cholls and I'm glad my post sparked some insights for you. The work your friend is doing / the approach she is developing / developed sounds really interesting. If you have a link I'd love to look it over. The situation you described where you had her repeat a question about your father twice sounds like maybe an internal defense you're fighting against. Asking her to repeat the question could be the defense that gives you time to think up a safe answer. ((I know that for me when I'm asked a question that 
may reveal ""secrets"" I deflect the question. For example I'm not really comfortable talking about my intentions or goals (and lack thereof), it feels like I'm giving away secrets. So if somebody asked me ""So, OutsideIn what do you want to do after you finish schooling?"" it depends if I'll need to interact with them again but usually I'll either slip on my happy mask to create an elaborate tableau that goes way beyond their question's scope and prevent further inquiries. Sort of like describing your dream house to somebody... I don't really know why I'm going to school except that I'm smart and it seems like a good way to fill my time before I kill myself. (Not a good thing to say in person) )) My father is a narcissist and I have tried to take him to task for his behavior, so to speak. So I totally know how frustrating that is. I stopped doing it because it never seemed to 'take' his behavior has never changed and I didn't feel any better afterwards. It made me wonder like how can he be this way? This per
son helped create me but only thinks of himself and treats me like an object. I'm a psychology student (and also really into nonverbal behavior) so I see in his reactions all the defensiveness he exerts to maintain control. It is like fighting a defense mechanism and like me and giving away information it seems involuntary. The theory that this isn't SPD specific and more a universal mental health seems very true to me to a certain extent anyways.. personality disorders and other psychological disorders not stemming from physiological abnormalities (brain and other organ functioning) can be thought through with techniques like your friend is working on. The key to helping folks in this category is deep introspection and consideration of how the illness affects your life and tackling the ""problems"" one at a time. Other mental illnesses that come from abnormal brain chemistry / structures like schizophrenia or depression (via shrunken hippocampus) don't really apply but they'd still benefit from the approach. 
I think we're in the same boat Eldror... or at least in the same ocean. Practice makes better and since writing my original post I've been to therapy every week and have been embracing those moments where I feel like the real self even though they're awkward. I think it's helping and in my day to day I'm masked less. I'm pretty mentally drained from the effort by the end of the day but it's sort of like exercising my real self. Oblivion your post gave me a lot to think about. Like the fact that I was considering it as a problem to be solved gave me pause. I had to consider whether or not the way I handle interactions was something I wanted to change or not and what I wanted to change about it. Changing my thinking about my psyche (who I am, how I am) from considering it as one unit to a way more like partitions in a computer allowed me to tweak a things and accept more of how I am in general. Your post was especially helpful. Thank you I'm still active and will have more time for responses later. Lets keep ta
lking about this everyone! -?"

175965756,"I experienced psychosis in my mid twenties. During that time I became very paranoid. It felt like I was being watched through the TV, web camera and magazines. Any photo with eyes would stare back at me and it was a very penetrating stare. My privacy was gone, including what I was thinking. Everything about me the public could see and hear. The world was grey and cold. The bottom half was red. The North Koreans were taking over the world and I was the only one who knew. Gradually I felt like I was being pursued, because I knew this was happening. This information was being communicated to me through magazines and the TV. It was also revealed in my dreams. This experience was torture. It made me very anxious. The agitation I had was also bad. At times it got severe that I would just walk around the city at night for hours and hours, just so I wouldn't violently explode. One time I walked by a hospital and thought about going to Emergency but didn't, because 5 years previously, I had a traumatic psyc
hiatric experience. I was misdiagnosed with BPD and accused of attention seeking. I wasn't going to submit myself to that again, so I walked past the place. - I got treated thanks to a social worker. The Zyprexa started to clear my thinking within 3 days. For years I was was sort of ashamed of this experience. I never really discussed it in depth until recently with my psychiatrist, who wasn't treating me at that time."

175965758,"Minipuff: It’s like getting a Christmas present hearing from you. You present the most gosh awful of situations, people try to help you, then you give a short reply, then we don’t hear from you. It’s like the parent worried about the child for leaving them in the lurch about how they are doing. You don’t know how excruciating that is. It’s like bad news is better than no news. I’ve been in situations like that. Does your ego strength get very low when times are tough? And you can’t reach out or respond? That’s what happens to me when I’m low. I use to have anxiety attacks, from Dr. _PERSON_. I came in as depressed, and instead of wondering if I had mania, also, as in bipolar, which I do, he simply diagnosed me as depressed and gave me an anti-depressant. Without a stabilizer like Lithium, which I’m now on to slow down the anti-depressant Mirtazapine, I started having panic attacks. So I’m wondering when did your panic attacks start? Did they start with a medicine, but then I s
houldn’t ask you that? Did they start with a lot of anxiety? Web.md said, before you start taking Prozac, tell your doctor if you have a personal or family history of bipolar. Do you have bipolar? Symptoms are racing mind, coming up with more ideas than you have the energy or time to carry out, staying up late. Net says Prozac also treats depression in addition to anxiety. You need to check everything with your psychiatrist. Are you generally positive that you can get through this, for I found out that my thinking can influence the outcome? I was very negative and a lot of things did turn out that way. As for sleep, I take Melatonin, along with my regular meds."

175966026,"My resting heart rate used to average 90-100bpm. My resting heart rate right now is also 73bpm right now even though I'm on a stimulant. The lowest it's ever been while sleeping is 30bpm (But I was exercising a lot every day back then). It goes to ~60bpm when I'm sleeping now and not 40-50bpm when I'm sleeping anymore. I think it's because I'm not exercising as much + I'm on a higher dose of dextroamphetamine. I used to have terrible heart OCD. It was baaaadd... All started after I was on a 4-fluoro-methylphenidate binge and then took lots of 4-AcO-DMT - I was checking my pulse for hours during the trip - Neurogenesis developed and it took a lot of neuroplasticity and training to break the mold of my brain to reform it. The beta blockers helped. I went to my current doctor after the previous doctor in the clinic said my heart was fine and he didn't check my blood pressure. I was given the beta blocker by my current doctor. The first time I noticed my first beta blocker kicking in, I was so relieved
. It was better than a benzo for lowering heart rate. I used to panic if I had to stand up for a long time during work cuz of POTS + I'd lie down on the floor at work as well because that's when it beat at it's lowest bpm. I'm still afraid of intense exercise but I've done it before and nothing was wrong. The more exercise, the better. Antipsychotic - Sleep med - Benzo for panic - Beta blocker - Then stimulant. If it was in any other order, then these meds wouldn't be considered justified."

175966044,"That's the million-dollar question. And it seems to be vital for ""normal"" social integration in general. I think it is, in a way. Just not an absolute way. Non-rational belief of some kind is inevitable, but it won't be absorbed from the outside in the same way and measure as it is by most people, and it won't serve the same purposes under the same circumstances. Sometimes that will make those personal beliefs more pronounced than normal though, like with more stereotypical schizotypals. I think so too. I like reading/hearing about physics too, but I think it usually puts my head in the clouds instead. I'm trying to think of what it is that keeps my feet on the ground, but I can't name it in a simple way. There's this verse from a song I really like ("" there is harmony in everything ""). It resonates with me. Everything has a positive side. No exceptions. If I don't see it, it's because I haven't looked hard enough yet. Or sometimes because it really is hard to see (and maybe not worth the troub
le), but it's there anyway (and in an extreme-enough circumstance it might actually be worth it). It's obviously not ""true"" (or ""false"" either), but it's an effective guiding principle. The periods of my life when I feel the most troubled are the ones when I find it the hardest to frame reality under that belief, but I still strive to do it, and that's how I recover."

174356241,"First of all, I don't have schizophrenia. But the way my mind works is rather unsettling and I'm not sure how to describe it. I'm not sure whether it can be called hallucinations, but it might be that. Anyway, I'm not sure this is the right forum to post this in, so please move it if it's not - I couldn't find anything more appropriate. Anyway. I'm on Fluoxetine, or Prozac, and I feel like these meds are messing with my mind. Without them, my anxiety becomes unbearable, but I feel these meds mess with my memories and perception in a way it's beyond unsettling. I remember something from five seconds ago vividly and precisely - only to discover those memories are entirely wrong. I try to think about it again, and suddenly the clear memories are fuzzy. I no longer remember it clearly. Which makes sense, given the thing I just thought to remember was false, but how was I so sure? How did it feel so real? Today a car passed me, driving up to an intersection where my house is located. The parking spot to 
our house is also located there. The car brakes, and - at that moment - I saw the car park in our spot, only noticing there it was my dad that passed me. Though he did not get out of the car. As I approached it, he suddenly came out of the house. No driver in the car. He said he'd been home for the past 30 minutes. I vividly remembered just seeing the car park there, but that couldn't be. I felt like I had just encountered a glitch in the matrix - or rather, I felt nothing really. I feel like I should've panicked, but I didn't. Maybe because these clear memories I thought I had were no longer there. It felt like it was the strangest thing I ever encountered, yet just minutes later it already began feeling more normal since I no longer had these clear memories. Long story short, I feel like sometimes my brain just stops paying attention to the real world and fabricates its own reality for a few seconds, but begins throwing out that false memory as soon as you try to think back on it. I'm not sure how to feel a
bout this. I feel like this can be classified as hallucinations and it's incredibly unnerving and unsettling. I don't remember having had these encounters when I didn't take the medicine yet. Some other info that might be worth mentioning that might relate to this: - Sometimes I hear very subtle sounds, of which I'm not sure whether they are really there or not. - I had exploding head syndrome for a few months in the past, though it has stopped. I took the most medicine during that period. - I have already witnessed bright flashes at night that weren't there, though this was rather rare. - Often I find it very hard to focus. I don't give any deeper meaning to these occurrences myself, though it feels like my mind thinks reality is being warped itself (this might be related to my OCD). I don't feel like I'm going crazy, but I find this so unnerving and I'm not sure what to do."
175966074,"I read something cool in a book. It's about making questolutions instead of resolutions (of course I'm not saying resolutions are bad). But a questolution is something you propose to yourself in the form of a question. For example, one of mine is: How might I get myself to run every day? I just thought it was kind of a cool idea because it gets your mind thinking about how to make that come true without putting extra pressure on yourself or criticizing yourself."

174356237,"Hello, _PERSON_, I agree with a lot of what _PERSON_ said. Maybe because I also have a brother who had a suicide attempt and was diagnosed schizophrenic around age 20. I had already been in therapy for several years, and I believed he should be reported for his suicide attempt. I made the report, he was hospitalized against his will. He blamed me, of course, and wouldn't see me while in the hospital. The worst time in my family's lifetime, and we had already had bad times. So yes, there is the brutal pain of the others to consider. But also as in my brother's case, and I do feel much pain for _PERSON_, he is still with us at age right around 50. He struggles everyday with implications of his mental illness, but he is compliant with his meds, and he works a full-time job. My parents passed away in recent years and we found him an apartment not far from me. He's been there about 1.5 years. It has been a long road, with a few more hospitalizations in the meanwhile. He learned to know enough to sign hi
mself in when the doctors said he should. Last time coming up on 10 years ago. So, _PERSON_, sometimes it does work out in the longer run. And even making it for 30 years for _PERSON_ brother was an accomplishment for him and the family. We don't want to think about a tragic, painful ending. But we press on, like we family members do with our own lives, despite difficulties. I hope you find the treatment you need. If you tell us more about you personally, instead of the intellectual debate, maybe we can help."

175966121,"_PERSON_, I used to struggle with negative thinking as well...it was just how I was wired up. However, learning that you can retrain your brain so that thinking in a more posive way, has been a game changer! Our brains will respond to whatever thoughts they are exposed to...so catching the negative thoughts and redirecting them into good ones will become a habit over time. It takes some practice, but it will work with continued effort...and even start to change the brain's chemistry! Using 'Therapy Worksheets' to restructure negative thoughts...as well as practicing 'Positive Mantras' are two tools to start with. You can find directions for both in our Resources. I hope you can put these into use and start seeing a difference soon. You've already taken the 1st step in recognizing the issue...and that is HUGE! Well done! Keep us updated so we can keep you in support! S.C."

175966157,"Although I did say it later in the post from which the above quote was culled, I should point out that when given ample space, I am also more likely to seek out social interaction, or at least think about it without dismissing the idea so quickly. As far as people accepting you as you are, yes, there has to be some compromise. On both sides. But this compromise can be adjusted to fit the situation at hand. For example; it's perfectly reasonable for your wife to expect you to interact with her family, but she should also understand that when you pass the point of being able to tolerate it comfortably, she should offer you some kind of exit. That's all. I can't really give you any tips regarding the topic here, because I am not married. If anything, I enjoy too much isolation. Sometimes just going out onto the street after a few days inside can be surreal, even jarring. I'm tempted to say that's probably not healthy, but neither is the alternative. I can answer the following questions, though: What c
ounts as being alone? Mainly, knowing nobody has any expectations of me. No calls to return, no emails to respond to, no pending business that might cause somebody to call, or worse (unspeakably so) to knock on my door. I want one of these: Is it possible to increase feeling alone even when other people are nearby? When I lived in a house with five other people, simply being alone in my room was usually the best I could do. I suppose it's a matter of degree. If I found myself in a similar situation these days, it would take me a long time to adjust to accepting that my solitude would have to be compromised. In fact, being that I've lived alone for the past 25 years, I wonder if I could ever adjust. It's a scary thought, but that fear is tempered only by the fact that I am currently in quite a bit of financial distress, and taking on a roommate would be an ideal solution as far as finances go. But I've lived here for 12 years, alone except for the first, and having anyone move in would feel like a violation I 
could never come to terms with. If I were ever to share a living space with someone, it would have to be in a new place. The apartment where I live now is too much ""mine"". To see anyone else lounging on the couch at 10 PM would never stop feeling like an invasion. I've rubbed my scent everywhere. Are there good strategies for negotiating more time alone - particularly from family? Actually I can answer this. What I used to do is be aware of everybody else's schedule so I could make sure that if there was ever a window of time when nobody else would be home, I would make sure to take advantage of it. I can even remember calling out of work once or twice to take advantage of an empty house."

I have been diagnosed as bipolar, depression,social anxiety disorder, PTSD, and traumatic brain disoreder.I know it makes me sound pretty jacked up. A back story I was in the army for 12 years. During that time I had mental issues that I was able to powered through ,despite deployments ,until they caught up to me. At the end I started having bipolar episodes and anxiety attacks just the feeling of great fear anytime I had to be around people. This led me to lie to get out of having to be around others. I was a pretty good solider and ranked up quickly until about 6 months prior to being medically retired I completely fell apart. That was almost three years ago now, I can't feel anything but shame for my service.Since that time I have been deemed disabled. Now to my issues that constantly bother me, I feel so horrible for lying, and how my last 6 months went that I constantly

I get such anxiety and fear that I can't bring myself to actuality show up then I feel ashamed, then remorse just a constant cycle. A friend from the military committed suicide this week (that makes the 8th vet I have known that committed suicide). I can't stop thinking about death and how nothing in this life really matters in the end. It must be a sweet relief to finally feel shame and stress release from your body. I am really tired of living through death. The on
ly thing that keeps me going is my wife and son both of 14 years. I feel like I have let them down as well. I am tired of trying new meds, going through side effects. I really feel close to defeat. If anyone actually reads this whole thing I sincerely thank you."

175966168,"I have tapered my Sertraline 3 times. Also naturally, started 3 times. Starting gives me more side effects than tapering, it also depends on the dosage you are using. As others mentioned go slow, and discuss with your dr. Give yourself time. I say if you have been feeling stabilized for quite a while then yes, increased anxiety would be some amount of withdrawal. But it shouldn't be more than a week, just like starting sertraline first time. It's annoying but you can test it out if you still feel good after withdrawal. 175966231,"Dear _PERSON_, I totally understand how you are thinking. I've been there and my slightly out of range test result was something liver/pancreas related... imagine how anxious I became over that. xD Meanwhile the Dr was looking at my face and smiling. Then she said ""slightly out of range doesn't mean anything. Your other liver results are perfect. Don't worry"" After that of course I kept thinking about that for a month or so, then I replaced it with a new worry (it's typical for worriers) and when I realized the pattern of my thoughts, I calmed. It's been 4 years. I don't have a liver problem as far as I am concerned. And I don't want to check to be honest. So to sum it up, you will be fine if your Dr is not worried. Listen to them If you can't overcome the worry, ask for a second opinion. But it may cause more anxiety imo, so stick to your CBT skills as much as you can. All will be fine <3"

It’s been bothering me a lot lately and has been giving me a lot of anxiety. So I too have anxiety. I also see something similar to what I see in the dim lighting situation when I move my Ipad in a dark room. It’s not exactly the same though. I asked my brother if he saw the trail when he moved his phone in a dark room and he said he saw it too. So I am not really concerned about the one I s
ee with my Ipad as much I am with the one I see in dim rooms. I at first noticed this when I walked into my bedroom with a dim light on and approached my bed that has white bed sheets. I think the dim light was shining on the white bed sheets, making it brighter, but was not powerful enough to illuminate the rest of the room, making a dim environment and a slightly brighter bed. 174356676,"I've been closer and closer to complete dissociation, I struggle very much with bipolar type schizoaffective disorder. It's an ongoing battle and lately I've been slipping hard. I am starting to isolate myself, it's difficult to remain present and not many understand when I try to tell them whats happening. It can feel extremely lonely and I'm here with you. Different things work for others of course, but one thing i did when I was having extreme fear, axiety, and paranoiamy trip for a momentary relieve was smelling lemongrass oil. I'd carry it everywhere. I prefer methods that are not internal processes. Listening to music may help, but it can also effect your mood while you are vulnerable, or something of that sort. I have done a lot of meditating as well and have learned to only do it guided with my therapist, as I'm being taught that opening your mind up more while it is already batteling itself can actually exasperate whats going on in there. This is why i like to use things like aromatherapy. 
Massaging yourself may be beneficial as you are nurturing your body. If you are able to make an effort to get some exercise it could help perhaps even if its just climbing stairs a few times. I understand how difficult and frightening, its very complex, my suggestion would be to take baby steps. If you can relieve your heart and mind for even 30 seconds during those crisis moments you could find some form of relief. I hope this helps you somewhat , I'm here."

175966409,"Psychological torture is being exploited by states to circumvent the more widely understood ban on physically inflicting pain and may open the way to a future of “cyberculture”, the UN torture rapporteur has said. _PERSON_, professor of international law at the University of Glasgow and the UN’s special rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment or punishment, is cautioning that the internet could be used systematically to target individuals remotely – through “intimidation, harassment, surveillance, public shaming, and defamation”. A trenchant critic of the UK government’s failure to hold an inquiry into the rendition of jihadi suspects post-9/11, _PERSON_ has also voiced concerns over Britain’s treatment of the WikiLeaks founder _NAME_ in Belmarsh prison. Later this month the professor, who is Swiss, will present a report to the UN human rights council in _NAME_ highlighting his concern over “continuing development of psychological tortures and legal 
misconceptions about what conduct is prohibited by an international treaty”. His comments coincide with the UK release of a documentary, Eminent Monsters: A Manual for Modern Torture, which investigates covert CIA funding in the 1950s of techniques developed by the Scottish-born psychiatrist Dr. _NAME_. The documentary, directed by the Bafta-winning film-maker _NAME_, shows how patients were subjected to sensory deprivation, forced comas, LSD injections, and extreme physical and mental torture at a Canadian research establishment run by _NAME_. Those techniques, the documentary claims, were forerunners of methods used on the so-called “hooded men” who were subjected to white noise, put in stress positions, threatened and deprived of sleep, food, and water, and beaten after being arrested during internment in Northern Ireland in 1971. Similar techniques were later inflicted by US forces on jihadi suspects detained in Guantánamo Bay. In a 2018 judgment after the hooded men case was reopened, the European 
court of human rights reaffirmed that abuse of the 14 men almost 50 years before amounted to inhumane and degrading treatment, but did not constitute torture. That distinction, _PERSON_ argues, is wrong. “Judges think that physical torture is more serious than cruel, inhumane, or degrading treatment,” he told the Guardian. “Torture is simply the deliberate instrumentalization of pain and suffering.” Consequently, psychological torture methods are often used “to circumvent the ban on torture because they don’t leave any visible marks”. In his UN report, _PERSON_ points out that many countries “deny, neglect, misinterpret or trivialize psychological torture as what could be euphemistically described as ‘torture light’, whereas ‘real torture’ is still predominantly understood to require the infliction of physical pain or suffering. “Some states have even adopted national definitions of torture excluding mental pain or suffering, or interpretations requiring that in order to constitute t
orture, mental pain or suffering must be caused by the threat or infliction of physical pain or suffering, threats of imminent death, or profound mental disruption.” Many countries have invested “significant resources towards developing methods of torture which can achieve purposes of coercion, intimidation, punishment, humiliation or discrimination without causing readily identifiable physical harm or traces”, _PERSON_ states. “Some of these approaches have resurfaced most prominently in connection with interrogational torture in the context of counter-terrorism, ‘deterrence’-based detention of irregular migrants, alleged mass-internment for purposes of political ‘re-education’, and the abuse of individual prisoners of conscience.” An alarming development that Melzer contemplates is “cyberculture”. States, corporate actors, and organized criminals, he says, “not only have the capacity to conduct cyber-operations inflicting severe suffering on countless individuals but may well decide 
to do so for any of the purposes of torture. “Cybertechnology can also be used to inflict, or contribute to, severe mental suffering while avoiding the conduit of the physical body, most notably through intimidation, harassment, surveillance, public shaming and defamation, as well as appropriation, deletion or manipulation of information. “Already harassment in comparatively limited environments can expose targeted individuals to extremely elevated and prolonged levels of anxiety, stress, social isolation, and depression, and significantly increases the risk of suicide. “Arguably, therefore, much more systematic, government-sponsored threats and harassment delivered through cyber technologies not only entail a situation of effective powerlessness but may well inflict levels of anxiety, stress, shame, and guilt amounting to ‘severe mental suffering’ as required for a finding of torture.” In his UN report, _PERSON_ pays tribute to Eminent Monsters for showing “the origins and devastating effects o
f contemporary psychological torture”. Such experiments, he added, should be prevented in the future. Of the UK government’s decision last year not to hold a judicial inquiry into post-9/11 rendition, _PERSON_ told the Guardian: “I’m very worried. The convention against torture requires it. That refusal sets an example that we don’t really have to investigate and prosecute.”"

175966442,You seem to have good guesses on it. It is possible to have schizophrenia and dissociation. I used to hear voices in psychosis (Auditory) but they are different from dissociative voices (More mental). My dissociation was caused by use of psychedelics and is treated with olanzepine. I don't think most psychiatrists/psychologists are trained much about dissociation. I think the important thing is to make sure that your son is able to distinguish dissociative symptoms from those of schizophrenia (Because they can overlap) - So he doesn't get hospitalized for dissociative symptoms that can be treated with therapy rather than being hospitalized.

174356773,"Hey, so I read your post the other day, and I thought I'd respond now because I have time. First, awesome that you're interested in philosophy and especially Stoic philosophy. It interests me a lot as well. I bought the _NAME_ Holiday book recently. It's pretty good! I try to post occasionally on the Crazy Philosophy forum as well. Maybe start a thread on there. I'm not sure how Stoic philosophy can apply to cope with schizophrenia. The exciting thing for me about Stoicism is that the Stoics believed that mental anxiety was only mentally created, I suppose. So then does that mean that all of our thoughts are just psychological reactions to external events? If that is true, I believe it might be quite liberating. It also is somewhat scary and contrary to my experience to affirm that thoughts are mental representations of external events. One thing that stuck with me from the Stoics when I read them in college was that when you lose a person, for example, you should treat it (mentally) like you just 
lost an object or something like that. It stuck with me because I understand that people go through quite a lot of grief sometimes, and that's completely natural, and I do not deny that people should go through grief. However, it's also true that we can move forward and become even more strong through experiences like grief. I lost a friend right around that time in which I was studying the Stoics. And when the teacher explained that, I felt a weight lift. Not exactly in that moment; I mean, it wasn't like a scripted moment from a movie or anything, but I felt a lot better after understanding that we lose people like we lose objects. I don't believe that affirming that diminishes the importance of that person we lost; however, it's just a more balanced and rational way of dealing with things, in my view. Hope that wasn't too much of a ramble, and hope that maybe we could start a discussion on Stoicism or any other topic in the Crazy Philosophy forum."
175966463,"jellyfishLane... yes yes a thousand times yes !! Thank you for posting about this very thing that’s been annoying the crap out of me increasingly. I swear I was having a panic attack!” 20 minutes later “I’m still thinking about that creepy movie scene, I think I might have obsessive compulsive disease.” Uh.. you watched a HORROR movie. Why don’t you try living in MY brain which is a 24/7 horror show. Ugh."

175966520,"Hey there, thanks for joining Inspire! Definitely a good thing to do, I’ve recently joined and it’s so supportive and so much help is available. That is a terrible thing for you to deal with, especially dealing with these emotions alone for 7 months! I admire you for staying so strong throughout this difficult time. Your ex must have been such a manipulator, to leave you in such a sudden and shocking way, with no explanations, and taking all of your possessions! It must be so hard to live so far away from those you love and those who love you. You deserve to feel validated about your feelings, it must be so emotionally draining to deal with these feelings every day. I haven’t experienced any circumstances that you have, but I’ve heard people relate this sort of situation as an amputation. You get used to living without it, and you eventually heal, but you’re never the same. And I know it’s not something you can ‘just move on’ about, it involves a healing process and will take time a
nd perseverance. I’d recommend reaching out for support from a therapist, and I’m so so proud of you for reaching out today. I use the crisis textline 741741, since with COVID and an increase in daily duties I don’t have time to visit my therapist. Text ‘hey’ or ‘hello’ to that number and it’ll connect you to a professional (if you’re from the US). They’ve made an incredible difference in my life and have helped me so much. It’s much less anxiety than having to talk face to face with someone about what’s going on. Either finding a therapist to visit or using this textline are great options. Obviously as well as reaching out on Inspire! We’re here for you, don’t give up, you’ve got this!"

175966525,"oceanfisher: When years ago I was untreated for bipolar, which included depression and anxiety, decisions were difficult to make. For instance, I couldn't decide if I needed to see a psychiatrist. I was also negative, along with anxious, depressed and bipolar. Just a mental swirl, which, being negative, I didn't think I could solve. And I was right. Being negative, I couldn't solve it, so I stayed there in my apartment, pacing back and forth, until I had a nervous breakdown. So, if you have some negativity along with the anxiety, you might want to look at that. mayoclinic.org says one of the signs of anxiety is, ""Trouble concentrating or thinking about anything other than the present worry."" I typed in ""Anxiety and decision making"" in the search engine and Heysegmund.com said under ""How to Stop Anxiety Intruding on Decisions"": ""Be mindful. Mindfulness strengthens the pre-frontal cortex, which is the part of the brain that can be sent offline by anxiety. Without the full capacity of the pre-f
rontal cortex to weigh in on decision-making, decisions are more likely to become fixed and rigid and driven by intrusive emotions that don’t deserve the influence. Mindfulness strengthens the brain’s capacity to filter out distractions to make more grounded, relevant decisions. It limits the influence of the things that don’t matter, so you can focus on the things that do."" This above ""mindfulness"" (and being positive) are also stressed in this website's ""anxiety-panic resources"" at the top of the list of people who have written into this forum, which you might want to look at. Your situation is not unique. People have been down this road before. I'm one of them. It's good that you can reach out onto the computer, without having to leave your house, and get some websites such as this one to try and help out with the problem. We don't all have to repeat the same problems but can learn from those who have had this problem or studied it."

175966565,"S29, Morning anxiety is common and often due to Cortisol. This stress hormone makes is possible for us to get up and going in the a.m. Without it, we'd likely not get out of bed! However, those of us with anxiety either produce an excess of it, or are just particularly sensitive to its effects...and can end up having rough mornings until the levels naturally drop throughout the day. Try focusing on your coping mechanisms first thing when getting up to manage the anxiety and set a good tone for the day. Peace and progress, S.C."

175966641,"It comes down to motives for me. My own lies with motives to harm or exploit others are not ok with me. One reason being I still try to adhere to a 12 step program (at least to a degree) and making amends / admitting I'm wrong takes a degree of courage and humility I prefer to avoid indulging in as much as possible. Personally, I have a (possibly bad) habit of not paying much attention to (or even seeing) others' lies (unless I think their motives are to harm, exploit or betray me) because I tend to value people for my interactions with them rather than the content within those interactions. It's the little quirks or unique bits and pieces that are endearing (or I admire) that make things enjoyable for me, not what someone has or has accomplished, etc. I've always thought it was important and admirable to be authentic. One benefit of authenticity is when people try to betray your confidences, there's much less to be exposed. I'm slowly beginning to see why people choose not to be authentic though. 
I'm thinking that, rather than it being a strength or beneficial, it's quite inefficient because you end up in situations where people try to attack you or ###$ with you as a result < which is a lot of energy to have to tolerate. I think learning to hide authenticity (from the vast majority) might just be the more efficient way and I'm debating trying that type of shift < might be easier to do now that I know why it could benefit me. I'm only thinking out loud here; it's something I've been reflecting upon for a long time now. Anyways, I almost never (consciously) lie unless I need a shortcut to get out of something or to get someone off my back. Having to remember different stories is too much work. Unconsciously, I lie to myself just like every single other person does < ""blindspot"" and ""unknown"" quadrants of the Johari Window Model What's funny is when people go around calling others out for this type of dishonesty while being either completely unaware that they lie to themselves too - or proud that th
ey think they can hide themselves better than others - or they really can hide (but that's still not about self-honesty). We all think we're sneakier than we are - although some are more skilled at deception than others, for sure. Manipulation also encapsulates things like the essential behavior of an infant when it cries to be fed or changed, same with teaching a kid to potty train and any other form of purposeful conditioning in behaviorism. All about meeting needs and wants. Moreover, in many situations, taking the direct route is another one of things that can take a lot of courage with sometimes unpredictable results. Nobody likes that kind of thing when it comes to needs that matter to them. As for ""sending 'pictures' to other people"" by how you present yourself (also mentioned somewhere in this thread), I've never seen that as deceit or even a lie by omission. I've gathered together a variety of experiences and a variety of traits. If someone has a desperate enough need to categorize me because I cho
ose to highlight or focus on honest selections of those experiences and traits, in order to get to paint a ""picture"" - that's their problem - not mine."
175966642,"_NAME_ said... I appreciate the response, as it gives a good indication as to where you are in this situation. I once had a problem in which I didn't know if I should move from where I lived or not. I had once seen a true crime TV show where the detective was looking at a crime and said that the original police group should not have concentrated on suspect A, and ignored subject B. That the police should have run a ""dual investigation"" and investigated both subjects. So I applied that to my problem of, should I move or should I stay? In other words, look into the possibility of moving by calling different apart. complexes as to price, etc. But also, improve your situation at your current address, so if you decide to stay that will be possible. I decided to stay, and the improvements were already done. In your case, you have a dual situation. One physical and one emotional. Why not work on both? Why not go to a general practitioner about the physical problem, and a psychiatrist about the emotional 
problem? You don't have to take any medicine that the doctor might recommend, but it would be good to get his or her opinion, and also to have a psychiatrist in case you needed one. Another thing that might be going on is that you might have negative feelings about the outcome of this. That you might be looking to stay with these problems rather than solve them. If you were raised in a negative household like I was, you might have a negative outlook on things, on problems. As in ""no way am I going to solve this problem."" You could be holding yourself back, as I was for many years. Were you raised in a negative household? I appreciate the way you think."
