175966747,"I dont see or hear anything constantly, thank goodness. My visual hallucinations tend to be the most elaborate. Cats, bats, rats, snakes, people, bugs, then some more odd stuff like cartoon characters (only once or twice), monsters, symbols. Ive noticed that themes tend to come and go. I was seeing mostly small animals for a whilr... and then I was seeing monsters for a while... and then religious themes and symbols/demons/god... now its mostly like optical illusion stuff. Ill see a spot on the wall move in a circle or the carpet will seem like its moving- like its a carpet sea with waves. Thats all the visual stuff. The voices have taken on religious themes lately. One or two word phrases repeated. Heaven and hell/god and demons. Though theyve gotten much much rarer. Those one or two word phrases are only happening like once a week where for a while it was like... more than half of the days. “Again” is a common word repeated and one that drives me INSANE. Then dark threatening words which I ha
ve a hard time recalling when I think on them later bexause of the latent anxiety they cause. And then my name. Bells. Laughter. Angry voices. I do also wonder if I get olfactory hallhcinations because sometimes ill smell things that arent around either. But Im not sure on that"
175966748,"It's good you stayed on your other meds while you went off of the Zyprexa. I predict you'd be in another world if you hadn't stayed on your other medicines. You said, ""I wasn't sleeping for days, and I was fearful. She said that is why she put me on Zyprexa."" As a bipolar who takes Lithium and Mirtazapine anti-depressant, I have trouble with sleep, also. But I don't want to keep taking more doctor medicines if I can help it. So I try natural health food tablets for sleep, and what works for me is Melatonin. I'm on 4, 1 mg. tablets of Melatonin from the health food store, and it gets me to sleep. Sometimes, if I'm not sleeping good, I'll take 5. (I would start off with 1 or 2 of the 1 mg., and see how it goes.) Sometimes if I'm waking up at 3 or 4 in the morning and I've only had a few hours sleep, and I haven't been sleeping well, I can take one more Melatonin, because I'm thinking, the pills I took at 11 or 12 midnight, are wearing off. So by taking that extra Melatonin at about 3 or 4 a.m., it'
ll be kicking in at about 5 a.m., whereas the other meds will be wearing off. Also, I take the Melatonin about 1 hour before I go to bed, and at bedtime, I'm groggy, which is what I want. Someone on this forum said it can be taken 2-4 hours before bedtime, but I also don't want that to be wearing off at 3 or 4 in the a.m. So you might consider that, before running to the psychiatrist and she loads you up with some more doctor medicine. In addition to the Melatonin, I've also been taking my Mirtazapine anti-depressant one hour before bedtime. Mirtazapine causes muscle twitching and hunger. If I took it right when I went to bed, about an hour later, for about 5 years, my toes would start twitching (muscle spasms) and I would become so hungry I would have to get up and eat down the house. It was the side effects of the Mirtazapine. So, after 5 years of that, I decided, why not take the Mirtazapine an hour before bedtime, also, along with the Melatonin, so the side affects occur before I get into bed, not keep me 
awake an hour later? I just alert you to this in case you're having side affects of one or more of your medicines that you're taking at bedtime."

175966807,"Hi. I’m so sorry to hear this. My daughter had Lymes disease when she was in 6th grade. It went undiagnosed for about 3 months but devastated her health. She developed alopecia(including eye lashes eye brows gone) and had chronic headaches and joint pain for years. I also ended up having her take doxycycline two different times for 21 days each because she seemed to get the symptoms again. Changing her diet to more clean eating helped. 3 years after her hair fell out, it began to regrow. Her hair is long now with one stubborn area in the back that grows super slow. I took her to a neurologist who diagnosed her with migraines. He put her on a med for migraine and it has helped. Today, she is a senior. She has depression. She struggles in school. 175966825,"Bipolar 2 sucks. I was diagnosed about 20 years ago now (though I may be bipolar 1 or NOI (not otherwise indicated) now). It took nearly 15 years for me to get ahold of it, so maybe I can share some techniques that I've learned recently that seem to be of at least a little help. 1. Talk to your family members. My mom did similar things and I had to sit her down and have a discussion with her about how not only does the joking not help, it hurts the problem. 2. Have you tried any 5-senses techniques? For example, to stay in the moment, I may pick up something (literally anything) and start to actively note how it feels, smells, looks, sounds, and maybe even how it tastes. I have found that actively engaging in a 5-senses exercise, I'm able to come out of the exercise and not disassociate as much. 3. Find what I like to call ""moments of muchness"". These are spaces, art, music, or anything that can give me a sense of appreciation for the real world. I find that if I engage in finding things in the r
eal world that help me, it also helps me mitigate the disassociation. Also, there is a decent list of grounding techniques here. https://www.healthline.com/health/grounding-techniques. It will likely take some time to find the one that works for you, but don't get discouraged! Good luck with everything."

175966859,"Of the words you listed, indifference is the closest, but it's not exactly right. The best I can come up with is distraction. 175966933,"Hello idkwhatimdoinganymore, Welcome to Inspire! Thank you for sharing your story. We encourage you to check other discussions in this community about coping with depression. You can start by typing your search terms in the box near the magnifying glass at the top right side of the page or by clicking the link below. Search: coping with depression Our partner for this community, Mental Health America, also provides resources on their website including information about treatment options, guided recovery techniques, and self-help toolkits. This information can be found at the following links. Mental Health America: Finding Help for Myself Mental Health America: Recovery and Support Mental Health America: DIY Tools In addition, you may want to check out our iFred community. 175966958,"Greetings. I am not diagnosed as of right now, so I hope that it is still okay for me to post here on this section of the website. If not, I will leave - no problem. I will describe myself as having 'Schizoid traits' for now, since I want to be accurate. I will not change this until I have a professional diagnosis, even if I'm sure that I have the disorder. I simply wanted to match up my experiences with others who feel the same way as I do. Not necessarily talk to them, but... I want to read their well-written thoughts and ideas and possibly respond with my own (I guess that is just communication though, isn't it?). I never knew that Schizoid Personality Disorder existed until I went and did some research on my own. I personally feel as if professionals may misdiagnose me because of possible miscommunication or some other issue, but hopefully that will not happen. I plan to get a personality/psychological evaluation with an appointment some time in December, since that was the only appointment (ou
t of several that I have to go to) that was available. To anyone who has gone through these assessments - what is it like? What should I expect? The first time I looked at the DSM-5 diagnostic criteria, I simply thought that it described me perfectly. I am rather unemotional and bland, though I do put on a mask around others just so that I do not seem rude or get questioned (""are you okay? Are you sad/angry?""). I can still feel, it is just rather rare and not obvious at all. Others cannot tell how I have felt in the past, and an ex-lover described me as a ""robot."" The emotions I vaguely feel most often would be humor and annoyance. Even then, it is usually for a very brief moment before returning to that same level of nothingness. The feeling is almost like contentedness, but if that was more uncaring and apathetic. I have difficulty with empathy at times where it may be appropriate, and I would prefer to do things alone. I have two people I would consider 'friends' - but we talk maybe once a month at bes
t, and even then I get tired of it rather quickly. I remember even back in middle school I realized that the way I experienced emotion was different than others. I had went online and had taken 'tests' to see if I was a psychopath/sociopath, since that was the only thing I knew from the media where there was a lack of emotion involved. Of course I did not fit the typical criteria (such as impulsiveness, disregard of rules, aggression, manipulation, etc.) so I thought all was well. If only I knew how to use my head and research better as a kid. I get bored extremely easily, and I only do things because I have to (or it distracts me). I don't enjoy many things, which is why I start and stop them rather quickly. I'm not necessarily bothered by this. I'm doing my entire first year of college/university during my last year of high school and I don't feel motivated towards any degree path. I've taken the interest tests, and answer uninterested for pretty much every category possible. Nothing seems to truly intrigue 
or excite me in any way. The classes are boring (even though they are a normal difficulty) and I do the minimum amount I can to keep an A or B in everything. I am unsure if a professional will diagnose me with a personality disorder even if I have all of the symptoms. Isn't there some type of rift within the psychological field about diagnosing people under the age of 25 with personality disorders? It has been far longer than a year since I have been this way. It is not something that can be chalked up to depression or anxiety or anything similar - because I'm not continuously 'down.' I have dealt with both in the past several years prior, and this is not that. This is something below. Something that feels like a baseline in my personality and brain. I'm not happy nor sad. There is somebody directly in the bloodline above me who acts rather overt, and another covert - I'm guessing if there is a genetic factor, that those two on the same side of the family have transferred this directly to me. Can somebody be 
diagnosed with this when they are younger (and have you)? I feel as if I am rather overt (and I hate to say a ""special case"" in late teens - but that may actually be true). People in my family think that my personality and behavior is odd, and often tease me about acting like an ""old man."" If anyone knows more about younger people getting a diagnosis, I would be interested if you told me about your experience. This moved from an introduction rather quickly, didn't it? I apologize. I did not mean to make it so long and off-topic - but I feel as if it will do. Hopefully this forum will provide useful input from others with this disorder/traits of the disorder. See you around."

175966962,"As I decide what to say, my options are infighting with each other.. judging as to motive and intent. It's probably best to just keep to myself and stop trying to reach out to others.. that I'll only do harm no matter how much I wish to help, that I'll always leave the world a worse place than a better one as hard as I try. In many ways I don't think I can understand your pain because I'm dying of my own.. but it just occurred to me that we could be considered opposites, and yet still struggling in very similar ways. It's almost laughable how much it doesn't even matter what we think, how we perceive ourselves and what we want to change because then we're just as likely to want yet something else. I can't speak for anyone else, but this depression of mine seems to be like a fire in the wind.. uncontrollable, spreading, angst and dissatisfaction with how my life has turned out. Yearning for connection and sense of purpose and yet all I can manage to desire to do is just sleep it all away until I'm g
one. Don't want.. that's what I think I feel right now.. no matter what is, I don't want it anymore. I'm tired of trying. I'm tired of hoping beyond the odds that things will change. I'm tired of failing without any sense for what will finally work for me. What I think I want is someone to be able to call up and talk to but everyone's so busy all the time. I don't want to get in their way, and I don't mean to get in yours either.. so forgive me. It just stuck me reading your words that it's the negativity itself that must be fought because it doesn't matter if you're lonely or just want to be left alone, depression has a special place in hell for us all, if we let it."

175967009,"Hello _PERSON_..A very big welcoming hug to you, as you join the Inspire family! You have given us a well-presented picture of how you are doing, and I thank you for that. There is a lot there to digest. After reading it all, and returning to double check your age, let me suggest that you may be experiencing the beginning of menopause, which could explain the sudden onset of depression. However, that does need to be checked by your doctor, as they are able to tell from blood work. There are so many things that can go wrong, on a physical level, which very much effects our emotions. From what you have written, let me assure you that many of us have been through similar things before, and come out smiling, on the other side. You are not alone with those feelings, and you are going to find help! The endometriosis by itself could be the underlying problem. I am glad you have a doctor's appointment coming up, but in the mean time.....try to keep your mind occupied with things other than the anxiety. I a
m glad that you find walks a good diversion....that's healthy. Also, keep music playing as much as possible, read when you can, maybe even learn a new craft on utube.....anything that will keep the mind from staying stuck on how you are feeling. And one more thing....come here to Inspire as often as you can, to chat with others....that is good for you, because, with your husband at work, and you not feeling well, it is possible that you are spending too much time alone. 174357822,"Trying to figure out if the following is schizo ""disorganized thinking"" or a stress / anxiety reaction from being overwhelmed and shutting down. ^ I got stressed / distressed about triggering or retraumatizing topics repeatedly for months, and I began to deeply struggle with reading and putting written assignments together - especially in order (I couldn't think about the whole picture = only small pieces at a time) because my brain would go fuzzy and I'd feel kind of sick. ^ Yet, once I completed my work, it always made sense + was in order + exceeded expectations in quality (although not completed on the original due date because of how extremely difficult the reading and putting together of assignments was). When I said this to someone, they went straight to claiming it was disorganized thinking. I wonder what they would have said had I not mentioned having been diagnosed with a psychotic disorder years ago. + Would explaining it as thought disorder symptoms and decompensation have still been 
their go-to opinion about someone with trauma or anxiety or depression? - or without a mental disorder altogether? It's concerning how differently you can be seen by others when they're influenced by a tiny bit of information about you or a label (confirmation bias discussed elsewhere) and/or seeing you through the lens of their own personal experiences and belief systems."

175967322,"_NAME_: You said you had taken many antidepressants and they ""either had adverse side effects or inefficacy (for panic disorder)?"" And ""My psychiatrist wants to try Gabapentin next because she thinks antidepressants just don’t work for me. I want to hear about other people’s experiences with different medications while having panic disorder."" As a bipolar, going in as depressed, I got dxed as depressed when I was really manic-depressed. The anti-depressant put me into mania and panic attacks. When Lithium was added, the panic attacks stopped immediately. Now my panic attacks were caused by being given an anti-depressant with no stabilizer (from being mis-dxed). They were medicine caused. Yours doesn't appear that. But I was wondering if what helped me (Lithium and my anti-depressant), which combined to stop both the depression and the panic attacks, might help you. So in the search engine, I typed in ""can lithium treat panic attacks?"" One about the 5th or 6th entry, the ""National library 
of medicine"" wrote something about that. In reduced form it said, “There is evidence that panic disorder and major depression might share some common neurobiological factors. This would be consistent with the fact that most antidepressant drugs are effective in preventing panic attacks.” The report noted a woman who had panic disorder and was also depressed. “The depressive syndrome improved rapidly with amitriptyline (150 mg/day), but the panic attacks persisted.” (Net says Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant.) They tried adding Lithium Carbonate at 600 mg a day (900 mg was too much). “Forty-eight hours later the patient showed a clinical improvement…. …. ""She remained symptom free with the maintenance of the drug combination. “To date, several reports have confirmed the beneficial effect of adding Lithium to a tricyclic antidepressant drug in resistant major depression. However, we believe that the present case report is the first one documenting the augmentation of a tricyclic ant
idepressant drug by lithium in a patient suffering from a panic disorder.” Again, you can find this by typing into the Google search engine: ""can lithium treat panic attacks?"" and it was the 5th or 6th one from the top (National library of medicine). You might want to print out the full report and show it to your psychiatrist. It's only about 20 sentences long. Again, as a bipolar, I take 600 mg of Lithium a day and 7.5 mg. of Mirtazapine anti-depressant and have done well on that for decades."
175967323,"Psychosis and meds decreased my cognitive but it made me more empathetic and gave me some kind of wisdom that I think, knowing myself, wouldn’t have gotten them otherwise. I used to be a reckless careless logical person and I don’t like that kind of person. Not anymore."

175967376,"Hello! I made this account a few years back but never used it so I decided to give it a try again. 175967393,"I've had anxiety attacks and they are a horror. 175967474,"It may be part of the idolization and devaluing others that people with BPD often do. Accepting that he could be as good as he seems, means taking a risk with your heart and accepting the possibility of rejection in the future. The feeling of opening up to another person and then possibly being abandoned is at the core of BPD . It can seem easier to find things you dislike and to drive the person away or discard them than to possibly be abandoned yourself. I would talk with a therapist who is trained in dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) who can help you to develop skills to deal with the discomfort you feel. Best of luck. I hope everything works out well for you."

175967484,"Hi! Thank you for reaching out - a lot of courage is involved in doing so. You deserve to feel validated, yet all too often, those closest to you don't understand what it feels like, and think it's 'just being sad' etc. This must be really tough for you! Your parents have no reason to dislike you for how you are. And there is a difference between FEELING anxious (an upcoming exam, a big event planning, etc.) and anxiety controlling every day. I'm not necessarily saying your mom is wrong - she probably does have anxiety as well. But your anxiety is a lot more frequent, which makes a big difference. It must be hard to feel so alone with these feelings, I've felt the same all too often. Any time I say anything about my depression, how anxious I am, how I hate myself, etc, my family just doesn't get it. They think i'm just sad, and give me hurtful advise like 'get over it' or 'its just life', etc. At one point, my anxiety was so bad that I had to leave church multiple times because the SAME people I've 
always seen was too much for me. You deserve to feel validated about how you feel, because it's real - even if noone else around understands. Nothing is 'wrong' with you, everyone is different from one another, and all have struggles that vary person to person. I would try doing things to calm your anxiety (that don't conflict with your parents), and maybe also paying attention to who/what/where/why your anxiety flares up... and try to avoid certain circumstances that makes your anxiety worse. I'd recommend things like meditation - I really like the Calm app, listening to calming instrumental music, taking a bath with a bath bomb, getting outside and enjoying nature, getting a few steps in, etc. Sorry for the long epistle :D hope this helps, keep fighting - you've got this!"

175967506,"*I am not a doctor*, but have done years of research for the same exact scenario as I have been on and off a few meds and they can be brutal to come off of. I followed a precise weening schedule my doctor gave me for a couple meds I tried. Most recently, I am proud to say that I successfully got off of Lexapro. It was not a cake walk, to say the least. My first week was MISERABLE. Vertigo, nausea, headaches, mood swings, brain ""buzzing"" sensations and feeling like my body was being shocked. I was DETERMINED not to say ""forget it"" and go back on the Lexapro. I decided to fight back. I came across a mental health blog post and it mentioned a mixture of a Magnesium supplement, b vitamin supplement, and a fish oil supplement. I of course consulted my doctor and he said give it a go. Honestly after 2 days I had energy again, I was not nauseous and the shocking feeling was very distant and minimal. I stayed SUPER, like CRAZY, hydrated to let my body do it's thing and filter the meds out. Also...sound
s crazy, but my mom was also researching for me and she got me a body brush (like you would bathe with) and directed me to ""dry brush"" my skin is circular motions before bed. Long story short, doing that is said to give your lymphatic system (lymphnodes) a boost and circulate more of the meds out of you system! I stayed super active and leaned on my amazing husband for his support and got thru it all! It has been 3 months and I feel great...this is coming from somone who NEVER thought it would be possible to fully end my love/hate relationship with anxiety/depression meds! You CAN do it!! Stay strong and stay DETERMINED!"

175967594,"There was a brief time in college but it didn't stick. A anomaly in my life as a whole. There was a lot going on at the time so it's hard to point a single finger at a cause. The air around me was charged, and my senses were running wild. I can still feel the memory. Sense it brush against my mind in a shudder. The only way I'll get back into that state is kicking and screaming. When the murmurs come, whispered thoughts about coincidences and spirits...I push it away. There's a risk in entertaining possibilities. I can feel it trembling beneath the surface like a cup too full of water. A rich imagination that could drown me."

175967598,"Morning. I’ve been dealing with more anxiety and stress lately. So much so, I’ve forgotten my meds 2x in the past week. I found this app tho on VR called Tripp. It’s a scientifically made app to help you calm down from anxiety. Also, to help you focus/refocus. Plus other things. It asks you how you feel before and after the visuals, which are kaleidoscopic type visuals, plus interactions where you use your head as the pointer/lead in the visuals instead of your controllers. It’s a meditative app. Before I rated myself 5 out of 10 with 10 being I feel excellent. After, i rated myself an 8. So it said I have a 30 percent increase in my mood."

175967600,"_PERSON_ I'm sorry that you've been struggling with not only your disease but also learning to trust again. Youre not alone! I've struggling with almost the same thing for around 15 years. I dont know how to rebuild friendships or establish new ones bc I've had major depression, migraines and anxiety for almost 20 years. I dont even know how to make friends anymore and I tend to come across offputting and most ppl I meet dont like me and I dont know what I'm doing wrong, I'm just out of practice from isolating so long. It's not just being able to make friends again, but deep down I think I kind of resent the friends that slowly disappeared over the years. Not the friends I was less close with and we obviously drifted apart bc I didnt go out anymore. But I find myself resenting the ppl I considered my best friends. The ones I told everything to, but when it came to telling them about my depression, there was no response other than 1 friend that asked why I was starting meds even after I told her my 
problems. She scrunched up her nose in disapproval and that was that. I've heard by many that I could get over it if I tried, it was all in my head, I was just lazy, etc. But never a ""how are u feeling, how was today, did your meds work?"" The thing is ppl dont respond to depression like they would any other disease that has some sort of test or proof that you really have the disease and the symptoms are real, so your more likely to get sympathy and understanding. Mostly I HATED when I experienced any emotion even if i got angry over something most would get angry about too, my friends would weird out on me and keep a distance just watching and thinking that I'm crazy or have issues. My bf from high school went to college together and lived together sophmore year (when I had my first major depressive episode and spiraled down from there) and 4 months later she told me she was moving in with someone else. After that we rarely if ever talked. My other roommate who I supported thru many major issues stopped tal
king to me when I decided to move in with my brother to save money. And my dorm suite mate and I always confided in each other but she got in a sorority so we still talked but not as often. A few years ago I saw that they had all been bridesmaids at each others weddings and I wasnt even invited. And I was closer to the two other roommates than my bc from high school and they still didnt invite me. It's hard to decide if I lost all friends bc I started isolating and not going out bc I was depressed. If me being depressed and negative about life made me unbearable to be around (bC I admit spending time with the mentally I'll isn't much fun so who would want to) or if my closest friends either didnt know how to deal with me or if they really weren't great friends who even checked up on me now and then. My trust in making new friends is completely gone. Instead of having a good time I wonder what kind of impression I'm making, trying to stay positive and cheerful and not do anything that makes them not like me. A
nd I'm a complete failure at it! Will it ever get better? I have NO friends now and I really dont know where to find new ones. I'm 38 and most are married with kids. I dont go to the gym and I dont know where to meet ppl and how to actually start a relationship I'm here for you if you want to talk or vent! We can practice our friendship skills together! 175967680,"Hi I'm a lifelong social phobic with bouts of severe depression and sometimes with panic attacks. I am so miserable that I don't get up until early afternoon just to make my days shorter. I was traumatized by a near drowning incident when I was small child and was a shy youngster before that. I must've been unconscious for a longer period of time because I don't remember coughing up water after CPR. I was messed up after that. I failed the next grade level and had a speech impedament problem. I had a difficult time in school thereafter. I found it difficult to concentrate on my studies. I did manage to graduate from highschool but my social phobia kept me from attending my graduation ceremony, prom dance and all other social events. I have had many doctors, tests and medications over my lifetime with little results. I have managed to hold down a job for over thirty five years and lived independently for most my life. But, I had difficulty, even thoughts of ending my life. It's difficult to describe 
this ugly feeling inside of me. I don't laugh or smile. This turns alot of people off. Can you imagine how frustrating it is for a social phobic with depression to approach others and have them turn away because I don't have a friendly appearance and I have difficulty in striking up a conversation. I grew up in a large family. How did I become so isolated? I currently live in a small motorhome and wonder from campground to campground and somehow had thought that I'd find myself getting out more and hiking in my new environments. It didn't workout that way. I had ended up staying inside alot at campgrounds. I think that this fulltime rv lifestyle is just me trying to leave my problems behind but they just follow me around wherever I go. I shouldn't have quit my job because that was the only place that had forced me to interact with other people even though, I was tense inside due to my social phobia. My parents had passed away many years ago. My older sister died of cancer years ago too. My older sister was th
e healthy one. She had the organic garden, ate healthy foods and exercised regularly. It shook me up to see her in her final days. How cancer had eaten away at her once healthy and lively body. She was one of the sweetest sisters one could of wished for. I had always thought that I'd go first before any of my other brothers and sisters due to my struggles with mental illness. When I'd first started out in my motorhome, it felt kind of good. It was like I freed myself from my mental illness. The great outdoors was going to cure me! I was going to finally experience the happiness that had been missing in my life. I don't have interests. I feel like I'm living on the outside but dead on the inside, if that makes any sense. Holidays mean nothing to me. It's been so long since I've seen any of my brothers or sisters. But, I just don't want to bother them with my problems. People want to be visited by happy, upbeat people. I wish that a person can exchange a life for another one like a suit that doesn't fit right. 
Or maybe, go into a clinic and ask for a shot of happiness like a flue shot that alot of people get once a year. Yeah, that's right. Why can't a vaccine be developed to prevent mental illness. I have been on several different types of medications without much improvement. I've seen many doctors and specialists and had many different types of tests. I have felt good for a little while, naturally, when I had a job that I was performing well at and my boss liked my work, I left work feeling good about myself. That's only when I don't have to work closely with others that would cause problems with my social phobia. I have worked with a team on a job but never fit in due to my inability to socialize comfortable around my coworkers and that had kept me from advancing in all my jobs. Once I start to feel shunned by my coworkers, the depression sets in, job performance suffers and I begin hating my job which would make me quit or get fired and then the depression gets worse because I screwed up another job, blame mys
elf, and start thinking about if heaven really exists and should I go there instead of looking for another job. I have managed about thirtyseven years of employment. I knew that I could of performed my jobs better, made advancements, if my social phobia and depression didn't get in the way. I wasn't a screwoff at work either. I really did want to fit in and feel comfortable around my coworkers and do a great job. Having a job that you do well at gives you dignity and makes you feel wanted. Retiring without overcoming social phobia with depression and wondering around in a rv is a early death sentence."

175967726,"""10 minutes of just trying to understand the state my mind is in usually helps me realize what I’m feeling anxious or guilty about. Personally, I’ve promised myself that I’m my own best friend, and if I saw a best friend struggling with bad feelings I would do anything I could to help them not feel that way anymore. So I help myself by erasing the time-blocks I have for the rest of the day and start back from square 1: “What do I want to do? What do I need to do? What is the root reason WHY I don’t want to avoid doing these things? How long will each item take me to do? How much time do I have left in the day? I will start in less than 5 seconds. 5, 4, 3, 2, go.”"""

175967769,"A person deserves to be treated with dignity, kindness and respect. The examples you shared about their relationship don't appear to reflect those things. I'm curious if your friend would think it appropriate if she were to treat anyone without dignity, kindness and respect. I've noticed with some people I personally know, they accept being treated in a way they themselves would never treat another person. Something I've been told by at least a couple of those people is that in childhood, when they were developing their own self-esteem, someone who had influence over them taught them to believe that they weren't worthy human beings. (Worthy of respect, kindness, being loved because they are human and not because of what they can achieve, etc.) My cousin's roommate was dealing with a difficult relationship that in some ways seem similar to the one you described. Her counselor introduced her to the concept of codependency. While that may or may not be the case with your friend, perhaps she might want 
to bring the topic up with her counselor. There are many books written about co-dependancy so if she has yet to establish with a counselor, she might find reading one of the books helpful in formulating questions that she can ask a counselor when she chooses one. Now, that all being said, I have found that there are a significant number of people to whom you can give perfect advice and yet they still won't choose to take it. Ultimately we each have to make our own choices regardless of what others suggest. If I had a friend who was going through struggles similar to your friend's, I would strongly suggest that a professional counselor might be of great help to her. I would also tell her that she deserves to be treated with dignity, respect, compassion and love. Reminding her of that is what I consider the best thing I could do for my friend and I feel it would be more valuable than any advice. In my experience, intimate relationships that are lacking in dignity, respect, compassion and unconditional love brin
g nothing but heartache and are doomed to failure. We can only be happy if we're true to ourselves and we can't be true to ourselves if we don't love ourselves- which I know is easier said than done. I sure hope things work out positively for your friend."

175967799,"Listened to a good podcast, a _NAME_ talk about the 1 minute secret to forming a new habit. It’s basically about not being overly ambitious when starting out with a new habit, and just doing something that’s better than nothing when starting out. Something like 1 minute of walking if you want to get into a daily walking routine for example. That’s not the end goal but it creates the routine and you get accustomed to getting up going out and doing it. And initiating tasks is usually the hardest part"

175967808,"Psychotherapists try and often succeed at making a difference in the lives of those struggling with mental illness by giving them helpful advice. But psychiatric technicians who work in mental hospitals and psychiatric wards help people in a different way. Psych techs aren't trained therapists. Instead, it's their jobs to keep patients in mental hospitals and psych wards safe. For example, they make sure that suicidal patients don't harm themselves while in the hospital. Psych techs certainly do help others. I think that's awesome. However, if you're thinking of becoming a psychiatric technician, be aware that the pay is low. And it's one of the most stressful ways to make a living."

She was my everything, my life, and my world. We met 12 years ago while I was overseas. We were both young, in my mid 20's and her early 20's. Being overseas I had no plans on finding a permanent or even a meaningful relationship but she turned that ship right around. Fast forward 12 years later, we have 1 child and live in our first home now for over 5 years. About 2 weeks ago she decided to sleep with someone else. I was devastated and for 40 hours didn't sleep. I still don't really sleep and I guess thats why i'm up at 3am writing this. She isn't fully to blame because I honestly neglected our relationship and although she has hinted in the past that she was not happy, I fought to get her back but once again slipped into complacency and made her unhappy again. Take that as me pushing her towards someone else, but I still think that infideli
ty is the highest crime that can be committed in a marriage and although I was heartbroken I felt her heart empty and she didn't want any part of our relationship anymore. I was finally ready to let go. 1 week after she broke the news to me though, she decided to go to an urgent care because she wasn't feeling well and found out that we were having our second child. She was 8 weeks pregnant. You can't make this stuff up. So we decided to stay together and have been working on making things work again. Although I want her to be happy and am currently doing my best to let things hopefully mend, i get anxiety attacks during the day. My mind races and thinks that she is still talking to or looking for another man to make her happy. I also wonder if one day she'll just cheat again. I am battling with myself every day to stay sane and for the sake of our children I am doing what needs to be done but all I really want to do is end my pain. I call some close friends from time to time and started vaping CBD to calm my 
nerves. I want to be happy with her, I love her so much, but the thought of her with another man kills me and makes me want to do something crazy. It makes me so angry that I can't think straight. I obviously have a hard time sleeping. I try to work out as much as possible to relieve the tension but its only temporary. I'm crying out for help because I want to lash out at everything and anyone who gets in my way and I just don't know what to do anymore. Will I ever be happy again? Can I ever trust her again? I don't know if I can live the rest of my life looking over my shoulder waiting for the day she comes home again to tell me that something happened or she's not happy so she found someone else. Who would want to live with some depressed and unhappy husband? Anyone to talk to or response would be appreciated."

175967819,"I actually tried three types of B12 (the shots, the pills, and the sublingual) I got the shots and the pills while I was deficient in B12 but I take the sublingual from time to time when I feel my energy is too low and muscles too weak. If your doctor prescribed you the shots rather than any other type because you require a very high dose or your B12 levels might be very low and the fastest way to make it go up is the shots. If you are not suffering from B12 deficiency symptoms, you can discuss with your doctor about trying other types (there are chewables too). Anyways, the shots are administered via the muscles. When I was having them, I did not experience any side effects or bad reactions instead they really made me feel better."

175967835,"By ""simulation theory"", do you guys mean a ""we live in the Matrix"" sort of thing? If so, then unless it is proven (with some kind of information that's clearly from outside our ""simulverse"" somehow ""leaking"" or being brought in here), it can't possibly prove anything. Metaphysics has no business proving things. There's that too, though I rarely remember dreams, so that's not really a defining trait of sleep for me. I think what actually defines the experience of sleep is the experience of both a level of continuity and a level of discontinuity between what you experienced before you fell asleep and what you're experiencing as you wake up. Or in short, awakening is what defines the experience of sleep. And death is nothing like that."

175967850,"I once saw a TV show on scuba divers who went into sunken boats. And some of them would get into the vessel and couldn't find their way back out, going backwards, One of the commentators who was a scuba diver said, ""Once you get into the first level of trouble, start backing out."" Meaning, don't get into one more level of difficulty than you can handle. If you get in past your limit, you might be in real trouble, is the way I interpreted it with problems in general. It sounds like you're in about 3 or 4 levels of trouble. I mean, it's pretty easy to understand why you're having a difficult time. One of those levels might be difficult enough, but 3 or 4? I think if you can deal with each of them separately and be positive that you can solve it, it might help. Can you be positive about each one? 175967852,"The most important thing that led to my recovery from serious mental illness was being denied Social Security Disability Income. I’m grateful we have a social safety net. It’s important to help people pull themselves up, and to provide care for those who cannot support themselves because of serious disability. The net may not be cast broad enough, as too many people who need help are denied services. However, some sort of meaningful work is crucial to heal, and to regain productivity and independence. I believe that many, if not most, people with mental illness want to recover and to successfully manage life with illness. They achieve wellness by applying the treatments prescribed for them, and by using whatever adjunct therapies work for them. Still others work just as hard but are tragically treatment resistant and find little solace. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/11/meaningful-work-is-the-best-therapy/"

175967895,"If you’ve worked before and are considered disabled at 22 or older, youll be on ssi. I was a kid that only worked 2 weeks out of my life at the time. I had records going back since I was 13 that I was in and out of the hospital. So they dated it back and I was on ssdi. “Disabled before 22” rule only applies to ssdi. Not ssi. Ssi is determined on an income based. _PERSON_ is determined based on hoe many quarters you’ve worked in your life (you need 40 quarters at the LEAST which is 5 years. Or you had to been disabled before 22 and not have worked). Had you had records showing u got diagnosed before 22 (can’t be ON 22) and whether u have worked or not, you can get ssdi from your parents income."

175967909,"Andwes, Do you have a benzo you can take before going in? If now I STRONGLY suggest asking for one to take pre-appointment. My sister does this and it is the only way she can get through going in to see the doctor or dentist. Making a dry run is another trick. Driving to your dr's office a few times and sitting in the waiting room for a few minutes and then leaving can help desensitize you to the environment a bit...making the real appointment time a little easier. Finally do you have someone who can take you. Someone who is understanding of your fears and can keep you calm and distracted? Trying all of these coping mechanisms can help you get through this. It may not ever be a pleasant experience...but at least you will be able to get it done. Best to you with this and keep us posted. S.C."

175968057,"It was hell, but was also strangely enough, the best time of my life. I was healthier, more active, with a sense of purpose. I just could not sustain it, which is unfortunate, but I had a glimpse of something else, a possibility. As for the alone time, maybe you could look at how you would look at it. Let's say you have plans and habits with someone else, probably it would annoy you if the other would just disappear. Its mainly a question of expectations, not so much about bad per say. Its no different than someone that would not show up for work, it disrupts. And those are relationships as well, even if mainly practical ones. And of course, doing well does not make it better, it makes the expectations higher. You don't get brownie points for doing work and then stopping. You get them for doing work constantly, even if on average it is lower. This is mostly because of proximity bias, where you are only good as your last interaction or action. Let's say you have a work load of 100 widgets and you ha
ve one week to do it. If you make the 100 widgets in two days and then expect to do nothing, think again. People will simply ask for 250 widget instead, or think you are lazy, even though the others take 5 days for the 100 widgets, because it is expected. They might applaud you on day 2 and 3, then hate you on day 4, 5 and 1, until you start producing again. So in the end, you will be called inconsistent, which is bad."

175968098,"Engaging your senses is one of the quickest and easiest ways to quickly self-soothe. You will need to experiment to find out which sensory based which stimulation works best for you. You’ll also need different strategies for different moods. What may help when you’re angry or agitated is very different from what may help when you’re numb or depressed. Here are some ideas to get started: Touch. If you’re not feeling enough, try running cold or hot (but not scalding hot) water over your hands; hold a piece of ice; or grip an object or the edge of a piece of furniture as tightly as you can. If you’re feeling too much, and need to calm down, try taking a hot bath or shower; snuggling under the bed covers, or cuddling with a pet. Taste. If you’re feeling empty and numb, try sucking on strong-flavored mints or candies, or slowly eat something with an intense flavor, such as salt-and-vinegar chips. If you want to calm down, try something soothing such as hot tea or soup. Smell. Light a candle, 
smell the flowers, try aromatherapy, spritz your favorite perfume, or whip up something in the kitchen that smells good. You may find that you respond best to strong smells, such as citrus, spices, and incense. Sight. Focus on an image that captures your attention. This can be something in your immediate environment (a great view, a beautiful flower arrangement, a favorite painting or photo) or something in your imagination that you visualize. Sound. Try listening to loud music, ringing a buzzer, or blowing a whistle when you need a jolt. To calm down, turn on soothing music or listen to the soothing sounds of nature, such as wind, birds, or the ocean. A sound machine works well if you can’t hear the real thing. For more information go to: http://www.helpguide.org/articles/personality-disorders/borderline-personality-disorder.htmWays"
175968099,Ugh god. Day 6 of little sleep. Idk why I can’t sleep anymore.

175968104,"I realize that it has been several years since this forum was created, but for anyone as confused and curious about SZPD as I was prior to diagnosis, I would like to share some details about my experience with fantasy. The schizoid fantasy is a common symptom in individuals with the disorder but to my understanding, not all people with SZPD have a fantasy life. I personally do. It would be a breach of my perceived anonymity to reveal too much about my own fantasy, but I do rely on it as a substitute for relationships. Specifically, my fantasy follows one individual with many similarities to myself. I feel extremely close to this individual; he is the only person for whom I am capable of feeling love. However, I never interact with him directly. Instead, I follow him throughout his day-to-day life and observe in a similar way to one might follow a character in a book or movie. Despite this, I created another character solely for the purpose of supporting and drawing close to him so that I feel more 
connected. Throughout the years, I have grown increasingly dependent on this individual so much so that his mood or circumstances determine my ability to function or interact for the day. For example, if he hits a rough patch, I become severely depressed and so exhausted that I am unable to communicate. On the other hand, if he is in a particularly good mood, I can pass as borderline friendly. Without him, I would be so withdrawn from the world that I do not doubt that I would currently be quite literally dead. I would have killed myself."

So sorry you had such bad experiences but thank you for taking the time to share. Hope things get much better, quickly. Respectfully, _NAME_"

175968134,"Hi everyone, I suffer from anxiety which is brought on by many things in my life. I have gone to many drs and given many meds. Between covid, chronic pain, fox and cnn news and just my day to day life-- I am struggling to function. I want to say thank you first to anyone who answers and also say I really care and agonize when I know others are in pain or suffering with anxiety. I was not prepared for how my life would turn out. I wish my parents and grandparents would have prepared me for life as a senior. I now talk with my own daughter to try to prepare her for what life will be like when she is my age. I feel as if I am so easily hurt by others now. People who are terse, rude or uncaring literally just break my heart. I just recently had someone close to me suffer a severe heart attack. Things such as this just cause me so much mental anguish. I go to my many drs appointments and honestly they push you in and out so quick I cannot express how I feel as I am rushed so the dr can move to the next 
patient. It seems the dollar is king in this world at times. Please don't misunderstand me I love my drs for the most part. I really appreciate any help they can give me. I used to be such a carefree type of person when younger. Now everything upsets me. The news is always negative. I suffer chronic pain which also makes my days anxious and difficult. I practice mindfulness and other relaxing techniques but with little help. I would like to ask if others here just get to the point where they are ready to just move on from this life? Please know I am not suicidal and have no thoughts of ending my life. I cant help but think there has got to be more to life than anxiety and pain. We live in a world of pain, fear, disease and a host of other problems our society suffers daily. I volunteered at our soup kitchen before covid but now I cant even do this. I try to help others financially when I can but not having much money myself makes it hard to help others. I know life is not all terrible yet the end of our lives 
just bring their own special troubles. I know this is a long message and I thank anyone and everyone who reads through it all. Please people-- just love one another because that is really what is important in life. All the rest is smoke and mirrors. Thanks and Merry Christmas"

174358955,"Thanks for the previous responses, getting by, theHTreturns, _NAME_ and many other beloved contributors. I'm sure you can guess that I posting at 3.58am in Singapore is an indication that all is still not quite well. To cut the long story short, my Bipolar wife was admitted to IMH hospital(voluntary admission) and stayed there for about a month. Visited her every day with food and my love. After that, she was discharged and is now on 2 pills of Sodium Valproate (500mg each) and 3 pills of Risperidone and 1 pill of Abilify. It was trying initially...sometimes, she would secretly spit out the medicine and hoped I wouldn't notice...However nowadays, she's resigned to the fact that she needs to take them, and sometimes gets water and swallows the pills without a reminder from me... She has been unable to secure a job and even when she did secure one, she left the job after one day. Last week, we went to watch Terminator: Dark Fate together at the cinema and she left the cinema one minute before the mov
ie started to go shopping. Textbook Bipolar 101 for her...I'm not sure about others. That was $7.50 down the drain. Just yesterday, we went to a café for cheese fries and I bought her caffe latte. After eating about 5-6 fries and drinking 3 sips, she said she wanted to go. I think that meal did not stretch past five minutes...some money gone down the drain too...at least I insisted on finishing my iced chocolate. I think I'm posting because I need support again...I'm not posting at another forum because of the negative vibes, but I'm back here because I fully remember the positive vibes here...and I guess that's what I need now. : / I checked my wife's handphone yesterday as I did not want to be taken aback by any future rude shock...she's been messaging this guy again...thankfully, he doesn't really answer her. She said she's thinking about being remarried and she's confused by all the male attention (when there is none). Her logical thinking and judgment is being greatly impaired. Though she did say she lo
ved him like a friend only. That was heartbreaking...but today, she said she missed me and did not ever want to leave me...and said I should consider looking for someone else if I was unhappy. She looked really melancholic and downcast. I told her she was the only girl I would ever love for the rest of my life till the day I died. She smiled momentarily. I know the real her...the real her is being smothered underneath all the Bipolar...the real her would never do anything to jeopardise our relationship. Knowing that and hoping that the real her will return someday, I press on like how _NAME_ wandered in the desert for forty years. Sometimes, I tell God I can't take it anymore and perhaps it might be better to end my life? But He doesn't end it. So, I press on, hoping to find water and respite some day... Nowadays, we do not sleep on the same bed. I've noticed that whenever I sleep on the bed with her, she will get up and not sleep anymore for the rest of the day, which makes her overall mood more unstable. He
nce, she will take her meds at 11+pm, and sleep till about 5+pm...and then I will sleep from then till mid-afternoon because my work starts late due to its unique nature. I know it's not normal, but it is something that I have to accept, till the real her returns. Recently, my wife lamented to me that she was angry with me for not giving her a kid...and she did not want to be lonely in her old age. I reminded her that we had agreed not to have one...for the fact that she was not well enough to have a kid and look after one. She claimed that she was of sound mind, but the reverse is true... Currently, she still whispers to herself...although it is markedly softer...she still makes strange and unsound decisions...sometimes, she will freeze completely and it is as if her soul left and she was in another world. In spite of all this, she makes sure that my lunch and dinner are all taken care of...God bless her soul. I think it's her way of telling me still loves me...even though she says I've become her best frien
d and not lover cos we don't 'do it' anymore... Sometimes, she will hold my hand at the shopping mall...and then suddenly release it...and then hold it...and then release it again...she's trying her best and really struggling and because of that, I cannot give up on her. It pains me to read of so many marriages that end up in divorce because of Bipolar. I don't want to be a part of this statistic, but no one can predict the future...so I can do is do my best and pray to God...what else can I do? I feel that one of the myriad reasons why these marriages break up is because the healthy spouse puts himself or herself above the Bipolar spouse's needs and will not accept anything that is deemed sub-standard. Although each and every person can exercise this right, I find it confounding from a moral standpoint. This is not to criticise or ridicule many people whose marriages have ended up in divorce because of mental illness. Believe me. My first marriage to my wife ended up in divorce (but I subsequently remarried 
her). My point is not to judge anyone. My point is that as the healthy spouse, I am ready to accept that some or most of my needs may not be met, if ever. I recognise true love, and for true love, I am willing to make this sacrifice, even if it is excruciating. I'm sure others think differently, and I will respect that, even if I don't always agree. Ah, what a foolish man, some might say. He should have bailed the first chance he had. Why did he even marry her in the first place? Because my wife(in her normal state) has something that I've never witnessed in many girls. Her humility, kindness and honesty. And she chose to take a risk and love me. So even though the going is very hard, I have to press on...to me, this is the only way. I made a promise before never to leave her, and I never will. I am not sure what tomorrow brings, but I'd like to think that God makes all things right in the end. If you have read so much, I thank you for reading my musings...if you are in the same boat as me, you have the choic
e to exercise any right you want, but I urge you to make it a moral one, even if love has dissipated. It's tempting to take the easy way out, but the course of true love is never smooth. Sometimes, we only find real love once in our life. So, hang in there till even this option exhausts itself... Post Edited (_PERSON_) : 11/20/2019 1:37:02 PM (GMT-7)"

175968144,"Not totally schizoid (see my signature), but I'm pretty much the same. I think I'm the same way with most emotions, kind of all or nothing. 99% of the time I'm neutral. If I'm happy or excited, I'm grinning like an idiot and bouncing around. If I'm sad, I'm sobbing. If I'm scared, I'm shaking and sweating. There's really no in between, and those extremes don't happen very often. They don't even have to be triggered by anything particularly major, most often it's stupidly small stuff. Imagining myself in somebody's position doesn't work for me either. I do find it easy to recognize and understand (at least theoretically) people's emotions though, even if I don't share them or think they're ridiculous."

175968157,"I'm very sorry to hear that you're struggling with making friends and feeling left behind. Health issues can sometimes make you feel like you're living on another planet, I know, I feel the same way. But you're not. You must remember your inherent goodness, offer yourself comfort and love. When we are wounded we often develop strategies that help us deal with our problems but that don't serve our wellbeing in other ways. Sometimes we armor ourselves or withdraw to protect ourselves, and then feel worse. Do you spend time with people at all? I feel a bit happier when it's warmer and I spend time in the yard gardening, and neighbors will stop and talk. Or even talking to the postman or the ups driver, or the cashier. Just those little casual conversations about nothing can make a world of difference to me. I sometimes listen to _NAME_ talks to deal with my struggles. (free podcast) She is great at teaching kindness to oneself, forgiveness, trust, etc. I can never learn those lessons enough, but respo
nding to you reminds me of my constant need to instill these ideas in my own heart. Perhaps then I could give you better words of support and encouragement , which is my intention."

I'm listening to _PERSON_, and I've always said his last three symphonies were his best works. Everyone knows the choir section of the ninth and final symphony, and the tragic thing is that _PERSON_ never got to hear his best piece of music. But anyway, the seventh symphony, mainly the second movement, has always been a doomsday piece for me. There was some movie, I think it was called ""The Knowing,"" but I'm not sure, I'm not a movie person, never have been, but anyway, this what they play when doomsday comes, and it's the perfect fit. I've always felt that this was the doomsday symphony, and _PERSON_ piano sonata in B minor was the tragic fall of an individual. A 
lot of people do NOT like _PERSON_ piano sonata because of ""doom and gloom"" it is. It's arguably the darkest piece of classical music made before the post-modernist era. Either way, there are other pieces of music that can give this tone, most of which came in the Romantic era. _PERSON_ had a bunch of pieces like that. _PERSON_ had a lot of pieces like that too. 175968199,"Ok so I know of 3 types of anxiety that I get.. 1. Mental anxiety (The worst because it causes a panic attack which causes physical anxiety. The only time I ever get ""anxiety"" is from panic attacks). 2. Physical anxiety (Second worst. I get this when speaking in front of a large group of people but I don't get mental anxiety when it happens. It actually feels kind of good like a rush.) 3. Stress (I don't even notice this. But it's always there). I'm constantly stressed. Stress is the main cause of diseases (Any disease). I can never relax. Marijuana doesn't help. Benzos make me feel numb and dull. I only use them for mental anxiety (Panic attacks). Opioids don't work on me and I don't like the feeling. Exercise and phenibut helps lift my mood. Meditation and stimulants seem to be the only thing that calms me down. I'm able to meditate better on stimulants because I don't crave dopamine. It's like the feeling of killing hunger but for thoughts."

175968232,"I got lazy and bunched the numbers together I was trying to use an example of emotional/behavioral states through a scale of 1-10 emotional continuum 1/10 would be calm and content 10/10 could be crisis Examples: emotional explosion or physical explosion, among other things I'm using the word ""baseline"" as one's most regular emotional/behavioral states. A typical individual who is managing stressors well, will probably have a baseline that is below 5/10 ^ Such as: 2/10 or 3/10 or 4/10 Those with trauma as well as those who lack skills or those who experience other struggles (including chronic stressors) usually have baselines higher than 5/10 ^ Such As: 6/10 or 7/10 or 8/10 If you imagine that number increasing everytime a stressor occurs without having ways to bring them down, it will take what looks like almost nothing to set them off (bring them to 10/10) because they're already naturally so close to 10/10 most of the time anyways"

175968299,"It’s good that you are reaching out seeking help, and are interested in improving her situation. She has a lot of things going for her, one of them is you. It sounds like she’s been diagnosed (bipolar) and has the medicine for that. If she will just take the medicine she already has. Do you know what medicine she has? As a bipolar myself, I take anti-depressant Mirtazapine and then Lithium which keeps the anti-depressant from throwing me into mania. What does she take? As for the symptoms for mania, to see if this sounds like what she might have, as noted by >medicalnewstoday.com<: *Higher energy (some people with mania may move from one activity to the next with many ideas of things that they want to do, often starting a variety of projects and not finishing them) *Feeling overly exhilarated (or extremely irritable) Inflated self-esteem *Racing thoughts (may include rapidly changing ideas and an inability to concentrate on one thing) *Pressured speech (tendency to talk very quickly and loudly. 
It often goes hand in hand with racing thoughts) Sleep difficulties (stay awake for more than 24 hours or only sleep 3 hours a night, yet report feeling as though they have slept well) Engaging in risky behaviors Does she show that in addition to depression? You need to know this so she can get on the right medicine. Is this her typical behavior? As far as not being able to afford medical help, there are free mental health and drug clinics around. You pay on a sliding scale, and pay only what you can afford, all the way down to free. You can look on your computer, type into the search engine, “mental health clinics in my hometown”. Write down the info and call one of them about an appointment. She can tell them she wants a female counselor if that's what she wants. As for what to do when she has an outburst, I use to have a Beagle dog who almost knocked herself out one night by sniffing under the front door and knocking loose a security pipe that attached over her head to underneath the door handle, and r
eached down to the floor. She inadvertently knocked the pipe loose from where it was lightly attached to the floor, and it fell on her head and she thought someone was beating her to death. She started running in circles, jumping up on my bed for a second or two, and then continuing her path, yelping loudly all the while. Whenever she got to the bed, I would tell her, “I love you.” I never tried to hold her down. I would advise not trying to hold you wife, but merely telling her you love her when she is having such an episode. I would consider such verbal support, getting closer to her if that was accepted, if so, lightly touching her and then maybe lightly holding her. I would be careful about physical restraint. Say supporting things like, ""I'm working on getting you some help."" You said she had “so many co-morbid conditions - PTSD, sexual assault from the past, anxiety, agoraphobia, seizures, etc.” So, that kinda explains what’s going on. So, what it sound like she is doing is taking out her an
ger out on herself, when it was others who mistreated her. Some people take the anger out on others by harming them. Neither one is really good. But at least you know what is going on. You said she “self medicates with marijuana consistently, and that helps most of the time, - that Marijuana isn't enough sometimes.” She may not be on the right medicine, she may not have been diagnosed right. If she was on the right medicine, she might not feel the need to self-medicate. If she was balanced, that would be a big help. That’s why we need to get her to a medical clinic. That’s why you need to determine if she’s bipolar by looking at those symptoms. Does she tell you about the trauma things? Also, what were her parents about ? One thing, were they negative? I use to have negative unconscious thinking and it really tripped me up. I probably learned that from my negative parents, and maybe from being bipolar, maybe both. But the form of positive thinking that I happened upon was to think positive going int
o the problem, thinking that I could solve it, even before I started trying. That put my brain on positive, looking for solutions, not on my unconscious automatic negative looking for failure as I was taught as a child. At the top of this bipolar forum are resources about dealing with illnesses, which includes a part about being positive as one portion of working on an illness. I would suggest you look at that. I think it’s good that you are trying to help her."

The going is tough and the language used to get there must be unambiguous and clear. Pure mathematics is the closest we come to it. 175968369,"zeze Welcome to Inspire............You say that you know it does not seem like a major problem.......oh yes it does! It effects our comfort with self. We have a strong and legitimate need to be satisfied with what we have accomplished on any given day. If we do not get that, then we walk through our life with the voice of a devil sitting on our shoulder, feeding us with negative thoughts and words as to our worth as a human being.....that is BIG !!!! YOU ALONE HAVE TOTAL CONTROL OVER THAT!! It is a matter of retraining your thought process. It goes like this: ""zeze you didn't do a good job of making the bed"". So then, you either stop and do a better job, or....you say to self ""maybe I didn't do my best job, but....I have several other things to do, so, given the amount of energy I had to donate to that job....I did it well enough and I will be satisfied""! It is a matter of retraining the thought process. That, of course, is not permission to do things in a half-assed fashion, but permission to 
do your best, AND BE HAPPY WITH THE RESULTS! Could that help?"

174359343,"So then, once this type of thinking transfers into emotions / distress overwhelming enough to constitute compulsive behaviors, it becomes a type of OCD? If so, then where is the line between what we're talking about and intrusive thoughts? Yes, when it interferes. Without going into detail, I'll say my experiences with ""odd beliefs"" can interfere. Not enough to stop me from functioning, but it sure as hell can slow things down and/or complicate very simple things. I've had the schizoaffective disorder dx more than once before, but I've also dropped it more than once. I haven't been considered SZA in approximately 2+ years (I'm bad with tracking time due to dissociative / partially dissociative states). Currently, they look at this part of me more in a way of who I am and coping mechanisms. When you say ""born out of experience and inappropriate interpretation,"" I'm assuming you mean? ^ Which I think you're saying is not the same thing as schizotypal ""odd belief"" thinking. ^ But since the DSM i
s only really interested in labeling, what if that was to be the actual cause of it? And if not, then what? This is particularly interesting. I'm not sure if I'm talking along the same lines, but there are times (or phases in my my life - I shift a lot) where I have to put effort into being understood. I make sense and am not unintelligent, but I can be quite creative in how I say things. Sometimes it's almost a metaphorical paraphrasing. If I'm to explain my thought processes behind what I say and tie everything together, I don't actually have ""disorganized speech."" I'm not as random as I sometimes appear (other times I am for fun/play) and I don't actually do ""word salad."" I'm wondering if this means leaving out information or framing what you say differently than how you see things to avoid _USER_ID_ / labels / judgment / confusion / having to explain (almost like I'm asking you to do right now ) ....? Also interesting. Sometimes I feel emotional connection / rapport enters me into a contract of agreem
ent or forced alliance with people which can lead to denying my authenticity and desire to do what I want mainly because I'm quite opinionated and don't see things the way a lot of the people I'm around do, but I'm pretty sure this isn't what you mean. 175968446,"_PERSON_, I agree with all of the above. Blood pressure is designed to fluctuate throughout the day, with activity, stressors, ect. You may have been nervous during your screening or it could have been an inaccurate reading. In other words one reading doesn't give you the overall picture...and the average of reading throughout the day is the best indication of what your median BP actually is. So if you have a home monitor and you don't already track it, starting to do so could be a good plan. Or you could just tell your doctor of your recent experience. (and/or ask for a recheck) If he/she isn't worried about it neither should you be. Peace and progress! S.C."

I noticed over time that while there, if I didn't focus on it and get upset about it, my mind slowly forgot. To the point that I may be seeing it but not really registering consciously per say. So I don't react. I can of course make myself see it, lighting conditions matter the most. Typically low lighting, or a bright source like a bright screen and moving my hand or objects over a dark desk or keyboard. So it's always there. I don't believe it has changed at all. I never have gotten an answer to this, or what causes it. But it's either an eye issue (unlikely), or a brain issue (likely). It probably is illusory palinopsia, idiopathic for me. No known cause, just appeared. It seems incredibly odd something can just ""appear"" one day for no apparent reason, but it did. I've tried to figure out the why, and have not ever been able t
o find a link between me and others. Outside say, stress. Which everyone has, and not everyone has this. I'm also near sighted, have a good amount of floaters and years ago did have periods of odd visual anomalies (not anymore) such as seeing certain lines and patterns wave and oscillate and such. Like everyone else, the doctors clear me for my eyes being fine, even with an in depth image retina scan. So, it's likely a brain issue. My biggest tip would be to not focus on it (easier said than done). My mind finally moved onto other issues I was having which helped separate myself from it. I don't react to it as badly anymore, and that has then in turn allowed my mind to not as easily pick up consciously that I'm seeing it."

(I'm sorry I don't know what that is... perhaps a psychiatric nurse practitioner?) I don't know if you have a psychiatrist you see regularly. But what occurs to me, with regard to what you wrote, is that perhaps what might be helpful would be if you could arrange to be seen consistently by one psychiatrist. I know, in my own case, every time I have had occasion to be seen by a different psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse practitioner, etc. each one always has wanted to do something different with me. And I think all of the changes that occur when that happens can really confuse a person's treatment. Plus just the changes in medications themselves can produce new & some
times disturbing side effects. (After a while one doesn't know what's causing what.) From my perspective, when it comes to mental health services, & psych med's in particular, there is something to be said for consistency. But then that's just my personal, non-professional opinion based on my own experiences. I hope you are able to find a solution to all of these disturbing experiences."

174359590,"Hello _PERSON_: Thank you for bringing your concern here to PC. I noticed this is your first post. So... welcome to Psych Central. I'm not a mental health professional myself. (Most of us here on PC are not.) So I can't tell you whether or not what you are experiencing could be considered psychosis. However here's a link to an ""Ask the Therapist"" column, from Psych Central's archives, where the writer asked about LSD use & psychosis. Perhaps the therapist's response may be of some interest: Derealization/Depersonalization & Fear of Psychosis or Schizophrenia After LSD-Induced Panic Attack - Ask the Therapist I'm sorry there really is nothing I can offer personally with regard to your concern. My personal opinion though, for what it's worth, is that using any kind of mind-altering drug when one has a mental illness is simply asking for trouble (maybe even if one does not have a mental health diagnosis.) It can be difficult enough to deal with the impact of having a mental illness without throwing 
something like LSD into the mix. So my personal non-professional suggestion would be to check in with your mental health & / or medical care providers & stop throwing the LSD ""monkey wrench"" into the works. I hope you find PC to be of benefit."

175968557,"I once read that some cultures have emotional states that others aren't aware of. A popular example is schadenfreude, which only recently grew in popularity as a way to feel good at someone else's misery. I bring these ideas up because it means that our interpretation of reality has a strong connection to the words we associate with our reality. One of the most classic examples deals with the fear/excitement interpretation. Things that usually arouse fear for most people (for example public speaking) can be interpreted as exciting. There's a boatload of examples of people doing scary things because they find it exciting (like jumping out of a perfectly good airplane). Now, I'm not telling you you haven't got a reason to feel anxiety about things which happened in the past. You feel what you feel and that's all there's to it. I'm saying, you don't have to interpret your fear as something you're powerless against. You don't even have to believe your fear means you ill will. It could be that you're af
raid of something because you're body is trying to alert you to something important. Your body doesn't use words to communicate, it uses feelings. Sometimes those feelings are a little overwhelming. Sometimes, they're so twisted up its hard to make sense of. Luckily, human beings have the ability to speak to one another. So other people are your best resource. People like me, might have words for the feelings you're having. Takeaway ==> talk more and keep working at it"

175968592,"Hugs When I had suffered ptsd I suffered many many panic attacks , sometimes more than once a day, they feel bad, really bad but I did not die and I knew that if my breathing became too difficult I would faint and start breathing freely again. My body would look after me. I would be fine. I was not in fact dying at all. And I never worried about people around me, I knew if something happened they would help me. And knowing I was going to be ok helped the attacks pass so much quicker. As I went through CBT for the ptsd the panic attacks stopped coming, still not sure what triggered them as the lag between the stress and the attack is about 30 minutes. Maybe there were many triggers. Besides proper diet helped me as well. I started drinking natural teas like chamomile or shilajit (here are interesting researches on both https://www.huffpost.com/entry/6-natural-tea-remedies-fo_b__PHONE_NO_ and https://purblack.com/moomiyo-extract-super-yogis/ ) My beliefs, that I would be ok, that I trusted my body, t
