175968605,"I'm not quite sure I understand what answer you're looking for. I thought the citadel was how you choose to react, your inner fortress against the outside world. Like a sort of meditative detachment. I'm not trying to be dense, I'm honestly a bit confused by the question. Are you asking how I see the world? Are you asking what I think about most? Are you asking about my fantasies and dreams? Are you asking what the mood is inside? Are you asking me to imagine my mind metaphorically as a physical place and describe it? That reminds me of The Fall of the House of Usher. Some believe it's about the mind. I suppose I can relate to that a bit. Not that I remember anything particular about that story but it is Gothic literature and like most Gothic literature it reaches for the ""sublime"". How do I describe sublime... it means to take enjoyment of something in a visceral way. Seeing beauty in things that are imperfect and sometimes even frightening. Enjoying the details of life that perhaps aren't often 
looked at. Gothic Literature is about creating a detailed setting, a strong atmosphere, and a story that isn't very pretty. In that, I have no castle. I have a large old wooden house in the woods. The place would have crooked trees fighting for the sky. The night's would have a big yellow moon and the days would be covered in overcast. The animals would be mostly quiet and observatory, hanging around the house lazily and having been there forever. There would be an ugly chained dog watching every step you make and chickens scratching around in the dirt. There would be flighty, tweeting birds, cardinals and sparrows. If you listened closely, you'd hear the bugs rustling in the leaves, grass, and dirt. Not really a comforting noise, but not too unpleasant. Like the feeling of being watched but for just the briefest moment. The house would be old and well developed. Large but not so big as to called a mansion. Never threatening to crumble despite it's age and uncared for state. Perhaps it gets cleaned up sometim
es, Perhaps a few things get repaired. But the plants keep vining inside and the front door never closes. The walls are always faded or dirty, with hidden details waiting to be found underneath. It would feel like an adventure and an identity all of it's own. Walking through the house and being filled up with it's presence. And at night unseen creatures would scream in the forest, their noises growing closer until your eyes leak and your bones shake. The trees shivering as the screams grow louder. The bushes begin to rattle far too close and you unfocus your eyes too afraid to see the reflective eyes shining wide and sinister, looking at you."

175968654,"Fatigue is another dreaded symptom of caffeine withdrawal. Caffeine improves energy and reduces drowsiness by blocking adenosine receptors. Adenosine is a neurotransmitter that can cause fatigue in some circumstances. Once caffeine is eliminated, many people feel tired and fatigued. Caffeine withdrawal can occur in anyone who regularly consumes caffeine and then abruptly discontinues its use. Common symptoms include headache, fatigue, low energy, irritability, anxiety, poor concentration, depressed mood and tremors, which can last anywhere from two to nine days. =]"

175968745,"Hi tigerlily3082, I tell my Psychiatrist things I wold never tell another mental health professional but we've known each other for 14 years or so. I used to work in the mental health field myself, and he knows this, so I'm always perfectly honest with him. He asked me last year if I had any thoughts of physical aggression against someone who was giving me a problem. I told him most definitely and in some detail. He asked me if I would promise not to do that, I told him yes and that was good enough for him. I never break a promise to him, not to mention I knew if I did assault him I would be going to jail, so I kept my promise and that was last year. They're right about not holding you unless they believe you're a danger to yourself or somebody else. Then it's only a 72 hour hold where I live before they bring you before a judge. If they state the belief you need to be held the judge will go with what they say and you will be held no matter what you say until they see fit to release you. My doctor 
knew me well enough to know I wasn't really a danger to this person. I was only unloading on him and telling him what I really thought. I asked for an increase of my Klonopin from .5mg BID to 1mg BID, but he said that would decrease my impulse control. He was wrong about that. I would be more relaxed and less likely to go off on him, but it was his call and I didn't debate the issue. He did, however, recently give me an increase to 1mg BID when coronavirus hit, and my legal actions against the person in question failed miserably. He didn't see impulse control as a factor then, but I'd had plenty of time to cool down since. So go figure. You just have to get to know your doctor and they need to get to know you to help you. They're not ""out to get you"" per se, and if you hold back from them too much it's not likely you'll establish any sense of trust in each other very soon. Of course, they may just be the wrong doctor for you and could need to find one that you feel more comfortable with. Never forget they w
ork for you. In any case, use discretion but don't be scared and good luck."

175968777,"Wouldn't second hand embarrassment be considered a form of empathy? I think I've felt it, but I can't think of any examples from real life. One of my oldest friends, whom I call Toe, is rather weird. Possibly undiagnosed schizotypal. I get mad at people who point and snicker at him when he gets unintentionally weird in public, but I'm not sure that would count as embarrassment because half of the time he's unaware of not only being laughed at, but of being weird as well. He's also the only person I can think of who will likely elicit a measure of emotion in me if he should drop dead. Why? He's ice cold, selfish and unemotional. I think it may have to do with the longevity of our friendship and some of the many things (good and bad) we went through together in the past. But I doubt I'd be sad for him because he's miserable anyway. I'd be sad for me because it would be like a large chunk of my life and history is gone. Just like when we feel a sudden pang of hatred for someone it usually boils down t
o what we see in them that reminds us of some aspect of ourselves we are either ashamed of or don't want to face. Maybe this is the same mechanism as second hand embarrassment at play here? I sometimes get embarrassed when people on TV make fools of themselves. Two examples would be someone being a complete idiot on a game show or a reporter screwing up royally or getting punched in the face on live TV. Neither of these examples makes sense because I can't stand television journalists or people who would purposely debase themselves by appearing on ""The Price Is Right"" . But then again, they do make sense because as I've said numerous times in the past, a well made movie or even a TV show can elicit emotions in me that I've never felt for anyone in real life. So I guess it has to do with being once-removed from the situation by it being artificial or otherwise safely remote."

175968865,Many of us eat less and therefore lose weight when we’re anxious and depressed. The irony for me has been when people comment how great I look and ask what I’m doing and I joke that it’s due to stress. I know it’s really hard to do but if you give yourself a hard time about losing weight and don’t accept your new image then it’ll likely get worse. Realize that you have value regardless of your weight. Accept that you are losing weight and try to focus on what is going well for you.

175968875,"As far as medicine going out of the system, psycheducation.org says, “Most medications have a half-life of about 24 hours…."" And, “If the medication has a half-life of 3 hours, then it will be close to gone in 12 to 15 hours after the last dose. But notice that half was gone in 3 hours, and by 6 hours you were down to a quarter of the original highest amount. The medication effects could be gone even though some medication is still in your blood.” I quit taking some medicine one time, through a foul-up with my doctor, and it pretty much lost its effectiveness in one full day. How were you doing on lithium, latuda and doxepin? Do you think that’s going to hold you if you stop the Zyprexa? Were you doing OK on those 3 medicines? Webmd.com says latuda is an anti-psychotic, which also helps bipolar, and which you are already taking. Webmd says, Zyprexa is an anti-psychotic which also helps treat bipolar. I took an anti-psychotic one time, stelazine (sp? may have quit making it by now), and i

175968924,"So, if our bodies produce BDNF, why is it so important to find compounds which can activate the receptor independently of BDNF? The main reason for this is that BDNF signaling can become effected through various factors such as stress, nutrition, and the environment we live in. When this occurs, our brains become less resilient. By reducing factors that decrease BDNF production, and by supplementing with a TrkB activator, we can support a positive mood and overall cognitive function, even in the face of elevated stress. In addition to this, TrkB activation may help protect our brains from oxidative stress and glutamate induced excitotoxicity. _USER_ID_: The TrkB receptors exist as monomers in their inactivated state. Monomer refers to there only being one TrkB receptor. Upon activation, structural changes in the TrkB receptor cause it to merge with another TrkB receptor. This process is called dimerization, and we now have a TrkB dimer instead of a monomer. The TrkB dimer can attract phosphate grou
ps from ATP (to learn more about this, read the ATP section of our creatine monohydrate blog), which causes the TrkB dimer to become phosphorylated. Once TrkB is phosphorylated, it can start giving phosphate groups to inactive signaling proteins, which require phosphate groups to become activated. The phosphorylated TrkB dimer can give out multiple phosphate groups to signaling proteins. This means that activation of the TrkB receptor by 7,8-dihydroxyflavone sets in motion a very large signaling cascade through multiple different signaling pathways. The three main pathways are the PKC, Ras/MAPK, and PI3 pathways. These pathways all affect a large variety of brain processes involved with neuroplasticity. However, they do all eventually converge to activate a protein called CREB. Once the CREB protein is activated, it can bind to the CREB binding protein (CBP), which coactivates CREB. At this point, CREB can start to influence transcription factors, which allows CREB to produce physical changes in the brain. Th
ese physical changes are collectively referred to as neurogenesis."
175968925,"I'm going to keep telling myself that I'm a ""good type of insane"" but not actually insane. Because I have figured it out.. It's just that I need structure.. Maybe it's lack of humour speaking of me having smoked too much weed right now. I don't think I'll ever smoke again.. But I likely will.. Some people need, love, others need safety, others need a challenge, others need to understand.. I have it all. I am it all. But I need to grasp something.. 174360132,"I have had psychosis so I think I am qualified enough to answer this question. Neurosis is actually an old term of a time when the combination of the diseases (anxiety as well as depression) was thought to be a nervous disorder (think of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's) but even after they found out it means ""no significant impairment of the nervous system"" they did not coin a new term for the combination of anxiety and depression. In modern times, depression and anxiety are considered to be separate disorders which can co-occur at the same time in the same person. Neurosis means you're ""almost sane"", and it's only considered as a diagnosis if you have anxiety and depression which interfere with your ability to cope with day-to-day life. Psychosis on the other hand, is a broad spectrum of diseases (but the internet being the internet, says it's a ""symptom"", yes of course, a symptom consisting of different symptoms) that interfere severely enough to cope with your day-to-day life. It generally inv
olves four parts - Disorganized speech. (The affected individual speaks but the healthy, non-mental health worker individual cannot make sense out of it) - Disorganized thoughts. (""They're after me!"") - Disorganized behavior (copying the moments of the person the affected individual is talking to, for example) - And a bunch of other stuff that depends on what kind of disorder you have (i.e., symptoms of a person affected by paranoid schizophrenia is differing appreciably from a person affected by schizoaffective disorder, although both have psychosis as a core) Just like depression, psychosis is different for different people. Some individuals may have an unshakable belief that they're godly and almighty, while others may have a 'mixed episode' of depression and psychosis where the persons may believe they're worthless and deserve to die. As an interesting ending note, I should say that I am a person diagnosed with psychosis. My psychiatrist does not tell me my diagnosis (I am not from the US) but yes I do 
have psychosis. But it's very possible to get back on the right track with the proper help from trained professionals. With the help of medications and mild therapy from my psychiatrist I am was able to get admitted to the BSc course I am currently in. I plan to get a doctorate in quantum chemistry and I plan to do research on quantum mechanics. Full recovery is possible, no matter whether you have neurosis or psychosis. I once read a research article that said depression could be helped when people over the age of 60 were given antidepressants. But proper and early treatment will help help. Get treatment as early as you can, if you have a loved one that may be affected or you believe you may be affected. Talk to your GP or internist first."
175968935,"I also agree with Crescent7. I live not far from NYC, technically in the nations second highest hot spot. My girlfriend and I go for walks late at night (10p-12a), it helps a lot with stress and anxiety. She and I are also worried about contracting it as well. We try to avoid people as much as possible. I tend to escape into a video game or a series when exercise doesn't seem to cut it. Hang in there! We'll make it."
174360154,"There's a new antipsychotic in phase 3 clinical trial called ""Roluperidone"". It helps with negative symptoms. I believe negative symptoms can be a symptom of positive symptoms."

175968960,"As a bipolar, I take Mirtazapine for depression and it works. I don't notice very much side affects, I know it has them, but I don't notice any that are really bad. I've been taking it for about 5 years with no problems. My psychiatrist is very good and I have a feeling she knows which pills to prescribe, although she has missed a couple and we had to change. I take one half of a 15.mg. tablet, by cutting it in half with a pill cutter. So I take 7.5mg. at night. I was taking the entire 15mg. pill for a couple of years, and 15-30 minutes after I took it my toes would start to twitch as I lay in bed, and my appetite would increase so I had to get back up and eat yet another snack. Finally figured out it was the Mirtazapine causing both of those side affects. She cut it in half to 7.5 mg of Mirt., and the side affects went away and the 7.5mg works just as well on my depression, so I was being over-medicated."

175968978,"Do you get mental anxiety or physical anxiety? Propranolol is a psychiatric beta blocker that can help better than a benzo for physical anxiety. 175968979,"You are not alone. Anxiety is hard to sort out during normal times, much less during a worldwide pandemic. You are doing so good by not watching the news or social media as that can contribute to your anxiety. Other tips that have helped are staying active, some kind of physical activity/exercise even if it's a walk around the block or just stepping outside for some sunshine in your backyard if you have one can be soothing. Knowing that you are doing everything in your power to stay safe can make you feel prepared and like you have a measure of control. For the things we cannot control, I always like to remember _NAME_:27 ""Who of you by being anxious can add one cubit to his life span?"" That helps remind me to stay grounded and not spiral about things that are out of my control and adding to my troubles. If it starts to get too much, I like to sing, read, listen to music, play my guitar, garden, walk. Anything to distract myself in a pleasant way. Hopefully, you have things available to distract 
you as well and can find some peace of mind during these difficult times. Best wishes."

175969004,"Hey bb, I wanted to say something. Getting on a weight neutral med is kinda like half the battle. I know personally, I cant eat candy and pastries anymore. It's just off limits if I want to lose weight. Diet is a much bigger thing, than exercise when it comes to losing weight. Many people say diet is 70 percent how u lose weight and exercise is 30 percent. Everyone has heard something a little different but its largely the same. Diet is key. I ate like crap during this vacation. I had 3 fast food meals, alcohol, and very fatty breakfasts. Keeping that up I'd personally gain tons of weight. The past few months I've cut back on how much I ate. Having a job helped tons. I no longer have extra time in my day to snack. I personally dont eat breakfast really. If I feel nauseous with my new meds recently, I may eat like something very small, but nothing sugary. Like, a plain bagel. Bread has sugar in it, yes, but I meant like I dont eat donuts or sugary cereals/breakfast meals. For lunch, since I dont tak
e lunch at work, i eat maybe a bag of chips from the vending machine at work, but that's it. I'm more of a salt-aholic anyway. Lunch is usually my time of time where I indulge very slightly. est advice, since I'm starting out too, but I've lost 11 pounds so far in the last few months."

175969048,"_AT_MENTION_ - In that regard, the coping with loss, the challenge of filling that void, trying to move on... I think a perspective not to lose sight of that may sound oversimplified or perhaps even trite; is that by the very fact you are addressing some of your emotions and grief here on this site - openly and transparently with acknowledgment of your pain is a sincere and strong statement of self-reflection and should help validate aspirations of peace and self-acceptance. It is likely that your kids deal with many of the same emotional conflicts, no matter what the specifics of the situation have been. There are no easy answers dealing with attachment to what one imagined the vision of it all would have or could have been.... Only answers to how you approach who you are now as a result: likely, wiser, more reflective. emotionally sensitive to the situation from both sides. But there is really only one side. All are in it together. There are gifts in there amidst the grief. There are beacons of e
nlightenment to find how one evolves for the better from such trauma. I try to practice remembering this concept myself, as I have become a stronger and more complete spirit and how one comes closer to this realization o Is less important than the ""why"" once you sign into the big guest book of Hotel Regret. You are, in fact, doing what you need to be doing. Your're having a contemplative conversation with yourself outside of yourself. Troubleshooting the mechanics on the remote control of your self-observation as you continue fine-tuning the reception of your self-assessment. You are both the guest and concierge. So I would encourage you to continue giving yourself 5 star service. You're on the right track already. Accept who you are and be good to yourself."

175969059,"The purpose of these exercises is not to change the frequency with which you experience anxious thoughts (though if that happens for you, fantastic!). Rather, defusion exercises are effective if they decrease your attachment to a particular belief or set of beliefs that are not currently serving you well. To learn more about cognitive defusion and other core processes of ACT, read this related post by the Association for Contextual Behavioral Science. Additional information about the techniques described above as well as other cognitive defusion exercises are described here . Your Mind, with a capital “M.” For the sake of this exercise, think of your mind as a separate entity from yourself. Name it “Mind.” When the anxious chatter begins, tell yourself something like, “Well there goes Mind again, chitchatting away” or “Wow, Mind is doing that thing he loves to do, telling me how nothing will ever work out.” By treating the mind as an external, rather than internal, creature you migh
t create enough space between you and your thoughts to feel a bit better. The car radio that won’t turn off. Imagine that you are sitting in the passenger seat of a car, and the driver has turned on an awful radio station that is playing a soundtrack of your anxious thoughts. You’re not in a position to change it or turn it off; instead, you must tolerate it and accept that the thoughts are there, and that the noise is unpleasant. A keychain in your pocket. You most likely carry a set of keys with you always. Try assigning each of your most common anxious thoughts to a specific key. When you use that key, make yourself think the corresponding thought. Notice that you can carry the thought and not always think it, and also that when you do think the thought, you can still use the key. It is possible to carry difficulty beliefs with you, and not let them dictate your actions. A bossy bully. Treat your thought like a bully on the playground of adulthood and ask, “Who is in charge here? Is my thought in cha
rge or am I in charge?” If it helps, get a little angry at the thought – colorful language included – as you assert yourself against the bossy bully. Thoughts for sale. Distinguish between a thought you are having and a thought you are buying as true. Label your thoughts: judgment, criticism, comparison, exaggeration, etc. Then ask yourself, “Do I want to buy the thought that I am Consider what it will cost you, and if it’s really a good investment. https://www.verywell.com/ways-to-defuse-anxious-thoughts-3863037"

I have to do something that I really enjoy.."

175969070,"Elsewhere in the forum I have posted about my recent adventures with palpitations. This has led me down a new path where I discovered something that I am curious about for others who suffer from anxiety disorder. Has anyone else gotten to the point that they feel comfortable going to doctor's offices? I noticed this last week when I had to visit the emergency room. Upon pulling up to the hospital, I found a bit of relief wash over me. Especially when I saw that the place was just about deserted and I was the only patient up there (the beauty of a small town emergency room.) Two days later I went for my follow up with my primary doctor, and I've been up there for so much stuff the last few years I no longer feel anxious going in. Especially considering she isn't taking new patients. I am often the only one in there prior to the next person's appointment and it helps me to considerably relax. I feel like when doctors know what is going on with me that I feel more secure and like it gives me a morale 
boost. I also realized that this is probably a significant sign of just how bad my anxiety really is if I am to the point that going to the doctor's office actually makes me feel better just by going and that I have gotten comfortable in a place known to give almost everyone anxiety. Is this something that anyone else experiences?"

175969078,"I was held back in the first grade. There, I had to read _NAME_ and the Giant Peach. It was awful. Who cares about some nobody, flying in a peach that nobody cares about, to who knows where. I don't even like peaches! I want to keep roasting this terrible book but that's not my entire point. The point is that we, as humans, need to find books that custom suit what we are moved by. The first great book I read was Ender's Game. A book about a kid genius who suffers isolation in order to grow in creativity in combat. What I learned is that I enjoy books where the character is of higher intelligence that is meant to suffer to become more than who he is now. It's part of the ""hero's journey"" found in great literature. A common book me and SP love is The Name of the Wind. Again a protagonist of higher intelligence that must encounter suffering for the sake of overcoming to forge his steel. _NAME_'s Odyssey has a lot of the same makings and it was written like 2,700 years ago! If you do enjoy this formu
la I recommend googling genius protagonists and a goodreads.com list will be found and check out those books. However, that might not be your jam. And that's cool. I started my journey reading with the Great Books of Western Civilization works to give me focus. I read most of them. The only downfall is that female writers are slim. Still, _NAME_ Frankenstein is in the top 10, a must. But theres just not enough o them, or people of color. So there is a limitation or a flaw. So what moves you? Why do you want to read? What are you looking for in a book exactly? Fiction, nonfiction, biographies? I need to read more biographies. What I find interesting, and what you find interesting, might be vastly different though. Part of my trick to focus on reading is the setting I choose. I often go without my laptop to a café, library, or bar and put my ear buds in. If you don't have an electronic/instrumental playlist that helps you focus, you can always use mine on Spotify! I'll link you to it if you want to check it ou
t. The point is that you don't want to be distracted by the ubiquitous screen found everywhere. It kills focus."

175969082,"You are very smart to write in. You are very fortunate that there are websites like this one so you can get different opinions, and get help. It’s good that you are seeing a psychiatrist. You say you have bipolar 1, which net says has the full mania and depression, which is what I have, also. Bipolar 2 has reduced or hypomania, net says. I looked on the net for the medicine you are taking, “clonazepam” and mayoclinic.org says that “Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine.” Web.md.com says, “Benzodiazeines are a type of medication known as tranquilizers. Familiar names include Valium and Xanax. ""They are some of the most commonly prescribed medications in the United States. When people without prescriptions obtain and take these drugs for their sedating effects, use turns into abuse.” I’ve heard on this site, and on the net such as the above medical websites, where benzodiazepines are for short-term use, but not for long term anxiety, depression or bipolar. They are not meant for that. They 
are meant to calm you down for months and years, but not get you addicted for a few hours worth of relief. What are the other two medicines you are taking? Again, I’m the same diagnosis that you are, Bipolar 1. Yet I’m only on 2 meds, and neither one is a benzo. I’m on the anti-depressant Mirtazapine, and I’m on Lithium which caps the antidepressant from sending me into mania, and also calms me down. Webmd says examples of mood stabilizers are: Carbamazepine; (Tegretol); Divalproex sodium (Depakote); Lamotrigine (Lamictal); Lithium; Valproic acid (Depakene). Adding, ""Mood stabilizers are medicines that treat and prevent highs (mania) and lows (depression). They also help to keep your moods from interfering with work, school, or your social life."". For panic attacks, you said, “ So the psychiatrist gave me clonazepam. But when I run out of it I use cannabis oil. The psychiatrist doesn’t wanna give me too much clonazepam cause I have a history of addiction."" “Sometimes I will have alcohol when 
i can’t get cannabis oil. I am seeing my psychiatrist today so I started getting panic attacks when my husband left the country and I had to take care of our son maybe he will adjust my meds again."" 174360424,"drugs.com says ambilify is an antipsychotic which treats schizophrenia and bipolar. I would walk to the park, I would walk around the apartment, when I sat down to eat I would tap my foot so that I could be moving. They've improved anti-psychotics since then, but then you say, ""five days ago I was switched to Abily"" and ""The abilify gives me a headache (feel queasy )and it makes feel so restless that I cannot stop moving around . This will last about 7 to 8 hours. I am on 1 mg of abilify for two weeks and then up to 2 mg."" drugs.com says the side effects of Abilify can include: ""severe agitation, distress, or restless feeling; twitching or uncontrollable movements of your eyes, lips, tongue, face, arms, or legs; mask-like appearance of the face, trouble swallowing, problems with speech; anxiety, feeling restless; sle
ep problems (insomnia)."" I can understand why you are fed up. It is a very distressing feeling. For bipolar, I am on Mirtazapine antidepressant (7.5 mg a day) and Llithium (600 mg. a day) which treats the mania and is also a stabilizer which keeps the Mirtazapine from making me go manic."

175969194,"I have generalized anxiety. I've been on medication continuously for 10 years, which has helped tremendously. I have also picked up, and continue to pick up, useful tools to deal with anxiety. Many have worked really well, most have worked somewhat, and only a few not at all. But doing what I can realistically do to maintain good health is in my control, so that reduces the associated anxiety."

175969196,"_PERSON_, bless your heart. It can be easy to fall into bad behavior we watched as we were growing up. Your strong stance that you would never hit a woman, given your past experiences, is to be commended. I understand the kind of anger you speak of, out of control anger that grabs you or an elevated anger you may even allow yourself for the time at hand. It can be hard to call yourself back from an angry outburst and while knowing this from the start, we permit it to heat up more. Even when you realize you can be causing another emotional harms. We only hope that our sorrow about our actions could stop us the next time. I found that usually it did not stop my next outburst. Actually, I think sometimes we are expecting others to feel the weight of our problem. We want them to feel the weight to underline to them the chaos we are feeling internally. A good question...are our angry outburst much more likely to occur in front of others? If so, then I would say we want another person to feel the weight 
of our problem(s) at hand. A selfish act? Probably. When you get so fed up with problems and especially repeated or unresolved problems it seems like the only way to go. Until you can calm yourself back down. I get it, I've done plenty of it in my life. If you think about it, it never brings any type of relief. You finish up feeling exhausted and with a good possibility of an accompanying headache. (Where are the Tylenol? Oh, they are now scattered across the floor. Right?) And whatever made you mad in the first place is still waiting. Perhaps that is a key. To understand the loud emotional outburst will resolve nothing. Now I am talking to you and me both here. But it can and does bring regret, shame & a certain loss of standing with others as well. I imagine it must involve some selfishness on our parts too. A selfishness that we think we deserve. I personally will know to stop my bad behavior and will allow myself to continue. And I know at times I look like a nut. So, what to do about it? One thing I can 
say is that problems come in and out of our lives all of the time. That is a real part of our existence. So, establishing that problems will always play a part in our lives perhaps we need to change the way we approach them. This is not to take away the difficulty of a problem, yet maybe lessen its impact on us. It would be wise to establish at the very start how losing control stops us from the first steps involved in solving a problem. Much like how you described your car problem for example. So, in effect, we are slipping away from the cure of the problem. I realize that you recognize this all ready. Yet it is so much easier to end up with misinformation when we are so riled up. And the usual case is this misinformation grows the problem. It rarely seems to lighten a problem. Practice at some self-parenting should help. Downright making yourself behave properly when we do not want to. I guess it might be like dividing yourself from your own self. One self is a child and the other self the parent. Could it 
be that we sometimes think that others around us will come to the rescue and parent us? Maybe, maybe not. Its worth investigating. We could also imagine ourselves at the mercy of another's outburst. You know and I know we would want it to stop. A gift to another, that's what it would come to. To stop our self-centered behavior and rescue our loved ones. It comes free of charge. It is a choice and one we owe to ourselves and to others. When we are so angry and acting out we think it something we own. Something we can do with what we want to. This anger. In a courtroom, before a judge most of us can shut it down. After all, we are in a courtroom and could make ourselves look real bad. Not good in a courtroom. Maybe that can be a tool to work with too. To imagine ourselves before a court of law. I believe patience plays a huge part. I know that I used up my patience & tolerance long, long ago. Out of everything I've written here for both you and I, I think the part about us thinking we own the anger to do with w
hat we want & the bit about a selfishness that we think we deserve are both key points. _PERSON_, I have been writing this to you and to myself. I think there are a few points worth hashing out. Good luck and my best wishes to your recovery from this self-made trap we both have created in our lives. I sure hope what I've written has made some sense. If any of this helps, let me know. If you discover something I have not mentioned that really helps you, tell me about it because I could use advice too! _PERSON_"

175969203,"This was labeled as tips for ""lockdown productivity"", but I think it applies just as well to anyone who ""practices social distancing"" on a permanent basis: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=snAhsXyO3Ck Every day I think about this and I still find it funny and odd how uniquely prepared I am for this bizarre situation, and how everyone else is not. It's not like I've actually been preparing for this event, but I've unknowingly been preparing for it for many years anyway. I have thought of all of those details and have been practicing it all for some time already, but I still remember that none of it is actually obvious or trivial. 175969204,"Same thing happened to me when I was a 16. I guess at the start, you don't have insight. People calling my name, hearing voices. But I was focused on other things that were tormenting me and didn't pay attention to what was happening to me. I was given risperidone at age 17. At age 18, I believe for me it was made worse by drinking dextromethorphan where I realized the meaning to the universe. Now I'm medicated but it seems that when I do have psychotic symptoms, I'm able to recognize it yet consumed by the thoughts to where there's no changing the thoughts without an PRN antipsychotic at the end of my injection. So antipsychotic medication is important. You should not refuse medication. A lot of my visual hallucinations were hypnotic ones where I'd wake up and have a conversation with family members that weren't there and they'd tell me weird things. I remember leaving school by just walking out of class because I was so paranoid thinking helicopters were after me, walking fast to home and then ta
king a high dose of risperidone to knock me out, all the psychotic writing I made on my laptop and agitation. Then I'd get bad akathisia from the risperidone. It all happened because I stopped taking the risperidone because I was too tired. It seems like there's a source for the voices (Like behind a door) but no one was home. I had thoughts of the legs of my family members being in the bathtub downstairs. It was a really bazar time. Thinking something in my mind which was an orb of some sort would give me great knowledge. I saw it with peoples faces coming up to my vision and disappearing. But now I'm on the right meds so you should find the right medication. To me, the psychosis seemed like what happened on my bad psilocybin trips."

175969206,"I hope you have been able to reach out to someone or are making plans to address your depression. You are so not irrelevant. You do matter. Having someone like a therapist, a family member, a spouse, or a friend to talk to can make all the difference in the world. If you are religious at all, you may find comfort from Psalm 34:18 where it says ""Jehovah is close to the brokenhearted; He saves those who are crushed in spirit."" If all those things above such as meditation, counseling, prayer, confiding in a loved one still do not seem to work, there is no shame in seeking medicinal help. You may have an imbalance that the depression meds will address. And you are certainly not a failure for needing help. I hope you are able to receive the help you need and will have better days ahead. Best wishes."

175969216,"Unless you were sleeping outdoors or have had an infestation of bats in your house, it sounds extremely rare for something like that to happen while you are sleeping... and even then so... a bat likely wouldn’t bite you unless you were endangering its safety or handling it unqualified to do something along the lines such as holding exotic species. Bats are rare in North America as well so it’s probably easier to believe that you don’t have rabies and didn’t get bit by a bat and that a bite from a bat would look a lot different then just a black spec on your finger correlating to a jolt in your sleep than it is to believe that the ladder of rabies and bat bites is possibly reality. Try to take a deep breath, count backwards from 200, and try putting yourself to sleep without a thought worth compulsive obsession overwhelming your brain. If this doesn’t work, try typing delta brain waves into YouTube and find some hypno brain waves to help you fall asleep without worry about rabies and getti
ng bit by bats while you’re asleep. I struggle with mild obsession at times but I manage it well with finding the right coping mechanisms that allow me to ask myself what would be reasonable to have worry over versus what is worrying me out of control. Hope this helps! Good night!"

175969283,"Humans are social animals. We require social structure to thrive. One simple example of this is the amount of time it takes for a human child to become self-sufficient. We need a social group to survive. Therefore, anyone who deliberately isolates themselves from others is abnormal. The only real question is what psychology exists behind this. Some may find that, for whatever psychological reasons, they are more comfortable on their own. However, some are alone because they have a deep-seated anger towards the rest of the world. Neither are healthy, but one is potentially dangerous to others. There's a series on UK TV, done by a guy named _NAME_, where he spends a week with people who have separated themselves from society and live as hermits. Without exception, every one of them, while not being overtly angry and seemingly mentally sound, have sighted issues as to what caused them to become socially distant. There's always a psychological reason why; it's never ""just a choice""."

175969289,"If you can afford it, go to a podiatrist or chiropodist and look into custom-made orthotics. Basically, insoles custom measured to your feet. They really help a lot more than off-the-shelf insoles. IDK about in the US, but in Canada they usually run around $300-$500, depending on where you go. Averaging around $450. I used to pay insurance claims and they were probably the most popular medical supply out there."
175969290,"""Ignoring"" may not be the best approach although I'm glad to hear that you're finding ways to deal with your triggers.. I only say that because it's possible that you could be inadvertently bottling up your feelings and that could end up causing you and others some harm. Regular triggers from regular encounters or activities might be better off to deal with as casually as possible.. even without being direct, and especially if it's not intentional, practice thinking of your triggers differently or in a more positive manner. When you face a trigger, your reaction to it is a choice. If you can't think of anything else, yes.. just try to ignore it. Perhaps, though (and try this a little at a time,) try to re-think about it with as much grace and forgiveness as possible. Put yourself in the shoes of the trigger itself and wonder why it exists in the first place. Try to focus on intent and realize it's not directed at upsetting you directly. Take some solace in that, but then also notice the usefulnes
s of it or the good that it does. If there's a better way to think about what ails you, attempt to adopt that state of mind in general and leave behind or try to ignore the part of you that is upset by it. There are lots of other approaches to investigate too and I'd talk to a therapist about some of these regular triggers even if it's to get the emotions off your chest (which you've probably already done by posting here about it.) And trying something to assume some control of your triggers and then returning to an ignore posture could help you feel like you're not just a victim but proud of yourself concerning your triggers due to the act of standing up to that which upsets you.. even if only a little bit. I hope this helps,"
